Full text: - The outbreak of the coronavirus resulted in the imposition of significant restrictions on economic activity and population, generating a recession in 2020, with output forecast to contract by 3.5% for the full year. Fiscal stimulus measures, as well as a substantial decline in oil sector revenue, will generate a looser fiscal stance that will persist throughout the forecast period (2020-24).
- Norway has a history of coalition governments and cross-party consensus, delivering high levels of political stability. The constitution does not allow for the dissolution of parliament. The ruling coalition comprises the Conservatives, the Liberals and the Christian Democrats (KrF) as a minority government, with 61 seats in the 169-seat parliament. The next election is in September 2021, and The Economist Intelligence Unit expects the centre-right bloc to re-enter government, owing to its competent handling of the coronavirus outbreak.
- We do not expect a reimposition of a national lockdown (although some municipal measures are likely) even in the event of a revival of infections. The economy will recover from 2021 to 2024, reaching 2019 levels by 2022, with growth averaging 2.4% as restrictions on mobility recede.
- We estimate that inflation will soften to 1.2% on average in 2020, from 2.2% in 2019, owing to worsening economic conditions, but pressures on core inflation from rising food prices pose an upside risk to price growth. Economic recovery will generate a rebound in inflation throughout the forecast period, generating inflation averaging 1.6% in 2021-24.
- In March Norges Bank (the central bank) reversed much of its monetary tightening, lowering interest rates by a total of 125 basis points, to 0.25%. Core inflation is falling as demand declines, and rates are expected to remain stable until the end of 2020. A steady policy of normalisation will follow, with policy rates reaching 1.5% by 2024.

- Norway's business environment score rises slightly in 2020-24, as the economy has become more resilient following oil industry reforms. Backed by vast oil wealth, the political and economic environments are robust, and financing opportunities should remain firm. Norway lags Nordic peers in some areas, with limited market opportunities, tight labour market regulation and high wages.

Country forecast overview: Norway's business environment at a glance Policy towards private enterprise and competition 2020-21: Low regulatory burden, but probable rise in already high level of state influence in the economy, following emergency policy measures in response to the coronavirus pandemic and related temporary lockdown.
2022-24: A strategic plan guides the Norwegian Competition Authority to raise sectoral competition and procurement rules.
Policy towards foreign investment 2020-21: Generally positive attitude towards attracting foreign direct investment, but capital inflows constrained by weak global economy and new domestic investment screening regime that can block investment on national security grounds.
2022-24: The economy further diversifies investor countries beyond Europe, although to limited effect.
Foreign trade and exchange controls 2020-21: Absorbing the shock to global trade from the coronavirus will be a major theme, with a discussion around "reshoring" strategic industries away from China likely to follow the immediate crisis.
2022-24: No change in policy towards joining the EU or leaving the European Economic Area (EEA). A reassessment of EEA membership is possible, but unlikely. Efforts to promote bilateral trade deals continue.
Taxes 2020-21: Temporary stimulus measures and easing of tax-payment requirements for firms in response to coronavirus.
2022-24: Government investigates reform of subsidy regime for oil and gas exploration. Expansion of environmental taxes to meet climate change goals.
Financing 2020-21: Significant expansion of central bank liquidity to support functioning of financial markets. Policy interest rates remain at record-low level. Private-sector balance sheets weakened by economic fallout from the crisis.
2022-24: Credit demand likely to remain subdued following the crisis, but opportunities could emerge for growth of non-bank financing channels, including private equity and venture capital. Tighter anti-money-laundering rules.
The labour market 2020-21: The coronavirus shock leads to a sharp increase in unemployment
2022-24: Improvements in employment and wages follow the crisis. Skills shortages remain an issue in some sectors.
Infrastructure 2020-21: Government applies 12-year transport plan (2018-29) and raises funds available for maintenance and construction of infrastructure projects. Gradual roll-out of fifth-generation (5G) mobile services.
2022-24: Investments in new road and rail transport links are made. Digital infrastructure upgrades continue.
Technological developments 2020-21: Implementation of Norway's cyber-defence strategy, after cyber-attacks on national infrastructure.
2022-24: The Open Artificial Intelligence (AI) lab grows in size and importance, underpinning AI preparedness.

Background: The Labour Party governed almost continuously in 1935-65, dominating until 2001, when a minority coalition comprising the Conservatives, the Christian Democrats (KrF) and the Liberals swept to power. In 2005 Labour returned to office in a centre-left coalition with the Socialist Left Party (SV) and the Centre Party-the first majority government in two decades-lasting until 2009. The September 2013 election led to a regime change, with a minority right-of-centre coalition of the Conservatives and the Progress Party (FrP) taking office. The centre-right coalition was re-elected in 2017. The Conservatives and the FrP were joined by the Liberals in January 2018 and by the KrF in January 2019.
Political structure: There is no right of dissolution between elections. Norway uses a modified proportional representation system: 150 out of the 169 members of the unicameral Storting (parliament) are "district mandates" elected by open-list proportional representation. The remaining 19 seats, the "levelling mandates", are distributed only between the parties that get more than 4% of the national vote and whose initial seat count (out of 150) is not proportional to their share of the vote.
Policy issues: The centre-right government will try to implement additional business-friendly policies and tax cuts, focused on further reducing the negative spillover effects of lower oil prices on wider economic activity and on strengthening the mainland economy. Spending from Norway's oil fund is expected to rise, but it will remain comfortably within the country's fiscal guidelines. Despite a cross-party agreement on tackling climate change, tension will persist in the Storting over the balance between industrial development and environmental protection.
Taxation: At the start of 2016 most parties agreed on a multi-year corporation tax reduction (from 27% to 23% by 2018) to improve competitiveness in the economy; it has since been reduced to 22% in 2019. Oil companies pay an additional flat-rate tax of 50% on income derived from the extraction, processing and transport of oil, but benefit from a 78% tax refund on the costs of exploration for oil and gas. The capital-gains tax was cut from 28% to 27% in 2014. The ordinary rate of value-added tax (VAT) is 25%. The top marginal income tax rate is 54.3% (including employers' social security contributions).
Foreign trade: Oil and gas output and prices greatly affect Norway's trade flows. The petroleum industry contributes about half of total goods export revenue. In 2016 the trade account registered its lowest level since 1999, but has been recovering since. The current-account surplus increased to US$16.7bn in 2019, down from US$31.1bn in the previous year. The trade and current-account balance will remain in surplus throughout the forecast period (2020-24).

Outlook for 2020-24: Political stability The current ruling coalition, comprising the centre-right Conservatives and two small centrist parties-the Liberals and the Christian Democrats (KrF)-is coming to the end of its term in September 2021. The coalition rules as a minority government, with just 61 members in the 169-seat parliament, after the far-right Progress Party (FrP) withdrew from government in January 2020 after a coalition dispute over infrastructure. Given the nearing of the next general election, scheduled for September 2021, and a strong tradition of political consensus, The Economist Intelligence Unit does not expect a change in government.
Despite the government being a minority in parliament, it is able to pass legislation with the backing of the FrP (which has pledged to support it in significant parliamentary votes). The ruling coalition can also rely on the support of other opposition parties (such as the centre-left Labour Party). Although the FrP will probably withdraw its support for the government on some matters (preventing the proposal of some legislation), the damage to political stability would be low, as the constitution prohibits a pre-term dissolution of parliament, and a snap election.
In the near term the outbreak of the novel coronavirus has strengthened the stabilising influences on the political outlook. The government has mostly unwound its restrictions on social interaction, after being among the first group of European countries to experience an outbreak of the disease. Public support for the ruling parties has strengthened markedly during the crisis, and political support for the lockdown was wide-ranging. Despite the economic disruption caused by the lockdown, there has been no increase in support for populist parties in Norway. Populist movements have historically had limited electoral appeal in the country, as the far-right FrP takes a largely pragmatic approach to government, in contrast with other European populist movements. Their presence has only a marginal impact on political stability, as the domestic political culture is highly consensus-driven, with frequent collaboration between the government and opposition parties on a range of issues.
Outlook for 2020-24: Election watch The next general election will be held in September 2021. The Storting (parliament) cannot be dissolved before completing a full four-year term, meaning that there is no risk of a snap election. A change in government is also not part of our forecast.
Although the handling of the coronavirus crisis is likely to shape political preferences in the run-up to the election, it is unclear how much of an effect it will have by September 2021. The governing bloc of right-wing parties (excluding the FrP) have seen their popular support increase in the wake of the pandemic, a feature common to most countries. We expect the government's competent handling of the coronavirus crisis to place the right-wing bloc in a good position before the election in 2021, although the decline in support for the FrP since 2017 means they may not be able to produce a stable majority.
Outlook for 2020-24: International relations EU relations will remain a significant foreign policy issue, and may steadily encroach on domestic politics as environmental affairs become increasingly prominent. As a member of the European Economic Area, Norway has access to the single market (in exchange for contributions to the EU budget), but must accept relevant EU regulations while having limited influence over them. This has historically been accepted as a substitute for outright EU membership (which has been rejected twice in national referendums in 1972 and 1994), but mounting concern over economic diversification and a reduction in carbon emissions has pushed environmentalist parties (the Greens and the Liberals) to support outright EU membership. Although we do not expect Norway to join the EU without a national referendum, political pressure for a third plebiscite on the matter may grow in tandem with environmentalist influence in the government. Norway will be under continued pressure to raise its defence spending, which at 1.8% of GDP, is below NATO's 2% target. Greater commitments to increase spending will take time to implement, and will probably only be met by the end of 2024.
Outlook for 2020-24: Policy trends The country has recorded a steady increase in coronavirus cases, in tandem with other European countries, since social distancing measures were largely unwound from June onwards. The number of new cases recorded each day rose from 9 on July 24th to 126 on August 25th. The increase in cases has primarily been among young people, meaning mortality rates remain low, but a substantial "second wave" of viral transmission (and death) through the wider population remains possible. The rise in cases has halted government efforts to loosen social distancing measures, and the imposition of regional controls (similar to those seen throughout Europe) is likely to form a component of the government's new anti-virus strategy.
Beyond the coronavirus crisis, the sharp fall in oil prices will probably re-focus government attention on diversifying the economy away from the oil sector. Emergent industries in fishing, professional services and light manufacturing will probably receive more extensive government support, despite the deterioration in the fiscal position. Recent political success for environmentalist parties nationally, and the departure of the FrP from the ruling coalition, will place the generous tax reimbursement policy for oil exploration (which compensates 70% of exploration costs if there is no discovery) under strain. Nevertheless, we expect the system to be maintained throughout the forecast period, as all major parties are committed to the oil sector's growth.
Outlook for 2020-24: Fiscal policy Like other European countries, Norway has announced fiscal stimulus in the wake of the coronavirus outbreak, although this is much smaller than in peer economies. Given a long history of fiscal probity, Norway has a greater level of fiscal space than most, meaning that we expect public debt to remain below 60% of GDP throughout the forecast period. Total discretionary stimulus has amounted to about Nkr160bn (US$16bn), or about 5.5% of mainland GDP. The budget that the government presented in October 2019 has been abandoned as the disruption from the coronavirus generates a shock to the mainland economy (with the oil sector broadly cushioned by greater production). The government's budget, presented in mid-May, targets a substantial withdrawal from the Government Pension Fund Global (GPFG; 4.2% of its value) to fund further expenditure, in breach of the government's fiscal rule to not withdraw more than 3% of the sovereign fund's value in any year. We expect that the government will have to lean on the fund for further fiscal support in the coming years, but this will not diminish its vast size. For the first time since 1993, this will not be enough to prevent a deficit in 2020, which we forecast at just 0.9% of GDP.
Existing government support for the labour market is similar to the measures implemented in response to the coronavirus in neighbouring countries. Under the system of permittering, the government temporarily pays a large portion (more than 60%) of the wages of workers who are placed on furlough. Expanded take-up of this scheme, although it will preserve much of the existing labour market for the duration of the pandemic, will leave the government liable for a significant increase in spending.
On the employer side, fiscal support has expanded rapidly. The government has deferred tax payments and purchased corporate bonds on the secondary market, reducing borrowing costs for businesses. About Nkr20bn has been set aside as a crisis fund to cover fixed costs for businesses during the coronavirus pandemic, modelled on the Danish fund set up for this purpose.
Outlook for 2020-24: Monetary policy In response to the substantial disruption caused by the pandemic, Norges Bank (the central bank) has lowered the policy rate by 150 basis points since February, to 0%-the lowest rate in modern history. This unprecedented monetary easing was completed over three meetings of the monetary policy committee. The central bank also lowered countercyclical capital buffers for major banks from 2.5% to 1% to ensure bank solvency and expand credit growth.
We expect Norges Bank to maintain its highly accommodative policy until the end of 2021, given the lingering uncertainty around the pace of economic recovery and the trajectory of the pandemic, which will weigh on business and con-sumer confidence. There are likely to be substantial scarring effects on both output and employment from the virus, with looser monetary policy required to accelerate the recovery in the near term. Looking ahead, Norges Bank targets inflation of "close to 2% over time", and the policy rate should rise steadily after 2021 when economic conditions improve. The steady rise in oil prices, gradual recovery of the domestic economy and revival in global trade should all generate a steady normalisation of interest rates over the forecast period.
Outlook for 2020-24: Economic growth The imposition of lockdown measures from March 12th to June 15th generated a substantial contraction in headline output, by 5.1% in the second quarter, as 11 of the 14 weeks of restrictions took place in that time. This comes after a 1.7% quarterly decline in the first quarter. But the performance of the mainland and offshore economies has diverged, with the mainland economy contracting by 7.6% annually (in line with the performance of other Nordic economies) but the offshore economy expanding by 9.7%, as the activation of the Johan Sverdrup oilfield boosts real production. The recent increase in viral infections could generate a reimposition of some social distancing measures, which would curtail the extent of the recovery. We judge that long-term scarring from the crisis will be significant, but modest compared with peer economies, as government support to counter short-term disruption to the labour market will remain substantial.
The pandemic and subsequent lockdown will primarily affect consumer spending and export demand, which we expect to decline by 6.5% and 5.8% respectively in 2020. For the mainland economy, the imposition of lockdown and continued uncertainty around the trajectory of the virus will increase precautionary saving and cool fixed investment (which we expect to contract by 4.5%). Weakened external demand, owing to widespread lockdowns, alongside disruption to trade, will curtail the growth of non-oil exports and reduce industrial activity throughout the rest of 2020. By contrast, in the offshore economy, real activity has been boosted by the activation of the Johan Sverdrup field, the third-largest discovery in Norwegian history, which will raise offshore output in annual terms for the rest of the year. We expect these divergent trends to blunt the force of coronavirus on headline output, with the economy contracting by 3.5% in 2020, recovering to pre-crisis levels by 2022.
Beyond 2020, these trends reverse. Growth in the mainland economy will recover more substantially from 2021 onwards as economic life returns to normal after the circulation of a vaccine and as the risk of a reimposition of controls abates. Household spending and external trade will recover quickly as consumer behaviour (both domestic and abroad) normalises. Whereas the export-oriented oil and gas sector will be especially damaged by the outbreak. Demand for both gas and oil globally is strongly pro-cyclical and Norway's entrenched exposure to markets that will be slow to recover from the crisis implies a substantial weakening of oil sector growth. Although firms within Norway's oil sector (especially Equinor, the state-backed oil firm) remain far from insolvency, real exports and the outlook for investment in the sector have worsened significantly.
Outlook for 2020-24: Inflation The pandemic and consequent lockdown has weighed on consumer prices, with the collapse in energy prices and demand for non-essential goods pulling down price growth. Headline inflation initially fell from 1.8% in January to 0.7% in March. Nevertheless, now that restrictions are being lifted, inflation has started to pick up pace again, rising to 1.4% in July. Rising core inflation, owing to an uptick in food prices, which was over 2.6% in July, will erode consumer purchasing power.
Overall, we expect that the disruptive effects of the coronavirus on consumer demand and oil prices will drag down inflation in 2020, to an average of 1.2%. This trend will be supported by an easing in household stockpiling as controls on social distancing abated, and as the fall in oil prices (which we expect to average US$42.3/barrel this year) ripples through the economy. The recent appreciation of the currency should also curtail inflation. A stronger than expected recovery in consumer spending continues to pose upside risks for price growth.
Outlook for 2020-24: Exchange rates The krone has largely followed the substantial changes in global energy markets since January. Between end-2019 and end-June, it depreciated by roughly 3.7% on a trade-weighted basis, as the price of oil has collapsed from US$65/b to US$44.7/b and economic activity has slowed.
Although the krone has strengthened from its nadir in March (when it had depreciated by over 17% from December), conditions of subdued demand and slower growth are likely to prevent the krone from fully returning to its December value until 2024, when oil prices have recovered, and production is restored. Further downward shocks to oil prices, chiefly from shocks to global demand, remain a risk to our exchange-rate forecast.
Outlook for 2020-24: External sector Norway's current-account surpluses are structurally supported by large inflows on the trade and primary income accounts, respectively reflecting the economy's position as a major oil exporter and the size of the GPFG.
Although inflows in both of these components will be damaged by the economic fallout from the coronavirus, we do not expect either of these accounts to fall into deficit. Oil exports will be damaged by the collapse in oil demand, but we expect that this will be balanced by the reduction in goods imports, keeping the trade balance in surplus despite the fall in oil prices.
As the coronavirus abates, steady rises in oil prices from 2021 onwards will further support the trade balance, and increases in production (barring any government intervention) will continue throughout the forecast period. We expect that this, combined with a revival of growth in major trading partners (particularly Germany), will support a rise in the current-account surplus over the forecast period, to 6.5% of GDP in 2024.

Full text: - Egypt's political sphere will remain tightly controlled during the forecast period, reflecting the government's wariness of dissent in the delicate security and economic environment. Nevertheless, the president, Abdel Fattah el-Sisi, will maintain internal stability during his second term, which has been extended to 2024 (with the possibility of serving a third term until 2030) as part of constitutional amendments made in 2019. All forms of protest activity will continue to be heavily suppressed, with the government concerned that the economic fallout from the global coronavirus pandemic could spark renewed unrest. The security forces will face persistent challenges from armed Islamist groups, both in northern Sinai, as part of an ongoing insurgency, and also in the form of sporadic terrorist incidents elsewhere in the country. The conflict in Libya and tensions with Turkey will be key strategic concerns.

- Egypt's business environment score improves in the forecast period, with its regional and global rankings rising by seven and two places, respectively, owing largely to greater economic resilience to the coronavirus pandemic than some other economies, owing to previous reforms and substantial external support. Investment and licensing reforms are helping to ease crippling levels of red tape and to boost incentives for private enterprise. Consequently, there is a leap in the score for policy towards private enterprise and competition. Nonetheless, progress will be slow in certain areas owing to resistance from vested interest groups in the government and military.

- The government has successfully sought out help from multilateral agencies to provide support through the pandemic crisis, including a renewed IMF programme, but the economic fallout of the coronavirus on economic activity and jobs will still be large, and fiscal adjustment will stall initially. Economic reform will remain focused on fiscal and structural deficiencies, with a view to consolidating the state finances, shoring up foreign reserves and enhancing the business environment in the long term. The Economist Intelligence Unit expects the fiscal and current-account deficits to narrow again from 2021, albeit slowly. Inflation is now returning to single digits. Following the worst of the pandemic, macroeconomic stability will be achieved slowly, spreading to the private sector only gradually, owing to weak institutional capacity.

- Egypt, which remains the most populous state in the Middle East, will experience an increase in its working-age population in 2020-24. This will present both a demographic opportunity, owing to the presence of a sizeable, youthful workforce, and a demographic challenge if unemployment continues to rise for an extended period after the pandemic (not our central forecast). The pandemic has resulted in the return of large numbers of the estimated 5m Egyptians working in Gulf Arab states. The role of the Gulf in absorbing surplus Egyptian labour is likely to diminish in 2020-21 but will reabsorb some workers again later in the forecast period. Egypt is highly urbanised, with nearly one-tenth of the population living in Cairo.

- In population terms, Egypt boasts the largest consumer market in the Middle East and North Africa. However, the potential of this market will be severely constrained in the first half of the forecast period by the immediate fallout from the coronavirus pandemic and weak purchasing power, reflecting low wage growth, with consumers wary of spending amid subsidy reform and recent economic instability. GDP per head figures mask deep income disparities between the rich and the poor, with most of the population in the latter category. Nevertheless, per-capita income will begin to pick up again in 2021-22, including in US dollar terms as the local currency appreciates.

- Egypt has started to address long-standing market distortions, and there is significant potential for strong real economic growth in the long term. However, success will also depend on a commitment to structural reform, as well as on major improvements to institutional effectiveness. We forecast that real GDP growth will average 4.2% a year in 2020-30 and 4.3% in 2020-50, with labour productivity growth being a significant contributor.

Background: In 1952 an army coup brought an end to the monarchy in Egypt. Two years later, Gamal Abdel Nasser, a former military officer, led the country (1954-70) and introduced nationalist policies. Under his successor as president, Anwar Sadat (1970-81), Egypt's political stance shifted towards the West and its economic policies became more liberal. Mr Sadat's signing in 1979 of a peace treaty with Israel eventually led to his assassination and the appointment of his deputy, Hosni Mubarak, as president in 1981. However, Mr Mubarak grew increasingly unpopular among Egyptians as official corruption became rampant during his three-decade tenure, and a popular uprising, backed by the military, forced his resignation in early 2011. The Muslim Brotherhood, which had been banned since 1954, won the parliamentary and presidential elections in 2012; however, in the wake of mass protests, it was ousted by the military in July 2013, and the former army chief, Abdel Fattah el-Sisi, was elected president in a landslide victory in 2014 and was re-elected in 2018.
Political structure: Egypt's semi-presidential system is based on the 2014 constitution, which granted parliament wider powers, including the right to withdraw confidence from the president. However, the current parliament-elected in late 2015-lacks an effective opposition bloc. In April 2019 the constitution was amended to extend the presidential term and strengthen the powers of the office-including over parliament, the judiciary and the military. Cabinet ministers are often subjected to scrutiny, which can result in their dismissal and, in some cases, court action.
Policy issues: Weak institutional capacity and opposition from vested interests often prevent economic reforms. Nonetheless, the Sisi regime is keen to enhance the business environment and consolidate the public finances through fiscal reforms, although reform capacity will be curtailed by the need to deal with the coronavirus outbreak.
Taxation: After multiple revisions, a presidential decree was passed in August 2015, reducing the top tax rate on companies and individuals from 25% to 22.5% on incomes of E£200,000 (US$22,523 at the pre-flotation official rate) or above. The decree also suspended a 10% capital gains tax for two years, to boost competitiveness. However, it retained a 10% tax on stock dividends. Value-added tax (VAT) of 13% was approved by parliament in August 2016 and raised to 14% in 2017/18.
Foreign trade: Egypt has a large structural trade deficit. Despite declining hydrocarbons output, oil and gas remain the country's leading export earners. Suez Canal transit fees provide about US$5bn a year in foreign-currency inflows, and the current account fluctuates between modest deficits and surpluses.

Political outlook: Political forces at a glance Present government: The president, Abdel Fattah el-Sisi, won a second four-year term in March 2018; the present government took office in June that year, with Mustafa Madbouly replacing Sherif Ismail as prime minister. The only significant change during the first year of Mr Sisi's second term was the replacement of the transport minister following a train disaster in February 2019. A reshuffle at the end of 2019 included the abolition of the Ministry of Investment, whose head, Sahar Nasr, left the government. Her role as international co-operation minister was taken over by Rania Mashaat, the former tourism minister, while the prime minister's office assumed oversight of investment. Domestic policy will remain largely focused on economic and social reform, but in the context of tightly controlled political process. Among the key ministers are the finance minister, Mohamed Maait, the foreign affairs minister, Sameh Shoukry, and the planning and economic development minister, Hala Zayid. The health and population minister, Hala Zayid, has also taken a central role in directing the government's response to the coronavirus pandemic.
The cabinet is largely technocratic in nature, which partly reflects the embryonic status of most political parties in Egypt and Mr Sisi's desire to contain alternative power bases. This may also reflect Mr Sisi's desire to remain neutral towards all political forces that are currently represented in parliament. Many cabinet ministers are Western-educated, and most are private-sector veterans without affiliations to political parties. The president has taken steps to boost the representation of Copts and women in the cabinet; following the end-2019 reshuffle, there are eight women ministers. Although former members of the now defunct National Democratic Party are rarely selected for ministerial posts, many of the lower-ranking officials in the government served under the ousted regime of Hosni Mubarak (1981-2011).
The armed forces and their various affiliates have assumed an increasingly important role in the economy during Mr Sisi's rule, and particularly in infrastructure projects. This trend is likely to be reinforced during the forecast period. One of the most important figures in the cabinet is the new transport minister, Kamel el-Wazir, who was head of the Egyptian Armed Forces Engineering Agency before his appointment in March 2019. Mr el-Wazir has been given a mandate to effect a major upgrade to the railway system.
Parliamentary forces: The complexion of parliament is set to change following elections to be held in late 2020, with Future of the Homeland, a relatively new party formed by pro-Sisi activists, set to establish a strong majority. The first election for a restored upper house, the Senate, took place in August 2020. This chamber had been abolished in 2013 after Mr Sisi, then commander of the army, effected the removal of Mohamed Morsi from the presidency. It has been restored as part of a set of constitutional amendments that were passed in early 2019. The ostensible reason was to provide an extra layer of parliamentary scrutiny, but, given that 100 of its 300 members are appointed by the president, it also provides a means for Mr Sisi to tighten his control over the legislature. The Senate election followed a change to the voting system that gave more scope to the larger parties to form strong blocs. One-half of the elected seats were decided on the basis of closed party lists, with the remainder based on individual constituency candidates. A 15-party bloc led by Future of the Homeland won the list allocation unopposed, and Future of the Homeland also won more than two-thirds of the individually contested seats on a turnout of just 14% of eligible voters. In the previous lower house election in 2015, the split between lists and individuals was 20% to 80%, with the result that the majority of the members were nominally independent, although they coalesced into a dominant pro-Sisi bloc named Support Egypt. The second largest party in the Senate is the People's Republic Party, formed by Ahmed Abu Hashima, an industrialist who had earlier provided financial backing for Future of the Homeland. The election to the lower house (which has 596 seats, including 28 appointed by the president) will take place towards the end of 2020, using the same 50:50 list:individual system as in the Senate election. Future of the Homeland is likely to be the largest party, and it could well win an outright majority.
Political outlook: Political stability The president, Abdel Fattah el-Sisi, will remain in power throughout the 2020-24 forecast period. Constitutional changes made in 2019 extend his current, second term from four to six years, to 2024. The changes also allow him to stand for a further six-year term, to 2030, and tighten his control over other branches of government, as well as expanding the role of the military. Mr Sisi will continue to tighten his grip on power. However, the centralisation of the president's authority poses increasing risks to political stability at a time of growing socioeconomic uncertainty following the global coronavirus (Covid-19) pandemic. The government has stifled critics of its pandemic response and will also suppress dissent on other issues. In parallel, it will attempt to defuse social unrest triggered by economic hardship with supportive measures. Subsequent fiscal tightening is a potential trigger for street protests. However, the authorities will crack down hard before any unrest can gather enough momentum to threaten the regime.
A combination of effective deployment by Mr Sisi's security apparatus, increased state largesse to the poorest Egyptians and public distaste for further instability is likely to keep such pressures contained for most of the forecast period, but continued political repression could fundamentally undermine Mr Sisi's rule beyond 2024.
In the long term domestic policies will focus on economic development, particularly in the still-restive Sinai and other deprived areas, and security. Mr Sisi, formerly the head of the armed forces, will exert tight control over internal security and will continue to crack down on Islamist militants. However, sporadic incidents of militancy will occur, with the risks increasing as economic development strategies fail to improve conditions for many pandemic-affected Egyptians. Mr Sisi could lose the loyalty of the armed forces and his position in such circumstances.
Parliament is subservient to Mr Sisi and will be further kept in check by presidential appointees to the new Senate (the upper house) and by the tight controls imposed on candidates who do stand for election. The most active opposition to the government remains Sinai-based jihadi groups, as well as the deposed Muslim Brotherhood-support for which has ebbed-and its militant offshoots, Hassm and Liwa al-Thawra. A sweeping anti-terrorism offensive launched in 2018 has eased security threats. Although militant groups will sporadically carry out attacks, The Economist Intelligence Unit expects the military operation to help to contain the number and size of attacks.
Political outlook: Political and institutional effectiveness Egypt's bureaucracy is arguably the largest in the region-and among the most bloated globally-with nearly 6m workers employed by the central government, according to official data. (This excludes around 3m additional workers who are employed by the state on temporary contracts.) As a result, low efficiency is particularly endemic in the government sector. This over-staffing has placed a heavy burden on the public finances and left few funds for improving public services and upgrading systems. Domestic reform is sometimes held back by the populist bent of the parliament, although it has co-operated strongly with the state on a raft of austerity measures that have helped to unlock significant multilateral financial support, notably from the IMF, which in 2020 agreed to provide US$8bn in loans to help the government to deal with the impact of the coronavirus pandemic, supplementing the US$12bn disbursed in 2016-19 in the form of an extended fund facility.
Mr Sisi has professed his determination to make the government more efficient and to crack down on corruption. In the 2019 Corruption Perceptions Index compiled by Transparency International, Egypt was ranked 106th out of the 180 countries surveyed, with the same score as Algeria, Brazil and Côte d'Ivoire. The agency tasked with combating corruption is the Administrative Control Authority. This body is closely tied to the presidency, and, according to a law passed in 2017, its scope is restricted to the civilian bureaucracy, which means that there is no institutional structure for scrutinising the expanding role of the military establishment and the intelligence services in the economy.
The prerogatives of the military were strengthened in the constitutional amendments that were approved in April 2019. These amendments also reinforced the presidency's control over the judiciary (and over military appointments). The tightening of restrictions on public expression has also hit civil society organisations, which are heavily constrained. The increasing centralisation of power within the presidential office and among senior military and intelligence figures is likely to yield some improvements in the efficiency of government operations, but at the expense of accountability and at the risk of fostering corruption within these privileged echelons of the state.
Another important development during the forecast period will be the transfer of government operations from Cairo to the new administrative capital, to the east. Ministries were scheduled to commence this process during 2020. The coronavirus pandemic has resulted in a delay to this schedule, but the government has indicated that the relocation of ministries will go ahead in 2021. The move provides an opportunity to streamline government operations through having a dedicated zone for them, with modern infrastructure and information technology services. However, there will inevitably be some disruption during the transfer.
Political outlook: Election watch Elections will be a means for Mr Sisi to consolidate power rather than a democratic exercise. This carries a risk of sudden and volatile regime change, albeit well beyond the forecast period. Elections will not be free or fair, with candidates almost exclusively from government-allied blocs. Voter turnout for the newly reconstituted partly elected Senate vote was exceptionally low, at 14%. The government has threatened to prosecute eligible voters who did not vote, which is likely to push up turnout in the parliamentary vote for the lower house (House of Representatives) in October-November, but the outcome is not in doubt regardless. Future of the Homeland, a dominant pro-Sisi party, is likely to be the favoured conduit for government policies. Constitutional changes have extended Mr Sisi's rule to 2024, when he can stand again. Mr Sisi, who appears to be in relatively good health, is therefore likely to remain in power until 2030. Repeatedly delayed municipal elections are unlikely to be held before 2021. Local polls are important for businesses, as municipal councils implement investment regulations at the local level.
Political outlook: International relations The government's priorities will centre on maintaining cordial ties with the US, strengthening defence capabilities and building a broadening range of international links to secure its strategic interests and access to financial support. Regionally, the government will cultivate strong political ties to seek to secure maximum economic backing from the Gulf Arab states.
Egypt will continue its engagement in Libya and build on security ties in the Gulf and eastern Mediterranean in a bid to curb the growing influence of its regional rival, Turkey, which it views as posing a threat to its energy interests through its military support for the UN-backed Government of National Accord (GNA) in western Libya. Egypt will also seek to limit threats from Islamist militancy emanating from Libya. Egypt will direct political and military support to groups allied with the GNA's rival government in eastern Libya but is unlikely to risk direct and sustained military engagement there.
Egypt will lean on the Gulf Arab states for economic support in the wake of the pandemic and co-ordinate on key international issues, including the ongoing boycott of Qatar to retain the backing of the UAE and Saudi Arabia in particular, although it will still seek Qatari investment. Egypt, the UAE and Saudi Arabia will step up joint efforts against security threats in the region.
Europe will also be an important source of military hardware, spending on which will remain a priority in the context of Egypt's security campaigns and geopolitical tensions in the gas-rich eastern Mediterranean region, where the country is taking an increasingly central role in hydrocarbons development. Egypt will seek to deter incursions by Turkey, which does not recognise the 2003 maritime border demarcation agreement between Egypt and Cyprus. Co-ordination with Israel over natural gas and shared security interests will continue.
The filling of the Grand Ethiopian Renaissance Dam by Ethiopia, which began in mid-July, will constrain the flow of water from the Blue Nile to Egypt. Various regional and international mediators will seek an agreement that addresses Egyptian and Sudanese concerns over flow rates, but tensions will remain high, although we do not expect an escalation into military confrontation. Ethiopia may agree to modest slowdowns in fill rates during drought periods, but Egypt is unlikely to secure greater concessions.

Policy reforms will continue in a bid to cement earlier gains despite pandemic Egypt's overall score improves in the forecast period (2020-24), and its regional and global rankings rise by two and seven places, respectively, owing to more effective government and continued efforts to enhance the business environment as part of reforms that have been undertaken with the support of the IMF and the World Bank. Egypt's economic prospects have been severely curtailed by the global coronavirus pandemic, but its chances of a recovery have been bolstered by the improvements made to the fiscal position and institutional framework in the previous three years, which means that its macroeconomic environment score shows the strongest improvement in any category in 2020-24, and its regional and global rankings improve markedly from their bottom rankings in 2015-19. Structural reforms will include efforts to upgrade the education system to better meet employment needs.
Egypt's score for taxation improves marginally but its ranking slips globally in 2020-24 as fiscal pressures mount. The Ministry of Finance is proceeding with plans to achieve full digitisation of its tax accounts, which should improve the efficiency of tax affairs and provide greater transparency. Value-added tax (VAT) was introduced in mid-2016. Stamp duty on share transactions was introduced in July, now delayed from 2020 to 2022 as part of a package of measures to mitigate the impact of coronavirus; stamp duty rates have been cut, and the tax rate on dividends from listed companies has been halved to 5%. Investors are entitled to income tax discounts. A new customs law, passed in August 2020, provides for electronic clearance of goods, helping to streamline trade and logistics. The restoration of such tax incentives, which were withdrawn in 2005, will improve Egypt's competitiveness in relation to other regional investment destinations. Access to finance will be much improved beyond the pandemic period, as companies will have much less difficulty in securing foreign exchange, and the increase in the government's external borrowing will free up more domestic bank liquidity for lending to the private sector.

Business environment outlook: Egypt's business environment at a glance Policy towards private enterprise and competition 2020-21: Regulations eased to support private businesses during pandemic. Public-private partnerships are encouraged.
2022-24: Military-run enterprises are encouraged to list on the stockmarket. Share offerings from state entities resume, including remaining shares in banks. The National Bank of Egypt is kept in full public ownership.
Policy towards foreign investment 2020-21: The government actively courts foreign investment and improves tax breaks to keep foreign partners in Egypt, but conditions will remain tough, given weakening global economic sentiment during the pandemic.
2022-24: The investment law is amended following complaints from foreign firms about delays and bureaucratic obstacles.
Foreign trade and exchange controls 2020-21: Capital controls intermittently reinstated to manage pandemic pressures. The government introduces measures to reduce red tape and import costs with new customs regulations.
2022-24: Capital controls removed. Remaining restrictions on imports, including tariff surcharges on goods deemed to be luxuries, are lifted.
Taxes 2020-21: Some sectors get waivers on certain tax payments during the pandemic crisis. Measures to ease the tax burden on financial markets introduced. Tax incentives and exemptions for the private sector improved. Employees face 1% tax surcharge on income for 2020/21.
2022-24: Corporate income tax is lowered from 22.5%, but the value-added tax (VAT) rate is increased. Capital gains tax is finally introduced in 2022, after numerous postponements. Stamp duty on share transactions is raised.
Financing 2020-21: Lending to the private sector curtailed by global pandemic aftershocks, despite increased government incentives.
2022-24: Domestic credit conditions improve despite a small rise in policy rates. Foreign banks increase their direct lending to Egyptian projects, and leading Egyptian banks receive enhanced ratings from international agencies.
The labour market 2020-21: The official unemployment rate surges amid an economic downturn, although workers push for wage increases to compensate for the erosion of real wages since 2016.
2022-24: Unemployment trends down again. Trade unions resist pension reforms raising the retirement age to 65.
Infrastructure 2020-21: Major new rail projects progress, including monorail serving the new administrative capital. A second container terminal is built at East Port Said. Suez development, new cities, slum clearance and Sinai infrastructure are prioritised.
2022-24: Road and rail connections to 14 new satellite cities are completed. Investment in seawater desalination increases.
Technological readiness 2020-21: Tax payments digitised and e-government expanded to help to ease pandemic pressures and as part of broader plans. Firms expand their presence on e-commerce platforms, although low internet penetration remains a hindrance.
2022-24: E-government portals are put into general use to automate processes of business-licensing applications.
