Reforms of 2016-19 have helped build some resilience during the crisis The macroeconomic category has strengthened markedly and despite the global pandemic will see the biggest improvement in the forecast period. This reflects improvements in most key indicators as a result of reforms enacted since 2016, although consumer demand had been slower to recover, as high inflation dampened household consumption, and public debt has been rising. Egypt's short-term economic prospects have been clouded by the impact of the coronavirus, with tourism and remittances among the worst-hit. Increased external borrowing has helped to mitigate the immediate balance-of-payments risks, but it has also aggravated the medium-term risk of a debt-service crunch. Real GDP growth will return to the previous trend of 5-6% later in the forecast period. Inflation is likely to remain subdued, and the exchange rate appears set for a period of stability. Since 2017/18 the government has achieved primary fiscal surpluses and expects to do so even during the pandemic crisis, as it seeks to achieve a medium-term target of lowering public debt below 80% of GDP.
High repayment obligations could put external finances at risk later in forecast period The flotation of the currency at the end of 2016 was a shock to the country's financial system, but it has contributed to a turnaround in Egypt's balance-of-payments position. The inflow of capital in the form of loans from international institutions, sovereign bond issues and a revival in direct and indirect foreign investment has enabled the central bank to rebuild its foreign-exchange reserves to a comfortable level, and to relax capital controls. Reserves fell sharply between February and May 2020 amid a reversal of portfolio investment, but they have since stabilised, owing to external borrowing and a resumption of inward portfolio investment. Reserves could come under pressure later in the forecast period, when substantial debt repayments fall due.
Business environment outlook: Policy towards private enterprise and competition                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2015-19 2020-24 2015-19 2020-24 2015-19 2020-24
3.8 5.0 68 55 11 8
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 17 countries: Algeria, Bahrain, Egypt, Iran, Israel, Jordan, Kuwait, Libya, Morocco, Qatar, Saudi Arabia, Tunisia, UAE, Angola, Kenya, Nigeria and South Africa.
Egypt's policy towards private enterprise and competition will improve considerably over the forecast period as the government seeks to streamline the regulatory system for investment and licensing. The country's global and regional ranks both rise as a result. However, private businesses-already hurt by the impact of the global pandemic on economic activity-will have to contend with the continued deep involvement of the armed forces and their various commercial arms in a wide range of economic sectors. The army frequently acts in the guise of a regulatory agency itself, by requiring permission for firms to operate in areas deemed to have a national security dimension, and military companies often compete with civilian firms, but with the advantage of being able to use cheap military assets, including land and labour. Efforts to promote private investment stretch back decades, but businesses still encounter obstacles arising from inconsistencies in the legislation and inefficiency and corruption in the bureaucracy. Recent reforms to the licensing and investment laws are likely to result in some improvements, depending on implementation.

- Law 15 on industrial licensing and Law 72 on investment, both passed in 2017, aspire to speed up the approval processes for private companies carrying out new projects and to enhance the authority of the quasi-autonomous agencies operating under the law: the Industrial Development Agency and the General Authority for Investment.

Legislation to encourage both new and existing projects will aim to attract investment
- A revision in 2019 to Law 72 now enables the expansion of existing investment projects to qualify for incentives (previously only open for new investment). The incentives include corporate tax discounts of 50% for projects in designated priority areas and 30% for projects in other areas. Another adjustment specifies that the fee for certifying signatures for contracts to set up a new project should be 0.25% of the paid-up capital, with an upper limit of E£10,000 (US$570; there was no upper limit previously).
- The establishment at the end of 2015 of SCZone, an agency responsible for the Suez Canal Economic Zone, was also intended as a signal to private business that the government was serious about creating a more user-friendly regulatory environment, but it has since become more closely tied to the state sector and the armed forces. However, changes to the leadership of the Suez Canal Authority, the public-sector agency in charge of overseeing the canal, has paved the way for the agency responsible for economic development in the canal zone to regain some autonomy, although it remains close to the military.
- The government has previously sought to assist domestic steel and cotton producers in the face of global pressures. Despite changes to reform competition policy, loopholes and other impediments to competition remain in certain sectors, such as telecommunications and utilities, and corruption is still a problem, especially at local government level.

Business environment outlook: Policy towards foreign investment                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2015-19 2020-24 2015-19 2020-24 2015-19 2020-24
5.1 6.4 66 48 11 6
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 17 countries: Algeria, Bahrain, Egypt, Iran, Israel, Jordan, Kuwait, Libya, Morocco, Qatar, Saudi Arabia, Tunisia, UAE, Angola, Kenya, Nigeria and South Africa.
Despite intermittent market pressure, reforms will stay in place Egypt's score for its foreign investment policies improves markedly for the forecast period, and its global and regional rankings rise by 18 and five places, respectively, to 48th and sixth. The government is actively courting foreign investment through revamping the regulatory framework, including the restoration of tax incentives, and through the intensive promotion of new project proposals and zones. Foreign investors have also been encouraged by the reforms to the exchange-rate system, which have helped to ease blockages in access to foreign exchange needed to finance imports of equipment and materials and to allow for repatriation of dividends. Inflows of foreign direct investment (FDI) have increased steadily over the past few years, reaching US$9bn in 2019 but fell sharply in the first quarter of 2020, in an early indication of the impact of the coronavirus pandemic. We do not expect FDI inflows to regain their recent levels until 2022, at the earliest.

- The new investment law of 2017 and the subsequent amendments in 2019 have given new powers to the General Authority for Investment, with the provision for electronic approval of project proposals. The main issues the new law has sought to address are inconsistencies in the approval process and the demand from investors for the restoration of tax incentives, which were removed in 2005 on the grounds that they led to manipulative behaviour by businesses and that they deprived the Treasury of revenue.
- The efficacy of a new investments approval system will be tested by the pandemic, given its dampening effect on global demand and financial flows. Businesses setting up new projects or expanding existing ones will be entitled to claim discounts of 30-50% on their tax bills, up to the equivalent of 85% of their paid-in capital. The higher discounts will be available for projects established in areas classified as deprived and for labour-intensive projects. The new law also allows for the creation of new special investment zones.

New legislation allows foreign acquisitions to be included in FDI figures
- The investment law was amended in 2019 to enable extensions to existing projects and the development of new product lines to benefit from tax exemptions. The amendments also included changes to the accounting system for FDI, through giving the General Authority for Investment full authority to record inflows. The definition of FDI has been broadened to reflect international practices, including allowing foreign acquisitions of stakes of less than 10% in Egyptian entities to be recorded as FDI. Foreign oil companies will be able to retain profits for reinvestment. Regularising the recording of flows will improve transparency, making for a more amenable FDI environment. The government has provided assurances that the investment law will bring an end to conflicts with the industrial licensing law, which also includes a streamlined approvals process. It remains doubtful whether such conflicts can be avoided in practice
- At the end of 2019 the post of investment minister was abolished, with responsibility for this area of policy shifting to the office of the prime minister. The government said that this would help to streamline investment policy implementation. The General Authority for Investment is the executive agency for investment, and now reports directly to the prime minister.

Business environment outlook: Foreign trade and exchange controls                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2015-19 2020-24 2015-19 2020-24 2015-19 2020-24
5.1 5.5 71 72 11 11
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 17 countries: Algeria, Bahrain, Egypt, Iran, Israel, Jordan, Kuwait, Libya, Morocco, Qatar, Saudi Arabia, Tunisia, UAE, Angola, Kenya, Nigeria and South Africa.
Foreign trade and exchange controls will remain lifted but government will be wary of further measures Egypt's score in this category improves, but its global rank falls by one place, and its regional rank is unchanged. This reflects the stabilisation of the foreign-exchange market amid more challenging global conditions following a period of improvement that has been underpinned by heavy external borrowing. Since 1994 there have been no explicit exchange controls in Egypt. Egypt has also accepted the obligations of sections 2, 3 and 4 of Article VIII of the IMF's Articles of Agreement. These oblige the authorities to refrain from imposing any restrictions on payments and transfers for current-account transactions or from engaging in discriminatory currency arrangements or multiple-currency practices without the IMF's approval. Nevertheless, the authorities did impose a series of restrictions on foreign-exchange transfers after the rapid depletion of net international reserves in the wake of the 2011 revolution, and companies found it increasingly difficult to secure access to foreign exchange to finance imports and for the repatriation of dividends. The situation has improved dramatically following the flotation of the Egyptian pound in November 2016. Restrictions on cash deposits to finance imports were relaxed, and in June 2017 the central bank removed limits placed in 2011 and only partly relaxed in 2014 on banks providing clients with foreign currency to transfer abroad (previously limited to one transfer per year of up to US$100,000 per client).

- Net international fell by almost US$10bn between February and May 2020 as a result of heavy withdrawals by portfolio investors in response to the coronavirus pandemic. Equilibrium was restored after the government signed two agreements with the IMF, worth US$8bn in total, and secured US$5bn through a sovereign bond issue. This has prompted a cautious return of portfolio investors. However, high external debt repayment obligations could put intermittent pressure on the external finances.
- The exchange-rate system is now operated by commercial banks, with the central bank playing no formal role in the market. The exchange rate depreciated in 2017-18 amid heavy divestment by portfolio investors. However, the Egyptian pound appreciated strongly in 2019 in response to renewed portfolio inflows, and it reached E£16.00:US$1 in early 2020. The rate depreciated by about 3% in May-June 2020, but had rallied to E£15.80:US$1 by early September. Recent multilateral and other external funding inflows and growing hydrocarbons prospects should support a stronger currency for most of 2020-24.
- The government and the central bank have taken steps to avert a balance of payments crisis arising from the pandemic. The strong relationship formed with the IMF during the US$12bn extended fund facility (EFF) programme in 2016-19 has helped Egypt to mobilise a further US$8bn from the IMF for 2020-21; US$5bn has been raised from the bond market in 2020, and a further US$2bn from a group of regional and international banks, stabilising the foreign-exchange market. However, there remains a risk that pressure on the currency will mount, once the government starts repayments of the EFF in late 2021.

Business environment outlook: Taxes                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2015-19 2020-24 2015-19 2020-24 2015-19 2020-24
6.2 6.3 38 50 9 8
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 17 countries: Algeria, Bahrain, Egypt, Iran, Israel, Jordan, Kuwait, Libya, Morocco, Qatar, Saudi Arabia, Tunisia, UAE, Angola, Kenya, Nigeria and South Africa.
Tax policy will keep most gains but an element of unpredictability remains
- Tax policy is likely to stabilise during the forecast period, although the scale of change will not be at the rate seen in the historical period. Egypt's global ranking falls by 12 places, but its regional ranking improves by one place to eighth. The basic rate of income tax for companies was lowered to 22.5% from 25% in 2015. The business community, which is strongly represented in parliament, has lobbied for a return to a 20% rate (in pace in 2004-11) but the need for fiscal adjustment after the pandemic is likely to preclude such a move. Collection of corporate tax will improve following the ongoing digitisation of the system. Tax discounts introduced in reforms to the investment law in 2017 and 2019 will remain in place. New legislation in July 2020 will enable companies to submit unified tax declarations, including income tax, VAT and stamp duties in a single package. The government might increase the VAT rate from 14% to 15% to derive more tax revenue as it tries to restore the fiscal finances after the pandemic. Withholding tax is likely to remain at 20%. Following the flotation of the local currency, international banks resumed investments in Egyptian Treasury bills as the high returns and reduced foreign-exchange risk offset reservations about the withholding tax. These flows have fluctuated in line with global market sentiment, with a renewed outflow in early 2020, but inward flows have resumed.
- As part of the response to the coronavirus pandemic, the government sought to stimulate the capital market through a range of tax measures. These included a further two-year deferral of the introduction of a 10% capital gains tax to May 2022. The government has also halved the dividend tax to 5% and reduced stamp duty on shares. However, a 1% emergency surcharge is being levied on salaries to help to cover extra spending associated with the pandemic.

The government has adjusted personal income tax thresholds
- Changes to personal income tax in the 2020/21 budget, include increases to thresholds, reflecting the impact of high inflation in 2016-18. The threshold for paying the lowest tax rate of 2.5% has been raised to annual earnings of E£15,000 (US$940) from E£8,000, and the rates charged for the next two bands have been lowered by 5 percentage points to 10% (for E£30,000-45,000) and to 15% (E£45,000-60,000). The rate for the E£60,000-200,000 band has been lowered to 20% from 22.5% but for earnings of E£200,000-400,000 it has been left at 22.5%. A new top rate of 25% will be applied to earnings above E£400,000.
- A new property tax law passed in 2014/15 has, since 2017/18, charged 10% tax on properties with a market value of E£2m (US$125,000) or more. There are exemptions for facilities and property owned by the armed forces. Valuations are to be reassessed every five years, but this has been postponed, owing to delays in tax collection. The pandemic is likely to lead to further deferral.

Business environment outlook: Financing                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2015-19 2020-24 2015-19 2020-24 2015-19 2020-24
4.4 5.9 70 50 12 8
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 17 countries: Algeria, Bahrain, Egypt, Iran, Israel, Jordan, Kuwait, Libya, Morocco, Qatar, Saudi Arabia, Tunisia, UAE, Angola, Kenya, Nigeria and South Africa.
Confidence in the financial system has strenghtened although the pandemic will test its limits The turnaround in Egypt's balance of payments that followed the signing of a its US$12bn EFF with the IMF in 2016 has helped to anchor the economy during the pandemic crisis, allowing a dramatic improvement in the score and ranking for the country in the financing category. The global rank rises 20 places to 50th. The regional rank moves up to eighth place from 12th. The increased confidence in the international financial system in Egypt has been reflected in the series of successful sovereign debt issues undertaken by the finance ministry since January 2017, which have raised more than US$25bn, includingf US$5bn in May 2020. The Ministry of Finance also raised US$2bn in a package of conventional and Islamic loans signed with a UAE-led group of banks in September 2020 and two loan agreements worth US$8bn in total with the IMF in May and June. This borrowing is mainly directed at fiscal financing, but it has also helped to stabilise the balance of payments. The shift to external deficit financing will make more liquidity available in the banking system for lending to the private sector later in the forecast period. However, investors and creditors will have to consider the future risk of the large increase in Egypt's stock of external debt.
Looser monetary policy should allow greater private-sector borrowing
- Lending to the private sector will grow as the Central Bank of Egypt (CBE) loosens monetary policy and seeks to promote lending as part of the broader effort to stimulate economic recovery from the coronavirus shock. A surge in inflation in late 2016 prompted the CBE to raise interest rates by 700 basis points, bringing its main operation rate to 19.25% by July 2017. Inflation started to ease at the end of 2017, and the CBE cut rates in 2018-19 by a total of 650 basis points. In March 2020, in response to the pandemic crisis, the central bank cut policy rates by 300 basis points, to 9.75%. High real interest rates help to attract foreign inflows into Treasury bills, but hampers private-sector borrowing, and there is scope for further rate cuts if inflation remains subdued.
- The central bank has launched a series of schemes aimed at directing credit towards specific sectors. The first, in 2016, set a target for banks to allocate at least 20% of the loan portfolio to micro, small- and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs). The interest rate was set at below market rates, and banks could offset the difference by reducing their statutory reserve. The scheme was extended to medium- and large-sized companies (with annual turnover of between E£50m and E£1bn) in late 2019, with the allocation ofE£100bn to be lent at 8% annual interest. In March-April 2020 the central bank took further measures to alleviate the burden on borrowers of the coronavirus. SMEs and household debtors were given a six-month waiver on debt-servicing, and a similar provision was made for companies in the tourism sector. The central bank also abolished the upper limit for preferential borrowing by medium- and large-sized firms.

Central banks provide guarantees to ease credit difficulties
- In May 2020 the central bank pledged E£100bn (US$6.3bn) in guarantees for subsidised loans to be provided by commercial banks to industrial, agricultural and contracting firms in order to provide assurance to banks at a time of elevated risk, owing to the coronavirus pandemic. This would provide an incentive for banks to continue to advance credit to businesses in order to help them to remain solvent and to retain their workforce during the downturn.
- According to the CBE, non-performing loans (NPLs) accounted for 4.1% of total loans in May 2020, compared with 7.1% of total loans in 2015. However, this improvement in loan quality has come about partly because of the preference of banks to lend to the government rather than to private businesses. The government currently accounts for 66% of total bank credit, compared with 21% for the private business sector, according to the central bank. As lending to business revives, we expect that the NPL ratio will also increase, albeit modestly.
- The stockmarket attracted strong inflows of foreign portfolio investment following the flotation of the pound, but there has been a slowdown in 2020 amid wider concerns among international investors about emerging-market risk. The EGX30 index fell by about one-third in the first quarter of 2020, before staging a modest recovery. At end-August 2020 the index was still about 20% below its level at the start of the year. The market had been preparing for a series of offerings of state-owned shares in more than 20 companies. This process has already been subject to delays, but the first offerings could take place in 2021.

Minimum capital requirements are rising for banks
- A new law approved in July 2020 increases the minimum capital requirement for commercial banks tenfold to E£5bn (US$300m). Foreign branches will be required to increase their capital to at least US$150m (currently US$50m). Banks will be given three years to comply. The new capital levels have been set with a view to complying with Basel III and Basel IV regulations, and to take account of devaluation since the previous level was set in 2003. Some smaller banks are likely to merge in order to comply with the new capital requirements. The law also has provisions for e-payments and fintech services.
- The Sovereign Wealth Fund of Egypt (Tharaa), which was set up in 2018 with authorised capital of E£200bn, is designed to provide a structure for increased private investment in Egypt. State assets will be transferred to the fund to form the basis of partnerships with private investors.

Business environment outlook: The labour market                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2015-19 2020-24 2015-19 2020-24 2015-19 2020-24
4.8 5.1 78 74 14 11
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 17 countries: Algeria, Bahrain, Egypt, Iran, Israel, Jordan, Kuwait, Libya, Morocco, Qatar, Saudi Arabia, Tunisia, UAE, Angola, Kenya, Nigeria and South Africa.
The labour market score and ranking rise modestly for the forecast period, reflecting improved economic performance and management since 2016. From a business perspective, the Egyptian labour market offers an abundance of young workers, with graduates, post-graduates and skilled and semi-skilled technicians available at very competitive rates. The return of Egyptian workers from the Gulf as a result of lay-offs of expatriates during the coronavirus pandemic will also add to the pool of experienced labour within Egypt. There are several drawbacks, however, notably the rigidity of labour market laws-which are set to become more restrictive-and regulations that make it difficult to fire workers (partly because it is an extremely costly exercise). Employers face pressure from workers for pay increases to compensate for the fall in real wages and the rise in the poverty rate during the surge in inflation following the 2016 devaluation, although the rise in the unemployment rate as a result of the pandemic will weaken workers' bargaining power.
Unemployment is rising due to the pandemic's economic fallout
- After reaching almost 13% in 2016, the unemployment rate fell steadily over the next three years, reaching 7.7% at end-March 2020. The unemployment rate then rose sharply to 9.6% by end-June; about 2.6m jobs were lost during the second quarter of that year, as a result of a sharp drop in economic activity amid the coronavirus pandemic. Sectors that were hit particularly hard included retail, tourism and manufacturing. There was also a significant reduction in the workforce, arising mainly from the departure of women from the labour market. The labour participation rate fell to 38.9% from 42.7% by end-March 2020. Labour participation has fallen steadily from a peak of 49%, suggesting that many disaffected Egyptians are no longer searching for work. The government is continuing with major infrastructure projects, partly in a bid to sustain jobs through the pandemic, but the unemployment rate is only likely to fall from 2021.
- The government has sought to lessen the risk of labour unrest by announcing a significant increase in the minimum wage for all workers in the state sector, to E£2,000 (US$120) per month, with effect from July 2019. The minimum wage was previously increased to E£1,200 per month in 2014. The government also increased the basic state pension by E£150 per month to E£900. Proposed reforms to the pension system, entailing a gradual increase in the retirement age to 65 from 60 and a shift to a hybrid defined benefit/defined contribution scheme tied to average lifetime earnings, rather than final salary, could also prompt opposition from workers.

Focus on private-sector employment
- The government will try to shift the burden of creating jobs back to the private sector, once economic growth starts to recover. In 2018 it also launched education reforms tailored to improving the skills of the future labour force.

Business environment outlook: Infrastructure                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2015-19 2020-24 2015-19 2020-24 2015-19 2020-24
4.5 5.8 60 52 11 8
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 17 countries: Algeria, Bahrain, Egypt, Iran, Israel, Jordan, Kuwait, Libya, Morocco, Qatar, Saudi Arabia, Tunisia, UAE, Angola, Kenya, Nigeria and South Africa.
Government will seek to sustain growth with continued infrastructure spending Egypt's score for the quality of its infrastructure improves in 2020-24, with the global and regional rankings rising by eight and three places respectively. This reflects heavy ongoing investment in upgrading infrastructure, with a particular focus on energy and transportation, but large gaps remain. The military will take a leading role in many infrastructure projects, particularly for transport. The principal focus of the investment drive in recent years has been the energy sector. Between June 2014 and June 2018 installed electricity-generating capacity rose from 32 GW to 55 GW, including the start-up of three 4.8-GW combined-cycle plants built by Siemens (Germany). The power sector has also benefited from an improvement in natural gas supply, initially through imports of liquefied natural gas, and more recently owing to a rapid rise in domestic production. There is now a surplus of more than 20 GW of capacity over peak load.

- The Sovereign Wealth Fund of Egypt (Tharaa) will seek to establish itself as a major player in infrastructure by taking strategic stakes in existing assets to be transferred to the private sector, as well as in new projects. Its first major deal will entail the establishment of a partnership with an international developer to take over ownership and operation of the three Siemens power stations. The fund is also planning to take an anchor investment role in the installation of 1.4m cu metres/day of desalination capacity over the next five years.
- The contribution of renewable energy to total power capacity will increase over the forecast period, with the recent start-up of 1.5 GW of solar capacity developed under a feed-in tariff programme and the development of a series of large-scale wind farms and solar installations.
- Work will start during the forecast period on a 4.8-GW nuclear power station at El Dabaa, west of Alexandria. The project is to be carried out by Rosatom of Russia, including the supply of fuel and the disposal of waste.

The government is investing heavily in energy and transport infrastructure
- The completion of a new 72-km channel in the Suez Canal has improved services for international shipping. A new channel has also been dredged at the northern end of the canal to upgrade access to the East Port Said container terminal and to allow for its expansion. A second terminal is likely to be built, although contract negotiations for this have so far failed to progress.
- Major rail transport projects will make progress during the forecast period. These include a monorail system serving the new administrative capital and the new 6th of October City, for which a contract was signed in mid-2019. The government is also pressing ahead with upgrades to the existing rail system, which has a poor safety record. The government has invited bids for a railway linking Sokhna, on the Gulf of Suez, to the Mediterranean. Further sections of the Cairo metro will be completed during the forecast period, and the European Investment Bank agreed earlier in 2020 to finance work on upgrading the urban transport system in Alexandria. The road network will continue to be expanded under the supervision of the Egyptian Armed Forces Engineering Agency. These will include the completion of the Rod el-Farag axis across northern Cairo.

Business environment outlook: Technological readiness                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2015-19 2020-24 2015-19 2020-24 2015-19 2020-24
3.8 4.9 66 63 11 9
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 17 countries: Algeria, Bahrain, Egypt, Iran, Israel, Jordan, Kuwait, Libya, Morocco, Qatar, Saudi Arabia, Tunisia, UAE, Angola, Kenya, Nigeria and South Africa.
Egypt is playing catch-up with technological developments Egypt's technological readiness score will improve in the forecast period from a low base, on the back of innovation driven by both the government and private ventures. The country's global and regional rankings rise by three and two places respectively. The Ministry of Communications and Information Technology was established by the government in 1999 to support and promote a national information and communications technology (ICT) sector. The main areas of focus for the ministry are telecommunications, digital citizenship, human capacity, industry development and innovation. To date, progress has been slow, as indicated by Egypt's low (albeit improving) ranking in the World Intellectual Property Organisation's 2019 Global Innovation Index at 92nd out of 129 ranked countries. The main weakness for Egypt appears to be in ICT infrastructure, while slow progress is being made in institutional capacity and market sophistication, as well as business complexity.
The ICT sector is gaining increasing attention from the government
- The government envisages the technology sector as one of the main drivers of economic growth, including the development of new ICT investment clusters, such as a proposed technology valley in the Suez Canal Economic Zone.
- According to the Ministry of Planning and Economic Development, the telecommunications sector grew by 16% year on year in real terms in the first three quarters of 2019/20, following growth of 16.7% in the previous fiscal year, and the information sector grew by 3.8%. The telecommunications sector is also growing rapidly, with the roll-out of 4G and improved data provision helping to support growth in e-commerce and in the use of data services.
- The potential for growth in the technology sector has been highlighted by the success of Fawry, Egypt's leading fintech firm, whose market capitalisation reached US$1bn in August 2020, a year after its initial public offering. The shift to online shopping during the pandemic has boosted E-commerce.
- Egypt tested 5G mobile data during the Africa Cup of Nations in 2019, but a broader build-out will take some years, with those firms using hardware from the Chinese company, Huawei, likely to face political pressure from the US.

Economic forecast: Policy trends In the short term, policy will focus on addressing the coronavirus pandemic and maintaining access to international financing. Egypt made good progress in its 2016-19 US$12bn programme with the IMF. However, given the impact of the coronavirus on economic activity and the fiscal and external positions, Egypt has tapped the IMF again, accessing US$2.8bn from the Fund's coronavirus rapid financing initiative in May to help it cope with the pandemic's economic fallout. Egypt and the IMF have also agreed a 12-month, US$5.2bn stand-by arrangement (SBA), with the first tranche of US$2bn disbursed by early July. Several other multilateral agencies will also disburse lending to Egypt to see it through the pandemic crisis, including funding to support small and medium-sized enterprises and to sustain infrastructure projects.
The government allocated E£100bn (US$6.4bn) to its initial mitigation strategy, which included regulatory, fiscal and monetary measures, and strengthened credit guarantees to banks, but more funds will be deployed to support tourism and other high-priority areas that are likely to remain particularly badly affected by the pandemic. Nonetheless, the depth of the pandemic crisis will prove challenging for the private sector, and the government's capacity to provide further relief will be tested. It has taken measures to lower costs for portfolio investors and improve the attractiveness of capital markets, halving the dividend tax and pushing back the introduction of capital gains tax to May 2022, and foreign investors will be exempt. In a move to support manufacturing, electricity prices for energy-intensive industries have been cut and tariffs for other industries have been frozen, including for natural gas supplies. A new law rationalising customs regulations and processes came into force in mid-2020. Firms will also receive tax payment and declaration waivers and deferments. Although these measures will ease the financial burden for firms, the government will also need to offset the impact of its support on the public finances; for instance, it has added a 1% surtax on employee salaries effective for fiscal year 2020/21 (July 1st-June 30th), which will dampen consumer activity.
The authorities will eventually need to refocus on putting the public finances back on a more sustainable footing, and on structural and regulatory reforms to make Egypt more attractive to foreign investors, and to boost the domestic private sector. Significant hurdles remain for export-oriented industries. However, the influence of powerful interest groups, especially the extensive business interests of the military, will hamper the reform process and private-sector development even after the immediate pandemic crisis subsides.
Improving water and rail infrastructure and addressing rural under-development-especially in the restive Sinai region-will be prioritised later in the forecast period, aided by multilateral funding packages. Although the slump in global energy demand will damage short-term prospects and require the temporary suspension of some projects, delaying the sector's upstream and downstream development, Egypt will seek to advance its role as a regional energy hub for the eastern Mediterranean and as a gas exporter, drawing on regional ties.
Economic forecast: Fiscal policy Fiscal indicators

Fiscal performance in 2019/20 has been sustained by stronger performance earlier in the fiscal year, but the budgetary fallout from the pandemic will be sustained into 2020/21 and beyond. Lower economic activity and new tax breaks aimed at supporting businesses will dampen revenue collection, although the government has sought to offset this by reallocating levies normally accruing to government firms to the state budget from 2020/21, as well as introducing the 1% tax surcharge on salaried employees for 2020/21. The government will increase transfer payments to the poorest and public-sector wages and pensions in order to limit political discontent, adding to the fiscal burden. Dealing with the coronavirus will use up some of the cost savings from recent subsidy reductions, which will continue to be implemented in a bid to contain upward spending pressures.
Value-added tax (VAT) revenue, which generates close to half of tax revenue, will be depressed, but the government will leave the corporate tax rate unchanged at 22.5% in the early part of the forecast period in order to encourage a recovery in investment. Given the impact on revenue of the pandemic and the cost of mitigation measures, it is likely that the fiscal deficit, and therefore the debt-service burden, will rise considerably in the short term, despite lower policy interest rates. We expect the fiscal deficit to rise further in 2020/21, to 9.8% of GDP. The deficit will decline thereafter, but the rate of consolidation will ease in 2023/24 as election-related spending ahead of the presidential poll slows consolidation efforts. The deficit will average 7.4% of GDP in 2021/22-2023/24. Funding the deficit will involve domestic borrowing and tapping multilateral and bilateral sources in the early years of the forecast period, topped up with more costly sovereign bond issuance, driving public debt up to a peak of 122.3% of GDP at end-2021/22.

Monetary policy will prioritise stimulating the economy and financial markets in the short term. The Central Bank of Egypt (CBE) cut its main rate by 300 basis points in mid-March to 9.25% in response to the coronavirus. Further cuts may be necessary in the short term, but the CBE will remain wary of currency volatility and renewed capital outflows or a return to higher inflation. Policy rates will therefore stabilise from 2021, and private-sector credit conditions are likely to improve broadly; the CBE will continue with stimulus measures aimed at reviving private-sector activity. The CBE has launched industrial and home-purchase stimulus schemes that aim to support a recovery in private-sector credit extension. Later in the forecast period, as inflationary pressures from rising international prices resume, the policy rate will rise modestly.

The impact of the coronavirus on trade and tourism flows and on domestic activity will last well into the first half of 2020/21. We expect the economy to contract overall in 2020/21, given the long-lasting hit to key sectors such as tourism. Tourism, which accounts for about 9.5% of employ-ment and 5.5% of GDP, has shut down and will be hit extremely hard, with many businesses unable to survive the shutdown. The tourism slump will further depress the retail and services sector. Multilateral backing will support continued government consumption and investment, but private consumption growth and exports will suffer heavily. The economy will expand from 2021/22 as global demand picks up in earnest and new energy projects gain momentum, driving investment. Lower unemployment will boost private consumption, although widespread poverty will remain a constraint on consumer demand growth. The construction and energy sectors will be the main engines of growth in the middle of the forecast period. The government is pursuing various low-income housing schemes with private contractors and is building a new (administrative) capital city east of Cairo, which has almost been completed. Capital goods imports will grow to support infrastructure projects.
Tourism and other export and service sectors will revive gradually after 2021. Confidence in the availability of hard currency will recover and help to attract foreign investors, especially from 2022. With growth becoming increasingly broad-based and unemployment falling, consumer spending should pick up more strongly in 2022-24. The development of hydrocarbons resources and processing capabilities could further boost expansion in the longer term, with growth forecast to average 4.4% a year in 2021/22-2023/24.


Enlarge this image.
Economic forecast: Sectoral trends The manufacturing sector, which includes oil refining, accounts for about 15% of real GDP, but the challenges facing the sector are numerous. Local manufacturing suffers from quality issues and is often unable to match competition from imported goods. The competitiveness of export-oriented manufactured goods has been undermined by a spike in the costs of imported intermediate goods and raw materials, and raw materials prices will weaken owing to the pandemic, and local currency appreciation will damage recent gains in export competitiveness. On top of this, many factories have been forced to curtail production significantly (or even shut down), owing initially to restrictions imposed to slow transmission of the coronavirus but also the impact of the pandemic on both domestic and global demand. The state statistics agency, CAPMAS, reported that more than 500,000 jobs were lost in manufacturing during the second quarter of 2020, although some sectors have been less affected. The oil-refining segment is set to grow rapidly in the next few years, with the completion of upgrades to a series of refineries. There are also prospects for growth in the petrochemicals sector. The building materials industry has benefited from demand for government-initiated construction and infrastructure, but the entry of military entities into this industry in recent years risks distorting this market.
Despite the subdued short-term outlook due to global energy demand weakness, the outlook for the oil and gas sector continues to improve, owing to substantial investments coming on stream from international oil companies (IOCs). Because of political instability, production in both sectors declined, and government debt owed to IOCs built up in the aftermath of the 2011 uprising. However, the natural gas industry has staged a vigorous recovery since late 2013, and IOCs remain strongly committed to Egypt, despite the current slump in the global oil and gas market. Arrears owed to IOCs for contracted gas purchases have fallen below US$1bn from a peak of above US$6bn, and the government has provided more attractive terms for exploration and production.
The leading operators, Eni of Italy and the UK's BP, have reached plateau production for their largest developments-Zohr and West Nile Delta, respectively-and are planning to develop fresh discoveries off the eastern coast of the Delta in the next few years. US majors ExxonMobil and Chevron have also taken on exploration blocks in Egypt's west Mediterranean offshore sector, and Chevron has secured one of the two blocks awarded in the Red Sea, in an inaugural bid round for this area. Egypt has reined in its natural gas production owing to the weakness of the global liquefied natural gas (LNG) market, but as prices recover it will have an opportunity to ramp up exports. The two LNG export terminals, in Idku and Damietta, are also likely to start processing Israeli gas during the forecast period. Adding Cypriot gas to this mix will depend on whether the tensions in the eastern Mediterranean arising from Turkey's maritime claims can be resolved, which is unlikely. Egypt's own gas consumption declined slightly in 2019, owing mainly to the increased efficiency of newly commissioned power stations. We expect Egypt to continue to have a surplus of natural gas supply over demand during the forecast period. Oil production is likely to continue to decline, as most of the main fields have reached maturity, but the upgrades to the refining sector will allow for a reduction in petroleum products imports, even though crude oil imports will increase. The mining sector is also likely to show strong growth in the forecast period following the entry into force of a new law that replaces the oil-based production sharing model with a tax and royalty scheme. Prospects for further development of gold resources in the eastern desert are highly promising, and interest has been galvanised by the surge in gold prices since the pandemic started.
The services sector-another major employer and traditionally a significant component of the economy-has experienced repeated setbacks. Tourism suffered a prolonged slump after the downing of a Russian airliner over Sinai by militants in October 2015, and the sector was hit hard once more in early 2020 by the coronavirus pandemic. The recovery after the Sinai crash started to gain momentum in 2018, and in 2019 arrivals rose to 13m, the highest since 2010; the sector contributed US$13bn to the current account in 2019, according to the Central Bank of Egypt. However, following the outbreak of the coronavirus (Covid-19), the government closed Egypt to foreign tourists in March 2020, and there has only been a limited reopening since July. The sector accounts for 10-15% of GDP and provides employment for about 3m Egyptians. The impact of the pandemic and associated travel restrictions and requirements in key markets will continue for much of 2021, and any recovery to pre-coronavirus levels is unlikely before 2023. Other important components of services, including the financial services and information and communications technology (ICT) sectors, which have been strong drivers of growth in recent years, will suffer some weakness as a result of the pandemic but, particularly for ICT, the crisis could also create new opportunities, and these industries will see a swifter pick-up than tourism.
Construction and transport are likely to continue to be among the fastest-growing sectors. These sectors have been affected by the pandemic (including a brief slowdown in building as a result of pandemic restrictions, but also owing to concerns about surplus demand), but to a lesser degree than in other areas of the economy. Projects such as the new administrative capital and 13 other satellite cities under development will underpin strong growth in the construction and building materials sectors. The first phase of the new capital is nearing completion, and private developers are preparing to embark on building new residential and commercial areas. The main foreign participant is China State Construction and Engineering Corporation, which is building the central business district. The new capital has generated a number of major transport schemes, notably a new monorail system that will link it to Cairo, and which will include a line from Cairo to the 6th of October City industrial and residential area to the south-west. The government is also promoting investment in logistics, including a series of inland dry ports to be carried out on a public-private partnership (PPP) basis.
Economic forecast: Inflation % 2019 2020 2021 2022 2023 2024
Consumer prices 9.2 5.6 6.0 6.1 5.5 5.4
Despite an uptick in food prices (which comprise about one-third of the consumer price basket) amid supply concerns early in the pandemic and a price increase in public transport fares, inflation will ease to an average 5.6% in 2020, because of the slump in international oil prices, declining non-oil commodity prices, and faltering domestic demand. We expect inflation to rise to an average of 6% in 2021-22 amid excess liquidity, but currency appreciation will help to offset the impact of higher international oil prices and stronger domestic demand. Annual inflation should ease to about 5.5% in 2023-24.

In 2020 the impact of the coronavirus on hard-currency earnings and financial markets will lead to increasing currency volatility. The pandemic has put pressure on emerging-market capital flows. After initial volatility in March the pound stabilised, but at the expense of foreign reserves, which fell sharply in March-May (although they remain above six months of import cover). In anticipation that the IMF would require a return to a free float as part of its SBA framework, temporarily reinstated foreign-currency liquidity guarantees for foreign investors have been removed, allowing the currency to depreciate before stabilising again in mid-July and subsequently appreciating. The pound will be volatile into 2021. In the longer term, we expect renewed real exchange-rate appreciation, reflecting a growing natural-resource endowment and contained inflation. The pound will still come under renewed pressure at times of crisis, although the level of intervention will fall. We expect the pound to strengthen to an average of E£15.72:US$1 in 2024.

The trade deficit will narrow sharply in 2020 as the decline in the value of energy imports outpaces the fall in export earnings in the wake of the coronavirus pandemic. Gas prices have also plummeted, but in the longer term gas exports and non-hydrocarbons exports will pick up as global demand recovers. However, from 2021-22 capital goods inputs for infrastructure projects and stronger consumer demand will push up import spending too, and the trade deficit will rise in nominal terms, although it will decline as a share of GDP during 2020-24, averaging a manageable 7.3% of GDP.
Services exports will fall sharply in 2020, hit by the impact on Suez Canal revenue of the disruption of trade flows caused by the coronavirus and the collapse in tourism, which accounts for about 15% of current-account receipts. Sources of income such as official transfers and remittances will also be hit in 2020, but will grow thereafter. The current-account deficit will widen in 2020 to 4.3% of GDP, although it will narrow thereafter. The CBE has sufficient foreign-exchange reserves to cover the deficit in 2020, and is able to call on support from the IMF and Gulf Arab allies.t

Economic forecast: Foreign direct investment in Egypt Stocks and flows The government changed its methodology for assessing foreign direct investment (FDI) inflows in July 2018 to include all undistributed realised earnings whereas previously it only counted reinvested earnings; this has raised the total FDI inflow level. Inflows FDI are set to fall during 2020 (net FDI inflows were US$970m in the first quarter of 2020, about 60% lower than in the same period of 2019 according to central bank data) as a result of the coronavirus pandemic, after averaging about US$8bn per year since 2016, with an uptick to US$9bn in 2019. However, we expect there to be a relatively rapid recovery as a result of the momentum that had previously been built up in sectors such as natural gas, infrastructure, mining and telecommunications. The government's efforts to improve the environment for foreign investors through new legislation passed in 2017 did not immediately have the desired result, as the oil and gas sector, which was not covered by these laws, continued to account for the bulk of FDI inflows. The government has since sought to address some of the flaws that investors have highlighted in the legislation, and it has made an effort to streamline the decision-making process by abolishing the Ministry of Investment and enhancing the powers of the head of the General Authority for Investment, who now reports directly to the prime minister. The increased role of the military establishment in the economy will have a mixed impact on FDI. On the one hand, it will deter investors from sectors in which military entities are perceived to have a competitive advantage, but, on the other hand, some investors will be content to form joint ventures with military agencies in the hope that this will give them a competitive edge. The Economist Intelligence Unit expects a recovery-initially fairly slow, reflecting global economic weakness-during the forecast period, reflecting improvements in the business environment and a wider availability of hard currency to meet business needs. We also forecast that outward direct investment will increase during the forecast period as healthier liquidity levels and easing foreign-exchange shortages enable companies to expand their overseas operations.
Origin and distribution EU-based investors, the majority of which are British firms, have accounted for about two-thirds of total inward FDI flows to Egypt during the past five years, and the US and Arab countries have supplied most of the remainder. The UAE, which is Egypt's closest regional ally, has been the largest source of investment among Arab countries, by a significant margin, followed by Saudi Arabia and Qatar. UAE banks are now poised to increase their presence in the Egyptian market by acquiring ventures set up by two Lebanese banks, and Saudi Telecom has agreed in principle to acquire the Egyptian arm of British-based Vodafone. Chinese companies have shown increasing interest in investing in Egypt, but, according to the most recent central bank data, China accounted for only about 1% of gross FDI inflows in 2017/18 and 2018/19. A slowing Chinese economy, as well as the US-Chinese trade and technology disputes, are likely to hamper further growth in investment from China. FDI inflows are heavily skewed towards the oil and gas sector, reflecting the major ongoing investment in developing new natural gas fields. In the first three-quarters of 2018/19, oil and gas accounted for 62% of total new FDI inflows, compared with 19% for greenfield projects and 16% for real estate.
Determinants Besides market size and the availability of cheap labour, the main determinants of FDI include the business and legal environment and the availability of foreign exchange for imports and profit repatriation. Under the current regime, the government is seeking to resolve a number of long-running disputes with Gulf Arab (and other foreign) investors, as part of a broader effort to encourage regional players to increase their activity in Egypt. Efforts to establish new free zones-such as the Suez Canal Development Zone-could help to court investments, and the sovereign wealth fund (Tharaa) established in 2018 has been designed as a channel for FDI. Downside risks to FDI will persist. These include business environment deficiencies, weak lending by domestic banks and the global economic slump resulting from the coronavirus pandemic.
Impact Increased FDI has helped to transform Egypt into a more modern market economy. Foreign firms are aiding economic diversification, improving the quality of human capital through better managerial and technical skills, increasing employment opportunities and assisting the transfer of technology. Leading petroleum firms are helping the government to exploit its rich oil and gas endowment and generating budget revenue.

Egypt's population will exceed 100m by the end of the forecast period Egypt's growing population provides opportunities for economic development but is also among the biggest challenges facing the govern-ment, as it places additional strains on the labour market and public services such as healthcare and education. The Economist Intelligence Unit forecasts that the population will rise from 98.9m in 2019 to 108.9m by 2024, an annual growth rate of 1.9%-nearly double the average for most developing countries but considerably lower than in the historic period despite the return in 2020 of expatriate workers from the Gulf and from Jordan (almost 10m Egyptians reside abroad), affected by the pandemic. Rural areas will experience higher growth rates than urban centres. The slower growth rate reflects our expectation that recent family-planning campaigns and the high cost of living since the 2016 currency flotation will reduce fertility rates.
Almost one-third of the population is below the age of 15, and more than half is below 24. About 700,000 new entrants join the labour market annually, and unemployment rose in the wake of the 2011 uprising, as real GDP growth averaged well below the 6-7% required to absorb the growing labour force. Since 2014 the unemployment rate has fallen from a peak of over 13% to below 8% by early 2020. However, the coronavirus pandemic has resulted in heavy job losses, pushing the unemployment rate above 9.6% as at end-June 2020, according to CAPMAS, the state statistics agency. The underlying situation is worse that this figure suggests, as there has been a large-scale withdrawal of women from the labour force. The unemployment rate for men rose from 4.5% to 8.5%, with 1.9m registered as out of work at end-June, compared with 1.07m at end-March; the female unemployment rate fell to 16.3% from 21.9%, with the number out of work almost halving to 640,000. The number of men in the total workforce dropped to 22.7m from 23.8m, while the number of women decreased from 5.2m to 3.9m. These trends were reflected in a sharp fall in the labour participation rate, which had already been trending down in recent years--to 38.9% from 42.7% in the first quarter. Government efforts to address unemployment have failed to resolve deep structural shortcomings and the lack of opportunities, particularly for younger graduates. The outlet of seeking work overseas will also be constrained in the medium term by the global pandemic.
Outward migration to the Gulf states, Europe and North America will be more limited Outward migration from Egypt to neighbouring Gulf Arab states, Europe and North America is likely to resume, but the coronavirus pandemic means that there will be fewer opportunities in these areas. Hundreds of thousands of Egyptians have been forced to return home from the Gulf during 2020. Expatriate remittances are among the major sources of foreign-exchange receipts for Egypt. Even before the pandemic, migrating to the oil-rich Gulf Arab states was becoming increasingly difficult, as these countries have stepped up their programmes to increase the proportion of their own nationals in the workforce. Similarly, public opinion in Europe and North America is turning increasingly against economic migrants, which is likely to be reflected in tighter immigration rules and restrictions on foreign labour inflows.
Poverty rate continues to rise Other consequences of Egypt's recent political and economic turbulence include a rise in the rate of poverty since 2011. According to the results of a household survey by CAPMAS, the poverty rate (calculated at an income below E£735.7 per head per month, (US$41) reached 32.5% in the 2017/18 fiscal year. This was 4.7 percentage points higher than in the previous published survey, for 2014/15, and reflected the impact of economic reforms enacted since 2016 that have squeezed household spending power. The government claims that the effects of the rise in the poverty rate have been mitigated by social protection programmes, but consumer spending has been hit. The absolute poverty rate in 2017/18 was 6.2%, according to a line set at E£490.8 per month, compared with a rate of 5.3% in 2014/15, based on income of E£322 per month.
Egypt has a highly urbanised population, with nearly 10m people living in Cairo alone. The current government has taken steps to promote internal migration from the overcrowded Nile Valley into unpopulated tracts of desert. These include a demarcation plan to create three new governorates-Central Sinai, Al Alamein and Al Wahat-bringing the total to 30. The government is also undertaking a number of major industrial projects outside urban centres, such as the Suez Canal Development Zone, with the aim of boosting employ-ment opportunities in the long-neglected rural areas. The government has embarked on the construction of 14 new satellite cities. The largest of these is the new administrative capital, where some government ministries have relocated and which is envisaged as eventually housing some 6m people.

The pandemic will undermine the beginning of a recovery in incomes Purchasing power was eroded in the immediate aftermath of the November 2016 currency flotation, which led to severe inflationary effects and pushed down disposable incomes. Amid this challenging backdrop, retail sales declined in 2017 in US-dollar terms-although there was some recovery in 2018 as inflation started to fall. GDP per head in US dollar terms only returned to pre-flotation levels in 2019/20 and suffered a further setback following the onset of the coronavirus pandemic. However, with the currency appreciating, the overall impact will be of stagnation (with a weak decline in purchasing power terms in 2021) and then slow growth in per capita GDP in the early years of the forecast period, before a stronger recovery from 2022/23. Egypt's GDP per head is expected to climb to US$5,021 by 2024, although this will remain low by regional standards. Even with the pandemic stalling the recovery in per capita incomes in the short-term, as the most populous country in the Middle East and North Africa, Egypt's large size makes it an important regional market, with huge potential (particularly in the second half of the forecast period) that will continue to grow over the long term. The population is easily accessible, not least because it is located in an extremely concentrated geographical area. However, the headline figures mask wide income disparities between rich and poor.
Wide income disparities remain Nevertheless, the spending power of a sizeable minority of the population, who reside mainly in newly built cities and neighbourhoods such as New Cairo and 6th of October, is comparable to that of consumers in the industrialised world. They will be less affected than lower-paid Egyptians by the pandemic and will find it easier to rebuild wealth. This segment retains substantial disposable income and beyond the immediate uncertainty of the pandemic period will be willing to spend it on consumer goods. A government survey published in July 2016 showed that the richest 10% of the population accounted for one-quarter of total spending by Egyptians. This indicates the extent of the inequality between rich and poor households in the country, with recent increases in the poverty rate likely to have intensified this polarisation. Later in the forecast period, as the economy recovers, inflation stays more manageable, and unemployment begins to fall again, this will help to boost private consumption; purchasing power will improve across a wider swathe of the population although large disparities will still remain.
Egypt's retail markets have seen little investment since 2011, which means that the market is under-saturated, and assets are under-priced. This could provide investment opportunities, but prospective investors are likely to wait until they have made a thorough assessment of the impact of the pandemic on consumer behaviour, with e-commerce finally beginning to gain substantial ground.

In common with the rest of the region, spending on food, beverages and tobacco accounts for the largest share of total consumer expenditure, and this will remain the case throughout the forecast period. With the pandemic denting incomes, consumer expenditure on basic necessities as a share of the total will rise sharply in 2020, before easing thereafter. Even by 2024, spending on basic household items, primarily food and beverages, as well as spending on housing, will dominate household expenditure. This is because a substantial chunk of the population will remain at or just above the poverty line, with only sufficient disposable income for subsistence; poverty rates have risen over the historical period although they are likely to begin to edge down in the forecast period, translating into a slow shift in spending patterns among some groups. There were signs of a recovery in consumer spending as the inflation rate fell to about 5% in late 2019 and early 2020, but this recovery has been knocked back heavily by the coronavirus pandemic.
In the long run, demand for higher-end consumer goods will be underpinned by rising incomes, employment and population growth. Demand for more sophisticated, foreign-produced electrical goods is certain to grow, not least because of mistrust of the quality of locally produced goods. Other markets will increase in importance as the forecast period progresses, however, notably transport and communications. As car ownership rises and demand for mobile and internet technology takes off, a rising proportion of household income will be spent on these items.

From May 2019 The Economist Intelligence Unit's long-term growth forecasts have been revised to take into account the economic impact of climate change.
Initial conditions: Egypt began addressing decades-old market distortions in 2016, backed by significant external financial support, which has been broadly sustained during the coronavirus pandemic and ensuing economic instability. The government has retained the policies adopted since 2016-centred around economic liberalisation and rationalising the public finances--but progress has been slow at times. Moreover, the public finances and external debt position will be further stretched in the pandemic, with the government entering the crisis under a large (but until 2020 gradually declining) fiscal deficit. Nonetheless, the agreement reached with the IMF in 2016 and the subsequent economic policy changes have helped to shore up investor confidence in the economy, and this has been further reinforced by the extent of renewed IMF and other multilateral and bilateral support that Egypt has received to cope with the shock to domestic and external finances from the pandemic. The economy is well diversified, and the abundance of cheap labour, coupled with its large market size, means that Egypt still has huge potential over the long term, although the large and still rapidly growing population also poses serious infrastructure and social stability challenges.
Demographic trends: Egypt's high population density has some advantages: access to consumers is relatively easy, especially in the two urban centres, Cairo and Alexandria. Overall population growth will begin to slow, owing to higher levels of development and government family-planning policies, but will remain high. Demographic trends are broadly favourable to growth prospects, in that the working-age population will continue to rise more rapidly than the overall population throughout the forecast period owing to the youthful demographic bulge. However, this will also add to the burden on public services such as education and healthcare. The government will press ahead with projects to develop areas of the desert beyond the Nile Valley to alleviate pressure on infrastructure. This will be supported by the government's efforts to reclaim 1.5m feddans (630,000 ha) of land. With most of the land surface uninhabited, the government will push ahead with long-awaited plans to create a number of new governorates, an idea that was first mooted in 2005 and later revived by the president, Abdel Fattah el-Sisi, in late 2014, who has since pushed forward with major urban construction projects, including a new administrative capital.
External conditions: External conditions will remain dependent on demand from key export markets in North America and the EU-Egypt's largest trading partner. These have been heavily affected by the coronavirus pandemic, but in the longer term should be restored to growth, especially with the US. The broader region is also embroiled in political and security turmoil, which will continue to dampen investment sentiment across the Middle East as a whole. Increased tensions with Turkey will remain a concern, particularly in terms of Egypt's ambitions to leverage its growing natural gas resource capacity and processing facilities to solidify its role as an energy hub for that region, but despite these concerns, this will be an important area of growth and co-operation with countries such as Israel, Cyprus, Greece and elsewhere in southern Europe. Over the longer term, economic recovery in Europe and the US should translate into higher inflows of foreign direct investment (FDI) as well as growing exports. Similarly, reliance on financial assistance should decline gradually as structural reforms put the economy back on a sustainable footing.
Institutions and policy trends: The present and future governments will work to streamline the bureaucracy and boost the accountability of public officials. They will also look to downsize the bloated public sector, which means that private-sector participation in the economy and attracting FDI will be key to developing the country's infrastructure and improving public services. However, such reforms will be slow and protracted, largely as a result of the presence of deeply entrenched interest groups in the government and the powerful influence of business lobby groups and of the military on the state. Moreover, democratic accountability will stay low with authority centred around the presidency. Threats to long-term political and social stability may persist, reflecting the stand-off between the state and its liberal opponents, as well as high unemployment rates and high levels of poverty.
Long-term performance: There is significant potential for strong real GDP growth over the long term. Egypt is a prime location as a base to export to Asia, Africa and Europe and has a plentiful and low-cost workforce. However, success will also depend on an ongoing commitment to economic reform and to major improvements in political and institutional effectiveness. The government must increase the efficiency of the bureaucracy; develop a more effective commercial legal system; continue to withdraw the state from economic activity; and reform the public finances. Progress is likely to be patchy, but The Economist Intelligence Unit expects real GDP growth to average 4.2% a year in 2020-30 and 4.3% in 2020-50, with labour productivity growth helping to offset slower population growth.
