From May 2019 The Economist Intelligence Unit's long-term growth forecasts have been revised to take into account the economic impact of climate change.
Long-term outlook: Long-term trends Climate change and sustainability Egypt has been struggling with rising temperatures in recent years, with summer heat typically averaging above 35˚C. This results in spikes in energy consumption during the hot summer season by both households and industrial users. However, successive heat waves and worsening climate conditions globally could create new health dangers for residents of the country, as well as the broader Middle East and North Africa region-particularly as the summer season lengthens and humidity levels rise further. This may also reduce arable land in Egypt, which is already facing the threat of worsening water scarcity as construction and the filling of the Grand Renaissance Dam (located on the Nile, downstream in Ethiopia) is completed in the coming years; Egypt is especially concerned that Ethiopia has not agreed to terms that will dictate water filling according to hydrological and climatic conditions. In addition to continuing to seek an agreement on these issues, Egypt will accelerate efforts to develop other water sources, especially desalination. The impact that higher air temperatures and humidity will have in reducing the ability of the human body to cool off through sweating is likely to lower the productivity of workers involved in construction and other outdoor activities (even at night). All of this will boost demand for energy further as time goes by and weather conditions deteriorate. The government is increasingly looking to renewable sources, especially solar, to meet power demand and is also beginning work on nuclear energy provision, but remains heavily dependent on natural gas. As part of managing the greater demand for energy, local authorities will need to diversify the energy mix to include more renewable sources of power.
Technological developments The government envisages the technology sector as being one of the main drivers of economic growth over the next five years, including the development of new information and communications technology (ICT) investment clusters, for example a proposed technology valley in the Suez Canal Economic Zone. Telecoms and the ICT sector have grown rapidly in recent years as 4G rollout has accelerated. Future growth is highly likely, considering the growing interest by foreigners in Egypt as a budding offshore IT centre. Indeed, despite the modest performance by regional comparison, Egypt has been gaining increasing attention by foreign companies as an outsourcing centre for IT operations-owing in part to the abundance of skilled workers and the country's proximity to European markets. A report by Gartner, an IT advisory group, ranked Egypt among the top nine locations for outsourcing in Europe, Africa and the Middle East.
There are currently more than 6,000 Egyptian companies active in the ICT sector, most of them in activities related to the internet. E-commerce and fintech have grown strongly during the pandemic crisis albeit from a low base. The government estimates that Egypt earns about US$1.5bn in annual exports of ICT-related services, and this figure is likely to climb significantly in the long term. ICT accounted for about 4% of GDP in 2018/19, according to the government, and it plans for it to reach 5% of GDP by 2022, targeting 12% growth a year in the sector; the growth target will be hampered by the coronavirus pandemic but its share of GDP will rise. Exports of digital services have also grown strongly. The government is rolling out e-government services for households in select areas; internet penetration is still fairly modest, although it is used in the business sector more widely. The number of internet users has risen strongly with the government estimating that almost 70% of individuals were using the internet on a daily basis by early 2020, according to Ministry of Communications and Information Technology (MCIT) data. Almost one-half of households had fixed broadband access to the internet by early 2020, compared with about 20% a decade earlier, and about 47% of households used mobile broadband (nearly all households have access to a mobile phone). Household home internet coverage in urban areas is far higher (about 70%) compared with rural areas (about 50%) where improved mobile services could play a particularly important role. The number of mobile internet subscriptions grew by 11.2% year on year in the first quarter of 2020, according to MCIT data while ADSL subscribers grew by 10.4%. Internet bandwidth is also growing, but at a slightly slower pace than the number of subscribers.
Long-term outlook: Methodology for long-term forecasts The time horizon for the detailed forecasts and analysis in the Country Forecast report is a five-year period. The Main report also carries a section on the long-term outlook, including projections of key macroeconomic and market size variables up to 2050. Depending on the indicator, average growth rates in a sub-period or values at select points in time are reported. Many companies make strategic business decisions over timeframes in excess of five years. The Economist Intelligence Unit's long-term projections will provide information to facilitate such decisions. Long-term forecasts and scenarios are also vital in understanding some of the big economic issues that will shape global business in the coming decades. We are well placed to build on and extend the five-year forecasts to produce long-term projections and scenarios because of the existing forward-looking analysis and models in the Country Forecast (in particular, the business environment rankings model). These are used to forecast some of the key drivers of long-run growth, as explained in detail below.
Growth projections The main building blocks for the long-term forecasts of key market and macroeconomic variables are long-run real GDP growth projections. We have estimated growth regressions that link real growth in GDP per head to a large set of growth determinants. The determinants of growth consist of the scope for convergence (based on initial GDP per worker at the start of a period); demographic variables; a set of policy variables (measuring the fiscal stance, openness to trade, and the government regulatory burden in product, credit and labour markets); a measure of institutional quality; geography (climate, location and the degree of primary export orientation); education levels and labour quality (as measured by mean years of schooling and life expectancy); the external economic environment (changes in the terms of trade); the level of development of information and communications technology (ICT); and historical legacies (history of independent statehood).
The regressions, which have high explanatory power for growth, allow us to forecast the long-term growth of real GDP per head for sub-periods up to 2050, on the basis of demographic projections and assumptions about the evolution of policy variables and other drivers of long-term growth.
Definitions of variables The dependent variable is GDPG: Average annual growth in real GDP per head, measured at national constant prices.
The independent variables include: LnGDPPL: The natural logarithm of GDP (adjusted for purchasing power parity-PPP) per worker (that is, per population aged 15-65) in constant 1980 US dollars at the start of each decade. Expressed as an index, US$=1.
LnSCHOOL: The natural logarithm of the mean years of schooling of the population aged over 15 at the start of each decade. Missing values for some countries are filled in by estimating mean years of schooling on the basis of an equation relating mean years of schooling (where available) to gross primary school enrolment ten years previously, and to secondary and tertiary enrolment ratios five years previously.
LnLIFEEXP: The natural logarithm of life expectancy at birth at the start of each decade. This variable also enters the equation in squared form, reflecting diminishing returns to growth of increases in life expectancy at high levels.
OPEN: Updated Sachs-Warner index of openness-the fraction of years during each decade in which a country is rated as an open economy according to the following four criteria: (1) average tariff rates below 40%; (2) average quota and licensing coverage of imports of less than 40%; (3) a black-market exchange-rate premium that averaged less than 20%; and (4) no extreme controls (taxes, quotas, state monopolies) on exports.
INST: Index of institutional quality (on a scale of 1-10) that is an average of five sub-indices of measures of the rule of law, quality of the bureaucracy, corruption, the risk of expropriation and the risk of government repudiation of contracts. Forecast values are based on corresponding indicators from our business environment rankings.
LABPOP: The difference between the growth rate of the working-age population (aged 15-65) and the growth rate of the total population in each decade.
TOT: The average annual rate of change of the terms of trade in a given decade.
GOVSAV: The average government savings ratio in each decade (current government revenue minus current government expenditure) expressed as a share of GDP.
TRADESH: The average share of trade (exports and imports of goods and services) in GDP, lagged by one decade to deal with the endogeneity of growth and trade.
GOVREG: An index on a scale of 1-10 of regulation of product, credit and labour markets. For forecast periods, the composite index is based on seven indicators from three categories of our business environment rankings model-from Policy towards private enterprise (ease of setting up new businesses, freedom to compete, price controls); from Financing (openness of the banking system, financial market distortions); and from Labour markets (restrictiveness of labour laws, wage regulation).
ICT: An index, on a scale of 1-10, of the development of information and communications infrastructure.
Control variables include PRIMARY: share of the exports of primary products in GDP at the start of a decade; TROPIC: percentage of the land area within a country that has a tropical climate; COLONY: history of independent statehood-a dummy variable taking the value of 1 if a country was a colony before 1945; and, in some specifications, regional dummy variables.
Summary of findings As in other studies, income per head and human capital are found to be important determinants of growth, with the coefficient on the logarithm of GDP per worker suggesting a relatively modest pace of convergence. The measures of institutional quality and of government regulation enter significantly in all specifications. We found a strong positive impact on growth of government savings and openness in all specifications. The criteria for classifying countries as open are quite permissive. The crucial aspect of trade policy captured by the measure is that it is a high level of distortion, rather than modest levels, that is deleterious for growth. The trade share variable is also moderately significant. The openness index (which is more of a true measure of policy) is hardly affected by the inclusion of trade/GDP shares in the equation. The correlation of the two measures is only 26. Although a tropical climate is highly significant, as is the share of primary exports in GDP, other geographic indicators-such as access to the sea, distance from major growth centres and the proportion of the population residing near coastlines-were not significant. A colonial past (pre-1945) is found to have a significant negative impact on growth, even in more recent periods.
Productivity growth The forecasts of GDP growth, of capital stock growth (based on estimated investment shares and assumed depreciation rates) and of growth in labour supply (based on projections of working-age population and assumptions on labour force participation) yield labour productivity growth and total factor productivity growth forecasts. The latter utilise the growth accounting identity, GY=b*GK+c*GL+A, where GY is growth of real GDP, GK growth of the capital stock and GL growth of human capital (the labour force adjusted for changes in skills). "A" stands for growth in total factor productivity; "b" and "c" are the shares of capital and labour in income. Trade values are forecast on the basis of simple import (function of GDP and relative prices) and export functions. Forecast market exchange rates (that is, the differential between PPP and market exchange rates) depend on the differential in labour productivity growth between a country and the US.

Guide to the business rankings model Outline of the model The business rankings model measures the quality or attractiveness of the business environment in the 82 countries covered by Country Forecast using a standard analytical framework. It is designed to reflect the main criteria used by companies to formulate their global business strategies, and is based not only on historical conditions but also on expectations about conditions prevailing over the next five years. This allows The Economist Intelligence Unit to utilise the regularity, depth and detail of its forecasting work to generate a unique set of forward-looking business environment rankings on a regional and global basis.
The business rankings model examines 11 separate criteria or categories, covering the political environment, the macroeconomic environment, market opportunities, policy towards free enterprise and competition, policy towards foreign investment, foreign trade and exchange controls, taxes, financing, the labour market, infrastructure and technological readiness. Each category contains a number of indicators that are assessed by The Economist Intelligence Unit for the last five years and the next five years. The number of indicators in each category varies from five (foreign trade and exchange regimes) to 13 (political environment), and there are 91 indicators in total.
Almost half of the indicators are based on quantitative data (eg GDP growth), and are mostly drawn from national and international statistical sources for the historical period (2015-19) and from Economist Intelligence Unit assessments for the forecast period (2020-24). The other indicators are qualitative in nature (eg quality of the financial regulatory system), and are drawn from a range of data sources and business surveys adjusted by The Economist Intelligence Unit for 2015-19. All forecasts for the qualitative indicators covering 2020-24 are based on Economist Intelligence Unit assessments.
Sources used in the business rankings model include Akamai Technologies, State of the Internet; CIA, World Factbook; The Economist Intelligence Unit, Country Risk Service, Country Commerce, Democracy Index, Risk Briefing; IMF, Annual Report on Exchange Arrangements and Exchange Restrictions; International Institute for Management Development, World Competitiveness Yearbook; International Labour Organisation, International Labour Statistics Yearbook; International Telecommunication Union, ICT Indicators Database; Transparency International, Corruption Perceptions Index; UN Conference on Trade and Development, Ecommerce Index; World Bank, World Development Indicators, Doing Business; World Economic Forum, Global Competitiveness Index; World Intellectual Property Organisation, IP Facts and Figures.
Calculating the rankings The rankings are calculated in several stages. First, each of the 91 indicators is scored on a scale from 1 (very bad for business) to 5 (very good for business). The aggregate category scores are derived on the basis of simple or weighted averages of the indicator scores within a given category. These are then adjusted, on the basis of a linear transformation, to produce index values on a 1-10 scale. An arithmetic average of the ten category index values is then calculated to yield the aggregate business environment score for each country, again on a 1-10 scale.
The use of equal weights for the categories to derive the overall score reflects in part the theoretical uncertainty about the relative importance of the primary determinants of investment. Surveys of foreign direct investors' intentions yield widely differing results on the relative importance of different factors. Weighted scores for individual categories based on correlation coefficients of recent foreign direct investment inflows do not in any case produce overall results that are significantly different from those derived from a system based on equal weights.
For most quantitative indicators the data are arrayed in ascending or descending order and split into five bands (quintiles). The countries falling in the first quintile are assigned scores of 5, those falling in the second quintile score 4 and so on. The cut-off points between bands are based on the average of the raw indicator values for the top and bottom countries in adjacent quintiles. The 2015-19 ranges are then used to derive 2020-24 scores. This allows for intertemporal as well as cross-country comparisons of the indicator and category scores.
Measurement and grading issues The indices and rankings attempt to measure the average quality of the business environment over the entire historical or forecast period, not simply at the start or at the end of the period. Thus, in the forecast we assign an average grade to elements of the business environment over 2020-24, not to the likely situation in 2024 only.
The scores based on quantitative data are usually calculated on the basis of the numeric average for an indicator over the period. In some cases, the "average" is represented, as an approximation, by the recorded value at the mid-point of the period (2017 or 2022). In only a few cases is the relevant variable appropriately measured by the value at the start of the period (eg educational attainments). For one indicator (the natural resources endowment), the score remains constant for both the historical and forecast periods.

Political stability The Economist Intelligence Unit expects that, with a majority in the Lok Sabha (the lower house of parliament) and an impending majority in the Rajya Sabha (the upper house), the ruling Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) will stay in power for its full term, which ends in 2024.

Full text: - The Economist Intelligence Unit expects the current government to serve out its second term, which will expire in 2024. We expect the prime minister, Narendra Modi, to run a highly centralised administration and to make some progress on pushing through structural reform.
- A deadly clash between Indian and Chinese troops in a disputed border area in June 2020 has caused deterioration in diplomatic and economic ties, but we do not foresee a large-scale military clash. The incident will cause India to seek warmer relations with the US and its allies. Bilateral relations with Pakistan will also remain strained, but we do not expect outright hostilities.
- As a result of economic pressure, we expect the government to continue to unwind gradually the lockdown measures introduced in March. The ongoing spread of the coronavirus (Covid-19) may overwhelm India's healthcare system.
- The budget deficit will widen to 7.9% of GDP in fiscal year 2020/21 (April-March) amid lower tax revenue and stimulus expenditures. The deficit will narrow but nevertheless remain wide between 2021/22-2024/25.
- We expect the Reserve Bank of India (RBI, the central bank) to cut interest rates by another 50 basis points in the fourth quarter of 2020. Its main policy rate will be cut to 3.5%. The RBI will also tweak its policy tools and regulatory framework to facilitate the transmission of accommodative monetary policy.
- Real GDP will contract by 8.5% in 2020/21. A combination of pre-existing credit strain among non-bank financial companies and a marked deterioration in the creditworthiness of stressed firms will restrain the pace of recovery; we expect the economy to grow by 6.7% in 2021/22.
- We forecast the rupee to depreciate against the US dollar in nominal terms in 2020, averaging Rs74.5:US$1 amid the subdued domestic economy. It will strengthen slightly in 2021 before depreciating again between 2022 and 2024.
- The trade deficit will narrow in 2020 amid a slump in global oil prices. It will widen from 2021 as India increases imports of capital goods. Business outsourcing and information technology will remain the key service export sectors in 2020-24.

- India's score improves over the forecast period, owing to improvements in the infrastructure category, but its overall regional ranking remains weak.

Country forecast overview: India's business environment at a glance Policy towards private enterprise and competition 2020-21: The government takes steps towards partial privatisation of some state-owned companies in 2021.
2022-24: The government continues to rationalise liquidation and bankruptcy laws to simplify the closure of loss-making businesses or merger-and-acquisition activity involving other corporate entities.
Policy towards foreign investment 2020-21: The government's policy towards foreign direct investment (FDI) will remain ambiguous.
2022-24: Foreign investment in export manufacturing increases markedly, albeit in only a few regions. Strong growth in e-commerce and the expanding Reliance Jio telecommunications platform will attract FDI from leading internet firms.
Foreign trade and exchange controls 2020-21: The country remains reluctant to join major regional trade deals. However, the government seeks to hold talks with members of the OECD to strengthen trade links.
2022-24: Full capital-account convertibility remains off the policy agenda.
Taxes 2020-21: Rationalisation of the goods and services tax (GST) continues, resulting in a reduction in the number of tax bands. Tax breaks and rebates are made available to businesses and individuals affected by the coronavirus (Covid-19) outbreak.
2022-24: Alcohol and petroleum products remain outside the scope of the GST.
Financing 2020-21: Bank lending growth will slow amid a decline in creditworthiness among defaulting borrowers, raising average loan rates and financing costs
2022-24: Private-sector banks account for a rising share of total lending, while bad debt issues persist in public-sector banks. Major consolidation and privatisations among the public-sector banks will continue.
The labour market 2020-21: Unemployment is high amid containment measures. Wage growth decelerates.
2022-24: Some labour reforms make headway at state level. However, reforms at the central government level remain stuck, owing to a lack of political consensus in support of the changes.
Infrastructure 2020-21: Containment measures slow down the construction of major infrastructure projects.
2022-24: As some projects near completion, India's infrastructure improves in terms of broadband connection speed, distribution, road and rail networks, ports and transport infrastructure, as well as electricity and office space supply.
Technological readiness 2020-21: Most technological innovation continues to be concentrated in a few clusters, such as Bangalore. Expenditure on research and development as a proportion of GDP remains low by Asian standards.
2022-24: The government makes efforts to digitise the delivery of public services, in an effort to cut corruption and promote the efficiency of "last-mile delivery". In this context, the Aadhar biometrics platform boosts government service delivery.

Background: India gained independence in 1947 after two centuries of British colonial rule. Partition at the same time created the state of Pakistan, with which India has fought three wars (two of them over the disputed territory of Kashmir). India is the second-most populous country in the world, with an estimated 1.37bn people in 2019, according to the UN. Its economy was the third-largest in the world in 2019 (measured in nominal US dollars at purchasing power parity exchange rates by the World Bank).
Political structure: India has been a democracy since independence. At federal level, the Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) holds a majority in the Lok Sabha (the lower house of parliament), although it governs in a broader coalition, the National Democratic Alliance. India follows the UK model of parliamentary government, with a prime minister as head of government. It has a president as the head of state. The country has a quasi-federal structure, with state governments having their own legislatures and enjoying a fair degree of freedom.
Policy issues: We expect the ruling BJP to undertake policy reforms once the coronavirus (Covid-19) pandemic passes. The government has already announced measures to privatise or merge public-sector units in many industries to promote competition. The government will also make modest progress on the liberalisation of regulatory requirements and foreign investment. However, the primary focus of the government will be on structural reform, particularly the contentious labour and land laws. We expect only incremental progress on these issues. The current administration has made headway in speeding up infrastructure projects, and this will also remain a priority in the next five years.
Taxation: The government will maintain efforts to broaden the tax base in 2020-24, including by further digitising tax departments. This, coupled with strong economic growth after 2020, will support a pick-up in tax collection. Despite some reforms, including a nationwide goods and services tax in 2017, India's tax system will remain highly complex.
Foreign trade: India's merchandise trade deficit narrowed to US$157.7bn in 2019, from US$186.7bn in 2018, while the surplus on the country's services account rose from US$80.8bn to US$84.2bn in the same period.

Outlook for 2020-24: Political stability The Economist Intelligence Unit expects that, with a majority in the Lok Sabha (the lower house of parliament) and an impending majority in the Rajya Sabha (the upper house), the ruling Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) will stay in power for its full term, which ends in 2024. The prime minister, Narendra Modi, who will remain the dominant figure in the government, is widely popular. Decision-making will remain centralised among the prime minister's office and key ministers.
The government is keen to facilitate an exit from the economically costly containment restrictions. However, the unabated and accelerated spread of the coronavirus (Covid-19) epidemic and the extensive economic damage caused by the restrictions highlight the risk of social unrest. The government's inability to provide large-scale income support will challenge the administration. We expect its reform agenda, especially the liberalisation of labour laws, to be another source of tension. However, these developments will not unseat the government; this is because of the support it enjoys from a large part of the citizenry and the lack of a strong opposition.
Over the medium term, protests by religious groups and communal clashes will continue to pose a threat to political stability. Large-scale protests tied to the Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA) were only cut short by social distancing measures introduced to slow the spread of the virus. In contrast to the country's current secular constitution, several far-right groups, including some affiliated with the BJP, have long been pushing for India to be recast as a Hindu nation-a view that puts them at odds with minority groups in the country, notably Muslims. The risk of social instability will be high in the latter part of the forecast period, particularly in the two-year period prior to the 2024 general election, if the ruling party moves ahead with its Hindutva (Hindu nationalist) agenda.
The security situation in the centrally administered territory of Jammu and Kashmir (J&K) will remain a concern throughout the forecast period. We expect security risks in the area to remain high. We believe that any attempt at protest is likely to face a heavy-handed response from the government, including the use of internet shutdowns, curfews and riot-control forces. The government's move has also increased the risk of terrorist attack by separatist forces in major Indian cities. A deadly border clash with Chinese troops in June 2020 will also affect political stability. Vocal domestic demands for a strong response pose political risks for Mr Modi, who will be reluctant to risk military escalation.
Outlook for 2020-24: Election watch The next general election is expected to be held around May 2024. The focus before then will be the state assembly elections. Historical precedent suggests that voters treat state and national elections differently, and that local issues tend to be more important in the former. We expect the BJP coalition to gain control of the state assembly in the upcoming Bihar election, to be held in October-November 2020, but only with the help of its coalition partner, Janata Dal (United).
The BJP and its allies form the largest grouping in the Rajya Sabha, although they command fewer than half of the seats. Nevertheless, we expect the BJP-led National Democratic Alliance (NDA) to win control of a majority in the upper house by end-2020 after elections in key seats in November. This will enable the alliance to pass legislation without opposition approval. However, it will struggle to win the two-thirds majority needed to make constitutional changes unchallenged.
Outlook for 2020-24: International relations Tensions with Pakistan have persisted amid the dispute over J&K. We expect relations to remain strained, but do not anticipate a complete breakdown of diplomatic ties. We believe that Pakistan's military will increase its support for militant groups in Indian-controlled Kashmir. This will raise the risk of terrorist attacks by non-state actors. Although small-scale military exchanges between the two countries are likely to occur in 2020-24, their nuclear arsenals will act as a powerful deterrent against full-scale conflict.
A deadly border clash between China and India in June has led to a substantial deterioration in bilateral relations. India retaliated economically against China, including by banning Chinese mobile apps and increasing non-tariff barriers on Chinese exports to India. We expect China to respond primarily with tit-for-tat tariff increases, rather than more detrimental export restrictions that could disrupt supply chains for Indian firms. We also expect further skirmishes tied to infrastructure development in border regions disputed by the two countries. However, large-scale military clashes are not within our core forecast.
Souring ties with China will encourage India to improve relations with the US, Japan and Australia, among other countries. India's foreign policy within South Asia will also focus on countering increasing Chinese influence in Nepal and Sri Lanka. India's relations with Bangladesh will remain cordial.
Outlook for 2020-24: Policy trends The government's majority in the lower house will give it flexibility in determining the economic policy agenda. Its key near-term priority will be controlling the coronavirus outbreak, to which India is particularly vulnerable, given its large population and weak healthcare infrastructure. The spread of the disease remains rampant; nevertheless, we do not expect the government to reintroduce a nationwide lockdown. Sporadic local containment measures will be adopted in states and cities in the coming months to ease pressure on the healthcare system in those areas.
We expect the government to take up policy reform after the crisis, as it looks to support growth. It plans to open up more sectors of the economy to private firms, by privatising or reducing the number of public-sector units. The administration will undertake piecemeal changes to legislation, such as a relaxation of regulatory requirements and a modest liberalisation of foreign direct investment rules. In terms of improving the business environment, one area of attention will be the liberalisation of contentious labour and land laws. Progress on this will be limited and the benefits will only be felt in the latter part of the forecast period.
The lockdown will amplify the mounting issue of non-performing loans (NPLs) in the banking and non-bank financial companies (NBFC) sector. The govern-ment will recapitalise some major banks and is also likely to arrange further consolidation of the sector, focusing on banks that are close to insolvency. However, these steps will prove inadequate to rejuvenate the financial system in 2021; lending to the private sector will fall well short of demand. Infrastructure projects-particularly pet projects of the Modi government, such as the National Infrastructure Pipeline-remain a priority, in response to the rapid pace of urbanisation and to boost the business environment. However, we expect a revival in infrastructure spending only from the fourth quarter of 2020, once the coronavirus outbreak has been brought under greater control.
Outlook for 2020-24: Fiscal policy The coronavirus outbreak will prompt a wider average budget deficit in 2020-24 compared with the annual average of 3.8% recorded in 2015-19. The government will temporarily suspend the Fiscal Responsibility and Budget Management Act to allow for more flexibility in supporting the economy. The containment measures have prompted an unbudgeted increase in social spending, especially through the National Rural Employment Guarantee Scheme, as well as an extension of existing support schemes for businesses.
The government announced an Rs20trn (US$268bn) package (equivalent to around 10% of GDP) to support the economy in May. However, this headline figure includes liquidity measures provided by the Reserve Bank of India (RBI, the central bank) and advances by banks under the government's measures. The actual amount of additional budgetary spending announced equates to around 1.4% of GDP. We expect the government to announce another fiscal package, worth 1-1.5% of GDP, in the fourth quarter of 2020, including an infrastructure development programme. In view of a fall in revenue and lower nominal GDP, the budget deficit is forecast to widen to the equivalent of 7.9% of GDP in 2020/21.
As the economy recovers, the government will look to consolidate the public finances gradually. This will narrow the budget deficit to the equivalent of 6.8% of GDP in 2021/22, and 5.9% of GDP in 2022/23. The authorities will look to deepen the tax base and increase (currently low) levels of tax compliance. However, the need to support welfare payments and infrastructure spending will maintain upward pressure on fiscal expenditure. We also expect subsidies to remain in place for small labour-intensive businesses, particularly those that are export-focused. This federal fiscal picture does not reflect the true level of the deficit. The deficits of many states and part of the expenditure of public-sector units represent implicit liabilities for the central government.
Outlook for 2020-24: Monetary policy The coronavirus epidemic will prompt further monetary policy loosening by the RBI. The central bank has lowered its policy repo rate by 115 basis points since May, to 4%, while also widening the monetary policy corridor by lowering the reverse repo rate (the "floor" of the corridor) by 155 basis points, to 3.35%. With inflationary pressure expected to moderate and economic growth at a far slower pace, we expect a further 50-basis-point reduction in the policy repo rate over the remainder of 2020. We also expect the further adoption of unconventional policy instruments, which will include more long-term refinancing operations.
Monetary policy will aim to support businesses. However, the outcome may be far from satisfactory, as monetary policy transmission is not smooth. While lending from the banking sector to micro, small and medium-sized enterprises will improve in 2020, as the government has provided a guarantee for those loans, banks will be reluctant to lend to other parts of the economy in the medium term, given increased risk. The level of non-performing assets in the financial sector is alarming, and the coronavirus outbreak will only exacerbate the issue, with more firms forced out of business. Policy support from the central bank and the government will be inadequate to support the recovery of the banking sector after the pandemic.
The RBI has maintained inflation-targeting as the cornerstone of its monetary policy framework. It seeks to contain consumer price inflation within a range of 2-6% and close to a target of 4%. However, strong political pressure on the RBI-which has forced out two hawkish heads of the bank under BJP rule-has complicated the achievement of these objectives.
Outlook for 2020-24: Economic growth We expect real GDP to contract by 8.5% in 2020/21-the sharpest annual decline in economic activity since India's independence in 1947. This is primarily the result of a 23.9% year-on-year contraction in April-June (the first quarter of the fiscal year), reflecting the impact of India's stringent lockdown measures. The economy will continue to contract year on year in the second and third quarters as the administration is unable to control the spread of the virus and intermittent local lockdown measures are put in place. We do not expect the economy to register growth on an annual basis in the fourth quarter of 2020/21, as job losses, business closures and social distancing measures depress activity. Sectors such as travel, hospitality and tourism will be the most affected.
On a GDP expenditure basis, we expect private consumption to contract sharply in 2020/21, as people's economic activities are constrained during lockdown and as consumption remains low, even after the restrictions are lifted. Investment spending is also expected to decline steeply as firms postpone activity amid high uncertainty. We also expect increased loan liabilities to be taken up by corporates and banks to further discourage new investment.
We have moderated our growth forecast for 2021/22 to 6.7%, from 9.1% previously. Our reassessment of the speed of the recovery in the financial sector suggests that rising NPLs will have a negative effect on banks' balance sheets. A combination of pre-existing credit strain among NBFCs and a marked deterioration in firms' creditworthiness will restrain the pace of recovery and limit investment and consumption. This trend will continue to weigh on growth in the medium term: we expect economic growth in 2022/23-2024/25 to average only 5.3% a year-slower than the annual average of 6.7% in 2015-19. Incremental progress on structural reform will provide some support for growth in the latter part of the forecast period.
Outlook for 2020-24: Inflation We expect consumer prices to increase by an average of 5.2% in 2020 as a whole. While food price inflation has remained elevated during the lockdown, we expect it to moderate once supply-side constraints ease towards the beginning of the fourth quarter. Non-food inflation will continue to lag behind food inflation, helping to prevent a rapid pick-up in the overall consumer price index. Our forecast assumes a normal monsoon this year (and in every year of the outlook period).
Relatively subdued inflationary pressures in 2021 will afford the RBI scope to keep its policy rate unchanged in that year as it continues to support the economy. The slowing investment resulting from the gradual tightening of the monetary policy stance in 2022 will offset the inflationary impact of strengthening oil prices. The central bank will accord higher priority to containing inflationary pressures towards the end of the forecast period; consumer price inflation is expected to average 4.4% in 2024.
Low oil prices and reduced domestic demand will generate producer price deflation of 0.3% in 2020. As prices for oil and other commodities strengthen, producer price inflation will firm to an annual average of 3.6% in 2021-24.
Outlook for 2020-24: Exchange rates The RBI's adoption of a fairly aggressive loosening stance in 2020, along with a sharp contraction in economic activity, will weigh on the exchange rate. We forecast that the rupee will depreciate by 6% on a nominal annual average basis in 2020, to Rs74.5:US$1, as the domestic economic situation worsens. While a current-account surplus (induced by a sharp fall in imports) will provide some support for the currency, the central bank's efforts to build up foreign-exchange reserves will more than offset it.
In 2021 we expect the rupee to appreciate slightly, to an average of Rs74:US$1, as foreign investment returns. The rupee will depreciate in 2022-24 amid rising oil prices and a persistent current-account deficit.
Outlook for 2020-24: External sector Lower oil prices and weak domestic demand will contribute to India registering a current-account surplus equivalent to 0.9% of GDP in 2020-the first since 2004. The contraction in merchandise imports is expected to be sharper than that in exports because of the rampant local spread of the virus, leading to weak consumption. However, merchandise imports are expected to rebound in 2021 amid a pick-up in domestic demand, returning the current account to a deficit.
Increased competition from other countries and changing industrial trends will weigh on the pace of growth in India's main service export sectors, particularly business-process outsourcing and information technology. Nevertheless, the services balance will remain in surplus throughout the forecast period, making a positive contribution to the current account. Owing to the large shortfall on merchandise trade, however, the current account will remain in deficit from 2021, averaging the equivalent of 1.2% of GDP in the remainder of the forecast period.
Significant foreign investment into Reliance Jio, a telecommunications operator, will support inward portfolio investment in 2020. However, investment in the overall economy will be depressed in 2020-21. Inward investment will pick up from 2022 as the expanding economy provides opportunities for businesses.

Data sources and definitions The sources for global and domestic data refer to historical data. The source for all forecast data, unless otherwise stated, is The Economist Intelligence Unit
Global data US & OECD GDP growth: OECD
World trade growth: Economist Intelligence Unit aggregate
US & OECD inflation: OECD
Oil prices: dated Brent Blend
Domestic data GDP: Central Statistics Office; all national-accounts data are for fiscal years beginning April 1st of year shown
Population: IMF, IFS
Public finance: World Bank, India CEM, unless revised by the GOI's annual budget papers
Oil production: Oil & Gas Journal; Ministry of Petroleum and Natural Gas
Inflation, exchange rates and money supply: IMF, IFS; Centre for Monitoring Indian Economy, MRIE; RBI, WSS
Yield on 91-day Treasury bills: World Bank, India CEM, unless revised by Centre for Monitoring Indian Economy, MRIE
Short-term benchmark interest rate: World Bank, India CEM; IDBI prime lending rate
Direction of trade: GOI, Economic Survey (annual)
Composition of trade and the current account: World Bank, India CEM, unless revised by Centre for Monitoring Indian Economy, MRIE or RBI, Annual Report
Foreign direct investment (FDI): IMF, IFS; UNCTAD, World Investment Report; includes reinvested profits
Foreign debt: World Bank, International Debt Statistics
Abbreviations CEM: Country Economic Memorandum
GOI: Government of India
IDBI: Industrial Development Bank of India
IFS: International Financial Statistics
MRIE: Monthly Review of the Indian Economy
RBI: Reserve Bank of India
WSS: Weekly Statistical Supplement

Full text: - Despite Venezuela's socioeconomic collapse and a public health crisis triggered by the spread of the coronavirus (Covid-19), The Economist Intelligence Unit expects the civic-military regime led by Nicolás Maduro of the Partido Socialista Unido de Venezuela to retain power throughout the 2020-24 forecast period. Mr Maduro's position will be supported primarily by his grip over a complex security apparatus and the opposition's lack of de facto power. On this basis, we expect continued deterioration of the economy, sustained outward migration, and a poorer and more violent Venezuela. Despite US sanctions (and their impact on oil production), the Maduro regime has managed internal dissent through a patronage system that rewards loyalty, as well as through its strict control over the security forces.
- The scale of the socioeconomic collapse and the elevated level of political instability will ensure that the Maduro regime continues to be challenged both economically and politically. Low international crude prices, combined with US sanctions on the regime, mean that Venezuela is struggling to place its oil exports abroad. We therefore forecast domestic crude production to average below 400,000 barrels/day in the coming months. Moreover, given that it will lose control of the legislature in 2021, the opposition will be under strong pressure this year to step up its efforts to oust the regime. Mr Maduro will continue to face challenges to maintain the current patronage system and remain in control.
- De facto dollarisation of the economy is expanding. Concurrently, the government has taken measures that have allowed the official exchange rate to float. These measures have so far aided price stability and therefore increase the availability of some basic goods. However, the measures are not a product of economic orthodoxy, but of policy decisions to ensure the regime's survival. We do not expect to see the comprehensive economic and institutional reforms that will be required to resolve the economic crisis within the forecast period.

- Venezuela is ranked 82nd of 82 countries in the global business environment rankings for 2020-24, having been in 80th place in the 2015-19 historical period, as the economic crisis deepens despite minor improvements. Reforms to institutions, economic policy and the business environment are unlikely.

Country forecast overview: Venezuela's business environment at a glance Policy towards private enterprise and competition 2020-21: Expansion of interventionist measures, including price controls. Corruption and selective application of regulations remain common and continue to undermine free competition.
2022-24: Contract rights remain weak, and red tape and ad hoc interventionism continue.
Policy towards foreign investment 2020-21: Most attempts to attract investment prove unsuccessful, owing to political and economic instability.
2022-24: Actual investment flows remain low amid ongoing economic volatility. Intellectual property protection and private property rights deteriorate.
Foreign trade and exchange controls 2020-21: Currency controls are weakened, but access to foreign currency remains limited.
2022-24: Efforts to remove trade and capital controls are taken on a gradual basis, and de facto dollarisation advances. Domestic supply of foreign currency improves as oil prices rise, albeit slowly.
Taxes 2020-21: Risk of further unrest and political instability reduces probability of tax increases, despite fiscal deficits. Severity of economic crisis precludes major rise in public spending.
2022-24: Tax system remains complex and unwieldy, but risk of discriminatory, ad hoc tax measures declines.
Financing 2020-21: Inflation remains high and concerns surrounding economic instability restrict financing to only short term.
2022-24: Economic adjustments take time to feed through to solid, sustainable growth in credit to private sector and development of capital markets. Long-term finance remains in short supply.
Labour market 2020-21: Labour laws add substantially to non-wage costs. Past emigration of skilled labour aggravates skills shortages.
2022-24: Labour-market rigidities persist, despite some increase in flexibility of hiring and firing practices.
Infrastructure 2020-21: Underinvestment in water network and electricity grid leads to continued rationing and unpredictable blackouts.
2022-24: Investors remain highly cautious of committing to long-term capital projects. Infrastructure deteriorates even further.
Technological readiness 2020-21: E-government services remain almost non-existent. Deteriorating infrastructure limits adoption of new technologies. Telecommunications sector is opened to foreign investment, but with little interest.
2022-24: Limited regulatory capacity and years of underinvestment continue to restrict internet and mobile coverage.

Background: From 1958 until the mid-1990s two parties-Acción Democrática and the Comité de Organización Política Electoral Independiente-alternated in power. Frequent economic crises and endemic corruption eventually led to a collapse in support for both parties and culminated in the 1998 election of Hugo Chávez, a former lieutenant-colonel and leader of a failed coup in 1992. Mr Chávez's policy programme exacerbated political polarisation, but several attempts to remove him from power before his death in March 2013 proved unsuccessful. His chosen successor, Nicolás Maduro, has seen his own popularity plummet as his mismanagement of a drop in oil prices, combined with strict sanctions on trade from the US, has plunged the country into a severe economic depression.
Political structure: Although Venezuela is nominally a federal republic with separation of powers, the ruling Partido Socialista Unido de Venezuela (PSUV) has systematically eroded institutions. In December 2015 the opposition coalition, Mesa de la Unidad Democrática, won control of the unicameral National Assembly (AN). In January 2016 the politicised Supreme Court declared the legislature to be in contempt of court, blocking all subsequent legislation. Since August 2017 a PSUV-only Constituent Assembly has granted itself a remit over all legislative matters, becoming the country's de facto legislature and sidelining the AN.
Policy issues: The most pressing policy issue is the need to stabilise an economy that remains mired in a long-standing economic crisis. The monetisation of vast public deficits has created an ever-increasing excess of domestic currency, triggering hyperinflation. Mismanagement of Petróleos de Venezuela (PDVSA, the state-owned oil company and originator of practically all foreign-currency inflows into the country) has resulted in a sharp contraction of oil production. This has restricted foreign-currency supply, giving way to currency controls, the rationing of imports, and the emergence of black markets for both foreign currency and basic goods. The scarcity of foreign exchange has also led to arrears on most of the external debt issued by sovereign and state-owned firms.
Taxation: The top corporate tax rate is 34% for non-oil companies and 50% for oil firms. The value-added tax (VAT) rate stands at 12%.
Foreign trade: The goods trade surplus fell to US$20.9bn in 2018 as the destruction of domestic supply led to increasing import dependence. The Economist Intelligence Unit estimates the 2018 current-account surplus to be 3.6% of GDP.

Outlook for 2020-24: Political stability The Economist Intelligence Unit considers that the coronavirus (Covid-19) outbreak and diminished oil rents-resulting from existing US sanctions and low international oil prices-present hefty challenges for the survival of the military regime led by Nicolás Maduro of the Partido Socialista Unido de Venezuela (PSUV). Owing to the bleak state of its healthcare system, Venezuela faces an uphill battle against the coronavirus, and there is a high risk that the ongoing socioeconomic crisis could evolve into a humanitarian calamity. Social unrest is prevalent; however, protests could intensify in the coming months owing to severe fuel shortages.
Despite these compounding social and economic shocks, we expect Mr Maduro to retain power throughout 2020, ruling over what is becoming a much less populous and much poorer country. Mr Maduro has two main factors working in his favour. First, the opposition led by the head of the National Assembly, Juan Guaidó, has lost the momentum that it held in 2019. Secondly, the regime retains strict control over the military, the police and paramilitary forces. Although the risks to our forecasts are very high, we assume that this control-together with the complexity of the security apparatus and the recurrent purges within it-will allow the regime to manage internal dissent.
Mr Maduro's recent actions show that he has the upper hand against the opposition. The new electoral council, inaugurated in June, was packed with Mr Maduro's allies, while opposition members loyal to the regime were appointed as heads of two major opposition parties-Primero Justicia and Voluntad Popular. These actions set the stage for rigged parliamentary elections in December, as opposition forces are now effectively disabled. The brazenness of these actions show that Mr Maduro is unperturbed by potential retaliation by the opposition and that political pressure against him is wavering.
Although it is not part of our baseline forecast, we recognise that there is a high risk of some sort of political transition. There are three main paths to this: military intervention, a negotiated transition or some sort of internal coup. We assess the prospect of military action by the US or Colombia as low, and we consider that a negotiated transition would also be difficult. In early March the US outlined a transition framework in which both Mr Maduro and Mr Guaidó would allow a new state council to be created and fresh elections to be held. However, the appointment of Maduro loyalists to the new electoral council demonstrated that this proposal has failed, as trust issues between the two sides are insurmountable.
We believe that the most likely scenario for regime change is an internal coup. The regime's main weakness is the fragility of its internal finances. Its patronage system is crucial for sustaining its security apparatus and resisting social unrest. Low international crude prices, US sanctions and the dampening effect of a global recession on workers' remittances will shrink US dollar inflows further. The regime will continue to benefit from funds from drug-trafficking and illegal mining activities, but a lack of hard currency could prove fatal to the patronage system and will test the regime's ability to maintain cohesion among its ranks. The regime's liquidity problems, and a rapidly worsening socioeconomic and humanitarian crisis, could prompt putsch attempts in the near term.
Outlook for 2020-24: Election watch Legislative elections will take place on December 6th, assuming that Mr Maduro clings to power and that the polls are not cancelled (Mr Maduro has hinted that they could be suspended as a result of the coronavirus pandemic). These elections would be neither free nor fair, and the opposition would lose control of the National Assembly. If the opposition were to secure some sort of political change in 2020, the interim government would pursue deep-seated reforms to the electoral authority and attempt to hold a vote within 12 months of its formation, although achieving this would be a major challenge.
Outlook for 2020-24: International relations Mr Guaidó has marshalled strong support from the international community, but efforts by most governments in Latin America to support him have reached an impasse. Mr Guaidó's most committed champion, the US, has instituted several rounds of crippling oil sanctions and has openly called for the Venezuelan military to accept Mr Guaidó in place of Mr Maduro. The US expects sanctions to put enough pressure on the regime's finances (and therefore on its patronage system) to force Mr Maduro to hold free and fair elections. The US also warned of additional sanctions in the near future; for example, it plans to impose sanctions on diesel imports as early as October. The US administration will remain hawkish in its approach to foreign policy, but we believe that a military intervention is unlikely, given the aversion of the US president, Donald Trump, to such adventurism. Nonetheless, we expect the US to further heighten diplomatic pressure before the next US general election and the next Venezuelan legislative elections, which will take place in November and December respectively. If tensions rise and political violence increases, the possibility of smaller-scale interventions cannot be discounted. Looking ahead, regardless of whether Mr Trump or his opponent, Joe Biden of the Democratic Party, wins the US election (our baseline forecast is for a Biden victory), we expect US sanctions to remain in place owing to strong bipartisan support. That said, efforts to reach a negotiated exit for Mr Maduro would increase under a Biden administration.
Mr Maduro's main global backers are Cuba, Russia, China and-more recently-Iran. Russia is helping Petróleos de Venezuela (PDVSA, the Venezuelan state-owned oil company) to circumvent US sanctions-in March the Venezuelan assets of Rosneft (a Russian energy firm) were transferred directly to Russia. Nevertheless, Russia and China seem unwilling to provide the financing-amounting to tens of billions of US dollars per year-required to stabilise the economy and secure PDVSA's long-term future. Mr Maduro has openly courted the two countries, but has had little success in securing finance for investment. If a transition from the regime were to come about, we believe that Russia and China would be willing to work with Mr Maduro's successor to protect their current investments. Iran recently sent 1.5m barrels of petrol to Venezuela in exchange for gold shipments and is helping to repair the Paraguaná oil refinery.
Outlook for 2020-24: Policy trends The Maduro regime will focus on weathering the fuel shortages and containing the public health crisis caused by the coronavirus outbreak. Despite community spread and an accelerating number of Covid-19 cases, Mr Maduro has eased nationwide quarantine measures to some degree. A "7/7" system is currently in place, whereby seven days of more flexible social distancing measures are followed by seven of tighter restrictions. Measures will remain in place over the short to medium term, as Venezuela's health system is simply unprepared to deal with the coronavirus outbreak. The country's medical infrastructure is poor and hospitals face significant shortages of water, soap, medicines and electricity.
Given its potential to ignite large protests, Mr Maduro has taken some steps to alleviate fuel scarcity. In May the regime announced a two-tiered petrol distribution system. Drivers will be subject to a monthly quota of subsidised petrol. When this has been reached, petrol will be available at internationally indexed prices. The quota system seeks to regularise black-market activity so that the regime (rather than a third party) benefits from the gains. Concurrently, the Maduro regime is seeking to switch on domestic gasoline production. On August 21st PDVSA repaired a naphtha reformer, which is now able to produce 17,000 barrels/day (b/d) of gasoline. However, these actions will only work to an extent, as arbitrage opportunities are still possible under the new subsidy system and the domestic gasoline production meets only a slim portion of local demand.
Based on our view that Mr Maduro will retain power throughout our 2020-24 forecast period, we do not expect to see the comprehensive economic and institutional reforms that are required to resolve the economic crisis. De facto dollarisation is expanding; although this was not a tacit goal for the regime, Mr Maduro now welcomes it. Other under-the-radar adjustments are possible in the coming years, as long as these benefit the regime's survival. Such efforts alone are unlikely to bring about economic stability, owing to the absence of a comprehensive microeconomic reform or improvements in the rule of law, and policy predictability will not be forthcoming under the current regime.
Outlook for 2020-24: Fiscal policy The authorities have not published complete data on fiscal accounts since 2011. We expect the non-financial public-sector deficit to narrow in 2020, and the public debt/GDP ratio to remain high in the coming years. The sovereign's default on most of its interest and principal repayments will curb government spending. The regime relies heavily on monetisation to fund its deficits, driving hyperinflation and the rationing of foreign currency. Money printing will continue to finance the government's deficits in 2020-24. However, in the medium term growing remittance inflows will partly offset the need to monetise budget deficits. We currently assume no debt restructuring in 2020-24. Venezuela's weak fiscal position is complicated by the existence of considerable off-balance-sheet debt financing-mainly PDVSA-issued debt and development funds from China-that understates the true size of total public liabilities.
All of the sovereign's outstanding global bonds are in arrears. However, bondholders are yet to go to the courts, perhaps waiting for news of policy shifts or a change in government. The key PDVSA 2020 bond, which was secured using 50.1% of the shares of Citgo (PDVSA's US subsidiary) as collateral, fell due at end-October 2019 and was not paid. A US court has ruled that PDVSA is an "alter ego" of the Venezuelan government; this will have far-reaching implications, as some international firms are seeking to seize shares of Citgo stock. However, the US considers Citgo to be under the purview of Mr Guaidó, thus currently shielding Citgo assets from seizure by creditors.
Outlook for 2020-24: Monetary policy The government's financing needs will force the Banco Central de Venezuela (BCV, the central bank) to ramp up money-printing in the short term. Growing dollarisation and a strong contraction in domestic demand slowed hyperinflationary pressures in 2019. However, we expect hyperinflation to return in the coming months, owing to monetisation of large fiscal deficits and severe goods shortages.
Overall, hyperinflation will continue until its underlying causes are addressed. Hyperinflation has quickened the pace of dollarisation of the economy (more than 60% of transactions are now thought to be conducted in US dollars). We believe that Venezuela is heading towards overall de facto dollarisation. Monthly inflation will rise again in the short term and will remain substantial. However, given the effect of dollarisation on price stability, we do not expect a return to the extremely high annual inflation rates of more than 1,000,000% experienced in 2018.
Outlook for 2020-24: Economic growth After an estimated contraction in real GDP of 36.2% in 2019 (and a cumulative contraction of almost 70% since 2013), we expect an additional decline of 30.3% in 2020. The contraction reflects plummeting oil exports and the adverse effects of the government's quarantine measures, which will further dent domestic demand. Fuel scarcity will also hit the non-oil economy indirectly, through a scarcity of inputs and hyperinflation. From a demand-side perspective, the GDP contraction will be driven by falling real incomes and continued mass emigration (which is fuelled by unemployment, violence and social instability).
Low crude prices and weak oil exports will put significant pressure on the country to slash crude production. Venezuela's average break-even price is about US$15-20/barrel. US sanctions on the regime raise the risks involved in dealing with Venezuela, forcing the country to offer a hefty discount on its crude. This means that, at current market prices, Venezuela is making only a limited profit (its oil basket traded at an estimated US$25/b by end-August). The current circumstances have inevitably led to production cuts; oil output fell to 339,000 b/d in July, according to OPEC, from 810,000 b/d in July 2019 and 1.3m b/d in the same month in 2018. We believe that average output will remain below 400,000 b/d over the coming months.
In 2021 we expect the economy to stabilise somewhat (contracting marginally), owing to a stabilisation of domestic demand as social distancing measures are lifted. In 2022 economic growth will return on the back of a surge in oil prices. Despite serious operational problems (such as difficulties in obtaining equipment for repairs or finding qualified staff) and a limited pool of suitable buyers of Venezuelan crude, oil output will recover somewhat in the medium term as producers become more accustomed to the new post-sanctions export markets. Furthermore, relative macroeconomic stability will allow the non-oil economy to recover marginally in the medium term. There are substantial risks to our forecasts, which assume that Mr Maduro will retain power throughout 2020-24. In the event of a transition, there would be upside risks to our medium-term baseline; the degree of improvement would depend on the characteristics of the transition and on the new government's macroeconomic programme.
Outlook for 2020-24: Inflation Severely reduced domestic supply, constraints on import capacity and the monetisation of large public deficits will continue to stoke hyperinflation this year. Dollarisation and the regime's heavy restrictions on credit helped to subdue hyperinflation in the second half of 2019. Consumer prices rose by 55.1% month on month in July after two months of relatively low inflation due to the subsiding effects of social distancing measures on demand-side inflationary pressures. However, as the economy reopens inflationary pressures will strengthen, owing to fuel scarcity, price controls and the ramping-up of government money-printing.
In the medium term inflation will remain high for as long as the Maduro regime is in power, given huge fundamental imbalances between supply and demand, and the need for the regime to monetise its fiscal deficits. Weather-related shocks are a perennial risk to the inflation outlook.
Outlook for 2020-24: Exchange rates Hyperinflation will sustain bolívar depreciation in 2020. Given incessant inflation and its effect on nominal values, we believe that another currency denomination (as in March 2018) or a new currency is a strong possibility, although the exact nature of such a move is hard to forecast. In mid-2019 the regime announced a loosening of currency controls. Although this was a positive move, significant barriers limit access to US dollars via formal means. We still believe that the government will maintain a number of indirect controls on the foreign-exchange market. In this environment, a black-market exchange-rate premium is inevitable. On August 25th the official exchange rate was BsS308,000:US$1, compared with a black-market rate of BsS320,000:US$1. The premium (currently 4%) is small by historical comparison.
Outlook for 2020-24: External sector Venezuela will post a small current-account deficit of 1.9% of GDP in 2020, owing to lower oil exports and limited remittance inflows resulting from the global recession. The BCV's official figures for 2017-18 show that Venezuela posted current-account surpluses in this period. In 2019 the collapse of goods export earnings (due to US sanctions on the oil trade) hit the trade balance hard. Nevertheless, based on the latest data, we estimate that the current account remained in surplus owing to growing inflows of workers' remittances and the non-payment of interest on bonded debt (saving in excess of US$5bn in 2019).
We expect the current account to return to surplus in the medium term, averaging 4.4% of GDP in 2022-24. Goods exports will recover as international oil prices increase and the country steps up trade with Asian markets. This recovery will be supported by continued weakness in domestic demand, rising remittances from abroad and the fact that the sovereign will remain in default throughout the forecast period.

Global data Oil prices: dated Brent

US 3-month commercial paper rate: IMF, IFS
US$ effective exchange rate: IMF, IFS; nominal weighted index
World trade growth: Economist Intelligence Unit aggregate
Domestic data Balance of payments, exchange and interest rates: IMF, IFS
Budget balance: non-financial public sector
Commercial banks' prime lending rate: average nominal interest rate charged on loans to agriculture
Deposit interest rate: average nominal interest rate on 90-day term deposits
Exchange rate: IMF, IFS; market rates expressed as BsS:US$
External debt; World Bank, International Debt Statistics
GDP: at constant 1997 prices, BCV
Inflation: BCV, consumer price index (1997=100) for the Caracas metropolitan area
Labour market statistics: derived from a series given in ILO, Yearbook of Labour Statistics
Oil production and export volumes: Bloomberg
Population: Centro Latinoamericano y Caribeño de Demografía (Celade, Latin American and Caribbean Demographic Centre)
Social indicators: World Bank, World Development Indicators
Stock of foreign investment: IMF, IFS; UNCTAD, World Investment Report

Full text: - The coronavirus (Covid-19) pandemic and the challenges of dealing with its severe economic and social effects mean that a general election in Italy before the end of the parliamentary term in 2023 is unlikely. The Economist Intelligence Unit expects the current government coalition dominated by the populist Movimento 5 Stelle (M5S) and the centre-left Partito Democratico (PD) to hold together for all or most of the parliamentary term. Given the fragility of the largely pro-European government, which is currently led by Giuseppe Conte, the prime minister, bouts of intense political instability are likely, potentially triggering cabinet reshuffles and variations in the composition of the wider coalition. Over the medium term we expect the pandemic to contribute to the reshaping of Italy's political landscape that began with the 2018 general election, deepening the divide between centre left and right, and consolidating the latter's popular support.

- Italy's business environment score remains broadly unchanged during the forecast period (2020-24), but the country falls by one place in the global ranking. The scores improve slightly for policy towards private enterprise and competition, foreign trade and exchange controls, taxes, financing, and the labour market, reflecting the impact of modest economic reforms taken by successive governments since late 2011. However, the scores for the macro-economic environment and market opportunities show more marked deteriorations, as we expect the coronavirus crisis to weigh heavily on economic growth, incomes and the public finances for several years at least.

- The near shutdown of the economy for two months and the wider demand-side effects of the pandemic will trigger a recession of 10.8% in 2020. The collapse of tourism, which contributes to 13% of GDP and 15% of total employment, weighs on the outlook. Real GDP growth will rebound in 2021, but a return to pre-crisis levels is unlikely before 2024. Government schemes will cushion the impact on the labour market to a certain extent, but will not prevent a surge in unemployment, which will hinder the recovery. The pandemic will lead to a substantial deterioration in Italy's public finances. We expect the budget deficit to reach 13% of GDP in 2020, and to narrow from 2021 onwards. Public debt will peak at 163% of GDP this year.

- The population increased at an annual average rate of 0.3% in 1999-2011. Since 2017 the population has begun to decline, falling from 60.7m to 60.6m in 2019, according to the UN's population estimates. We expect the population to continue falling slightly during the forecast period, to 60m in 2024, reflecting the natural decline of the Italian population and lower immigrant inflows.

- Italy is one of the largest and richest markets in Europe, with a population of about 6om. However, growth potential remains limited because the country is a mature consumer market with weak income and population growth prospects. Income levels differ greatly between the north and the south of Italy, with GDP per head in the south only about 46% of that in the north. Demographic trends will have an important impact on spending patterns, with population ageing driving healthcare expenditure.

From May 2019 The Economist Intelligence Unit's long-term growth forecasts have been revised to take into account the economic impact of climate change.

- Our baseline forecast is that Italy's weak demographic profile will act as a substantial brake on real GDP growth, which we expect to average just 0.3% per year in 2020-50 (the long-term forecast period). A more favourable political environment could produce better economic growth performance in the long term, but the chance of improvements in Italy's institutional framework being implemented in the short to medium term is low.

Background: Post-war Italy has been characterised by a weak political structure and, since the 1970s, a declining economic base. Between 1996 and 2011 Italy had a bipolar political system, dominated by a centre-right alliance and a centre-left coalition. Since 2011 the political landscape has become more fragmented, with the break-up of the centre right, the emergence of the anti-establishment Movimento 5 Stelle (M5S) and a recent splintering of the centre left. Following the 2018 general election M5S and hard-right Lega formed a government led by Giuseppe Conte, but it was highly unstable and undermined Italy's relations with the EU. In an agreement to avert a snap general election in late 2019 M5S and the pro-European centre-left Partito Democratico (PD) formed a new government also led by Mr Conte.
Political structure: Parliament, which comprises two houses with equal powers, is elected for a five-year term. In the event of a political crisis the president, who is elected by parliament for a seven-year term, decides whether to call an election or nominate a prime minister to try to form a government. The president also promulgates laws and may return a law to parliament for reconsideration, but has no power of veto. Executive power lies with the cabinet, which is nominated by the prime minister and approved by parliament. The prime minister cannot dismiss ministers without forming a new government. The legislative system remains unchanged following the rejection in the December 2016 referendum of a reform to reduce the powers of the Senate (the upper house). A new, predominantly proportional electoral system was adopted in October 2017.
Policy issues: The main issues are the management of, and attempts to reduce, Italy's large public debt (which stood at 134.8% of GDP in 2019), safeguarding the banking system and keeping Italy in the euro zone. In 2012 the government, led by Mario Monti, carried out a number of structural economic reforms to improve competitiveness. The process has since stalled. The M5S-Lega government loosened fiscal policy with tax cuts and income support for low earners, and reversed or diluted pension and labour reforms introduced during the euro zone crisis. The new M5S-PD government is forging a more constructive relationship with the EU, helping to reduce government borrowing costs.
Taxation: The top rate of personal income tax is 43%, and social security contributions are high, especially for employers. The corporation tax rate is 24%, reduced in 2017 from 27.5%, but additional regional and municipal taxes, including the regional business tax (IRAP), are levied to fund health services. The basic rate of IRAP is 3.9%. Income earned from most types of financial investment is taxed at 26%. The standard rate of value-added tax (VAT) is 22%.
Foreign trade: The value of exports of goods (fob) stood at US$510.9bn in 2019 and imports (fob) were worth US$447.1bn. In the same year the current account recorded a surplus of US$58.9bn, or 2.9% of GDP.

Political outlook: Political forces at a glance The March 2018 general election yielded a badly fragmented parliament. The centre-right coalition fell short of the roughly 40% of votes needed to win a majority under the most recent electoral law, the so-called Rosatellum 2, coming in at 37%. Within the coalition, the populist, anti-immigration Lega (17.4%) surpassed Silvio Berlusconi's Forza Italia (FI; 14%), which had previously been seen as the leading party on the right, and polled well ahead of the hard-right, post-fascist Fratelli d'Italia (FdI; 4.4%). The election also saw a surge in support for the populist, anti-establishment Movimento 5 Stelle (M5S), which won 32.7% of vote, making it by far the country's largest party. After three months of difficult coalition talks, M5S and the Lega agreed to form a coalition government under the leadership of a technocratic prime minister, Giuseppe Conte. Meanwhile the mainstream centre-left Partito Democratico (PD), under the leadership of Matteo Renzi, won just 18.9% of the vote, an all-time low, leading to Mr Renzi's resignation and the election of a new party leader, Nicola Zingaretti, in March 2019. The PD and its smaller coalition partners won a combined vote share of just 22.3%, and Liberi e Uguale (LeU)-a formation made up of primarily left-wing splinter parties that spun off from the PD in opposition to Mr Renzi's leadership-took 3.4% of the vote. In August 2019 the Lega, led by Matteo Salvini, withdrew from the coalition to try to engineer a snap general election in order to turn his surge in electoral support into seats in parliament, where the Lega is only the third-largest party, behind the M5S and the PD. To avert a snap election, the M5S and the PD, which used to be fierce political opponents, unexpectedly put aside their differences and agreed to form a new coalition government, still led by Mr Conte.
