Political outlook: Political stability Mr Conte presides over a fractious coalition. The centre-left PD and the populist M5S formed a new government in September 2019, after the previous coalition between the M5S and the right-wing Lega collapsed. The government relies on the support of two minor parties: the centrist Italia Viva (a splinter group of the PD) and the left-wing Liberi e Uguali.
The government is coming under pressure owing to its uncertain policy response to the coronavirus crisis, which is the result of institutional constraints, lack of fiscal space and political in-fighting within the governing coalition. Trust in the government has declined from a record approval rating of over 60% during the lockdown in April-May to just above 30% currently. Voters are drawing a distinction between the government's handling of the pandemic-supported by more than 70% of Italians-and its handling of the economic recovery, which is supported by 47%.
The Economist Intelligence Unit expects the M5S-PD coalition to put aside its inherent differences to keep the government in place for all or most of the parliamentary term, which expires in mid-2023. Failure to do so could undermine the effectiveness of the government's response to the pandemic and aggravate Italy's economic difficulties, not least through a spike in government borrowing costs that would be likely to ensue from a government crisis. Most importantly, all governing parties stand to lose from an early vote, making this scenario unlikely at the moment.
There are still considerable risks to the government's survival. The coalition is fragile, with a slim majority in the Senate (the upper house of parliament), and is vulnerable to defections, as happened in M5S in late 2019-early 2020. Over the medium term, an inevitable return to fiscal austerity after the unprecedented stimulus introduced to mitigate the economic effects of the pandemic is also likely to erode support for the government and fuel tensions within the coalition. Against this backdrop, the government is likely to undergo cabinet reshuffles and variations in the composition of the wider coalition. Such bouts of political instability are still likely to trigger speculation of an imminent election and related spikes in government borrowing costs.
Political outlook: Political and institutional effectiveness Italy is governed by weak, divided executives, generally comprising multiparty coalitions, in which small parties often wield disproportionate power over policy decisions. Under the bicameral parliamentary system, all bills have to be passed in the same form by both houses of parliament in order to be enacted, often resulting in delays and the dilution of measures. This is unlikely to change following the rejection in 2016 of the Renzi government's constitutional reform package, which sought to reduce drastically the legislative powers of the Senate and would have effectively made the parliament quasi-unicameral.
Efficiency may improve in the public administration, but not in the judiciary Red tape and Italy's inefficient judicial system are likely to continue to pose problems for businesses. Modest measures introduced in recent years to increase public-sector accountability and efficiency should help to gradually speed up some bureaucratic procedures, although given entrenched resistance to change within the public administration, the implementation of the reforms approved in 2015 has been slow. In July 2020 the M5S-PD government approved a package of measures (the so-called "simplification decree") aimed at cutting red tape. Attempts by previous governments to reduce bureaucratic procedures have been largely unsuccessful, and Italy still has among the highest levels of red tape in Europe.
A partial reform of the judicial system was undertaken in 2014-16. However, many of the problems facing Italy's judicial system have not been addressed, including a fee system for lawyers that acts as a disincentive to concluding cases swiftly, a lack of specialisation among judges and a highly fragmented court system. The average number of days to resolve a contractual dispute in Italy is more than double that in some other EU member states.
Corruption is still rife in business, judging by the number of corruption scandals revealed in recent years. A bill presented in March 2010 containing measures intended to combat corruption among public officials took almost three years to become law. Since then government action appears to have intensified. In June 2014 the powers of the anti-corruption authority were strengthened, and less than a year later parliament approved another anti-corruption law, including provisions eliminating the minimum threshold for the prosecution of accounting fraud and introducing harsher prison sentences for this offense, as well as for corruption of public officials, embezzlement and mafia association. The M5S-Lega government passed further anti-corruption legislation at end-2018, imposing harsher criminal penalties and public-office bans for graft, and from 2020 applying the statute of limitations only to first-instance trials so that fewer cases are dismissed owing to a lengthy appeals process.
Criminal organisations will continue to pose problems for businesses and deter investment, despite the authorities' efforts to combat extortion and usury, and the arrests of several mafia bosses in recent years.
Political outlook: Election watch The political landscape has changed dramatically since the March 2018 elections. Popular support for M5S has more than halved, from 33% to 16.6%, according to the latest available polls. In contrast, support for the Lega has surged from 17% to 25%, making it the most popular political party in Italy. Support for the PD has remained broadly stable, at about 20%, whereas support for the far-right FdI has more than tripled, from 4% to 14.5%. If elections were held today, a Lega-led right-wing coalition would gain a majority of seats in the parliament.
Under the current electoral law, 37% of the seats in the parliament are distributed with a first-past-the-post voting system and the remainder are distributed with a proportional system to all political parties that exceed a minimum threshold of 3% of votes. The government put forwards a draft bill to change the electoral law to a fully proportional system, raising the minimum threshold of votes to 5%. This proposal would undermine the chances of a right-wing coalition victory at the next election, and we expect it to be adopted before the next general election.
Political outlook: International relations Tensions within the euro zone have risen during the pandemic, and sharp divisions between the north and the south of Europe have re-emerged. On July 21st, after heated talks that lasted 90 hours, EU leaders agreed on a European economic recovery fund, which clears the way for joint debt issuance worth EUR750bn to be channelled to less-developed countries (in a European context) and those hardest hit by the pandemic. About EUR390bn is to be transferred via cash and the remainder through loans.
The deal is a landmark step for the bloc, as it establishes a precedent for the EU to issue debt to fund common needs. Germany's U-turn on joint debt issuance in May was crucial to the success of the fund. The exogenous nature of the coronavirus shock and its asymmetric impact was a powerful argument in support of the proposal. Nevertheless, concessions had to be made to the "frugal four" (Austria, Denmark, the Netherlands and Sweden), which were joined by Finland, to win their acceptance of the final package.
EU support is vital to mitigate financial stability risks. Italian sovereign bonds are a safe asset only if the European Central Bank (ECB) and the European Stability Mechanism (ESM) are willing to act as a lender of last resort for the government. Over the medium term, all existing facilities for providing financial assistance to governments will be conditional on compliance with EU fiscal rules. As the stance of the current government is pro-European and its policies are aligned with EU rules, we expect EU institutions to shield the Italian government from liquidity risks.

Italy's business environment score remains broadly unchanged during the forecast period (2020-24), but the country falls by one place in the global ranking. The scores improve slightly for policy towards private enterprise and competition, foreign trade and exchange controls, taxes, financing and the labour market, reflecting the impact of modest economic reforms taken by successive governments since late 2011. However, the scores for the macroeconomic environment and market opportunities show more marked deteriorations, as The Economist Intelligence Unit expects the coronavirus crisis to weigh heavily on economic growth, incomes and the public finances for several years at least.
Despite a modest improvement under the current government, Italy scores poorly for government effectiveness. Following the rejection of constitutional reforms in a referendum at end-2017, institutional reform is off the political agenda for the foreseeable future, although the government has pushed ahead with plans to reduce radically the number of members of parliament. Reforms in 2014-16 failed to resolve entrenched shortcomings in the judicial system. The severe recession triggered by the measures adopted to contain the coronavirus pandemic will make it more difficult to promote investment and employment, and reduce public debt. These issues, as well as repairing weaknesses in the banking sector, remain the biggest policy challenges facing the government in 2020-24. Italy's tax system remains a hindrance to businesses and foreign invest-ment, and evasion remains widespread, despite periodic efforts to clamp down on the phenomenon and improve compliance. Action to encourage bank mergers and support banks' efforts to reduce the level of non-performing loans (NPLs) on their balance sheets has made some progress, but the sector remains vulnerable.


Enlarge this image.
Business environment outlook: Italy's business environment at a glance Policy towards private enterprise and competition 2020-21: Major progress on reforms to improve competition unlikely under new administration led by Giuseppe Conte.
2022-24: Improvements in competition policy will depend on stabilisation of the political environment.
Policy towards foreign investment 2020-21: Modest reductions in red tape. Government imposes penalties on foreign firms that collect state incentives and then relocate production to non-EU countries within five years of the incentivised investment.
2022-24: Organised crime, legal complexity and shortcomings in judicial system remain deterrents.
Foreign trade and exchange controls 2020-21: Quotas and tariffs are in line with EU practice. The Conte government could oppose new EU trade deals. EU focuses on EU-UK trade deal in Brexit negotiations, further bilateral free-trade deals and responding to US tariffs.
2022-24: An EU-US agreement will probably remain elusive. The risk of a euro area break-up, which could lead to capital controls, is low.
Taxes 2020-21: Automatic rise in value-added tax (VAT) rate is averted in 2020, but the new Conte government abandons plans to complete the adoption of a two-rate "flat tax" owing to cost. Introduction of a "digital tax" on foreign multinational firms.
2022-24: Government seeks to implement a diluted corporate and income tax-reduction package.
Financing 2020-21: Bank mergers, recapitalisations and non-performing loan sales make further progress.
2022-24: Banking sector exposure to the Italian sovereign will persist. Mergers of smaller co-operative banks and possible foreign takeovers accelerate, as does the sale of securitised bad loans. Profitability and credit provision remain weak.
The labour market 2020-21: "Citizenship income" remains in place, but the dilution of pension reforms is partly reversed. Reversal of some aspects of 2014-15 labour market reforms in 2018 dampens employment growth.
2022-24: Decentralised private-sector productivity-related pay deals and changes to public-sector contracts face resistance.
Infrastructure 2020-21: Lack of fiscal space and bureaucratic obstacles constrain government plans for higher investment spending.
2022-24: Infrastructure still lags that of other euro area countries, despite some new investment.
Technological readiness 2020-21: Further digitalisation of public services. A preponderance of smaller and family-run firms, as well as high levels of corporate debt, keep research and development (R&D) spending low.
2022-24: Gradually improving economic prospects (as well as Brexit) encourage more information and communications technology graduates to seek work in Italy. Slight improvement in R&D and company-level technology investment.
Business environment outlook: Macroeconomic environment                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2015-19 2020-24 2015-19 2020-24 2015-19 2020-24
6.9 6.1 49 47 13 14
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
Our assessment of the macroeconomic environment focuses not on headline real GDP growth (measured in the market opportunities category), but on economic stability and the underlying policy framework, which influence business planning, hiring and investment. Italy's macroeconomic environment score deteriorates in the forecast period, causing its regional ranking to decline by one place. However, because of larger score falls in other countries Italy's global ranking improves by two places. Italy's biggest macroeconomic policy challenge remains reviving investment and economic growth, making it more socially inclusive, while also putting public debt on a sustainable downwards path. Italy's public debt and weak government effectiveness will continue to be a cause for concern for the core euro zone creditor countries, as well as being a risk to the stability of its financial sector.

- Despite some progress, economic reforms have generally been introduced with a lag relative to most other struggling euro zone economies, and implementation remains an issue. Further measures to reverse more than a decade of stagnant productivity growth are unlikely in the current political and economic environment. The containment measures adopted to slow the coronavirus epidemic will cause a severe recession in 2020 and a marked deterioration in Italy's public finances. Weak price growth will also complicate debt reduction as a share of GDP. Demand-side price pressures will remain subdued owing to low global energy prices, labour market slack, and modest wage growth. Low global energy prices and weak domestic demand will keep Italy's current account in surplus during the forecast period. Nevertheless, concerns remain over the erosion of the country's export competitiveness, stagnant productivity and escalating global trade tensions.

Business environment outlook: Policy towards private enterprise and competition                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2015-19 2020-24 2015-19 2020-24 2015-19 2020-24
5.8 6.0 46 42 18 17
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
Policy towards private enterprise and competition remains an area in which Italy scores poorly compared with its EU peers, reflecting weak implementation and enforcement of competition rules, and inadequate reforms to enhance the effectiveness and efficiency of the public administration and justice system. Generally, EU directives have been the main drivers of liberalisation in Italy, forcing successive governments (which, regardless of their political leaning, have not instinctively favoured competition) to open up markets in several sectors, notably telecommunications, energy and professional services. In its annual National Reform Programme for 2020 the government identifies service stations and fifth-generation (5G) mobile networks as being in particular need of liberalisation. The powers of the Italian Competition Authority (AGCM) were strengthened and its remit extended to cover the provision of public services in 2010, but political pressure has generally limited effectiveness. This is also true of other watchdogs, including the Commissione Nazionale per le Società e la Borsa (Consob), the public authority responsible for regulating the Italian securities market, and the telecoms watchdog, Autorità per le Garanzie nelle Comunicazioni (AGCOM).

- In early June 2020 the Movimento 5 Stelle (M5S)-Partito Democratico (PD) government introduced a decree law containing "urgent measures" aimed at simplifying administrative procedures, eliminating and speeding up bureaucratic obligations, digitalising the public administration, and supporting the green economy and business activity more generally. The immediate aim is to unlock funds to kickstart a range of public contracts, particularly in the construction sector, in the wake of the coronavirus lockdown. It remains to be seen whether the measures will have a noticeable impact. Past reforms aimed at cutting red tape and improving the efficiency of the public administration to boost the economy have had limited success owing to obstacles to implementation of the measures and the inadequate capacity of the public administration at national and local levels.

External constraints will continue to be the main drivers of liberalisation
- An EU directive aimed at empowering the competition authorities of member states to be more effective enforcers of competition rules and ensure the proper functioning of the internal market took effect in January 2019. Member states have until February 2021 to transpose the directive into national law. It will require several amendments to the AGCM's current legal framework but is expected to strengthen the Authority's independence from political interference.
- Weak contract enforcement, few convictions for white-collar crime, and notoriously long court case backlogs will remain a deterrent of foreign direct investment (FDI) and domestic business investment. Improvements introduced in 2014-17 include extended prison sentences for some white-collar crimes such as bribery, the establishment of support offices to reduce the backlog in Italy's Supreme Court and an extension of the statute of limitations for serious crimes. The M5S-PD government has proposed further changes to both the criminal and civil justice systems designed to improve efficiency and speed up court cases. However, political opposition and resistance from the judiciary remain strong, which will hamper implementation.

Further privatisation of major state-controlled companies is unlikely
- The privatisation plan that was re-launched in mid-2015 to highlight Italy's openness to foreign investment and reduce the level of public debt made little progress before the 2018 general election and is unlikely to be revived under the M5S-PD government. Both parties have vigorously opposed the sale of state assets in the past. This means that the planned public offering of the state's remaining 30% stake in the national post office and financial services group, Poste Italiane, and the mooted sale of a 40% stake in Ferrovie dello Stato, Italy's state-owned railway utility group, are unlikely to happen.
- The Cassa Depositi e Prestiti Spa (CDP)-the state-owned development bank-already has sizeable stakes in state-controlled firms, such as the energy conglomerates, Eni and Enel, Italy's electricity transmission company, Terna, and the shipbuilder Fincantieri. We expect the CDP's role in the economy to expand further as it provides support for businesses struggling in the recession triggered by the coronavirus pandemic.

Business environment outlook: Policy towards foreign investment                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2015-19 2020-24 2015-19 2020-24 2015-19 2020-24
6.9 6.9 39 38 16 16
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
The positive impact of economic reforms will only be felt incrementally FDI inflows into Italy have generally been low compared with other similarly sized countries, including those such as France that have traditionally been seen as no more open than Italy. The main deterrents to FDI in Italy relate to complex bureaucratic and legal procedures, barriers to entry in areas of the services sector, inadequate infrastructure, high levels of taxation and energy costs, and labour market rigidities. Under past governments labour market reforms, modest business tax cuts and streamlining of Italy's complex tax system have begun to address some of these issues. However, given the Italian economy's long-standing structural deficiencies and the likelihood that the impact of recent reforms will be felt only incrementally, inward FDI in Italy will continue to lag that in other large EU member states. In March 2019 Italy became the first G7 country to sign a Memorandum of Understanding to participate in the Belt and Road Initiative-China's flagship global infrastructure integration plan. Chinese investors signed 29 separate deals for projects worth a total of EUR2.5bn, including investment in Italy's port infrastructure in Trieste, Genoa, and Palermo, which could give Chinese firms faster access to Europe. However, hardening sentiment at the EU level towards foreign takeovers and non-EU inward FDI-with a particular focus on inflows from China-has resulted in a steady tightening of regional investment screening provisions since 2017. The economic fallout from the pandemic is likely to spur increased scrutiny at the EU level, with Italy having extended domestic restrictions on acquisitions to cover banks, insurers, healthcare and energy.

- Judicial reforms should gradually improve contract enforcement, with signs that those introduced in 2014-17 are already reducing civil case backlogs. Although less ambitious than hoped for, anti-corruption legislation introduced since 2013 represents a further sign of intent to improve the operating environ-ment for domestic and overseas investors. Legislation passed in 2015 and banks' progress in recent years in reducing NPLs should encourage further financial sector consolidation, which could eventually attract FDI into the banking sector, although progress is likely to be slow owing to political resistance.

Foreign takeovers, especially of luxury goods brands, are likely to continue
- The 2011-14 economic downturn hit corporate balance sheets and Italian firms' ability to raise capital. As a result, foreign companies acquired or merged with a rising number of internationally renowned Italian corporate brands, particularly in the luxury and consumer goods sectors, such as Bulgari, Valentino, Loro Piana and Luxottica. The coronavirus-induced recession is likely to weigh heavily on firms' balance sheets and equity valuations, so there is likely to be renewed foreign interest in acquisitions of Italian companies.

Business environment outlook: Foreign trade and exchange controls                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2015-19 2020-24 2015-19 2020-24 2015-19 2020-24
8.7 9.1 28 10 14 4
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
Italy's score in this category improves slightly in the forecast period, leading to large improvements in its global and regional ranking, owing to deteriorations or stagnation elsewhere. Italy's foreign trade regime is largely defined by its EU membership. Freedom of movement of goods, services, capital and persons exists within the bloc and we do not expect any exchange controls. However, there is a risk of further temporary border closures and travel restrictions within the Schengen area in the case of a second wave of coronavirus infections across Europe. No tariffs or quotas are permitted within the EU, most non-tariff restrictions have been abolished and administrative costs related to cross-border trade are low. Bilateral trade disputes between EU countries are resolved by the European Commission or, in extreme cases, the European Court of Justice (ECJ), the jurisprudence of which has played a major role in developing the single market. Compliance with judicial or other rulings within the EU is higher than in other regional trading blocs or the World Trade Organisation (WTO). Trade with Norway, Iceland, Liechtenstein and Switzerland is unrestricted under the European Free-Trade Association (EFTA). The EU also has a customs union with Turkey and a range of bilateral agreements with Switzerland. All of these arrangements exclude agriculture. Trade with other non-EU countries is mostly subject to moderate customs duties, with bilateral and regional agreements providing for lower or zero tariffs, as well as co-operation on non-tariff barriers.
The EU will focus on bilateral trade deals
- Amid a fraying multilateral trade system and opposition in many countries (notably the US) to further trade liberalisation, the EU's focus will remain on bilateral trade deals. However, progress will be constrained by a weakened and more volatile global trading environment over the forecast period. The global recession triggered by the coronavirus pandemic in 2020 is likely to exacerbate many existing geopolitical trends, such as increasing US-China frictions, a rise in nationalist anti-globalist policies and the shift in the economic balance of power from West to East. This implies an increasing risk of a rise in EU-US trade tensions and a more challenging backdrop in which to manage EU-China relations. Over the medium term these pressures could encourage increased trade diversification amid increased recognition of the risks of supply-chain overreliance on a single market (such as China).

Trade deals between the EU and other trade blocs will be implemented gradually
- In recent years the EU has finalised free-trade agreements (FTAs) with Canada, Singapore, Vietnam and Japan, upgraded its FTA with Mexico and launched trade talks with Indonesia, Australia and New Zealand. In mid-2019 the EU and Mercosur (the South American trading bloc comprising Argentina, Brazil, Paraguay and Uruguay) reached an agreement in principle to create the world's largest free-trade market of almost 800m people, after 20 years of talks. Phased-in measures will aim to eliminate about 90% of tariffs and provide greater access to agricultural and services markets, and to public procurement contracts, from 2021 at the earliest. However, the deal needs to be ratified in national parliaments (which will be a politically complex process, given opposition in some EU member states).

The impact of a "hard Brexit" on Italy is likely to be only moderate
- The UK officially left the EU at end-January 2020 and the increasing possibility of the transition period ending with no deal in December will put a further dampener on the near-term trade outlook in Europe. Negotiation of a substantive EU-UK free-trade deal by end-2020 was ambitious prior to the coronavirus outbreak, and such an outcome is now highly unlikely, especially given the UK government's strong ideological stance over Brexit. The negative impact of a "hard Brexit" will primarily be felt in the UK, but an increase in tariffs and non-tariff barriers to trade will also inflict damage on its trading partners in Europe. Italy's direct exposure through trade and investment links is relatively limited compared with some other EU countries. However, the UK is Italy's fifth-largest export market, accounting for 5% of the total value of Italian goods exports.

Business environment outlook: Taxes                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2015-19 2020-24 2015-19 2020-24 2015-19 2020-24
4.3 4.8 80 79 18 18
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
Italy's tax system remains highly complex, so compliance is costly Italy's score for taxation improves in the forecast period, but the country ranks third from last in our global ranking and bottom in our regional ranking in 2020-24. Notwithstanding some streamlining under previous governments, the tax system remains complex, making compliance costly and time consuming for private-sector companies. Also, despite some modest tax cuts since 2014 and measures such as tax payment deferrals during the coronavirus crisis, the tax burden will remain high and is unlikely to decline much owing to Italy's high public debt and EU sovereign debt reduction requirements. Tax policy will remain uncertain, as the M5S-PD government plans to introduce further changes in 2021, the nature of which is as yet unclear.

- According to Istat (the national statistics office), total tax revenue/GDP (including social security contributions) stood at 42.4% in 2019-slightly higher than in 2018, but broadly in line with the euro zone average (41.7% in 2018, latest data). According to Eurostat data, Italy has the third-highest implicit tax rate on labour in the EU (aggregate tax revenue from labour as a percentage of the potential tax base), after Slovakia and Greece. This was 42.7% in 2018 (latest available data), down from a high of 44.2% in 2013, but 4.5 percentage points above the euro zone average. At 15.7% in 2018, Italy's implicit tax rate on consumption was one of the lowest in the EU, highlighting that there is scope to shift taxation towards consumption and away from labour.

Despite promises to reduce labour taxes, they will remain high
- Italy's standard rate of corporate tax is 24%, after a cut of 3.5 percentage points in 2017. In addition to a corporate tax rate, businesses also pay a regional business tax (IRAP), which is levied at a standard rate of 3.9% (and slightly higher than this for most financial institutions). However, the central government can raise the rate as high as 4.4% in regions running budget deficits. Regions and municipalities also apply personal income surtaxes at varying rates to offset the impact of cuts in transfers from the central government, which have been an almost constant feature of budget adjustments in recent years. Companies pay social security contributions at a high rate, by international comparison, of 30% (9.5% for employees). These are unlikely to be reduced significantly unless pension spending, which amounts to about 15% of GDP (one of the highest rates in Europe), is significantly reduced. Currently the marginal personal income tax rate is 43% on gross annual incomes of more than EUR75,000.
- Some progress has been made in reducing tax evasion and avoidance in Italy since the 2013 crisis, but it remains widespread, encouraged in the past by frequent tax amnesties, the limited number and scope of inspections, and weak political will to close loopholes in tax laws. Governments have sought to encourage the use of electronic payments rather than cash, but their approach has been inconsistent, with stipulated limits on the maximum payments you can make in cash undergoing frequent changes. The M5S-Lega government raised the limit from EUR1,000 to EUR3,000 in 2019 and indicated that it wanted to abolish the limit altogether. The M5S-PD government has recently lowered it to EUR2,000, effective from July 1st 2020.

Business environment outlook: Financing                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2015-19 2020-24 2015-19 2020-24 2015-19 2020-24
6.6 7.0 33 28 14 14
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
Fragmentation remains one of the main weaknesses of the banking sector Italy's score and global ranking improve in the forecast period, reflecting the impact of a range of measures adopted by recent governments to encourage consolidation in the banking sector, support recapitalisation and tackle the issue of high NPLs. Nevertheless, the country still ranks below most other developed countries, which largely reflects delays in introducing reforms to address the Italian banking sector's weaknesses after the 2008-09 global crisis. The sector's main shortcomings are fragmentation, with few large banks and many small and medium-sized lenders; high operating costs, because of excessive branch networks and personnel costs; low profitability; uncertainty about the quality of supervision; and heavy exposure to the sovereign, which leaves them vulnerable when concerns about government-debt sustainability increase. NPLs have declined considerably in recent years, but are still high, at 6.7% of total credit as at end-2019. This is well down from 16.9% in the third quarter of 2015, but more than double the EU average of 2.7%. Much of the decline is the result of large NPL securitisation operations by a few major Italian banks. The reduction of the high levels of NPLs on the balance sheets of Italy's smaller banks has made slower progress. Perhaps with a view to supporting these banks' efforts, the government has extended the system of guarantees (Garanzia sulle cartolarizzazioni delle sofferenze, or GACS) until May 2021. Progress towards consolidation in the sector has been slow, but the takeover bid launched in February 2020 by Intesa Sanpaolo, Italy's second largest bank, for UBI Banca, the sixth largest, suggests that a new wave of bank mergers and acquisitions is likely during the forecast period. The stress tests carried out by the European Banking Authority on Italy's four major banks (Intesa Sanpaolo, UniCredit, Banco Bpm and UBI Banca) in 2018 highlighted the improved health of Italy's banks compared with the EBA's stress tests in 2016. The next round of EU-wide stress tests due in 2020 has been pushed back to 2021 to allow banks to focus on their response to the coronavirus outbreak.

- The resilience of the financial sector will be severely tested by the fallout from the coronavirus pandemic. An array of policy support by the ECB, as well as domestic stimulus measures by the government and the Bank of Italy (the national central bank) will help to bolster liquidity and hold down banks' funding costs. However, a slump in economic output, weaker demand for credit, an increase in loan losses amid higher unemployment and business failures, a period of increased global financial market volatility and a continuing squeeze on profitability from record-low interest rates will put pressure on lenders' balance sheets, potentially exposing areas of weakness and reducing their capacity to provide credit as the economy gradually recovers. Italy's large number of small and medium-sized enterprises will continue to rely largely on bank borrowing for financing.

Business environment outlook: The labour market                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2015-19 2020-24 2015-19 2020-24 2015-19 2020-24
5.4 5.5 61 60 18 18
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
Recent reforms will reduce long-standing rigidities only gradually Italy's global ranking improves by one place in the forecast period, but the labour market category remains an area in which Italy performs poorly, especially compared with its EU peers. The Jobs Act legislative package that was passed in 2014-15 was a welcome development, but because the main reforms only applied to new private-sector hires, it will only reduce long-standing rigidities gradually. Having promised to dismantle the Jobs Act, the M5S-Lega government made limited changes to its so-called Dignity Decree. Restrictions on the use of easily terminated fixed-term contracts were tightened, allowing them to be used for up to 24 months, compared with 36 months under the Jobs Act. It also required firms to provide a justification for the use of such contracts, which is likely to increase litigation, and pay an additional levy of 1.9% (up from 1.4%) when they extend a fixed-term contract. However, the cap of 20% of the workforce on temporary contracts for an individual firm remained unchanged. The decree also raised the minimum compensation for unfair dismissal from four months' salary to six months' and from a maximum of 24 months' salary to 36.

- Other measures introduced under the Jobs Act that remain intact include reduced employment protection for long-term contracts and a much simplified contract system for labour market entrants by introducing a standard open-ended employment contract with gradually increasing protection. The Jobs Act also increased the availability of unemployment benefits and streamlined the use of wage guarantee funds for temporary lay-offs or firm restructuring. In 2018 the new national agency envisaged under the Jobs Act to co-ordinate the activities of all employment services providers became operative.
- The shortcomings that persist in the Italian labour market leave it particularly vulnerable to severe disruption as a result of the coronavirus pandemic. Given the scale of economic damage and the time-limited nature of state-backed schemes to protect jobs, the level of unemployment will rise sharply as support is withdrawn. The effects are likely to show significant variations across different sectors of the economy, with tourism, travel and hospitality among the worst hit. Low-skilled, low-paid and temporary contract workers are also likely to be the worst affected.
- In view of a protracted recession, delayed reforms and a weak economic recovery in 2014-19, Italy's headline jobless rate was relatively high even before the coronavirus pandemic hit. At 9.9% in 2019, the unemployment rate was well above the euro area average of 7.6%. Youth unemployment remains high, despite increased emigration of young people, especially graduates. At 29.2%, the youth unemployment rate is the third highest in the euro area, where the average rate is 15.8%. Despite some improvement in recent years, Italian labour market participation remains low, particularly among women and young people. According to Eurostat, Italy's employment rate was 59.1% in 2019, compared with the euro area average of 68.1%. The female employment rate was 50.1% (63.1% in the euro area).
- In 2018 Italy's three main trade union confederations and the business association, Confindustria, agreed a new national wage bargaining framework. It provides the basis for sectoral accords at the national level, as well as second-level plant or regional agreements linking wage increases to company performance and productivity gains. The M5S-Lega government made the introduction of a national minimum wage a policy priority, but failed to legislate for it before the government collapsed. The M5S's flagship citizenship income scheme, which aims to reduce poverty, was established in 2019. There are concerns that it will act as a disincentive for people out of work to search for employ-ment, resulting in higher structural unemployment.

Business environment outlook: Infrastructure                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2015-19 2020-24 2015-19 2020-24 2015-19 2020-24
6.3 6.5 32 40 15 17
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
Infrastructure quality in the south will continue to lag the rest of the country As reflected in the decline in Italy's regional and global rankings, the quality of Italy's infrastructure is set to remain below the average of other developed countries during the forecast period. A significant disparity between the north and the south of the country will also continue. Budgetary constraints have limited public investment in the past 25-30 years, and local interest groups have succeeded in blocking or delaying several major projects in the transport and energy sectors. Corruption investigations are another relatively common reason for delays. As illustrated by the collapse of the Morandi motorway bridge in Genoa in August 2018, maintenance of existing infrastructure also remains an issue. However, the reconstruction of the bridge in record time (it reopened in late July 2020) highlights that when there is political will to overcome bureaucratic obstacles there is ample scope for improvement in Italy's performance. Italy continues to lag most other developed countries in these markets, and the rollout of high-speed broadband services has been slow.

- Successive governments have promised to revive public capital spending by curbing current spending, freeing up funds earmarked for infrastructure projects and removing administrative obstacles that have held up investments. However, Italy's high debt servicing costs, combined with competing demands within coalition governments, make a radical change in policy direction unlikely. M5S has actively opposed the continued construction of the high-speed rail link through the Alps, from Turin in the north east of Italy to Lyon, a major city in south-eastern France, putting the completion of the project in doubt.

Fiscal consolidation will hold back public investment in infrastructure
- Limited domestic energy sources and popular opposition to the development of nuclear-power generation will continue to cause uncertainty about security and diversification of supply. Poor infrastructure in energy distribution is likely to keep upward pressure on costs. Investment will also continue to face strong local resistance.
- Building a high-speed broadband network across the country has been a policy priority of successive governments in Italy for several years. Progress has been extremely slow so far, but the current government's focus on the need to accelerate the digitalisation of the public administration may provide some much-needed momentum. Central to the government's plan has been Open Fiber, a wholesale broadband operator that is jointly owned by Enel and CDP. Open Fiber expects to build fibre-to-the-home (FTTH) networks in 270 cities in Italy by 2023. The government wants Open Fiber and Telecom Italia to merge their network assets to accelerate the roll-out of the network and avoid unnecessary duplication, but the talks between the two companies have been fractious, making the merger unlikely.

Business environment outlook: Technological readiness                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2015-19 2020-24 2015-19 2020-24 2015-19 2020-24
8.0 7.8 22 29 10 13
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
Italy's technology readiness score deteriorates in the forecast period compared with the historical period, thereby contributing to falls in both our global and regional rankings. E-commerce is growing rapidly (up by 18.4% year on year in value terms in 2019 and by 17.2% in the first quarter of 2020, according to Istat), reflecting improvements in the online environment. However, growth has been from a low base, with online purchases accounting for less than 10% of retail sales (compared with about 20% in the UK).

- Mobile-phone penetration is one of the highest in Europe, and take-up of new technologies such as smartphones and high-speed mobile contracts has usually been impressive. Spending on innovation, and research and development (R&D) is low for a developed economy, largely reflecting a preponderance of smaller and family-run firms, high levels of corporate debt, and limited public financial support. According to OECD data for 2018, total R&D spending (for both the public and private sectors) was the equivalent of 1.4% of GDP (compared with an OECD average of 2.4%).

Digitalisation of public services is a policy priority
- The implementation of the 2017-19 Plan for the Digital Transformation of the Public Administration has facilitated some progress. The M5S-PD government has made further progress a priority in its Action Plan 2025.
- We expect a slight improvement in R&D and firm-level technology investment, partly supported by the tax credit for R&D investment in effect since mid-2015, but growth will be from a low base. According to the European Patent Office, the number of patent applications in Europe originating in Italy increased by just 1.2% in 2019, compared with average growth in Europe of 4%, and only accounted for 2% of the total. Relative to population size, patent applications in Italy were low, at just 71 per million population, ranking Italy just 19th-well behind other major European economies such as Germany, France and the UK.

Economic forecast: Policy trends Italy has gone from the worst-hit country in Europe to a model of virus suppression. The government has been successful in keeping the spread of the virus under control. Although about 35,000 people have died since the start of the pandemic and Italy remains among the countries with the highest number of deaths per million people in the world (586), the number of active cases has decreased gradually to about 15,000-one of the lowest in Europe. According to a 14-day sum measure published by the European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control (ECDC), as at mid-August the number of cases per 100,000 people in Italy is 9.7. As a point of comparison, there are currently 140 cases per 100,000 people in Spain, 45.7 in France, 20.7 in the UK and 16.6 in Germany. The rate of positive tests has also remained low (below 3%) by international standards, meaning that Italy performs many tests relative to the size of the outbreak.
The economy has been reopening gradually under new safety rules since May 4th. Following one of the most stringent lockdowns in Europe in March-May (which comprised the shutdown of all commercial activities for eight weeks and factories for two), manufacturing and construction reopened on May 4th. Retail shops, restaurants, cafés and hairdressers opened on May 18th, followed by sports facilities on May 25th, and cinemas and theatres on June 15th. On June 3rd the government lifted restrictions on freedom of movement between regions and on tourism from other EU member states and the UK. To prevent a spike in new infections, especially among young people, on August 16th the government re-imposed some restrictions for the first time since the end of the lockdown. Clubs will remain closed for three weeks and it is now compulsory to wear a mask outdoors between 6PM and 8AM.
In March the government adopted a major stimulus package ("Cura Italia") worth EUR25bn to boost healthcare capacity (EUR3.2bn); support the income of employees and self-employed individuals (EUR10.3bn); help businesses with tax deferrals and other measures (EUR6.4bn); and support credit provision (EUR5.1bn). A second package was adopted in April ("Liquidity Decree") to deploy state guarantees of up to EUR400bn (25% of GDP). A third package was adopted in May ("Relaunch Decree") to provide an additional EUR55bn to boost household incomes (EUR14.5bn), further strengthen the national healthcare system (EUR3.3bn), and support businesses with subsidies and tax deferrals (EUR16bn). In early August the government adopted a new EUR25bn package to extend income support for households and provide further funding for temporary unemploy-ment schemes until year-end. Other important measures include the extension of the moratorium on debt repayments for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) and the deadline to pay back tax obligations.

The coronavirus outbreak will lead to a substantial deterioration in the public finances. We forecast that the budget deficit will expand to 13% of GDP in 2020, from 1.6% in 2019. About 6% of GDP of this deficit results from the measures taken by the government to stimulate the economy, and the remainder stems from the adverse impact of the recession. We forecast that the debt/GDP ratio will increase by about 27 percentage points this year, reaching over 163%.
Asset purchases from the European Central Bank (ECB) will continue to mitigate risks to financial stability, shielding Italy's sovereign debt from liquidity problems in 2020. The ECB's ultra-dovish monetary policy stance will keep the government's borrowing costs low, which is important given Italy's heavy debt load. A sovereign debt default is therefore unlikely in the near term. Moreover, government bonds are mostly held domestically.
The budget deficit will start to shrink again next year owing to a rebound in economic activity and following the expiration of the stimulus measures adopted by the government. GDP will nonetheless remain below its pre-crisis trend level throughout our forecast period (2020-24), leading to a structural shortfall in tax revenue. As a consequence, we forecast that the budget deficit will average 3.9% of GDP in 2022-24, and public debt will stabilise just below 157% of GDP. Although EU fiscal rules have been temporarily suspended, a multi-year fiscal adjustment will be required over the medium term.

The ECB has deployed an arsenal of policy weapons to limit the financial and economic fallout from the public health crisis. In addition to the open-ended quantitative-easing (QE) programme and negative interest rates, several crisis tools have been brought into play.
Among the most effective is the pandemic emergency purchase programme (PEPP), designed to be temporary and flexible, allowing the ECB to expand its sovereign bond holdings, front-load purchases and take more risk onto its balance sheet (by buying short-term corporate debt of sufficient quality and Greek government bonds). Starting with an initial size of EUR750bn, the PEPP was recently boosted to EUR1.35trn (10% of euro zone GDP) and extended until mid-2021. At its current pace of EUR30bn per week, the PEPP will be exhausted by February 2021. Although the ECB could slow the rate of purchases, another boost to the programme's size remains possible.
The ECB has also preserved an ample degree of liquidity in the banking system. First, it made some refinancing operations cheaper-the interest rate for longer-term refinancing operations (LTROs) was lowered to -1%-and others more accessible for non-bank financial intermediaries. Second, it eased the rules around the collateral that banks can use in exchange for central bank liquidity, effectively preventing a wave of asset-price devaluations from constraining bank lending to the economy.

Economic forecast: Economic growth The impact of the coronavirus: global and regional assumptions The Economist Intelligence Unit's forecasts are built on a series of epidemiological assumptions about the novel coronavirus (Covid-19). Without rapid access to a vaccine, we expect that the disease will eventually infect up to 30% of the world's population; of the symptomatic cases, we assume that about 15% will be severe and up to 1% will prove fatal. Death ratios will depend on a country's ability to detect, track and contain the virus, and the capacity of the national health system. Governments are lifting restrictions on freedom of movement gradually in countries where the number of cases is falling. Some countries may be forced to re-impose measures if cases spike again. Based on previous viral outbreaks and the progress made on other coronavirus vaccines (such as that for severe acute respiratory syndrome-SARS), we expect a vaccine to be available by end-2021.
We forecast that global real GDP will contract by 5% year on year in 2020. We believe that trade disruptions will remain severe and forecast that global trade will contract by 22.6% this year. We assume that oil prices will decline by about 37% this year, to average US$40.5/barrel, before they recover to US$45/b next year. Real GDP will contract in all regions this year, but the drop in output will be especially severe in OECD countries, at 6.3%. All G7 countries and all but two G20 countries (China and Indonesia) will experience a full-year recession, and the US's output will contract by 5.3%, while China will record real GDP growth of 1.4%. Asian countries will recover the fastest, with some (including India and South Korea) returning to pre-coronavirus GDP levels in 2021. Of the G7 countries, Germany's output will also be back to 2019 levels in 2021, but others will recover more slowly, with GDP returning to 2019 levels in either 2022 (Canada, France and the US), 2023 (the UK) or 2024 (Italy and Japan). Most countries have responded with fiscal programmes to support businesses and households, raising the risk of sovereign debt crises in the medium term. Central banks have cut interest rates and, more importantly, have stepped up as buyers of last resort for government and corporate debt.
Europe is heading for a historic recession, with both production and consumption collapsing in the first half of 2020 as a result of the pandemic and containment measures. We forecast a bounce-back from the third quarter, but this will reflect base effects rather than a robust return of economic activity. Global supply chains will remain disrupted, unemployment and business failures will continue to rise and consumers will remain cautious. Southern Europe, which depends on tourism, will take longer to recover as quarantines and weak confidence deter holidaymakers. We expect the economic bounce-back in Europe to lag the global average and do not expect real GDP to recover to its 2019 level until 2023. Variations across the bloc will be determined by factors such as starting positions, the fiscal response, economic structure and export dependencies. Germany will be the first major European economy to recover, and Italy the last.
The political and geopolitical effects of the crisis will be significant. The pandemic has resulted in an extraordinary expansion of executive powers, with limited parliamentary oversight. Elections have been cancelled or delayed in some countries. When the pandemic has passed, governments' handling of the response will face scrutiny. Failure to address the humanitarian crisis triggered by the coronavirus could further erode trust in national institutions. A severe global economic crisis, followed by large-scale unemployment, could fuel a new wave of popular protests. The crisis may encourage support for the nation state, and a backlash against globalisation and open borders. It will also intensify the competition for global leadership between China and the US, and a realignment of geopolitical spheres of influence may ensue in Europe, Africa and other regions.

We expect the Italian economy to contract by 10.8% this year, as a result of the supply- and demand-side shock stemming from the coronavirus pandemic. Although there is a higher than usual degree of uncertainty around the exact outturn, it will be substantially worse than the 5.3% contraction in 2009 following the global financial crisis. As expected, the most severe damage to the economy so far took place in the second quarter, which contained six of the eight weeks that the country was in lockdown. Output declined by 12.4% in the second quarter of 2020, following a contraction of 5.4% in the previous three months.
The gradual lifting of the lockdown since May has helped to revive confidence and lift economic activity from the trough registered in April. The 12.5% month-on-month increase in retail sales in June followed a jump of 25.1% in May. Nonetheless, in year-on-year terms, this was still equivalent to a fall of 3.1%. Uncertainty will continue to lead households to increase their precautionary savings and businesses to delay investments. Consumers may continue to self-quarantine even after the government has lifted travel restrictions for fear of contr-acting the coronavirus. The impact on external demand is also likely to be long-lasting, particularly in the tourism industry, as foreign travellers may be reluctant to visit Italy even after the pandemic has been contained.
As the extraordinary measures adopted to tackle the coronavirus pandemic have been eased gradually since May and demand conditions have improved, activity in Italy's industrial sector has recovered strongly, having collapsed in March-April. However, output remains well below the levels recorded in 2019 or even at the start of 2020. In January-June calendar-adjusted industrial output declined by an average of 18.3% year on year. Italy's export-oriented industries posted the largest declines on an annual basis. Even assuming further increases in output in the third quarter, the industrial sector will post a large full-year contraction in 2020.
We expect a rebound in activity from the third quarter, but this will mainly reflect strong base effects, with consumers and firms still behaving cautiously. Sporadic containment measures may need to be used to keep the outbreak under control until a vaccine becomes available for public use, which we expect to be in late 2021. Moreover, the recovery will remain vulnerable to a recent new spike in infections around Europe, which could lead to the re-imposition of local lockdowns in Italy in the coming months. We expect a partial recovery in the economy in 2021, with growth of 6%. However, we do not expect real GDP to return to its end-2019 level until late 2024.

Economic forecast: Sectoral trends The 2008-o9 global financial crisis and the subsequent euro area crisis had a severe impact on the Italian industrial sector. As a consequence, in 2019 industry (excluding construction) accounted for 23.9% of nominal gross value added, compared with 26.5% of gross value added in 2007, and 21.9% of employment, up slightly from 21.8% in 2007. The manufacturing sector has long been the main strength of the Italian economy, especially Italy's family-owned small and medium-sized export-oriented companies specialising in products that require high-quality design and engineering. However, the sector faces major challenges owing to Italy's structural problems, and concerns about the global economic outlook stemming from the lingering effects of the coronavirus pandemic on global trade, the ongoing trade war between the US and China, and rising trade tensions between the EU and the US. Our outlook for world trade volumes foresees an annual collapse of 22.6% in 2020, followed by an only partial recovery of 11.9% in 2021. In addition, the free-trade model that has dominated global trade discussions in recent decades is clearly in retreat. Italy and its biggest trading partner, Germany, are exposed not only to the trade protectionism that the US administration has brought to bear on China, but also to the threat of US tariff increases on EU exports. Regardless of the result of the US presidential election in November 2020, we expect US-China frictions to continue, especially over questions of technology, investment and finance.
Italian industry faces major challenges owing to structural deficiencies In 2019 manufacturing accounted for 16.6% of gross value added, down from 17.8% in 2007 and 20.3% in 1997. The sector's decline has largely been driven by the prolonged weakness of domestic demand, but also by the difficulties that Italian exporters face in remaining competitive within the European single currency area. Unit labour costs have remained well above the euro area average since 2005 and have continued to rise in Italy since 2010, whereas they have fallen in other peripheral euro area economies such as Spain, Greece, Ireland and Portugal. Weak competitiveness and further transfers of low-value-added production out of Italy are likely to lead to a further decline in manufacturing's contribution to the economy during the forecast period.
The automotive industry is one of the flagship sectors of Italian industry. It accounts for about 8% of GDP-almost a quarter of the contribution from all manufacturing industries and about 10% of the total value of Italian exports. Fiat (Fabbrica Italiana Automobili Torino), which was renamed Fiat-Chrysler Automobiles (FCA) in 2014 after merging with a US-based producer, is the dominant producer in Italy, but the sector also comprises hundreds of firms that manufacture components or provide related services.
After declining in 2008-13, vehicle production in Italy picked up by 6% in 2014 and 45.3% in 2015, slowed to 8.8% in 2016 and 3.5% in 2017, and contracted by 7.2% in 2018 and 13.9% in 2019. At 900,000 units at end-2019, annual production is still well below its 2007 levels. The drop in Italian production disproportionately affected passenger-car output. In 2013 passenger-car output was more than 70% lower than in 2000. Following a modest increase of 3% in 2014, Italian passenger-car production rose by 65% in 2015, before moderating to 7.5% in 2016 and 4.2% in 2017, and then contracting sharply in 2018 and 2019, by 9.3% and 19.5% respectively. Passenger-car production and sales suffered last year, mainly owing to the introduction of new EU emissions standards that distorted industry statistics. We expect vehicle output to fall again this year as coronavirus-related lockdowns slashed demand for motor vehicles in Europe during the first half of 2020 and forced most automakers in the region to halt production temporarily. In mid-July the Italian government announced purchase incentives for low-emission cars, and hybrid and electric vehicles (EVs). From August to December this year buyers of Euro 6 vehicles costing less than EUR40,000 will receive a subsidy of EUR3,500, instead of EUR1,500 previously, if they trade in cars older than ten years. Pure EVs costing less than EUR61,000 will also get a discount of EUR6,000, compared with EUR4,000 earlier. However, we expect passenger-car sales to plummet by 28.2% in 2020, and the commercial-vehicle market will shrink by 23.5%. The outlook for the new-vehicle market in Italy is also subdued for the rest of our forecast period.
Fiat's strategy to become a major global player has proved challenging Fiat's strategy to become a major global producer through mergers, acquisitions and alliances abroad is proving challenging and will probably not boost production in Italy, even if it is successful. The company has succeeded in raising margins globally, but has set ambitious targets through to 2022, which will be all the more difficult to fulfil following the sudden departure and death of Sergio Marchionne, the firm's iconic chief executive officer since 2004, in late July 2018. Given Italy's high labour costs and other difficulties of doing business in the country, the recent trend of shifting automotive production out of Italy is likely to continue, despite FCA's repeated promise to increase domestic production. Fiat now produces about two-thirds of its vehicles abroad, in China, Brazil, Turkey, Russia, Serbia, Poland and elsewhere. It closed its Termini Imerese plant in Sicily at the end of 2011 and began producing cars at a new plant in Serbia in the first half of 2012. Integration with Chrysler could also result in more production being transferred to plants outside Italy.
Manufacturing sector performance will depend on the speed of reforms In the medium term the performance of the manufacturing sector will depend largely on the implementation of reforms to tackle Italy's structural deficiencies. These include issues such as a lack of competition, particularly in the non­tradeable services sectors and utilities. This has meant that companies in Italy pay high prices for domestically produced inputs, such as electricity, compared with competitors elsewhere. The predominance of small companies and their lack of investment in areas such as innovation, and research and development (R&D) has prevented them from moving up the value-added chain. There are about 388,000 manufacturing companies in Italy, about 97% of which employ fewer than 50 people. Firms with fewer than ten employees account for about 82% of the total.
Italian SMEs are often aggregated within sector-specific industrial districts, which, through a combination of co-operation and competition, help to mitigate the impact of the difficulties arising from a lack of expansion. Italian SMEs have begun to consolidate under the pressure of intense competition and the global financial crisis. However, the availability of domestic funds to support mergers or recapitalisations to start new projects is likely to be curtailed by the need to reduce the government debt burden.
Construction sector activity is likely to remain subdued in 2020 Activity in the construction sector accounted for 4.3% of gross value added in 2019-down marginally from 2016, but well below an annual average of 6% of gross value added in 2006-09-and 6.2% of employment in 2016, compared with 8.6% in 2007. After nine full-year contractions, which left output in the sector about a third below its 2006 peak in real terms, the decline appeared to bottom out in the final quarter of 2015. However, activity is likely to remain subdued during the forecast period, reflecting the impact of an eight-year decline in property prices up to 2016, as well as the coronavirus pandemic (construction contracted by 5.6% year-on-year in the first quarter of 2020). The pandemic will weigh on recovery in the construction sector, as will ongoing corruption investigations involving public works contracts. Various govern-ments have sought to accelerate EU co-financed infrastructure investment plans to provide some support to the sector, but little progress is likely to be made, largely owing to delays at the regional and ministerial levels.
Services will be significantly disrupted by the pandemic Already accounting for 74% of gross value added, the services sector will be significantly disrupted by the pandemic. The hotel and restaurant sector will be the worst affected, along with other services related to tourism. The retail sector will also suffer in the short term. In contrast, the information and communications technology (ICT) sector will benefit from the increase in remote working, and we expect a continued rise in its share of real value added. Sectors that serve mainly the domestic market and have so far enjoyed a high level of protection from competition will come under pressure as a result of reforms to reduce barriers to entry, but this is likely to be only gradual. Over the near term, the Movimento 5 Stelle (M5S)-Partito Democratico (PD) government is unlikely to embark on ambitious service sector liberalisations and would be more likely to introduce protective legislation. High-value­added services sectors, such as design, which are closely tied to clothing, textiles and automotive, Italy's main export sectors, should continue to perform well, even though in some sectors production is increasingly being moved abroad to countries where labour costs are lower.

Inflation will remain weak and well below the euro zone average over our forecast horizon. In 2020 we expect inflation to decline to 0.1% (from 0.6% in 2019) as weaker consumer confidence and a 37% collapse in global oil prices pull down prices. In 2021 price growth will firm to 0.9%, following a moderate recovery in domestic demand and improving conditions in the labour market. Over 2022-24 we expect inflation to stabilise at an average of about 1.4% per year-below the average in the rest of the euro area.

The oil price crash and the prospect of rate cuts by the Federal Reserve (the US central bank) sent the euro soaring to US$1.15:EUR1 in early March, but this surge proved temporary as the global spread of the coronavirus boosted the US dollar's safe-haven status. In April-May the euro hovered between US$1.08:EUR1 and US$1.11:EUR1, but it has since strengthened, as an agreement between EU leaders on a significant economic recovery fund in late July and higher political risk in the US have supported the euro. We expect the euro to average US$1.11:EUR1 in 2020. A stronger rebound in the US economy relative to the euro zone will keep the euro broadly stable next year. Thereafter, we expect a gradual strengthening, supported by the bloc's large current-account surplus and a reduction in global risk.

The current account will remain in surplus throughout our forecast horizon, at close to 2.4% of GDP on average. Large trade surpluses and a small positive balance in the primary income account more than offset a trade deficit in services and a negative balance in the secondary income account. Overall, the persistent current-account surplus reflects a lack of domestic demand combined with a limited return for domestic investments, which is driving investors to recycle capital into overseas markets.
Economic forecast: Foreign direct investment in Italy Stocks and flows Net inward foreign direct investment (FDI) flows are low compared with most other EU countries, and Italy has generally been a net exporter of FDI. Net inflows to declined to close to zero in 2012, owing to large disinvestments. Net inflows recovered moderately in 2013-16, averaging US$18.9bn per year (0.8% of GDP). Inward FDI rose to US$39.6bn in 2018 (equivalent to 1.9% of GDP), up from US$11bn in 2017, before dropping back to US$29.2bn in 2019 (equivalent to 1.5% of GDP) amid political volatility. Italy attracts less greenfield foreign investment than other large European economies. The total stock of FDI was US$574bn in 2019, about 60% of total FDI in France, about a third of that in Germany and a quarter of that in the UK. In relation to GDP, the stock of FDI was 28.7% in 2019-lower than in every other EU country apart from Greece. FDI outflows have also generally been small, mainly reflecting the prevalence of small and medium-sized companies in Italy. In 2005-09 Italy recorded substantial outward FDI flows as a result of several major investments abroad in the banking and energy sectors. A similarly large outflow, of about US$52bn, was recorded in 2011-the year that Italian car manufacturer Fiat bought the US Treasury's remaining stake in Chrysler.
Origin and distribution FDI from Europe accounts for about 60-65% of company revenue and employment generated by foreign companies with operations in Italy. Companies from North America represent about 25-30% of revenue and employment, and those from Japan for about 3-4%. The manufacturing sector contributed about 40% of the total revenue and value-added of foreign­owned firms, but this has generally been on a downward path and dropped sharply in 2005, when General Motors (US) sold its stake in Fiat. The utilities and telecommunications sectors have registered the most rapid expansion. In 2018, the last year for which data are available (expressed according to the directional principle), the largest FDI stocks came from the Netherlands (US$63.4bn), Spain (US$40bn), Germany (US$35.7bn) and France (US$30.5bn).
Determinants The main attraction for foreign companies to set up operations in Italy is the size of the domestic market, which offers a population of about 6om and average GDP per head of US$44,004 at purchasing power parity (PPP). Deterrents include the complexity of Italy's legal system, inefficiencies in public administration, inadequate infrastructure-particularly in the south of the country-and often high regulatory barriers to entry, especially in services sectors. In addition, studies of the determinants of FDI in southern Italy have highlighted typical deterrents to investment, such as distance from major European markets, low presence of other foreign companies and a high level of organised crime. Such studies seem to indicate that fiscal incentives and the presence of specialised producer service providers have a low impact on foreign entrants' decisions, but that human capital is an important positive variable. Italy has an abundant workforce in the south, which has attracted a few high-technology investments to areas such as Catania in Sicily, where a Franco-Italian joint venture, ST Microelectronics, has a production plant and several research centres.
Impact According to the Italian Trade and Investment Agency (ITA), foreign-controlled companies employ more than 1m people in Italy and generate revenue of about EUR5oobn per year. Foreign companies invest on average three and half times more in research and development (R&D) than Italian companies. However, because of the comparatively low level of inflows and their concentration in the north of Italy, the impact of FDI on the Italian economy as a whole has been limited. The depressed areas of the south, which attract limited Italian private-sector investment, would benefit substantially in terms of employment and through the spillover effect of advanced technology, management practices and production processes. However, almost all of the inward FDI stock is located in the north and centre of the country. Despite massive state investment in 1950-84, the south has continued to lag central Italy and the north in GDP per head terms (less than 55% of the average in the centre and north). The unemployment rate in the south is almost double the national average and about three times higher than that in the north.
Potential The possibility of higher FDI inflows in the forecast period (2020-24) will be hampered by the uncertainty caused by the Covid-19 pandemic and the fact that most of the factors that have deterred FDI in the past will remain in place. The previous Movimento 5 Stelle (M5S)-Lega administration implemented a less friendly policy stance towards foreign investment, marginally tightening labour contract regulations through its so-called Dignity Decree in 2018, and enforcing penalties on foreign firms that take advantage of government investment incentives and then divest or relocate production to other markets. Over the forecast period a slight improvement is expected in the efficiency of the public administration, as a result of recent and ongoing reforms. The performance of the state body responsible for attracting foreign investors may also improve. Given Italy's need to reduce its dependence on imported energy, there could be potential for investment in the still state-dominated energy sector as liberalisation continues to make progress and the authorities are forced to focus on investment in renewable energy sources. Under the current M5S-Partito Democratico (PD) government, political opposition to foreign interest in ownership of utility networks and possibly some companies in the manufacturing sector is likely to continue, as such companies are deemed to be of a "strategic" nature. M5S, which has taken strong environmental stances in the past, may also use potential ecological consequences as a justification for limiting inward investment, particularly in infrastructure or energy projects. Banking sector reforms may increase opportunities for foreign investment in smaller Italian banks.
