Business environment outlook: Thailand's business environment at a glance Policy towards private enterprise and competition 2020-21: The authorities put off management reform and provide substantive financial support to state-owned enterprises.
2022-24: Thailand improves its domestic intellectual property rights (IPR) enforcement regime, which leads to the country's removal from the US Trade Representative's IPR watch list.
Policy towards foreign investment 2020-21: The Bank of Thailand (BOT, the central bank) relaxes rules-on a short-term basis-on inflows into Thailand's financial markets, as it seeks to exit the pandemic-induced recession.
2022-24: Opposition to the sale of assets to foreigners persists, particularly in the utilities sector. The authorities introduce new incentives to promote inward investment in targeted industries while removing incentives in low-value-added sectors.
Foreign trade and exchange controls 2020-21: Negotiations to finalise the delayed Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP)-an agreement to harmonise exisiting free-trade agreements (FTAs) between ASEAN and Japan, Australia, China, New Zealand and South Korea-continues following India's withdrawal.
2022-24: Thailand completes negotiations with the EU on a free-trade zone and investment treaty, as its integration with other members of the ASEAN Economic Community results in a freer flow of goods, capital and labour.
Taxes 2020-21: The authorities implement one-off tax breaks and fee waivers for small- and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) amid an extended economic slowdown exacerbated by the coronavirus (Covid-19) outbreak.
2022-24: Mandatory employer social security payments rise from 3% to 5%. The government raises the rate of value-added tax (VAT) slightly from its current level of 7%.
Financing 2020-21: Access to business financing becomes more favourable as the government rolls out concessionary loans and loan guarantees to help struggling businesses to stave off bankruptcy amid the coronavirus outbreak.
2022-24: Commercial banks based in other ASEAN countries begin to offer retail services in Thailand.
The labour market 2020-21: The government freezes the minimum wage following an incremental increase in January 2020 and implements community work programmes to help boost employment amid the pandemic-induced recession.
2022-24: Shortages of skilled labour become more acute, driving up costs in high-value-added industries. The government loosens immigration controls on foreign skilled workers sought after by strategic sectors, such as IT.
Infrastructure 2020-21: The expansion of road and rail infrastructure progresses, providing a boost to the construction sector.
2022-24: Expansion work is completed at Don Mueang and Suvarnabhumi international airports in the capital, Bangkok.
Technological readiness 2020-21: The roll-out of the 5G network begins in major cities as the government implements regulations related to data privacy, e-commerce and cyber-security.
2022-24: The Board of Investment continues to prioritise investment approval for projects in the sectors targeted by the "Thailand 4.0" industrial policy.
Business environment outlook: Macroeconomic environment                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2015-19 2020-24 2015-19 2020-24 2015-19 2020-24
7.8 6.9 26 28 9 9
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 17 countries: Australia, Bangladesh, China, Hong Kong, India, Indonesia, Japan, Malaysia, New Zealand, Pakistan, Philippines, Singapore, South Korea, Sri Lanka, Taiwan, Thailand and Vietnam.
Thailand's macroeconomic environment score falls in the forecast period. This has prompted a fall in the country's global rankings: the imminent deep recession will erode the traditionally strong fundamentals underpinning Thailand's macroeconomic stability. GDP growth will decelerate considerably compared to the pace achieved in recent years, averaging only 1.8% in 2020-24, compared with 3.4% in 2015-19. The economy will shrink by 5.3% in 2020, owing to a contraction of private consumption growth and a drastic slump in receipts from exports amid the global pandemic. External and domestic demand will pick up only in the later part of the forecast period, and growing competition with peers in the Association of South-East Asian Nations (ASEAN) will keep a lid on growth.
The economy will take at least two years to return to its pre-pandemic level The military will maintain a strong grip on economic affairs in 2020-24, and oversee the approval of major spending plans to stimulate the economy back to growth. The constitutionally mandated "National Strategy", the junta's 20--year blueprint for development, will undergo changes after an ongoing review by the government's National Economic and Social Development Council, with a stronger emphasis on generating tangible results in terms of job creation and GDP growth in the short term. This will include an expedition of infrastructure projects and renewed commitments on sectors such as tourism and agriculture, where Thailand has traditionally been competitive. At the same time, the government will also ensure that business-oriented tax reform and investment incentives are maintained and expanded in 2020-24, and that major infrastructure investment projects continue beyond this period. In the early part of the forecast period, the export-dependent economy will be hit hard by external headwinds amid the pandemic. Nonetheless, broad economic stability will be ensured by sound macroeconomic fundamentals, including a still-healthy current-account surplus and manageable levels of public debt. This will be helped by a recovery in growth in 2022-24, as global economic conditions normalise.
The central bank will welcome Setthaput Suthiwart-Narueput as the new governor, after the incumbent, Veerathai Santiprabhob, who took the reins in October 2015, declined to seek a second term. However, this will not undermine the BOT's credibility as it remains relatively free from political pressure in setting policy rates and managing excess volatility of the local currency, the baht. It will nevertheless continue to take aggressive measures, including maintaining a loose monetary policy, to revitalise the economy, which aligns neatly with Prayuth's economic agenda.
Business environment outlook: Policy towards private enterprise and competition                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2015-19 2020-24 2015-19 2020-24 2015-19 2020-24
6.5 6.3 31 38 8 8
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 17 countries: Australia, Bangladesh, China, Hong Kong, India, Indonesia, Japan, Malaysia, New Zealand, Pakistan, Philippines, Singapore, South Korea, Sri Lanka, Taiwan, Thailand and Vietnam.
We expect a modest drop in the score for policy towards private enterprise and competition as the government prioritises saving state-owned and large corporations with connections to powerful officials. Thailand's global ranking falls from 31st in 2015-19 to 38th in 2020-24. However, the country's regional ranking will remain unchanged owing to concurrent declines in other Asian countries. Corruption and favouritism will continue to distort free-market dynamics, as evidenced by the slow progress of cases, despite the media attention the National Anti-Corruption Commission (NACC) has received in recent years. The political elite retain a disproportionate influence on commercial affairs: individuals with ties to military and royalist leaders tend to extract concessions from government and influence legal judgments. Against this backdrop, the return to a quasi-civilian regime since the March 2019 election will not lead to any significant improvement in government accountability.
The pace of privatisation of SOEs will slow further in 2020-24
- Reforms to bolster the operational efficiency of state-owned enterprises (SOEs) have been proposed in recent years, but the prospect of their implementation has grown even more remote in the wake of the coronvirus (Covid-19) pandemic. Any such reform would redistribute economic rents away from current holders. Privatisation remains a sensitive issue among both powerful interests and the public. It is unlikely that the military-aligned government will sell off state assets, especially after those assets have received government bail-outs and will likely remain at discounted prices for the foreseeable future. A long-standing area of concern is the lack of protection for intellectual property (IP): legal provisions are in place to control piracy of digital and online content, but enforcement is poor, even by regional standards. As a result, the country remains on the EU's priority watchlist. The continuation of price controls will distort competition in Thailand, as the government will keep price controls for some basic goods to make them affordable; prices for goods on the "sensitive" list cannot be changed without the permission of the Ministry of Commerce.

IP infringement will remain an issue in the medium term
- The reform of corporate governance at 56 SOEs, controlling assets worth over US$300bn, will stall. Since the 2019 election, Prayuth's government has made no tangible attempt to kick-start such reform. As the political agenda will centre on post-pandemic recovery, complex and divisive longer-term initiatives that do not result in immediate gains will be put on the backburner. "Superboards", devised under the junta regime to address public-sector corruption and oversee reform, will remain prone to political influence. SOEs will continue to be favoured in the state's often opaque procurement processes, as government is set to step up its investments to support the economy. In the unlikely event that the current opposition wrests power from the government amid the pandemic, such reforms will not occur, as the latter will want to avoid upsetting the establishment.
- Thailand has been on the US Trade Representative's lower-priority Watch List for IP since late 2017. While the country continues to make minor progress on matters related to patents and copyright legislation in recent years, instances of IP infringement remain relatively frequent. This is owing to a combination of legislative and enforcement issues, such as the country's absence from the World Intellectual Property Organisation's (WIPO) Copyright Treaty, a limited level of punitive measures and patent application backlogs. As the country seeks to reinvent itself as a "digital economy" under its "Thailand 4.0" initiative, we expect improvements in the legal apparatus that will offer greater protection for patent holders during the latter part of the forecast period. As with many emerging economies, however, enforcement will remain flawed.

Business environment outlook: Policy towards foreign investment                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2015-19 2020-24 2015-19 2020-24 2015-19 2020-24
6.4 6.9 48 38 9 7
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 17 countries: Australia, Bangladesh, China, Hong Kong, India, Indonesia, Japan, Malaysia, New Zealand, Pakistan, Philippines, Singapore, South Korea, Sri Lanka, Taiwan, Thailand and Vietnam.
The score for policy towards foreign investment will improve in 2020-24, compared with the historical period, raising both the country's regional and global rankings. Thailand will continue to encourage inward investment, especially in higher-value-added industries, as part of the "Thailand 4.0" industrial policy. Further incentives are almost certain to be rolled out in the aftermath of the pandemic, and the Board of Investment will continue to fast-track investment approvals. The government will also decline to revive proposals to amend the Foreign Business Act, which would make it more difficult for foreign companies to control Thai entities unless they own a majority of shares.

- The BOI's investment promotion strategy for 2015-22 offers incentives and government support for foreign investors. The strategy's central tenet provides for offers of generous tax breaks, land rights and so-called smart visas for companies and entrepreneurs involved in high-technology industries that will contribute to enhancing Thailand's productivity through technical training or promotion of automation technology. Amid the pandemic, the country will expand the list of sectors eligible for such incentives, such as manufacturers of medical equipment and drugs. It also focuses on the development of special economic zones (SEZs) along the land borders of Thailand and its neighbours as part of the "Eastern Economic Corridor". This is in place to take advantage of Thailand's increasing flows of international labour and goods via the country's seaports and aviation networks under the ASEAN Economic Community (AEC), which was formally established in 2015. These objectives dovetail with the longer-term Thailand 4.0 policy.

Business environment outlook: Foreign trade and exchange controls                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2015-19 2020-24 2015-19 2020-24 2015-19 2020-24
8.7 8.2 28 36 5 5
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 17 countries: Australia, Bangladesh, China, Hong Kong, India, Indonesia, Japan, Malaysia, New Zealand, Pakistan, Philippines, Singapore, South Korea, Sri Lanka, Taiwan, Thailand and Vietnam.
The score for foreign trade and exchange controls falls in 2020-24, driven primarily by ongoing and expected travel restrictions owing to the spread of the coronavirus. This causes Thailand's global ranking to drop to 36th from 28th in 2015-19. The imposition of travel barriers will impede exchange of goods, especially cross-border trade during the early part of the forecast period. Thailand's reliance on international trade, as well as a collapse of external demand in 2020, will ensure that the government strives to maintain a favourable relationship with major export markets in 2020-22, beyond the necessary quarantine measures. Authorities will be more likely to accommodate the demands of influential domestic groups in 2023, with an approaching election and the expectation of a full recovery in its major export markets. The government will be keen to diversify export markets and continue to pursue trade agreements, both individually and in partnership with other ASEAN members. The bloc's agreements include those in place with China and India, and a combined agreement with Australia and New Zealand. Thailand will also be keen to complete negotiations on the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP), but its delayed progress following India's withdrawal will compel the country to pursue alternatives.

- In the meantime, the country will adhere to its commitments as a member of the WTO. Thailand has accepted the obligations laid down in the IMF's Article VIII, which stipulates that transactions on the current account should be free of restrictions. Foreign investors do not face restrictions on the repatriation of profits and dividends. The central bank has eased restrictions on outward capital flows, and temporary measures to control capital inflows imposed in 2019 and early 2020 will be lifted in the aftermath of the pandemic as the country urgently seeks a return of foreign investors.
- Thailand's continual liberalisation of its trade regime, in line with its commitment to implementing the ASEAN Economic Community (AEC), will slow in 2020-24. While the AEC had already led to the lifting of most tariffs and freer movement of services, investment and skilled labour (in eight selected sectors) since end-2015, a commensurate increase of onerous customs regulations and non-tariff barriers (NTBs) from 2015 to 2019 continued to limit intra-regional trade. With the pandemic wreaking havoc on the fiscal and current accounts of ASEAN members, the use of such NTBs will rise further amid a shift to protecting domestic external sectors. This will have a particularly obvious impact on services trade, which has long been more vulnerable to such measures than are flows of goods. Expectations that the ASEAN Trade in Services Agreement (ATISA), in effect since October 2019, will lead to phenomenal growth of services trade in 2020-24 will not materialise during the forecast period. For instance, some of the subsectors that ATISA seeks to liberalise (such as healthcare) coincide with the strategic industries high on governments' protection lists.

Negotiation on joining the CPTPP will begin
- Formal talks on a bilateral free-trade agreement (FTA) between Thailand and the EU were put on hold after the 2014 coup, and were about to resume in early 2020 before the pandemic hit. European and Thai businesses are both keen to conclude a deal. Barring a deterioration in Thailand's politics, a Thai-EU deal is likely to be concluded before the end of the forecast period. At the same time, Thailand will start negotiation to join the 11-strong Comprehensive and Progressive Agreement for Trans-Pacific Partnership (CPTPP), which counts Australia, Canada and Japan among its members.

Business environment outlook: Taxes                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2015-19 2020-24 2015-19 2020-24 2015-19 2020-24
7.9 7.8 11 17 5 7
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 17 countries: Australia, Bangladesh, China, Hong Kong, India, Indonesia, Japan, Malaysia, New Zealand, Pakistan, Philippines, Singapore, South Korea, Sri Lanka, Taiwan, Thailand and Vietnam.
Thailand's score in the taxes category declines only marginally in 2020-24. This is enough to prompt a drop in the country's global and regional rankings from 2015-19, from 11th to 17th and 5th to 7th, respectively. The minor drop in the score is owing to the unexpected year-long delay in the implementation of the new, fairer property and land tax. Nonetheless, Thailand's tax regime remains relatively simple and changes have been made in recent years to reduce the overall burden on households and firms. The standard rate of corporate tax was reduced from 30% in 2011 to 20% in 2013. We expect it to remain at 20%, given the government's priority of attracting foreign investors. The personal income is also relatively favourable, with the top marginal rate standing at 35% for Thai and foreign workers with annual earnings over Bt5m (US$145,000). Wide-ranging waivers for VAT, corporate and income taxes are in effect until at least September 2020 amid the pandemic.
Taxes will remain relatively low across the board
- Successive governments repeatedly postponed returning the VAT rate from a reduced rate of 7% to 10%, as per the official law. Amid the pandemic, The Economist Intelligence Unit expects this lower rate to be extended again into 2021. The authorities will raise the rate in 2023-24 as the need to plug the fiscal gap arising from a jump in expenditure in 2020-21 takes precedence. However, this decision will also be influenced by the prevailing political climate, as an increase in the VAT rate could serve as a catalyst for further protests. This means that the government will be unlikely to sanction a rise in 2022 owing to the proximity of the next election, which is due in early 2023.
- Coronavirus-related tax waivers will be in effect in the earlier part of the forecast period, as the military-aligned government will keep them in place to cushion the impact of the pandemic. This will include deferring the filing and payment of income and corporate tax for a year. For small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs), as well as individuals, the government will increase the allowance of tax deduction in 2020. The withholding tax rate will also fall to 1.5-2% on income received from April to December 2020.
- The government will be prepared to run a significantly larger fiscal deficit in 2020-21 in order to finance the aforementioned measures. From 2022 onwards, the government will opt to cut spending, rather than raise taxes, to reduce the fiscal deficit. As a longer-term initiative, the government will make efforts to expand revenue collection. These will include measures to enable digital and mobile payments in order to broaden the tax base, as well as the imposition of capital gains tax later in the forecast period. Meanwhile, the aforementioned delayed tax on property and land will be implemented only in 2021. It will have only a minor impact on foreign business, with the tax rates most applicable to foreign investors likely to be set at less than 2%.

Business environment outlook: Financing                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2015-19 2020-24 2015-19 2020-24 2015-19 2020-24
7.0 6.6 23 35 8 9
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 17 countries: Australia, Bangladesh, China, Hong Kong, India, Indonesia, Japan, Malaysia, New Zealand, Pakistan, Philippines, Singapore, South Korea, Sri Lanka, Taiwan, Thailand and Vietnam.
Thailand's score for financing will worsen in 2020-24, as the banking sector will face the headwinds of the pandemic-induced recession. As a result, Thailand's global ranking for the category slumps from 23rd in 2015-19 to 35th. Similarly, its regional ranking will slip to 9th, from 8th. The ratio of non-performing loans (NPLs) to total loans remains relatively low, but, alarmingly, it had already surged to a nine-year high of 3.7% as at May 2020. This is likely to rise further for much of the remainder of 2020 as the devastating impact of the pandemic and lockdown continue to show. This will erode the overall health of the banking sector, although the central bank's support will contain any systemic shock.
The trend of consolidation in the financial sector will accelerate
- The BOT and the finance ministry will continue to focus on shoring up the resilience and competitiveness of the financial sector, principally via the consolidation of a number of private- and state-owned financial institutions. This will take on greater urgency as an expected surge in NPLs will likely weaken some commercial lenders, especially those with a portfolio of mostly SMEs and individuals. The facility set up by the central bank to purchase bad debts from troubled financial institutions will help clear the way for mergers and acquisitions. The ongoing negotiations on liberalising banking services under the ASEAN Banking Integration Framework will drag on amid the pandemic and only conclude towards the end of the forecast period. However, Thailand's other pursuit of increasing interoperability across ASEAN markets-via facilitating local currency settlement and standardised digitisation of payments-will make faster progress and be implemented by 2021.
- The local bond market will continue to expand under the guidance of the BOT. Although the pandemic has tampered investors' responses to Thai corporate bonds, this will be short-lived. Post-pandemic, the market will stay on its rapid-growth trajectory. Thailand's strong macroeconomic fundamentals and credible central bank, with a reputation for prudence, has made it ASEAN's largest local-currency bond market. Although government bonds continue to dominate the market, at over 70% of all bonds issued, debt-laden large and medium-sized companies are increasingly using the bond market to refinance their bank loans and offshore borrowings. Strengthening demand in this market will continue during the forecast period as capital flows into relatively safe assets and markets.

Business environment outlook: The labour market                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2015-19 2020-24 2015-19 2020-24 2015-19 2020-24
6.6 6.4 24 36 8 9
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 17 countries: Australia, Bangladesh, China, Hong Kong, India, Indonesia, Japan, Malaysia, New Zealand, Pakistan, Philippines, Singapore, South Korea, Sri Lanka, Taiwan, Thailand and Vietnam.
The deterioration in Thailand's global and regional rankings in the labour market category reflects its waning competitiveness. The country is a labour-scarce economy and the official unemployment rate remains consistently low, which continues to hold true even amid the pandemic. Labour market conditions will, in general, remain adequate in terms of supporting the operations of foreign-invested enterprises, but weaknesses, especially rising wage costs and skill shortages, will persist and exacerbate. The country's advantages as a cost-efficient base for labour-intensive production will quickly vanish amid growing competition from its low-income neighbours such as Cambodia, Myanmar and Vietnam, which also happen to boast a large workforce.
Labour shortages threaten the implementation of "Thailand 4.0"
- Shortages of labour trained to work in high-value industries will continue to pose a huge problem to the government's "Thailand 4.0" policy ambitions, which are premised on developing the country's advanced technology sectors. These skilled labour problems stem in large part from Thailand's underperforming education system, which ranks poorly both globally and regionally. Educational reforms in the last two decades have been poorly and inconsistently implemented, and there are currently still no plans for a major overhaul of the system. The ability of the labour force to meet the needs of businesses (in terms of specialist skills) is therefore likely to remain below global standards. In view of this situation, hiring skilled foreign workers will become easier with the government set to relax visa restrictions, especially for the research and technology sectors during the forecast period.
- From January 2017 the nationwide daily minimum-wage schedule was replaced by minimum wages per province. The range of the wage floor was raised to Bt313-336 (around US$10) with effect from January 2020. Further increases in the minimum wage will be frozen amid the pandemic and rising unemployment in 2020-21. Despite long-standing opposition in parliament and among business associations owing to the damage it would incur on private sector costs and Thailand's regional competitiveness, we expect the government to yet again succeed in raising the minimum wage in 2022-24 as a populist measure to appease the working class.

A poorly skilled workforce will remain the biggest issue in 2020-24
- Thailand is facing the social and economic consequences of a rapidly ageing society, including a steadily declining workforce as a share of the total population. The new government will introduce steps to mitigate this crisis towards the end of the forecast period. Proposals advocating a staggered increase in the retirement age of civil servants-from 60 years to 63-will be fully implemented in 2024. Civil servants can also now voluntarily delay their retirement by up to 10 years. These policies will invariably put pressure on private employers to follow suit. However, stagnant productivity will prevent such measures from adequately addressing related issues, such as the increasing financial burden of elderly care.
- Migrant workers account for over 10% of the total labour force prior to the pandemic, according to the UN. These workers typically come from neighbouring Myanmar, Cambodia and Laos, and fill low-skilled vacancies in industries such as agriculture, construction and domestic work. We expect the size of the local labour force to rise in Thailand post-pandemic, when they are allowed to return, with businesses set to become even more reliant on cheaper migrant workers. This will also be driven by the development of SEZs, which the government has opened in border areas in order to capitalise on the supply of low-cost migrant labour from neighbouring countries. As a result, tensions will inevitably rise between local and migrant workers on issues of mistreatment and locals' resentment of job losses to migrant labourers. International concern over potential human rights abuses in Thailand, especially in the fishing industry, have resulted in stronger protective measures for migrant workers, but the UN still reports exploitation.

Business environment outlook: Infrastructure                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2015-19 2020-24 2015-19 2020-24 2015-19 2020-24
4.8 5.8 57 52 10 10
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 17 countries: Australia, Bangladesh, China, Hong Kong, India, Indonesia, Japan, Malaysia, New Zealand, Pakistan, Philippines, Singapore, South Korea, Sri Lanka, Taiwan, Thailand and Vietnam.
Thailand's infrastructure score will experience a marked improvement in the next five years. This will propel the country to 52nd in 2020-24 from 57th in 2015-19. Concurrent developments in neighbouring countries, however, will keep the country's regional ranking unchanged, at 10th. The military-aligned government will expedite smaller community work projects while continuing to bet on long-pending "megaprojects" for faster growth, although the latter will still face occasional delays. Improvements in telecommunications services have also been slow. Although 4G coverage is widely available, average speeds remain slow by regional comparison. Electricity supplies have risen, but the potential for shortages remains. At present, over 70% of the country's electricity is generated using natural gas, according to the Energy Policy and Planning Office, making the country vulnerable to fluctuations in global gas prices.
Infrastructure will be a key pillar of the government's plan for recovery
- The government has faced delays in the financing and implementation stages of its ambitious infrastructure development megaprojects, owing to issues with land acquisition, environmental impact and commercial viability. This includes the much-vaunted Thai section of the high-speed railway linking Thailand and China, via Laos, which had still not started as at August 2020, despite a decade of planning. Elsewhere, regional transport projects have faced similar delays owing to wrangling over financing with Chinese and Japanese investors. This partly reflects the government's efforts to take advantage of the ongoing competition for geopolitical influence between the two countries in order to secure the best deal. We expect these dynamics to result in uneven progress on priority projects in 2020-24. Thailand's more difficult financial position after the pandemic also means that the conditionality of loans and terms of repayment will feature more prominently in the government's decision to greenlight certain projects at the expense of others.
- The state-run management company, Airports of Thailand, faces a dismal year in 2020, as its finances have been hit hard by the pandemic. This, in addition to the halt of international travel since March 2020, will derail the planned upgrade of the country's three major airports. The airport expansion in Bangkok will still complete by 2024, but the construction of new airports in Chiang Mai and Phuket will likely only materialise beyond the end of the forecast period.

5G networks will be key part of the ambitious "Thailand 4.0" initiative
- The pandemic has spurred development of 5G networks in Thailand, and the country now leads its ASEAN counterparts in the 5G race. Two operators have already launched 5G networks across hospitals in major cities and powered robots for telemedicine. These developments will put Thailand on track to meet its regulator's optimistic forecast that it will be able to provide commercial 5G services by end-2020.

Business environment outlook: Technological readiness                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2015-19 2020-24 2015-19 2020-24 2015-19 2020-24
5.8 6.3 45 42 10 10
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 17 countries: Australia, Bangladesh, China, Hong Kong, India, Indonesia, Japan, Malaysia, New Zealand, Pakistan, Philippines, Singapore, South Korea, Sri Lanka, Taiwan, Thailand and Vietnam.
Thailand will experience an improvement in its technological readiness score in 2020-24, which boosts its global rankings by three places, to 42nd. The change reflects our expectations that the government will increase its investments in R&D, STEM education and continue to improve the digital infrastructure in 2020-24. To fulfil the government's "Thailand 4.0" goals, it will scale up incentives for international companies to set up research bases inside the country. However, internet use will exert a fundamental drag on Thailand's performance. Although the number of internet users per 100 population has increased to 60.2 in 2019, it remains below those of Malaysia (81.2) and the Philippines (66). This limits Thailand's viability for e-commerce and digital services.
Benefits of digitisation will probably stay within urban areas
- The government has outlined plans to pursue digital infrastructure projects initiated by the junta as part of the Thailand 4.0 strategy and the 20-year digital roadmap. These include projects to bring national broadband to 25,000 remote communities, in order to develop rural areas and to give private-sector enterprises access to public infrastructure. Progress on this front will continue to be sluggish as escalating costs and the poor quality of wifi hotspots plague the project. State telecommunications company, TOT, has been blacklisted by the government following its failure to deliver broadband to these villages on time. As a result, any socio-economic transformation to be brought about by 5G internet in the forecast period will be limited to the big cities and their surrounding areas.
- The Board of Investment will likely step up incentives, such as import duty exemptions on raw materials used in R&D, to expedite the development of innovative capacities in the private sector, which has long shown a lack of commercial acumen in deployment of technology. Companies focused on biotechnology, nanotechnology, advanced materials or digital technology are also eligible for up to 13 years' exemption from corporate income tax if they co-operate with public research institutions in R&D.

Economic forecast: Policy trends As an urgent matter, the government will focus on implementing fiscal stimulus measures, comprising three components: tax breaks; the facilitation of bank loans in the form of collateral guarantees and concessionary rates; and direct handouts for those businesses and households worst hit by the pandemic. Industry-specific stimulus plans, in particular for the tourism sector, will also feature high on the government's agenda in the second half of the year as the economy reopens fully.
After the pandemic, the government will-in a similar way to the junta that preceded it-return to its priority of boosting the country's medium-to-long-term investment prospects as a sophisticated manufacturing and technology hub, partly through increased public spending on infra-structure. This will include the development of the EEC, based on new and upgraded transport links. The initiative will also cover the continuation of the sector-specific Thailand 4.0 industrial policy, which will provide significant tax and working-visa incentives for foreign investors in knowledge-intensive industries within and outside the EEC. This business-friendly policy will also manifest itself in the government's renewed pursuit of FTAs and bilateral investment treaties with major trading partners. However, this aspiration of reinventing Thailand as a high-technology economy will face severe headwinds-most notably the lack of skilled labour and fierce competition from regional peers such as South Korea and Taiwan.

The Economist Intelligence Unit expects the budget deficit to stand at the equivalent of 6.4% of GDP in 2020, which will be the largest deficit in 30 years. The government estimates its multiple rounds of parliament-approved stimulus packages to be worth around Bt2.5trn (US$79bn). We do not expect further significant stimulus measures in the remainder of 2020 and 2021.
The government has stated that it will issue Bt1trn in new debt (domestic and external) to finance the deficit in 2020. Total government debt as a share of GDP will jump from an estimated equivalent of 41.2% of GDP in 2019 to 53.5% of GDP in 2021.
Concerns over fiscal sustainability, amid rising debt servicing, will lead to a tightening fiscal stance from 2021. We forecast the budget deficit to average 3.4% of GDP per year in 2021-24. Increased infrastructure spending and investment will form the bulk of rising government expenditure. Stronger trade growth in 2022-24 will boost revenue from import and export duties and help to ensure that the deficit does not exceed 4% of GDP in this period. A likely increase in value-added tax (VAT) in the latter part of the forecast period, from the current rate of 7%, will also bolster revenue.

We expect the Bank of Thailand (BOT, the central bank) to reduce its policy rate, the one-day repurchase rate, throughout this year to near zero. The central bank cut the rate by 75 basis points between February and May, to a new record low of 0.5%, and we expect it to reduce the rate by another 25 basis points in September. It will only sanction gradual rate rises from 2022, as domestic and external economic conditions strengthen.
The BOT also mandated concessionary rates for loans to low-income house-holds and relaxed the conditions on loan repayments for small businesses.
The central bank is likely to scale up new forms of open-market operations that involve purchases of government and corporate assets, with the aim of supporting govern-ment financing and reassuring investors about the continued robustness of the country's financial system. It set up a Corporate Bond Stabilisation Fund in April with the aim of bolstering liquidity, and has already conducted two rounds of purchases.

Economic forecast: Economic growth The impact of the coronavirus: global and regional assumptions The Economist Intelligence Unit's forecasts are built on a series of epidemiological assumptions about the novel coronavirus (Covid-19). Without rapid access to a vaccine, we expect that the disease will eventually infect up to 30% of the world's population; of the symptomatic cases, we assume that around 15% will be severe and up to 1% will prove fatal. Death ratios will depend on a country's ability to detect, track and contain the virus and the capacity of its national health system. Governments are lifting restrictions on freedom of movement gradually in countries where the number of cases is falling. Some countries may be forced to re-impose measures if the number of cases spikes again. Based on previous viral outbreaks and the progress made on other coronavirus vaccines (such as that for severe acute respiratory syndrome, or SARS), we expect a vaccine to be available by end-2021.
We forecast that global real GDP will contract by 5% year on year in 2020. We believe that trade disruption will remain severe and forecast that global trade will contract by 22.6%. We assume that oil prices will decline by about 37% this year, to average US$40.5/barrel, before they recover to US$45/b next year. Real GDP will contract in all regions in 2020, but the drop in output will be especially severe in OECD countries, at 6.3%. All G7 countries and all but two G20 countries (China and Indonesia) will experience a full-year recession, and the US's output will contract by 5.3%. Asian countries will recover most quickly, with some (including India and South Korea) returning to pre-coronavirus GDP levels in 2021. Of the G7 countries, Germany's output will also be back to 2019 levels in 2021, but others will recover more slowly, with GDP returning to 2019 levels in 2022 for Canada, France and the US, 2023 for the UK and 2024 for Italy and Japan. Most countries have responded with fiscal programmes to support businesses and households, raising the risk of sovereign debt crises in the medium term. Central banks have cut interest rates and, more importantly, have stepped up as buyers of last resort for government and corporate debt.
Asia and Australasia will experience a recession in 2020 for the first time since 1998, with regional real GDP forecast to contract by 1.8%. All countries in the region will see their economic performance affected by demand slumps caused by lockdowns within their own borders and those introduced in other countries. Among the region's major markets, Singapore is forecast to experience the steepest economic contraction in 2020, at 6%, followed by India, Thailand and Japan. Some trade-dependent economies, such as South Korea and Taiwan, will evince a degree of economic resilience because their early response to the pandemic allowed them to avoid costly nationwide lockdowns. Parts of Asia are still expected to post GDP growth in 2020, albeit at a much less rapid rate than normal. Vietnam's economy will grow by 3.3% this year, while China's is forecast to expand by 1.4%, despite a steep economic contraction in January-March. While the pace of recovery will be sequentially weak in Asia in 2021, with many countries still forced to implement localised (if not national) lockdowns, a low comparison base will help to ensure that real GDP rebounds to growth of 5.5% that year.
The political and geopolitical effects of the crisis will be significant. The pandemic has resulted in an extraordinary expansion of executive powers, with limited parliamentary oversight. Elections have been cancelled or delayed in some countries. When the pandemic has passed, governments' handling of the response will face scrutiny. Failure to address the humanitarian crisis triggered by the coronavirus could further erode trust in national institutions. A severe global economic crisis, followed by large-scale unemployment, could fuel a new wave of popular protests. The crisis may encourage support for the nation state and a backlash against globalisation and open borders. It will also intensify the competition for global leadership between China and the US, and a realignment of geopolitical spheres of influence may ensue in Europe, Africa and other region.
Thailand has been in a state of emergency since March 24th, which grants the prime minister, Prayuth Chan-ocha, the power to enforce measures restricting some rights and liberties normally guaranteed by the constitution. His emergency decree has banned public gatherings, including protests, as well as publications that are deemed to cause public unrest. The government has also denied entry to all foreigners except holders of residential and some business visas. Since mid-May, however, most shops and malls have reopened, and the country has also started to allow domestic travel, as the pandemic appears to have been brought under control. The total number of cases remained at around 3,200 at the end of July, as the daily total of new cases had fallen to single digits. Despite an apparent improvement in the situation, the government is likely to extend the emergency decree for another month, to end-August. This has raised fears that Prayuth could take advantage of the crisis to crack down on his political opponents, amid growing criticism of his government's early response to the outbreak.

We expect the economy to shrink by 5.3% this year amid the coronavirus (Covid-19) pandemic, which will curtail Thailand's export revenue-most notably in its tourism sector. Consumer spending will also suffer as unemployment and pay cuts in the external sector mount.
We expect exports of goods and services to contract by 14.9% in real terms in 2020. The steep decline will be driven mainly by the loss of 70% of tourism revenue, as we expect inflows of Asian tourists to begin to recover only towards the end of 2020, with a full recovery not expected until 2022. This partly results from the fact that it will take much longer for Western tourists to return, considering the longer-lasting damage to those economies. Export volumes for both merchandise and services will rebound robustly but not fully in 2021, posting growth of 11.9% as external demand picks up again.
The stimulus packages in 2020 will help to slow the contraction, but not significantly. Facing an inevitably damaging decline in domestic and external demand, the measures are primarily about preventing widespread bankruptcy and cushioning the blow to livelihoods, rather than boosting output.
In the medium term, Thai automotive exporters are likely to reap moderate benefits as multinationals diversify their regional supply chains. This will partly reflect strategies to mitigate US-China trade tensions, which are likely to intensify despite the "first-phase" trade agreement between those countries. The shock from the coronavirus outbreak has also demonstrated the risks of over-reliance on China-centric supply chains. Following a year of recovery in 2021, we expect trade growth to firm further from 2022 as producers of parts and vehicles start to move up the value chain through knowledge-intensive manufacturing, and as the development of the EEC strengthens Thailand's competitiveness.
Total fixed investment will contract by 7.6% in 2020, as businesses struggle to stay afloat amid a substantial decline in demand. Foreign capital will shun fixed assets in emerging markets (which are seen as risky at a time of uncertainty) in favour of safer and more liquid alternatives. The government is prioritising cushioning the blow, rather than boosting investment growth. With a decent economic recovery beginning in 2021, we expect investment growth to average 5% a year in 2021-24. This is because of our assumption of overarching political stability, which will ensure policy continuity, including a focus on major infrastructure upgrades. A large share of this will take place within the EEC under the Thailand 4.0 initiative, which should encourage additional investment by private businesses.
Private consumption will contract by 3.1% in 2020 amid mass unemployment in the tourism sector and quarantine measures. Even after a strengthening of the economy takes shape from 2021, high levels of personal debt and a relatively high share of the workforce in lower-wage agriculture will continue to constrain household spending prospects. This will ensure that private consumption grows at a markedly slower pace in Thailand than in many of its regional peers in 2022-24.


Enlarge this image.
Economic forecast: Sectoral trends On the supply side of the economy, we expect the industrial sector to grow at an annual average of 2% in 2020-24. The coronavirus pandemic has dealt a heavy blow to Thailand's export-oriented manufacturing sector, in particular the automotive industry. A weakening in global demand, which will not fully recover until at least 2022, will weigh on growth in the industrial sector in 2020-21. In the latter part of the forecast period, industrial production will accelerate amid increased public investment in infrastructure. Thailand will likely not benefit significantly from the relocation of supply chains away from China amid ongoing US-China trade tensions. This reflects concerns over the country's increasingly expensive labour and a relatively small pool of skilled workers compared to the rapidly growing regional economies.
The services sector will continue to be dominated by tourism The services sector will grow by an annual average of 1.5% in 2020-24. Tourism, which accounts for over 70% of Thailand's services exports, will suffer a historic decline in 2020 and not recover fully until at least 2022. We expect onerous travel restrictions and quarantine measures to remain in place until early 2021, which will essentially halt inbound tourism. During such time, the importance of tourists from China and domestic tourism will grow. We expect China to emerge in relatively good shape from the pandemic in 2021. Stronger rates of growth in this subsector will eventually resume in the latter part of the forecast period, as Thailand's retains its attraction as a key tourist destination.
Meanwhile, the financial sector will remain relatively healthy. Although the ratio of non-performing loans (NPLs) to total loans is likely to surge amid the pandemic, the sector will be able to weather the storm with its adequate capitalisation and a competent central bank. However, household debt remains elevated, which will crimp demand and dampen the expansion of the sector as a whole in 2020-24. In the first quarter of 2020 household debt rose to 79.8% of GDP, from 79.1% in late 2019. Elsewhere, the telecoms segment industry will see strong growth towards the end of the forecast period as the consumer electronics cycle recovers from its slump and the rollout of 5G networks is mostly completed. This will allow firms to meet surging demand for mobile internet services and will dovetail with the continued expansion of e-commerce platforms in the country.
The agriculture sector will remain vulnerable to extreme weather cycles, including droughts and floods. Productivity is also likely to suffer as tentative efforts to reform the sector are repeatedly set back by implementation issues and lack of government attention, which will also mean that producers are largely unable to upgrade from current basic technologies. Some industries, such as fishing, will struggle early in the forecast period as the industry adapts to Western countries' market-access requirements regarding labour rights. These weaknesses will ensure that farmers remain an important interest group for the new government. We expect the agriculture sector to grow by an annual average of 2.1% in 2020-24.

Consumer prices will experience deflation in 2020, at -0.2%, for the first time since 2015. This reflects the impact of declining global commodity prices, which we expect to remain low until 2021. Price pressures will weaken further this year against the backdrop of a rare fall in domestic demand, prompted by the coronavirus-related lockdown.
Stronger global economic activity and rising energy prices thereafter will help to lift average annual inflation to 1.7% in 2022-24. This rate will remain well below that of Thailand's regional peers, mainly reflecting underwhelming growth in household consumption.

Dim prospects for the economy amid the pandemic, particularly in the tourism sector, have undermined investor sentiment towards the local currency, the baht, since the beginning of the year. This will result in an overall weakening of the currency against the US dollar in 2020 compared with the pre-coronavirus level last year. However, Thailand's persistent current-account surplus and foreign-exchange reserves will lend strong support to the exchange rate throughout the forecast period, ensuring that any depreciation remains mild and transitory (including the one related to the pandemic earlier this year). The BOT will also continue to intervene to prevent excessive volatility in the baht. These factors will help to stabilise the currency at around Bt31.5:US$1 in the latter part of the forecast period.

We expect the current-account surplus to narrow to 3.4% of GDP in 2020, amid a deep recession. The drastic decline in inbound tourism resulting from the coronavirus outbreak will contribute to this, as the services account is set to record a rare and sizable deficit. A broad slowdown in exports, driven by the pandemic-induced global recession, will also result in a consider-able fall in outbound merchandise shipments, which will be offset slightly by a surge in demand for gold and electronics products amid worldwide lockdowns. Nonetheless, an even steeper decline in imports, attributable in part to tumbling global oil prices, will ensure a widening trade surplus compared with 2019.
Merchandise shipping and inbound tourism will post a strong recovery in 2021 as the coronavirus outbreak fades. Thereafter, the current-account surplus will average 7.4% of GDP per year in 2022-24. This will broadly mirror fluctuations in the trade surplus, which will be determined in large part by global oil prices and external demand for Thai goods.
The primary income account will remain firmly in deficit in 2020-24, reflecting the continued repatriation of profits and dividends by foreign-owned firms. The wide deficit will be reduced slightly by a consistent surplus on the secondary income account from personal transfers, notably remittances.


Enlarge this image.
Economic forecast: Foreign direct investment in Thailand Stocks and flows Net foreign direct investment (FDI) inflows had increased steadily in 2015-19, owing to a more stable political environment and the previous junta's efforts to attract infrastructure investment, which included a range of incentives and the liberalisation of strategic industries. The coronavirus (Covid-19) shock will halt such growth in 2020, but expectations of policy continuity under Prayuth's government and gradual recovery of external demand should see an increase in inflows from 2021, assuming that the pandemic eases by then. Outward investment, particularly to countries within the Association of South-East Asian Nations (ASEAN), is also expected to increase later in the forecast period after the pandemic. In 2019 the stock of inward FDI stood at US$268bn, equivalent to 49.3% of GDP, while the stock of outward FDI stood at US$152bn.
Origin and distribution The private manufacturing sector has traditionally attracted the largest proportion of FDI into Thailand. In particular, manufacturers of automotive parts and producers of electronics and electrical appliances have attracted significant foreign interest. In recent years, however, the financial and real-estate sectors have also gained prominence, particularly as industrial production faces bottlenecks and weak external conditions prevail even before the pandemic. Japanese firms retain their position as the main investors in Thailand, but investment from China has greatly increased in the past few years. Chinese investors, at least as much as their Japanese counterparts, are likely to gain from Thailand's infrastructure development plans, but this will come in the form of vendor contracts in construction, logistics planning and technology.
Determinants Thailand has traditionally been an attractive investment destination, owing to its relatively decent infrastructure, flexible labour laws and advantageous location within the region. Nonetheless, any sign of political instability, which remains a persistent risk, as well as growing regional competition, will pose challenges to Thailand's attractiveness in the medium term. The Board of Investment (BOI) offers incentives, which generally take the form of exemptions from corporate income tax and reduced taxes on imported machinery. The BOI also offers non-tax incentives, including granting permission to bring in foreign workers, to own land and to take or remit foreign currency abroad. Indeed, the new large-scale Eastern Economic Corridor (EEC) special economic zone (SEZ) includes fast-tracked environmental assessments as an incentive. Thailand has generally been regarded as one of the most open economies in the region to foreign investment. The BOI's seven-year investment promotion strategy, launched in 2015, has continued to extend incentives to newer industries such as "alternative energy and environmental services" and "hospitality and wellness", while removing existing incentives in certain low-value, labour-intensive industries. The BOI has also been encouraging investment into infrastructure, through a number of big-ticket projects. In addition, it has expedited the investment application and approval process in recent years, and is likely to retain this as a priority to lure back foreign investors after the pandemic. Disagreements from lawmakers and sometimes within the governing coalition will slow the pace of decision-making on investment related to expensive infrastructure mega-projects.
Impact Large FDI inflows have helped to support overall economic growth and have contributed to Thailand's development as a leading exporter to other countries in Asia in a number of sectors, including vehicles (particularly light pick-up trucks), electronics (especially computer parts) and electrical appliances. Reliance on FDI has nonetheless compounded the economy's already significant exposure to external conditions.
Potential Thailand's political scene has stabilised since the public approval of the junta-drafted constitution in a referendum in 2016 and the smooth accession of the new king. After a brief period of uncertainty around the election held in March 2019, political stability will be maintained in 2020-24. Serious challenges to the new political structure are unlikely to materialise before 2023, which bodes well for steady FDI flows in the forecast period. The volatile nature of Thailand's politics will remain a risk, however. A number of other challenges may limit the potential for strong growth in FDI in the next five years. Thailand's attractiveness as a location for investment has been diminishing because of a rising relative cost base (particularly for labour) and sluggish domestic demand compared to other markets in the region. Although the current administration will maintain the junta's commitment to liberalisation, mainly through the legally binding 20-year National Strategy, access to strategic sectors such as telecommunications, media and utilities remains difficult. The standard of infrastructure in the country has improved in recent years, but it remains inferior to Malaysia, a rival manufacturing location, while poorer competitors such as Vietnam begin to catch up. The junta-drafted infrastructure development programme, which the government will follow, will rectify this shortfall to a degree. Thailand will continue to attract foreign investment by virtue of its leading position in the development of the ASEAN Free-Trade Area, but there is a rising risk that it may lose out to others in the region as they make improvements to their business environments at a faster rate.

Effective family-planning programmes and changing social norms, such as later marriage and smaller families, will keep Thailand's average population growth rate relatively low, at 0.2% a year, in the forecast period. By 2024 the population is forecast to reach 70.3m, with females accounting for 51.5% of the total. Owing to continued improvements in healthcare and childbirth procedures, the infant mortality rate will drop to an average of 8.2 per 1,000 live births in the forecast period, from 9.2 per 1,000 in 2015-19. Life expectancy will also improve, with men expected to live for an average of 73.5 years in 2020-24, up from 72.2 in 2015-19, while female life expectancy will rise from an average of 79.6 to 80.9 years over the same period.
Demographic ageing will raise pressure on healthcare provision and finances Thailand's population is ageing, with the proportion aged under 15 falling steadily from 2011. Meanwhile, the proportion aged over 65 is set to grow to 15.3% in 2024, up from 12.3% in 2019. This will mean that the young-age dependency ratio falls to 0.22 in 2024, from 0.25 in 2014, while the old-age dependency ratio rises from 0.14 to 0.22 over the same period. This demographic trend will place further strain on healthcare provision. The country's health system is structured around a universal healthcare scheme that was introduced in 2001 and has been free for all citizens since 2006. The Economist Intelligence Unit expects this scheme to remain free in the forecast period. It will, nonetheless, face growing burdens resulting from the country's rising levels of air pollution and ageing population.
Road accidents will continue to be a leading cause of death The crude death rate is forecast at 8.3 per 1,000 in 2020-24. Non-communicable illnesses such as heart disease, stroke and respiratory diseases are responsible for 74% of all deaths in Thailand, according to the World Health Organisation (WHO). The WHO also reports in 2015 that Thailand has the world's second-highest road traffic fatality rate, at 36.2 per 100,00 population. Deteriorating air quality-pollution levels in Bangkok and northern provinces hit record highs in recent years, including 2019-also poses a threat of increased premature deaths and health burdens. Meanwhile, Thailand continues to confront the challenge of preventing the spread of HIV/AIDS, which emerged as the country's leading cause of death in the early 2000s. The UNAIDS estimates the death rate from the disease at around 21 per 100,000 people in 2019, although 470,000 people continued to live with the disease in that year. Other infectious diseases, such as cholera, measles and mumps, have become less common but have not been eradicated.
The labour market will tighten owing to the ageing of Thailand's population, and shortages of skilled labour are likely to become more pronounced in the next five years. The size of the labour force will contract slowly, dropping to 37.5m by 2024, owing to a decline in the working-age population. Migrant labour will return from an anticipated hiatus in 2020 and remain abundant post-pandemic, with workers from neighbouring Myanmar, Cambodia and Laos dominating unskilled jobs in the construction industry and as household employees. However, Thailand will gradually become a less attractive destination for unskilled migrants over the long term. In the near term, this will partly reflect a less welcoming stance on the part of the authorities and the general public, who are keen to channel unskilled migrant labour into legitimate strategic industries in border-located special economic zones. In the longer term, job opportunities in Myanmar, Cambodia and Laos will expand as those economies record faster growth than Thailand
Rural-urban migration is still a significant demographic trend Despite slow population growth, the number of households in Thailand is expected to rise strongly in the forecast period, with a subsequent reduction in average household size. Internal migration and changing social patterns mean that it is increasingly common for households to consist of nuclear rather than extended families. Steady economic expansion in recent years has encouraged this trend, as migrant workers from rural areas have been moving to the major cities, and particularly the metropolitan area centred on the capital, Bangkok. Although Bangkok remains the main focus for the urban population, other cities, including Surat Thani, Chiang Mai and Hat Yai, have also been growing rapidly. The share of rural population stood at almost 50% in 2019 according to the World Bank, which is quite high by the standard of middle-income countries. This means that further expansion of metropolitan cities amid growing urbanisation will continue to feature as a prominent demographic theme in the forecast period.

Thailand constitutes a sizeable market in its own right, with a population of 69.6m and nominal GDP equivalent to around US$543.8bn at market exchange rates in 2019. Moreover, the development of the Association of South-East Asian Nations (ASEAN) Free-Trade Area means that goods exported from Thailand will continue to enjoy almost entirely duty-free access to ASEAN's market of 500m, including a burgeoning middle class with growing disposable income.
The Economist Intelligence Unit forecasts that aggregate personal disposable income will grow at a slower rate in 2020-24 than it did in 2015-19, primarily because disposable income will suffer a rare fall in 2020 amid the pandemic. Growth will resume in 2021 at a steady pace. A more alarming challenge in the longer term will be the wide wealth gap, which will widen with lower socio-economic groups being disproportionately affected by the ongoing pandemic. According to the latest data from the Asian Development Bank (ADB), of the 9.9% of the population defined as living below the nationally defined poverty line in 2018, the majority reside in the rural north and north-eastern parts of the country. This number will only grow in the aftermath of the pandemic, and it will take several years for it to come down again. The capital, Bangkok, remains the wealthiest region by far. Structural issues, such as the fact that opportunities in rural areas remain limited compared with urban centres, will remain largely unaddressed.
High household debt will limit growth in consumption in 2020-24 Household spending will be tempered by still-high personal debt. In particular, debt burdens among those on lower incomes have a significant negative impact on consumer demand overall and limit the prospects for social mobility among this group. This will particularly affect the share available for spending on consumer goods, ensuring that Thailand's retail goods market experiences relatively low growth compared to its neighbours. Following a year of relatively modest growth in 2021, the release of pent-up demand will help to underpin retail sales in 2022-23, as the economy fully rebounds from a deep pandemic-induced recession. On average, retail sales volumes will grow by 2.5% a year in 2020-24.

Private consumption will grow by an annual average of 2.9% in 2020-24, slower than the rate of 3.5% in 2015-19. In the early part of the forecast period, a fall in household income and macroeconomic uncertainty amid the pandemic will dampen consumer sentiment. In 2020-21 the government will expand policies aimed at supporting consumption through cheap loans and cash handouts aimed at helping low-income and unemployed citizens. Given the frail state of private consumption, the value-added tax (VAT) rate is likely to be frozen at the current level of 7% until later in the forecast period. The government will finance such emergency measures by running a larger budget deficit and increasing borrowing. Meanwhile, higher "sin taxes" on sugar, alcohol and tobacco will have a minor impact on the consumption pattern of the population at large.
Discretionary spending will remain low in the early parts of the forecast period Consumer expenditure on essential items, such as food, household goods and clothing, will rise as a proportion of total expenditure as average incomes fall and remain stagnant in the early parts of the forecast period. The average individual outlay on hotels and restaurants is likely to see a marked decline as a result of a much reduced number of international tourists in 2020-21. This will only be marginally offset by government efforts to promote domestic tourism as foreign tourists tend to spend more on this category on average. A similar situation applies to other categories of discretionary expenditure such as leisure, which will plunge in 2020 and not return to pre-pandemic level until 2022. Growth in healthcare spending is forecast to increase steadily in 2020-24 with an ageing population in the forecast period. The projected increase in spending on transport and communications will largely reflect the expanding market for and popularisation of information technology (IT) products, which will be boosted by faster and cheaper internet services following state-led upgrades.

From May 2019 The Economist Intelligence Unit's long-term growth forecasts have been revised to take into account the economic impact of climate change.
Initial conditions: The past two decades have been characterised by political turmoil, with coups in 2006 and 2014 and many (sometimes violent) anti-government protests and rallies. Economic growth has been volatile in the years since the 2008-09 global financial crisis owing to natural disasters and political crises. Physical infrastructure remains inadequate in many respects. Reform of the education system has long been promised, but successive governments have largely failed to modernise the quality of teaching or the curriculum. The workforce is therefore characterised by a low level of technical skills-a problem made worse by rapidly demographic ageing. On top of these long-standing structural issues, the current government will also have to deal with a battered economy in the aftermath of the coronavirus (Covid-19) pandemic.
Demographic trends: Slower population growth and longer life expectancies will account for the ageing population. While female labour force participation rate will have risen by 2030, this will not prevent an average annual contraction of almost 1% in the labour force in 2031-50. Nevertheless, a gradual loosening of regulation concerning immigrants' right to work, especially in skilled positions, will preclude a steeper fall in the size of the workforce. Successive governments are likely to be forced to ease immi-gration and long-term visa policies further, owing to the country's negative demographic profile. The effectiveness of this will be limited by concerns among immigrants regarding rising inter-ethnic tensions, worsening air pollution and the growing attractiveness of neighbouring regions.
External conditions: Thailand faces a challenging external environment in the period to 2050. Although many export-oriented, labour-intensive industries will shift away from China, Thailand will struggle to capitalise on this opportunity owing to a lack of competitiveness compared with lower-cost locations, such as Cambodia and Vietnam. New regional rivals will also gain ground, including Laos and Myanmar. Closer integration with China could open up market opportunities for Thai businesses in more niche subsectors. One possibility is that Thailand may develop itself as a services centre for China, meeting that country's increasing demand for foreign holidays, regional-specific agricultural goods and other niche products. The government is already spearheading a move in that direction under its "Thailand 4.0" industrial policy and, in part, via its new Eastern Economic Corridor special economic zone (SEZ). This is particularly the case for the tourism sector, and the ongoing expansion of transport infrastructure will go some way to supporting these aims. Similarly, economic and trade links will be strengthened by the development of overland transport routes between China and Thailand in the next decade or so. The development of the ASEAN Economic Community, formally established in 2015, will motivate business and technical innovation in Thailand to the degree that the country retains its prominence in the region. In 2020-30 a relocation of regional supply chains will pick up pace amid increased trade and geopolitical tensions. Although Thailand will benefit from these shifts, gains will be limited by the attractiveness of regional competitors such as Taiwan and Vietnam.
Institutions and policy trends: In the coming decades, there will be no resolution of the power struggle between the established military and older bureaucratic elites in the capital, Bangkok, who will continue to side with the palace to bolster their legitimacy, and the rural as well as younger masses that form the majority of the Thai electorate. The level of political tension will depend on successive governments' ability to restructure the economy further away from agriculture and tourism, not least by moving a far greater proportion of the workforce into high-value industry and services. Democratically elected governments might be successful in instigating such a shift with the introduction of appropriate electoral reform, as well as a focus on medium-to-long-term rural development policies, rather than just short-term relief measures.
Long-term performance: The long-term outlook for Thailand's economy is heavily dependent on whether future governments prove capable of initiating and implementing the required structural reform that will continue into the medium-to-long term, while also upgrading infrastructure. Liberalisation in a number of important sectors, such as power and communications, will help Thailand to regain some of its competiveness relative to its regional neighbours. The effects of an ageing population on the budget could be offset by greater use of advanced healthcare technology and 5G-enabled technologies. On the issue of boosting productivity to rival Thailand's competitors, the government could improve educational attainment on the part of the existing workforce. However, progress is likely to be slow in both areas. A more probable and effective measure would be greater immigrant access to the labour market, although rising ethnic tensions could undermine its implementation.
