From May 2019 The Economist Intelligence Unit's long-term growth forecasts have been revised to take into account the economic impact of climate change.
Long-term outlook: Long-term trends Climate change and sustainability Thailand published a long-term climate change adaptation plan in 2015, entitled the Climate Change Master Plan 2015-50. It outlines a three-pronged approach divided into mitigation, adaptation and capacity-building targets. The near-term goals included setting emission-reduction targets and establishing incentives for low-carbon-emission development. Medium-term targets included reaching at least 25% of energy consumption from renewable sources. Longer-term targets are vaguer, with general goals to increase private investment in green industries and to reduce the carbon intensity of the economy. In line with this plan, Thailand signed and ratified the Paris Agreement of the UN Framework Convention on Climate Change (COP21) in 2016, committing to specific targets for the reduction of greenhouse gas emissions. Under COP21, Thailand has pledged to reduce its greenhouse gas emissions by 20% from the projected business-as-usual forecast by 2030. The latest government figures in 2020 show reasonable results in the country's push to reduce greenhouse gas emissions. More crucial to meeting the climate target by 2050 will be more far-reaching and costly measures, such as carbon pricing.
The main determinant of emissions levels in Thailand in the coming decades will continue to be energy sourcing. Coal-fired power plants generate close to one-fifth of the country's electricity, while lesser-polluting liquefied natural gas (LNG) facilities account for nearly two-thirds of electricity generation. Most of these plants are situated in the south of the country. The government will continue to push for the expansion of renewable energy sources as a share of the country's energy mix, and renewable energy is likely to account for around one-quarter of total generation capacity by 2040. The commissioning of nuclear power plants in Thailand, which would reduce reliance on high-polluting forms, is also a possibility. However, the relatively low prices of coal and gas will mean that these continue to account for the majority of energy generation over the next two decades.
The country, especially its most economically productive areas including Bangkok, will be vulnerable to the intensified impact of climate change in the coming decades. This will be felt most acutely through the rising sea level, flooding, droughts and air pollution, which will in turn feed into economic insecurity, infrastructure strains, health burdens and social unrest. In 2019 we developed a model to calculate the impact of climate change on long-term growth. Our latest calculations find that the Thai economy will be 2.2% smaller in 2050 than it would have been without this hit to growth.
Technological developments In May 2016 the junta unveiled "Thailand 4.0", a sector-specific industrial policy that aims to attract new investment in the transformation of the economy. The name of the strategy describes the intended next stage in the sectoral development of the economy, characterised by the industrial application of state-of-the-art technology. It follows the current domestic industrial situation, which is dominated by heavy industry with advanced machinery, in segments such as automotive and chemicals production. While the pandemic in 2020 will force the government to make some changes to the initiative in the forecast period, the key focus of the Thailand 4.0 strategy in the longer term will return to strategic industries where value can be added via new technologies; these include smart electronics, high-income and medical tourism, agriculture and biotechnology, food and beverages, and the automotive industry. It will also extend to the development of new industries, such as robotics, aerospace, digital services, bioenergy and biochemicals, and healthcare. Incentives for investment in these sectors will remain in place for several years and are explicitly targeted towards the introduction of new technology, for example by offering import-duty exemption on capital goods for listed industries. Thailand will make some progress in upgrading its industries, but is likely to be constrained by a limited supply of skilled labour.
Long-term outlook: Methodology for long-term forecasts The time horizon for the detailed forecasts and analysis in the Country Forecast report is a five-year period. The Main report also carries a section on the long-term outlook, including projections of key macroeconomic and market size variables up to 2050. Depending on the indicator, average growth rates in a sub-period or values at select points in time are reported. Many companies make strategic business decisions over timeframes in excess of five years. The Economist Intelligence Unit's long-term projections will provide information to facilitate such decisions. Long-term forecasts and scenarios are also vital in understanding some of the big economic issues that will shape global business in the coming decades. We are well placed to build on and extend the five-year forecasts to produce long-term projections and scenarios because of the existing forward-looking analysis and models in the Country Forecast (in particular, the business environment rankings model). These are used to forecast some of the key drivers of long-run growth, as explained in detail below.
Growth projections The main building blocks for the long-term forecasts of key market and macroeconomic variables are long-run real GDP growth projections. We have estimated growth regressions that link real growth in GDP per head to a large set of growth determinants. The determinants of growth consist of the scope for convergence (based on initial GDP per worker at the start of a period); demographic variables; a set of policy variables (measuring the fiscal stance, openness to trade, and the government regulatory burden in product, credit and labour markets); a measure of institutional quality; geography (climate, location and the degree of primary export orientation); education levels and labour quality (as measured by mean years of schooling and life expectancy); the external economic environment (changes in the terms of trade); the level of development of information and communications technology (ICT); and historical legacies (history of independent statehood).
The regressions, which have high explanatory power for growth, allow us to forecast the long-term growth of real GDP per head for sub-periods up to 2050, on the basis of demographic projections and assumptions about the evolution of policy variables and other drivers of long-term growth.
Definitions of variables The dependent variable is GDPG: Average annual growth in real GDP per head, measured at national constant prices.
The independent variables include: LnGDPPL: The natural logarithm of GDP (adjusted for purchasing power parity-PPP) per worker (that is, per population aged 15-65) in constant 1980 US dollars at the start of each decade. Expressed as an index, US$=1.
LnSCHOOL: The natural logarithm of the mean years of schooling of the population aged over 15 at the start of each decade. Missing values for some countries are filled in by estimating mean years of schooling on the basis of an equation relating mean years of schooling (where available) to gross primary school enrolment ten years previously, and to secondary and tertiary enrolment ratios five years previously.
LnLIFEEXP: The natural logarithm of life expectancy at birth at the start of each decade. This variable also enters the equation in squared form, reflecting diminishing returns to growth of increases in life expectancy at high levels.
OPEN: Updated Sachs-Warner index of openness-the fraction of years during each decade in which a country is rated as an open economy according to the following four criteria: (1) average tariff rates below 40%; (2) average quota and licensing coverage of imports of less than 40%; (3) a black-market exchange-rate premium that averaged less than 20%; and (4) no extreme controls (taxes, quotas, state monopolies) on exports.
INST: Index of institutional quality (on a scale of 1-10) that is an average of five sub-indices of measures of the rule of law, quality of the bureaucracy, corruption, the risk of expropriation and the risk of government repudiation of contracts. Forecast values are based on corresponding indicators from our business environment rankings.
LABPOP: The difference between the growth rate of the working-age population (aged 15-65) and the growth rate of the total population in each decade.
TOT: The average annual rate of change of the terms of trade in a given decade.
GOVSAV: The average government savings ratio in each decade (current government revenue minus current government expenditure) expressed as a share of GDP.
TRADESH: The average share of trade (exports and imports of goods and services) in GDP, lagged by one decade to deal with the endogeneity of growth and trade.
GOVREG: An index on a scale of 1-10 of regulation of product, credit and labour markets. For forecast periods, the composite index is based on seven indicators from three categories of our business environment rankings model-from Policy towards private enterprise (ease of setting up new businesses, freedom to compete, price controls); from Financing (openness of the banking system, financial market distortions); and from Labour markets (restrictiveness of labour laws, wage regulation).
ICT: An index, on a scale of 1-10, of the development of information and communications infrastructure.
Control variables include PRIMARY: share of the exports of primary products in GDP at the start of a decade; TROPIC: percentage of the land area within a country that has a tropical climate; COLONY: history of independent statehood-a dummy variable taking the value of 1 if a country was a colony before 1945; and, in some specifications, regional dummy variables.
Summary of findings As in other studies, income per head and human capital are found to be important determinants of growth, with the coefficient on the logarithm of GDP per worker suggesting a relatively modest pace of convergence. The measures of institutional quality and of government regulation enter significantly in all specifications. We found a strong positive impact on growth of government savings and openness in all specifications. The criteria for classifying countries as open are quite permissive. The crucial aspect of trade policy captured by the measure is that it is a high level of distortion, rather than modest levels, that is deleterious for growth. The trade share variable is also moderately significant. The openness index (which is more of a true measure of policy) is hardly affected by the inclusion of trade/GDP shares in the equation. The correlation of the two measures is only .26. Although a tropical climate is highly significant, as is the share of primary exports in GDP, other geographic indicators-such as access to the sea, distance from major growth centres and the proportion of the population residing near coastlines-were not significant. A colonial past (pre-1945) is found to have a significant negative impact on growth, even in more recent periods.
Productivity growth The forecasts of GDP growth, of capital stock growth (based on estimated investment shares and assumed depreciation rates) and of growth in labour supply (based on projections of working-age population and assumptions on labour force participation) yield labour productivity growth and total factor productivity growth forecasts. The latter utilise the growth accounting identity, GY=b*GK+c*GL+A, where GY is growth of real GDP, GK growth of the capital stock and GL growth of human capital (the labour force adjusted for changes in skills). "A" stands for growth in total factor productivity; "b" and "c" are the shares of capital and labour in income. Trade values are forecast on the basis of simple import (function of GDP and relative prices) and export functions. Forecast market exchange rates (that is, the differential between PPP and market exchange rates) depend on the differential in labour productivity growth between a country and the US.

Data sources and definitions The sources for global and domestic data refer to historical data. The source for all forecast data, unless otherwise stated, is The Economist Intelligence Unit
Global data US & OECD GDP growth: OECD
World trade growth: Economist Intelligence Unit aggregate
US consumer price inflation: OECD
Oil prices: dated Brent Blend
Non-oil commodity prices: IMF, IFS
Manufactures prices: UN, Monthly Bulletin of Statistics
Domestic data GDP growth: Bank of Thailand, Annual Report; Asian Development Bank, Key Indicators
US$ GDP: IMF, IFS
Population: Asian Development Bank, Key Indicators; UN, World Development Report
GDP per head: nominal GDP divided by population
Inflation: consumer price index, Department of Business Economics, Ministry of Commerce
Budget: fiscal year (October-September)
Wages: local-currency wage data derived from minimum-wage data, inflated to correspond with occasional UNIDO data for US dollar manufacturing-sector wages
Exchange rates: IMF, IFS
Commercial banks' prime rate: Bank of Thailand, Quarterly Bulletin
Balance of payments: IMF, IFS
Foreign debt: World Bank, International Debt Statistics; OECD, External Debt Statistics (for data on short-term debt)
Abbreviations IFS: International Financial Statistics
UNIDO: UN Industrial Development Organisation
Guide to the business rankings model Outline of the model The business rankings model measures the quality or attractiveness of the business environment in the 82 countries covered by Country Forecast using a standard analytical framework. It is designed to reflect the main criteria used by companies to formulate their global business strategies, and is based not only on historical conditions but also on expectations about conditions prevailing over the next five years. This allows The Economist Intelligence Unit to utilise the regularity, depth and detail of its forecasting work to generate a unique set of forward-looking business environment rankings on a regional and global basis.
The business rankings model examines 11 separate criteria or categories, covering the political environment, the macroeconomic environment, market opportunities, policy towards free enterprise and competition, policy towards foreign investment, foreign trade and exchange controls, taxes, financing, the labour market, infrastructure and technological readiness. Each category contains a number of indicators that are assessed by The Economist Intelligence Unit for the last five years and the next five years. The number of indicators in each category varies from five (foreign trade and exchange regimes) to 13 (political environment), and there are 91 indicators in total.
Almost half of the indicators are based on quantitative data (eg GDP growth), and are mostly drawn from national and international statistical sources for the historical period (2015-19) and from Economist Intelligence Unit assessments for the forecast period (2020-24). The other indicators are qualitative in nature (eg quality of the financial regulatory system), and are drawn from a range of data sources and business surveys adjusted by The Economist Intelligence Unit for 2015-19. All forecasts for the qualitative indicators covering 2020-24 are based on Economist Intelligence Unit assessments.
Sources used in the business rankings model include Akamai Technologies, State of the Internet; CIA, World Factbook; The Economist Intelligence Unit, Country Risk Service, Country Commerce, Democracy Index, Risk Briefing; IMF, Annual Report on Exchange Arrangements and Exchange Restrictions; International Institute for Management Development, World Competitiveness Yearbook; International Labour Organisation, International Labour Statistics Yearbook; International Telecommunication Union, ICT Indicators Database; Transparency International, Corruption Perceptions Index; UN Conference on Trade and Development, Ecommerce Index; World Bank, World Development Indicators, Doing Business; World Economic Forum, Global Competitiveness Index; World Intellectual Property Organisation, IP Facts and Figures.
Calculating the rankings The rankings are calculated in several stages. First, each of the 91 indicators is scored on a scale from 1 (very bad for business) to 5 (very good for business). The aggregate category scores are derived on the basis of simple or weighted averages of the indicator scores within a given category. These are then adjusted, on the basis of a linear transformation, to produce index values on a 1-10 scale. An arithmetic average of the ten category index values is then calculated to yield the aggregate business environment score for each country, again on a 1-10 scale.
The use of equal weights for the categories to derive the overall score reflects in part the theoretical uncertainty about the relative importance of the primary determinants of investment. Surveys of foreign direct investors' intentions yield widely differing results on the relative importance of different factors. Weighted scores for individual categories based on correlation coefficients of recent foreign direct investment inflows do not in any case produce overall results that are significantly different from those derived from a system based on equal weights.
For most quantitative indicators the data are arrayed in ascending or descending order and split into five bands (quintiles). The countries falling in the first quintile are assigned scores of 5, those falling in the second quintile score 4 and so on. The cut-off points between bands are based on the average of the raw indicator values for the top and bottom countries in adjacent quintiles. The 2015-19 ranges are then used to derive 2020-24 scores. This allows for intertemporal as well as cross-country comparisons of the indicator and category scores.
Measurement and grading issues The indices and rankings attempt to measure the average quality of the business environment over the entire historical or forecast period, not simply at the start or at the end of the period. Thus, in the forecast we assign an average grade to elements of the business environment over 2020-24, not to the likely situation in 2024 only.
The scores based on quantitative data are usually calculated on the basis of the numeric average for an indicator over the period. In some cases, the "average" is represented, as an approximation, by the recorded value at the mid-point of the period (2017 or 2022). In only a few cases is the relevant variable appropriately measured by the value at the start of the period (eg educational attainments). For one indicator (the natural resources endowment), the score remains constant for both the historical and forecast periods.

Full text: - The outbreak of the coronavirus resulted in the imposition of significant restrictions on economic activity and population, generating a recession in 2020, with output contracting by 5.5% for the full year. Fiscal stimulus measures, as well as a substantial decline in oil sector revenue, will generate a looser fiscal stance that will persist throughout the forecast period (2020-24).
- Norway has a history of coalition governments and cross-party consensus, delivering high levels of political stability. The constitution does not allow for the dissolution of parliament. The ruling coalition comprises the Conservatives, the Liberals and the Christian Democrats (KrF) as a minority government, with 61 seats in the 169-seat parliament. The next election is in September 2021, and The Economist Intelligence Unit expects the centre-right bloc to re-enter government, owing to its competent handling of the coronavirus outbreak.
- We expect real GDP to contract by 5.5% in 2020, owing to the fallout from the virus. We do not expect a reimposition of a lockdown even in the event of a revival of infections. The economy will recover from 2021 to 2024, reaching 2019 levels by 2023, and growth averaging 2.4% as restrictions on mobility recede.
- We estimate that inflation will soften to 1.2% on average in 2020, from 2.2% in 2019, owing to worsening economic conditions, but pressures on core inflation from rising food prices pose an upside risk to price growth. Economic recovery will generate a rebound in inflation throughout the forecast period, generating inflation averaging 1.6% in 2021-24.
- In March Norges Bank (the central bank) reversed much of its monetary tightening, lowering interest rates by a total of 125 basis points, to 0.25%. Core inflation is falling as demand declines, and rates are expected to remain stable until the end of 2020. A steady policy of normalisation will follow, with policy rates reaching 1.5% by 2024.

- Norway's business environment score rises slightly for 2020-24, as the economy has become more resilient following oil industry reforms. Backed by vast oil wealth, the political and economic environments are robust, and financing opportunities should remain firm. Norway lags regional peers owing to limited market opportunities, tight labour market regulation and high wages.

Country forecast overview: Norway's business environment at a glance Policy towards private enterprise and competition 2020-21: Low regulatory burden, but probable rise in already high level of state influence in the economy, following emergency policy measures in response to the coronavirus pandemic and related temporary lockdown.
2022-24: A strategic plan guides the Norwegian Competition Authority to raise sectoral competition and procurement rules.
Policy towards foreign investment 2020-21: Generally positive attitude towards attracting foreign direct investment, but capital inflows constrained by weak global economy and new domestic investment screening regime that can block investment on national security grounds.
2022-24: The economy further diversifies investor countries beyond Europe, although to limited effect.
Foreign trade and exchange controls 2020-21: Absorbing the shock to global trade from the coronavirus will be a major theme, with a discussion around "reshoring" strategic industries away from China likely to follow the immediate crisis.
2022-24: No change in policy towards joining the EU or leaving the European Economic Area (EEA). A reassessment of EEA membership is possible, but unlikely. Efforts to promote bilateral trade deals continue.
Taxes 2020-21: Temporary stimulus measures and easing of tax-payment requirements for firms in response to coronavirus.
2022-24: Government investigates reform of subsidy regime for oil and gas exploration. Expansion of environmental taxes to meet climate change goals.
Financing 2020-21: Significant expansion of central bank liquidity to support functioning of financial markets. Policy interest rates remain at record-low level. Private-sector balance sheets weakened by economic fallout from the crisis.
2022-24: Credit demand likely to remain subdued following the crisis, but opportunities could emerge for growth of non-bank financing channels, including private equity and venture capital. Tighter anti-money-laundering rules.
The labour market 2020-21: The coronavirus shock leads to a sharp increase in unemployment
2022-24: Improvements in employment and wages follow the crisis. Skills shortages remain an issue in some sectors.
Infrastructure 2020-21: Government applies 12-year transport plan (2018-29) and raises funds available for maintenance and construction of infrastructure projects. Gradual roll-out of fifth-generation (5G) mobile services.
2022-24: Investments in new road and rail transport links are made. Digital infrastructure upgrades continue.
Technological developments 2020-21: Implementation of Norway's cyber-defence strategy, after cyber-attacks on national infrastructure.
2022-24: The Open Artificial Intelligence (AI) lab grows in size and importance, underpinning AI preparedness.

Background: The Labour Party governed almost continuously in 1935-65, dominating until 2001, when a minority coalition comprising the Conservatives, the Christian Democrats (KrF) and the Liberals swept to power. In 2005 Labour returned to office in a centre-left coalition with the Socialist Left Party (SV) and the Centre Party-the first majority government in two decades-lasting until 2009. The September 2013 election led to a regime change, with a minority right-of-centre coalition of the Conservatives and the Progress Party (FrP) taking office. The centre-right coalition was re-elected in 2017. The Conservatives and the FrP were joined by the Liberals in January 2018 and by the KrF in January 2019.
Political structure: There is no right of dissolution between elections. Norway uses a modified proportional representation system: 150 out of the 169 members of the unicameral Storting (parliament) are "district mandates" elected by open-list proportional representation. The remaining 19 seats, the "levelling mandates", are distributed only between the parties that get more than 4% of the national vote and whose initial seat count (out of 150) is not proportional to their share of the vote.
Policy issues: The centre-right government will try to implement additional business-friendly policies and tax cuts, focused on further reducing the negative spillover effects of lower oil prices on wider economic activity and on strengthening the mainland economy. Spending from Norway's oil fund is expected to rise, but it will remain comfortably within the country's fiscal guidelines. Despite a cross-party agreement on tackling climate change, tension will persist in the Storting over the balance between industrial development and environmental protection.
Taxation: At the start of 2016 most parties agreed on a multi-year corporation tax reduction (from 27% to 23% by 2018) to improve competitiveness in the economy; it has since been reduced to 22% in 2019. Oil companies pay an additional flat-rate tax of 50% on income derived from the extraction, processing and transport of oil, but benefit from a 78% tax refund on the costs of exploration for oil and gas. The capital-gains tax was cut from 28% to 27% in 2014. The ordinary rate of value-added tax (VAT) is 25%. The top marginal income tax rate is 54.3% (including employers' social security contributions).
Foreign trade: Oil and gas output and prices greatly affect Norway's trade flows. The petroleum industry contributes about half of total goods export revenue. In 2016 the trade account registered its lowest level since 1999, but has been recovering since. The current-account surplus increased to US$16.7bn in 2019, down from US$31.1bn in the previous year. The trade and current-account balance will remain in surplus throughout the forecast period (2020-24).

Outlook for 2020-24: Political stability The current ruling coalition, comprising the centre-right Conservatives and two small centrist parties-the Liberals and the Christian Democrats (KrF)-is coming to the end of its term in September 2021. The coalition rules as a minority government, with just 61 members in the 169-seat parliament, after the far-right Progress Party (FrP) withdrew from government in January 2020 after a coalition dispute over infrastructure. Given the nearing of the next general election, scheduled for September 2021, and a strong tradition of political consensus, The Economist Intelligence Unit does not expect a change in government.
Despite the government being a minority in parliament, it is able to pass legislation with the backing of the FrP (which has pledged to support it in significant parliamentary votes). The ruling coalition can also rely on the support of other opposition parties (such as the centre-left Labour Party). Although the FrP will probably withdraw its support for the government on some matters (preventing the proposal of some legislation), the damage to political stability would be low, as the constitution prohibits a pre-term dissolution of parliament, and therefore a snap election.
In the near term the outbreak of the novel coronavirus has strengthened the stabilising influences on the political outlook. The government has mostly unwound its restrictions on social interaction, after being among the first group of European countries to experience an outbreak of the disease. Public support for the ruling parties has strengthened markedly during the crisis, and political support for the lockdown was wide-ranging. Despite the economic disruption caused by the lockdown, there has been no increase in support for populist parties in Norway. Populist movements have historically had limited electoral appeal in the country, as the far-right FrP takes a largely pragmatic approach to government, in contrast with other European populist movements. Their presence has only a marginal impact on political stability, as the domestic political culture is highly consensus-driven, with frequent collaboration between the government and opposition parties on a range of issues.
Outlook for 2020-24: Election watch The next general election will be held in September 2021. The Storting (parliament) cannot be dissolved before completing a full four-year term, meaning that there is no risk of a snap election. A change in government is also not part of our forecast.
Although the handling of the coronavirus crisis is likely to shape political preferences in the run-up to the election, it is unclear how much of an effect it will have by September 2021. The governing bloc of right-wing parties (excluding the FrP) have seen their popular support increase in the wake of the pandemic, a feature common to most countries. We expect the government's competent handling of the coronavirus crisis to place the right-wing bloc in a good position before the election in 2021, although the decline in support for the FrP since 2017 means they may not be able to produce a stable majority.
Outlook for 2020-24: International relations EU relations will remain a significant foreign policy issue, and may steadily encroach on domestic politics as environmental affairs become increasingly prominent. As a member of the European Economic Area, Norway has access to the single market (in exchange for contributions to the EU budget), but must accept relevant EU regulations while having limited influence over them. This has historically been accepted as a substitute for outright EU membership (which has been rejected twice in national referendums in 1972 and 1994), but mounting concern over economic diversification and a reduction in carbon emissions has pushed environmentalist parties (the Greens and the Liberals) to support outright EU membership. Although we do not expect Norway to join the EU without a national referendum, political pressure for a third plebiscite on the matter may grow in tandem with environmentalist influence in the government. Norway will be under continued pressure to raise its defence spending, which at 1.8% of GDP, is below NATO's 2% target. Greater commitments to increase spending will take time to implement, and will probably only be met by the end of 2024.
Outlook for 2020-24: Policy trends The country has recorded a steady increase in coronavirus cases, in tandem with other European countries, since social distancing measures were largely unwound from June onwards. The number of new cases recorded each day rose from 9 on July 24th to 59 on August 8th. The increase in cases has primarily been among young people, meaning mortality rates remain low, but a substantial "second wave" of viral transmission (and death) through the wider population remains possible. The rise in cases has halted government efforts to loosen social distancing measures, and the imposition of regional controls (similar to those seen throughout Europe) is likely to form a component of the government's new anti-virus strategy.
Nevertheless, a revival in some control measures in economically concentrated areas (such as Oslo) remains a substantial risk to our economic forecast in 2020-21 and will probably curtail the extent of the recovery in headline output, as fear of infection will supress demand. Countervailing this, a rise in infections is likely to be met with a more robust public response. Although the lockdown has proved economically costly, it has given time for improvements in the capacity of the healthcare system and in a trace and quarantine system that will reduce the spread of the virus even without a vaccine.
Outlook for 2020-24: Fiscal policy Like other European countries, Norway has announced fiscal stimulus in the wake of the coronavirus outbreak, although this is much smaller than in peer economies. Given a long history of fiscal probity, Norway has a greater level of fiscal space than most, meaning that we expect public debt to remain below 60% of GDP throughout the forecast period. Total discretionary stimulus has amounted to about Nkr160bn (US$16bn), or about 5.5% of mainland GDP. The budget that the government presented in October 2019 has been abandoned as the disruption from the coronavirus generates a dual shock to both the mainland and oil sectors. The government's new budget, presented in mid-May, targets a substantial with-drawal from the Government Pension Fund Global (GPFG; 4.2% of its value) to fund further expenditure, in breach of the government's fiscal rule to not withdraw more than 3% of the sovereign fund's value in any year. We expect that the government will have to lean on the fund for further fiscal support in the coming years, but this will not diminish its vast size. For the first time since 1993, this will not be enough to prevent a deficit in 2020, which we forecast at just 0.9% of GDP.
Existing government support for the labour market is similar to the measures implemented in response to the coronavirus in neighbouring countries. Under the system of permittering, the government temporarily pays a large portion (more than 60%) of the wages of workers who are placed on furlough. Expanded take-up of this scheme, although it will preserve much of the existing labour market for the duration of the pandemic, will leave the government liable for a significant increase in spending.
On the employer side, fiscal support has expanded rapidly. The government has deferred tax payments and purchased corporate bonds on the secondary market, reducing borrowing costs for businesses. About Nkr20bn has been set aside as a crisis fund to cover fixed costs for businesses during the coronavirus pandemic, modelled on the Danish fund set up for this purpose.
Outlook for 2020-24: Monetary policy In response to the substantial disruption caused by the pandemic, Norges Bank (the central bank) has lowered the policy rate by 150 basis points since February, to 0%-the lowest rate in modern history. This unprecedented monetary easing was completed over three meetings of the monetary policy committee. The central bank also lowered countercyclical capital buffers for major banks from 2.5% to 1% to ensure bank solvency and expand credit growth.
We expect Norges Bank to maintain its highly accommodative policy until the end of 2021, given the lingering uncertainty around the evolution of the pandemic, which will continue to weigh on business and consumer confidence. There are likely to be substantial scarring effects on both output and employment from the virus, with major risks to Norway's oil sector, with looser monetary policy required to accelerate the recovery in the near term. Looking ahead, Norges Bank targets inflation of "close to 2% over time", and the policy rate should rise steadily after 2021 when economic conditions improve. The steady rise in oil prices, the gradual recovery of the domestic economy and the revival in global trade should all generate a steady normalisation of interest rates over the forecast period.
Outlook for 2020-24: Economic growth Despite the shift in policy towards a steady easing of lockdown restrictions, the gradual pace of withdrawal throughout the second quarter of 2020 will guarantee a contraction in April-June, after an initial decline of 1.6% in the first quarter. With most forms of the lockdown extending from March 12th to June 15th we judge that the bulk of the decline will take place in the second quarter, as 11 of the 14 weeks of restrictions took place in that time. The economy will rebound only in the latter half of 2020 as control measures subside and economic activity improves, bringing full-year output down by 5.5% from 2019. The recent increase in viral infections could generate a reimposition of some social distancing measures, which would curtail the extent of the recovery. We judge that long-term scarring from the crisis will be significant, but modest compared with peer economies, as government support for short-term disruption to the labour market will remain substantial.
The coronavirus pandemic and the subsequent lockdown will primarily affect consumer spending and export demand in Norway, which we expect to decline by 6.9% and 11.8% respectively. On the consumption side, the imposition of social distancing measures damages consumer spending both directly, through the prevention of consumer activities such as services spending, and indirectly, through a decline in total employment and consumer spending power. On the external side, similar lockdowns among major trading partners (namely the UK and Germany) will weigh on demand for major exports, such as energy goods and shipping.
The export-oriented oil and gas sector will be especially damaged by the outbreak. Demand for both gas and oil globally is strongly pro-cyclical and Norway's entrenched exposure to markets in Europe (the region worst hit by the crisis) implies a substantial contraction in real exports this year. Although firms within Norway's oil sector (especially Equinor, the state-backed oil firm) remain far from insolvency, real exports and the outlook for investment in the sector have worsened significantly.
Investment in both the oil and non-oil sectors will also weaken, as uncertainty around a possible recurrence of the virus (at least until a vaccine is produced) will chill investor appetite for risk, and cuts in oil sector production will weigh on the returns of offshore projects. Growth will recover more substantially from 2021 onwards as economic life returns to normal and the risk of a reimposition of controls steadily abates. However, the prospect of lasting damage to household balance sheets (with household debt at 110% of GDP in December 2019), business confidence and oil investment will keep real GDP below pre-crisis levels until 2023.
Outlook for 2020-24: Inflation The pandemic and consequent lockdown has weighed on consumer prices, with the collapse in energy prices and demand for non-essential goods pulling down price growth. Headline inflation initially fell from 1.8% in January to 0.7% in March. Nevertheless, now that restrictions are being lifted, inflation has started to pick up pace again, rising to 1.4% in July. Rising core inflation, owing to an uptick in food prices, to over 2.6% in July, will erode consumer purchasing power.
Looking ahead, we expect that the disruptive effects of the coronavirus on consumer demand and oil prices will drag down inflation in 2020, to an average of 1.2%. This trend will be supported by an easing in household stockpiling as controls on social distancing abate, and as the fall in oil prices (which we expect to average US$40.5/barrel this year) ripples through the economy. The recent appreciation of the currency should also curtail inflation. A stronger than expected recovery in consumer spending continues to pose upside risks for inflation.
Outlook for 2020-24: Exchange rates The krone has largely followed the substantial changes in global energy markets since January. Between end-2019 and end-June, it depreciated by roughly 7.2% on a trade-weighted basis, as the price of oil has collapsed from US$65/b to US$42.8/b and economic activity has slowed.
Although the krone has strengthened from its nadir in March (when it had depreciated by over 17% since December), conditions of subdued demand and slower growth are likely to prevent the krone from fully returning to its December value until 2024, when oil prices have recovered, and production is restored. Further downward shocks to oil prices, chiefly from shocks to global demand, remain a risk to our exchange-rate forecast.
Outlook for 2020-24: External sector Norway's current-account surpluses are structurally supported by large inflows on the trade and primary income accounts, respectively reflecting the economy's position as a major oil exporter and the size of the GPFG.
Although inflows in both of these components will be damaged by the economic fallout from the coronavirus, we do not expect either of these accounts to fall into deficit. Oil exports will be damaged by the proposed cuts to production, but we expect that this will be balanced by the reduction in goods imports, keeping the trade balance in surplus despite the fall in oil prices.
As the coronavirus abates, steady rises in oil prices from 2021 onwards will further support the trade balance, and increases in production (barring any government intervention) will continue throughout the forecast period. We expect that this, combined with a revival of growth in major trading partners (particularly Germany), will support a rise in the current-account surplus over the forecast period, to 5.4% of GDP in 2024.

Full text: - The Economist Intelligence Unit believes that the prime minister, Narendra Modi, and the Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) will retain significant support and tight control over the government until 2024. We expect the BJP-led coalition to gain control of the Rajya Sabha (the upper house of parliament) by end-2020, which will give the administration power to pass legislation unilaterally. The government's Hindu-nationalist agenda will cause social tensions to rise in the longer term. The relationship with China will become more strained during the forecast period, while India will be more aligned with the US on strategic matters.

- The business environment will improve in 2020-24, owing in part to increased political effectiveness as the BJP-led government increases its representation in the upper house, which will enable it to enact legislation unchallenged. An anticipated improvement in the infrastructure category has also helped to push up the overall score. However, improvements elsewhere mean that India's global ranking rises only slightly, from 62nd in the historic period to 58th out of the 82 countries assessed. Among its BRICS peers, India scores better than Russia (5.51) but fares worse than Brazil (6.11), China (5.96) and South Africa (6.04).

- Economic growth in fiscal years 2020/21-2024/25 (April-March) will be below potential, averaging 3.7% per year, owing to significant disruption to business activities and the unabated local spread of the coronavirus (Covid-19) pandemic in 2020, despite containment measures. The administration will pursue an expansionary fiscal policy in the early part of the forecast period as it attempts to cushion the negative impact of containment measures used to limit the spread of the coronavirus. We expect the budget deficit to narrow from 2021/22 as a gradual revival in economic activity boosts revenue collection, allowing the administration to accord a higher priority to fiscal consolidation. The Indian rupee will face downward pressure over the next five years, owing to the country's current-account deficit from 2021 and relatively high rates of inflation. We expect the Reserve Bank of India (RBI, the central bank) to cut interest rates in the remainder of 2020 and to start to tighten monetary policy only in late 2021.

- India's economy will benefit from a growing population, and the labour force will expand by 0.5% a year on average in 2020-24. However, reaping the full benefits of the country's young population will prove immensely difficult amid a shortage of suitable employment opportunities. Large skills gaps will persist owing to inadequacies in the education system. The tertiary education sector will broadly underperform, with the exception of a few pockets of excellence. Underemployment and unemployment will add to social tensions. This will be exacerbated by a wide gender imbalance. Continued migration into towns and cities from the countryside will also add to existing economic and social stresses in urban areas.

- Sustained real GDP growth from 2021/22 will support the outlook for wage growth and assist the expansion of the middle class, even as average national GDP per head remains low, at US$2,606 in 2024. The consumer market will return to growth as the pandemic eases and a vaccine becomes available from end-2021. Growth will be supported by rapidly rising income levels among the huge population of around 1.4bn. We also expect that more households will be able to afford relatively high-value products. The e-commerce sector will expand strongly with higher smartphone and internet penetration.

- India's economy will grow substantially, supported by a shift in employment from rural to urban areas. However, income inequality will become more pronounced and lead to heightened social and political tensions. India's growing economy will make it an increasingly influential diplomatic force. Owing to shared strategic geopolitical and economic interests, India will move closer to the US and Japan. The continuing rivalry for influence in South Asia will weigh on ties with China.

Background: India gained independence in 1947 after two centuries of British colonial rule. Partition at the same time created the state of Pakistan, with which India has fought three wars (two of them over the disputed territory of Kashmir). India is the second-most populous country in the world, with an estimated 1.37bn people in 2019, according to the UN. Its economy was the third-largest in the world in 2019 (measured in nominal US dollars at purchasing power parity exchange rates by the World Bank).
Political structure: India has been a democracy since independence. At federal level, the Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) holds a majority in the Lok Sabha (the lower house of parliament), although it governs in a broader coalition, the National Democratic Alliance. India follows the UK model of parliamentary government, with a prime minister as head of government. It has a president as the head of state. The country has a quasi-federal structure, with state governments having their own legislatures and enjoying a fair degree of freedom.
Policy issues: We expect the ruling BJP to undertake policy reforms once the coronavirus (Covid-19) pandemic passes. The government has already announced measures to privatise or merge public-sector units in many industries to promote competition. The government will also make modest progress on the liberalisation of regulatory requirements and foreign investment. However, the primary focus of the government will be on structural reform, particularly the contentious labour and land laws. We expect only incremental progress on these issues. The current administration has made headway in speeding up infrastructure projects, and this will also remain a priority in the next five years.
Taxation: The government will maintain efforts to broaden the tax base in 2020-24, including by further digitising tax departments. This, coupled with strong economic growth after 2020, will support a pick-up in tax collection. Despite some reforms, including a nationwide goods and services tax in 2017, India's tax system will remain highly complex.
Foreign trade: India's merchandise trade deficit narrowed to US$157.7bn in 2019, from US$186.7bn in 2018, while the surplus on the country's services account rose from US$80.8bn to US$84.2bn in the same period.

Political outlook: Political forces at a glance India's constitution came into effect in 1950, underpinning the country's democratic system of governance. The state is technically secular, giving no preference to any of the manifold religious or social groups. India's democracy is well entrenched and elections for the national and state parliaments have been held for decades. The country's two major political parties are the Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP), the dominant component party of the ruling National Democratic Alliance (NDA), and the Indian National Congress, which governed the country for decades, often in coalition with smaller regional parties. Regional parties are prominent in many state assemblies, enabling them to wield significant influence on national politics through the Rajya Sabha (the upper house of parliament). The BJP holds a majority in the Lok Sabha (the lower house) and governs with the support of smaller parties in the NDA. The BJP currently falls short of a majority in Rajya Sabha, but we expect it to secure enough seats to attain a majority in this chamber before the end of 2020.
The BJP's ideological approach leans towards Hindu nationalism, mixing social conservatism with a more aggressive foreign and security policy. Its growing dominance of national and state governments has thus challenged India's secular tradition. The party has moved recently to extend its vote base beyond its roots in the urban middle class by adopting more rural-focused policies. Congress has a more centre-left ideological approach to socio-economic issues.

Political outlook: Political stability The BJP won the majority of seats in the election for the Lok Sabha that took place in April-May 2019. The Economist Intelligence Unit expects the central government to remain in power for its full term, which ends in 2024. The results of the 2019 election were a testament to the popularity of the prime minister, Narendra Modi, who will remain the dominant figure in the government. Decision-making will remain centralised among the prime minister's office and key ministers.
In late March the government implemented what has been among the most stringent lockdown measures around the world, designed to stem the spread of the coronavirus (Covid-19). These measures were initially welcomed by the public as an effective method of containing the virus. However, the unabated spread of the epidemic and the extensive economic damage caused by the restrictions highlight the risk of social unrest. The government's inability to provide large-scale income support will challenge the administration. We expect the government's reform agenda, especially the liberalisation of labour laws, to be another source of tension. However, these developments will not unseat the government; this is because of the formidable support it enjoys from a large part of the citizenry and the lack of a strong opposition.
Over the medium term, protests by religious groups and communal clashes will continue to pose a threat to political stability. Large-scale protests tied to the Citizenship Amendment Act were only cut short by social distancing measures introduced to slow the spread of the virus. In contrast to the country's current secular constitution, several far-right groups, including some affiliated with the BJP, have long been pushing for India to be recast as a Hindu nation-a view that puts them at odds with minority groups in the country, notably Muslims. The risk of social instability is high in the latter part of the forecast period, particularly in the two-year period prior to the 2024 general election, if the ruling party moves ahead with its Hindutva (Hindu nationalist) agenda.
The security situation in the centrally administered territory of Jammu and Kashmir (J&K) will remain a central concern throughout the forecast period. We expect security risks in the area to remain high. Any attempt by protesters to destabilise the region is likely to face a heavy-handed response from the government, including the use of internet shutdowns, curfews and riot-control forces. The government's move has also increased the risk of terrorist attack by separatist forces in major Indian cities such as Delhi and Mumbai. A deadly border clash with Chinese troops in June 2020 will also affect political stability. Vocal domestic demands for a strong response pose political risks for Mr Modi, who will be reluctant to risk military escalation.
Political outlook: Political and institutional effectiveness The outlook for political and institutional effectiveness in 2020-24 is mixed. The BJP dominates the political landscape at national and-increasingly-state level. Some members of state legislative assemblies have defected to the BJP. The party has full control of the lower house, and its re-election in 2019 will help to bolster policy effectiveness. It will soon attain a simple majority in the Rajya Sabha, after which it will be able to pass legislation without approval from the opposition. This will ease the passage of laws in parliament, although we believe that the BJP's growing dominance will also result in greater levels of corruption within the party.
Support for the BJP and Mr Modi has been relatively high in 2020, as the government acted swiftly to implement a lockdown to limit the spread of the coronavirus. However, that support might weaken as the toll exacted on the economy by the measures becomes more pronounced. However, the administration will actively pursue its Hindu nationalism agenda to woo supporters. Since we do not believe the BJP can go too far in pushing forward labour law and land acquisition reform, we expect it to win a few more state elections within the forecast period, which will help it to consolidate its power.
The BJP has been an advocate of so-called competitive federalism, which encourages competition between India's states. We believe that this approach will lead to a notable improvement in political and institutional effectiveness in reform-oriented states, particularly in the south and the west. However, it is also likely to deepen economic disparities between India's more economically successful states and its laggards, increasing social friction, competition for fiscal resources and pressure for migration between regions.
The BJP's dominance of national and state politics will have a corrosive impact on institutional checks and balances within India during 2020-24. There have already been signs that the government has successfully pressured media groups to rein in critical coverage. The independence of the Reserve Bank of India (the central bank) has also been eroded. There remains a significant risk that the government will engage in a major confrontation with the judiciary at some point in the next five years, particularly if judges overturn a key policy decision, such as the move to revoke the special status of J&K in 2019. Judicial challenges to the government's policies towards minority religions could also be a point of friction.
Political outlook: Election watch The next general election is expected to be held around May 2024. The focus before then will be the state assembly elections. The results of the previous state elections suggest that voters treat state and national elections differently, and that local issues tend to be more important in the former. We expect the BJP coalition to gain control of the state assembly in the upcoming Bihar election, to be held in October-November 2020, but only with the help of its coalition partner in the state.
In the Rajya Sabha, the BJP and its allies form the largest grouping, although they command fewer than half of the seats. Nevertheless, we expect the BJP-led NDA to win control of a majority in the upper house by the end of 2020 after elections in key seats in November. This will enable the alliance to pass legislation without opposition approval. However, it will struggle to win the two-thirds majority needed to make constitutional changes unchallenged.
Political outlook: International relations Tensions with Pakistan have persisted amid the dispute over J&K. We expect relations to remain strained, but do not anticipate a complete breakdown of diplomatic ties. We believe that Pakistan's military will increase its support for militant groups in Indian-controlled Kashmir. This will raise the risk of terrorist attacks by non-state actors. Although small-scale military exchanges between the two countries are likely to occur in 2020-24, the nuclear arsenal of the two countries will act as a powerful deterrent against full-scale conflict.
A deadly border clash between China and India in June has led to a substantial deterioration of bilateral relations. India has taken steps to retaliate economically against China, such as toughening the approval process for Chinese investments and increasing non-tariff barriers on Chinese exports to India. Economic retaliation by China will focus primarily on tit-for-tat tariff increases, rather than more detrimental export restrictions that could disrupt supply chains for Indian firms. We also expect further skirmishes tied to infrastructure development in border regions disputed by the two countries. However, large-scale military clashes are not within our core forecast.
Souring ties with China will encourage India to improve relations with the US, Japan and Australia, among other countries. India's foreign policy within South Asia will also focus on countering increasing Chinese influence in Nepal and Sri Lanka. India's relations with Bangladesh will remain cordial.
