India's overall score in The Economist Intelligence Unit's business environment rankings rises to 5.74 in 2020-24, from 5.25 in 2015-19. However, improvements elsewhere mean that its global ranking rises only slightly to 58th out of the 82 countries assessed, from 62nd in the historic period. Among its BRICS peers, India scores better than Russia (5.51) but fares worse than Brazil (6.11), China (5.96) and South Africa (6.04). India's score is dragged down by weak ratings for policy towards private enterprises & competition and the labour market.
The huge opportunities presented by India's enormous population and rapidly growing economy contribute to a strong (albeit declining) score for market opportunities: indeed, India ranks eighth in the world in this category in our forecast period (2020-24), up from 12th in the historical period. We expect infrastructure to improve markedly in 2020-24. The country will also score relatively well in terms of technological readiness, largely reflecting its well-developed internet and telecommunications sectors. Political effectiveness will be bolstered when the coalition led by the Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) coalition secures a majority in the Rajya Sabha (the upper house) before the end of 2020, improving the political environment. Still, despite the improvement the score for political effectiveness will remain poor, at just 4.2.
Infrastructure will register the largest gains We see the score for foreign trade and exchange controls improving in 2020-24 as the government looks to support India's development as a centre for export manufacturing. However, in the areas of financing, taxes and foreign trade & exchange controls India will remain a global laggard. While the country will still draw inward investment seeking to tap its huge market opportunities, the difficult business operating environment (for both foreign and local firms) will serve as a drag on productivity, holding back the economy's potential.


Enlarge this image.
Business environment outlook: India's business environment at a glance Policy towards private enterprise and competition 2020-21: The government takes steps towards partial privatisation of some state-owned companies in 2021.
2022-24: The government continues to rationalise liquidation and bankruptcy laws to simplify the closure of loss-making businesses or merger-and-acquisition activity involving other corporate entities.
Policy towards foreign investment 2020-21: The government's policy towards foreign direct investment (FDI) will remain ambiguous. Some companies face a lengthy approval process
2022-24: Foreign investment in export manufacturing increases markedly, albeit in only a few regions. Strong growth in e-commerce and the expanding Reliance Jio telecommunications platform will attract FDI from leading internet firms.
Foreign trade and exchange controls 2020-21: The country remains reluctant to join major regional trade deals. However, the government seeks to hold talks with members of the OECD to strengthen trade links.
2022-24: Full capital-account convertibility remains off the policy agenda.
Taxes 2020-21: Rationalisation of the goods and services tax (GST) continues, resulting in a reduction in the number of tax bands. Tax breaks and rebates are made available to businesses and individuals affected by the coronavirus (Covid-19) outbreak.
2022-24: Alcohol and petroleum products remain outside the scope of the GST.
Financing 2020-21: The Reserve Bank of India (the central bank) relaxes regulatory norms for debt-laden banks and non-bank financial companies, raising risks to banking-sector stability but improving the availability of funding for corporates.
2022-24: Private-sector banks account for a rising share of total lending, while bad debt issues persist in public-sector banks. Major consolidation and privatisations among the public-sector banks will continue.
The labour market 2020-21: Unemployment soars in the wake of a nationwide lockdown and the retention of restrictions in various states. Use of the rural employment guarantee scheme increases.
2022-24: Some labour reforms make headway at state level. However, reforms at the central government level remain stuck, owing to a lack of political consensus in support of the changes.
Infrastructure 2020-21: The government increases its budgetary allocation for the expansion of healthcare facilities in response to the coronavirus outbreak.
2022-24: As some projects near completion, India's infrastructure improves in terms of broadband connection speed, distribution, road and rail networks, ports and transport infrastructure, as well as electricity and office space supply.
Technological readiness 2020-21: Most technological innovation continues to be concentrated in a few clusters, such as Bangalore. Expenditure on research and development as a proportion of GDP remains low by Asian standards.
2022-24: The government makes efforts to digitise the delivery of public services, in an effort to cut corruption and promote the efficiency of "last-mile delivery". In this context, the Aadhar biometrics platform boosts government service delivery.
Business environment outlook: Macroeconomic environment                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2015-19 2020-24 2015-19 2020-24 2015-19 2020-24
6.6 6.1 54 47 15 14
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 17 countries: Australia, Bangladesh, China, Hong Kong, India, Indonesia, Japan, Malaysia, New Zealand, Pakistan, Philippines, Singapore, South Korea, Sri Lanka, Taiwan, Thailand and Vietnam.
Twin deficits on the current and fiscal accounts will persist in 2021-24 India's score for the macroeconomic environment falls to 6.1 in 2020-24, from 6.6 in 2015-19, on account of a substantial contraction forecast for real GDP in fiscal year 2020/21 (April-March). The imposition of a nationwide lockdown between March 24th and June 8th and the maintenance of restrictions in a number of states will cause the economy to contract at its fastest rate on record in the current fiscal year. However, the country's global ranking for 2020-24 has risen from 54th to 47th; although we expect the economy to contract in 2020/21, we still expect it to be among the fastest-growing economies in the world over the remainder of the forecast period. Twin deficits on the fiscal and current accounts beyond 2021 will remain one of the weakest aspects of the macroeconomic environment. We forecast the current-account deficit to persist after 2021 and to widen over the forecast period owing to a persistent goods trade deficit. Fiscal pressure will be stronger, despite rising tax collection from 2021, as the government outspends its receipts to fund burgeoning development projects. The coronavirus (Covid-19) will force the government to consolidate public finances only gradually, and the fiscal deficit will remain at an elevated level during the forecast period. The erosion of the independence of the Reserve Bank of India (RBI, the central bank) in recent years will weaken the management of monetary policy. Consumer price inflation will pick up as consumer demand and global oil prices recover.
Business environment outlook: Policy towards private enterprise and competition                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2015-19 2020-24 2015-19 2020-24 2015-19 2020-24
4.5 5.0 58 55 11 11
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 17 countries: Australia, Bangladesh, China, Hong Kong, India, Indonesia, Japan, Malaysia, New Zealand, Pakistan, Philippines, Singapore, South Korea, Sri Lanka, Taiwan, Thailand and Vietnam.
The score for policy towards private enterprise and competition improves to 5 in 2020-24, from 4.5 in 2015-19, largely owing to efforts to privatise state-owned enterprises, which will reduce the distorting impact of the state sector on the economy, and improvements in the protection of intellectual property (IP). However, owing to progress elsewhere, this improvement in the score has only a modest impact on India's global rankings in this category. The government has made progress on streamlining the bureaucracy and merging some ministries, easing the approval process for industrial and infrastructure projects. It has also encouraged competition between states by devolving power to them to experiment locally with pro-business liberalisation in special economic zones. According to a statement made in parliament in March 2020 by the commerce minister, Piyush Goyal, the states of Andhra Pradesh, Telangana, Haryana, Jharkhand and Gujarat have the highest ranking in terms of the ease of doing business within India. Despite these state-level measures, however, the scope for improvement remains immense and more reforms will come within the forecast period.

- The government has gradually raised targets for disinvestment (a term that includes privatisation receipts) and seeks to raise Rs2.1trn (US$28bn) in 2020/21. The National Democratic Alliance (NDA) administration has habitually fallen short of its disinvestment targets, and delays to planned sales will continue amid opposition from unions and other vested interests. Nevertheless, we expect the government to achieve substantial levels of privatisation in 2020-24, including the sale of loss-making entities such as Air India and a telecommunications firm, MTNL. The successful privatisation of the Life Insurance Corporation of India in the forecast period would signal a strong commitment to privatisation, as this long-mooted move has been opposed vehemently by employees.
- The government's drive to expand the use of public-private partnerships, notably in rail and digital communications infrastructure projects, will create opportunities for private firms in the next five years. However, there is a substantial risk that firms will experience problems in correctly pricing bids for such projects, which may render many unprofitable.
- We expect the protection of IP in India to improve over the next five years. This will reflect pressure from domestic companies to toughen enforcement as local levels of investment in research and development (R&D) increase. The regime is nonetheless likely to remain patchy, with courts in more developed parts of the country offering better levels of protection than those in poorer regions. Reform and strengthening of the Intellectual Property Appeal Board would provide further impetus for improved protection of IP rights.

Business environment outlook: Policy towards foreign investment                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2015-19 2020-24 2015-19 2020-24 2015-19 2020-24
5.5 6.0 63 56 15 11
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 17 countries: Australia, Bangladesh, China, Hong Kong, India, Indonesia, Japan, Malaysia, New Zealand, Pakistan, Philippines, Singapore, South Korea, Sri Lanka, Taiwan, Thailand and Vietnam.
Regulatory changes will make India a more attractive destination for FDI India's score for policy towards foreign investment improves to 6 in 2020-24, from 5.5 in 2020-24. The improvement is driven by friendlier government policy towards foreign capital. This enables India's global ranking to rise from 63rd to 56th, even as other countries have also made headway in their efforts to attract foreign investors. The NDA government, led by the BJP, has pursued gradual liberalisation of the foreign-investment regime in recent years. The administration reinforced its commitment in the budget for 2020/21, particularly in the energy and infrastructure sectors. Nevertheless, some important sectors of the economy, such as multi-brand retail and banking, will remain subject to foreign investment caps. Discrimination and restrictions against investment from China will be extended in the next few years, as India strives to shield the domestic market from Chinese influence, owing to strategic competition in the region. Levels of foreign direct investment (FDI) in India averaged US$44.2bn a year between 2015-19, but will decline to US$40.4bn on average in 2020-24 as the impact of the coronavirus pandemic hurts investor sentiment and reduces willingness to commit to large investments abroad.

- The government will seek to give added impetus to its "Make in India" campaign and the "self-reliant India" package, which seeks to boost local manufacturing during 2020-24. Notably, it will offer added tax incentives to major foreign investments in advanced production fields such as semiconductors, solar cells, lithium batteries and servers. India will attract some manufacturers, particularly as international firms shift some production out of China amid growing concerns over rising labour costs and trade conflicts. Moreover, the impact of these initiatives on the economy will remain limited, owing in part to continued problems with the business environment in areas such as land acquisition.
- The 2020/21 budget underscored the government's commitment to attract foreign capital and expertise to strengthen the ailing domestic power sector. By reducing the corporate tax rate for power-generation firms to 15%, the government raised the possibility of greater participation by foreign firms in this critical sector in the future.
- E-commerce rules that came into effect in February 2019 generated opposition from foreign investors in the sector. The rules notably bar companies from selling products via firms in which they have an equity interest and from establishing special arrangements with suppliers to sell exclusively on their sites. A news agency, Reuters, reported in mid-2019 that a US retail giant, Walmart, had argued that the rules discriminate between large foreign e-commerce companies and their domestic counterparts. The issue is likely to be a point of discussion between negotiators seeking to resolve India-US trade tensions. Given the evolving state of e-commerce legislation in India, the rules are likely to be tweaked in 2020-24 in a way that addresses some of the complaints of foreign investors.

India's large online market will attract considerable FDI
- We expect the broader online market to attract a considerable amount of FDI over the forecast period as US and European firms vie to establish a presence. The Reliance Jio platform, the country's largest online platform, with more than 400m subscribers, will prove particularly attractive for foreign firms by offering a simpler way to operate in the Indian online technology market. For instance, local media reported in July 2020 that Google (US) would invest US$4.5bn for a 7.7% stake in the platform. Additional investments from other US-based firms (such as Facebook) indicate that foreign investors are willing to deploy capital in India, given the size of the domestic market. Chinese investors used to participate actively in Indian internet start-ups. However, ongoing bilateral tensions between China and India will significantly reduce the former's presence, which will leave a gap in funding for many start-ups.

Business environment outlook: Foreign trade and exchange controls                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2015-19 2020-24 2015-19 2020-24 2015-19 2020-24
5.1 6.4 71 64 16 13
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 17 countries: Australia, Bangladesh, China, Hong Kong, India, Indonesia, Japan, Malaysia, New Zealand, Pakistan, Philippines, Singapore, South Korea, Sri Lanka, Taiwan, Thailand and Vietnam.
The score for foreign trade and exchange controls improves significantly to 6.4 in the forecast period, from 5.1 in 2015-19, resulting in an improvement in India's global and regional rankings in this category. This progress is due to significant improvements in trade-related bureaucracy and modest deregulation of capital-account restrictions. In recent years the government has lowered an array of export subsidies and harmonised them under two general schemes-one for goods and one for services. It has also invested in improved infrastructure; reduced costs through greater use of online and mobile platforms; permitted the electronic submission of documents with digital signatures; and allowed exporters to self-seal their containers using radio frequency identification (RFID) technology. These measures have formed part of a broader effort to stimulate exports through supply-side reforms that are intended to boost the competitiveness of Indian exporters.

- Negotiations between India and the EU on a proposed free-trade agreement (FTA) have been stalled since 2013 owing to disagreement on a few contentious issues; the deal is unlikely to be revived in the forecast period. In June 2020 India and the EU held talks with the aim of restarting negotiations, but the sides remain too far apart on a deal. In November 2019 India withdrew from talks on the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP), a proposed FTA between ASEAN's ten member states and the six countries with which the bloc already has FTAs in place.

India will seek trade ties with OECD countries, but progress will be limited
- The NDA government will adjust its overall trade strategy amid a slowdown in global commerce in 2020. We expect the administration to initiate negotiations on FTAs with some advanced economies, such as the UK and Australia, but none of these agreements will be finalised within our forecast period. Trade relations with the US will remain strained, and we expect India to remain out of the US Generalised System of Preferences for an extended period. A more limited trade deal focusing on sectors of key strategic interest, such as steel for India, seems a more likely outcome from talks with the US.

Business environment outlook: Taxes                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2015-19 2020-24 2015-19 2020-24 2015-19 2020-24
4.5 5.9 79 60 16 13
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 17 countries: Australia, Bangladesh, China, Hong Kong, India, Indonesia, Japan, Malaysia, New Zealand, Pakistan, Philippines, Singapore, South Korea, Sri Lanka, Taiwan, Thailand and Vietnam.
India's score for taxes rises to 5.9 in 2020-24, from 4.5 in 2015-19. As a result, the country's global and regional rankings improve considerably. This is driven by improvements in the corporate tax burden and the consistency and fairness of the tax system, as well as reduced complexity. The nationwide goods and services tax (GST) introduced in July 2017 was one of India's biggest tax reforms in decades. It replaced a slew of indirect central and state taxes and marks a significant step towards the creation of a single national market. Since the roll-out of the tax, the GST Council has met regularly and taken measures to simplify the tax and cut its rates. (The GST Council comprises a group of ministers authorised with deciding changes to the rate and structure of the tax.) Several landmark tax disputes between the Indian authorities and major foreign investors have arisen in recent years, involving claims of expropriation and retrospective changes of tax regulation. Some have been resolved (a major case with a Finnish technology company, Nokia, was settled in 2018), but several cases remain in the courts and continue to cast a cloud over the country's reputation as an investment destination.
As fiscal consolidation comes into focus, the tax net will be widened
- We expect tax revenue to decline in 2020/21, owing to the impact of the coronavirus on economic activity and corporate profits. We anticipate that the government will announce a range of tax relief measures to bolster growth and reduce pressure on corporate cash flows. In the latter half of the forecast period, however, there will be growing impetus to widen the tax net to reduce the large fiscal deficit, by means such as increasing the capacity of the tax authorities.
- As collections from the GST tax pick up, the government will continue to rationalise GST rates and to bring more items into lower tax brackets, although multiple tax slabs will remain in place. Several key items, including alcoholic spirits and petroleum products, will remain outside the GST net.
- Despite noticeable improvements, foreign investors will remain wary of the government's opaque tax regime, highlighted by the risk of retrospective changes to tax laws. Public concerns over tax evasion have led the government to increase the regulatory power of tax authorities, raising concerns over possible overreach in a country where tax laws remain complex.

Business environment outlook: Financing                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2015-19 2020-24 2015-19 2020-24 2015-19 2020-24
5.1 5.5 57 62 12 16
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 17 countries: Australia, Bangladesh, China, Hong Kong, India, Indonesia, Japan, Malaysia, New Zealand, Pakistan, Philippines, Singapore, South Korea, Sri Lanka, Taiwan, Thailand and Vietnam.
The score for financing improves from 5.1 in 2015-19 to 5.5 in 2020-24 as the quality of the financial regulatory system strengthens. However, India's position in the global rankings deteriorates from 57th to 62nd as other countries make greater progress in this area. A number of massive bank fraud cases have emerged in recent years, including an alleged US$1.4bn fraud at Punjab National Bank. The bad debts associated with these (and other pre-existing problems in the banking sector) will continue to weigh on the health and resilience of the banking system. In the most recent edition of its twice-yearly Financial Stability Report, published in June 2020, the RBI indicated that it expects the non-performing loan ratio in the banking sector to rise to 12.5% in March 2021, from 8.5% a year earlier (under its baseline scenario). Unfortunately, as bank lending has slowed in recent years, companies have turned to non-bank financial companies for credit, and problems in this segment have further weakened the resilience of the financial system considerably.

- We expect financial regulation in India to improve throughout the forecast period. However, the insolvency law will probably be amended: as court cases involving the insolvency law are decided, they will set precedents that could underline the effectiveness of the law. Better bad-loan provisioning and stricter regulation will support an improvement in the sector's health towards the latter part of our forecast period, improving the availability of financing.

Weakly capitalised banks will weigh on private-sector credit growth
- Public-sector lenders will continue to account for the bulk of total lending, especially in rural areas. The capacity of state-owned banks to increase lending has been held back in recent years as they sought to address balance-sheet weaknesses. In the 2019/20 budget the government announced plans for a Rs700bn (US$9.3bn) capital injection into public banks. In the absence of the coronavirus, this would have helped to reinvigorate their lending over 2020-24. However, the economic slowdown has weakened corporate balance sheets, and this will impair their repayment capability. We believe that amid deterioration in asset quality, further recapitalisation will be necessary. This will prove politically and fiscally challenging, weighing on the ability of banks to fund private sector credit growth. It should be noted that marked improvements in lending practices would be unlikely even if banks were fully recapitalised.
- Priority-sector lending (minimum mandated lending to specific sectors aimed at achieving socio-developmental objectives) will remain a feature of government policy throughout the forecast period. The RBI will continue to push both state-owned and private banks to meet priority-sector targets. Indian commercial banks and foreign lenders with more than 20 branches in the country are currently required to provide 40% of their net bank credit to the priority sectors, which include agriculture, housing and renewable energy. A significant reduction in this target is unlikely in 2020-24.

Business environment outlook: The labour market                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2015-19 2020-24 2015-19 2020-24 2015-19 2020-24
5.0 5.0 73 77 16 17
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 17 countries: Australia, Bangladesh, China, Hong Kong, India, Indonesia, Japan, Malaysia, New Zealand, Pakistan, Philippines, Singapore, South Korea, Sri Lanka, Taiwan, Thailand and Vietnam.
India's score for the labour market remains unchanged at 5 in the forecast period. Moreover, the country is now the worst performer in Asia on this metric. Our core forecast is that progress on the liberalisation of contentious labour and land laws will be limited and the benefits will only be seen in the latter part of the forecast period. Under the previous NDA administration India took some limited steps towards overhauling its outdated array of labour laws (many of which have not been comprehensively revamped in decades). For example, it moved to allow all industrial establishments to hire workers on fixed-term contracts, which was previously permissible only in the textile industry. Several BJP-governed states, including Gujarat, have temporarily suspended the strict labour code to facilitate economic recovery. We expect this trend to continue broadly in 2020-24, but progress will be inhibited by opposition from trade unions (including those affiliated with the ruling coalition).

- A major reason for the slow progress on labour law reform is the government's lack of a majority in the Rajya Sabha. We expect the NDA to obtain a majority in the upper house from the end of 2020, which should speed up the legislation process.

The Code of Industrial Relations will not be passed easily
- The government has prepared a Code of Industrial Relations, representing the consolidation of more than 40 different labour laws under four major codes covering wages, industrial relations, social security and occupational safety, health and working conditions. Parliament passed the first code, on wages, in July 2019. This includes clauses that allow the government to set national minimum wage rates for various regions and industries. We believe that given the context of the coronavirus, as well as strong resistance from opposition parties and trade unions, passage of these changes will not be swift in 2020-24.

Progress in overhauling labour laws will be driven by states
- Although the central government is harmonising and simplifying many labour regulations at national level, the states will still retain considerable autonomy to advance their own reforms in this field. For example, in response to the economic slowdown triggered by the coronavirus in mid-2020, several states-including Gujarat, Uttar Pradesh and Madhya Pradesh-temporarily suspended some federal and state-level labour laws. This included the suspension of provisions relating to daily working hours (which have risen from eight to twelve hours), trade unions and industrial disputes. While these changes may remove some obstacles to investment (particularly in labour-intensive manufacturing), the suspension of large parts of labour regulation increases risks to workers' rights and could erode working conditions.
- The BJP government has vowed to improve workforce education in order to provide the labour force with the skills necessary to supply talent to emerging sectors such as artificial intelligence, 3D printing, robotics, virtual reality, the internet of things and big data. We do not believe that these commitments will result in much change on the ground in 2020-24, and the shortage of workers with suitable skills will remain a problem for many industries.

Business environment outlook: Infrastructure                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2015-19 2020-24 2015-19 2020-24 2015-19 2020-24
3.8 5.8 73 52 14 10
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 17 countries: Australia, Bangladesh, China, Hong Kong, India, Indonesia, Japan, Malaysia, New Zealand, Pakistan, Philippines, Singapore, South Korea, Sri Lanka, Taiwan, Thailand and Vietnam.
The score for infrastructure improves from 3.8 in 2015-19 to 5.8 in 2020-24. This is driven by higher scores for broadband connection speed, distribution, road and rail networks, ports and transport infrastructure, electricity and office space supply. These gains will result in a marked improvement in India's global ranking to 52nd in the forecast period, from 73rd in 2015-19. Infrastructure improvements and expansion remain key priorities for the NDA government. We expect the bulk of public investment to be diverted to transport, energy and urban improvement projects. However, the pace of progress on projects that are already under way will remain constrained by weak government effectiveness and delays in regulatory clearances (particularly environmental approvals).

- The finance minister, Nirmala Sitharaman, announced in February 2020 that the budget would allocate financial support to build an additional 100 airports for 1bn travellers by 2024. While delays in their construction are likely, we expect that these airports, once finished, will improve regional connectivity and bolster domestic labour flows between states.
- India will make considerable improvements in enhancing internet speed as well as connectivity. According to the International Telecommunication Union, the proportion of internet subscribers in India has increased steadily to 54.3% in 2019, from 21.4% in 2014. However, the aggregate figure conceals a wide disparity in internet penetration rate by income group, with poorer households or those in remote areas at risk of falling behind.
- Progress on urban civic infrastructure projects, such as water supply, will be hindered by inadequate private-sector involvement. The limited returns on investment in these sectors mean that official efforts to draw in more private-sector participation will struggle. The private sector will focus instead on areas that promise faster returns, such as airport construction, and there will be significant progress in these areas in 2020-24. However, demand for infrastructure will continue to exceed supply by a significant margin in the forecast period, placing stress on already scarce resources.
- Two publicly funded connectivity projects, Bharatmala (road construction) and Sagarmala (port construction), will continue to be prioritised throughout the forecast period. The first phase of Bharatmala is aimed at connecting 550 of the country's districts through the national highways network, from only 300 in 2017. The government plans to build a total of 24,800 km of roads by 2022. However, progress on this project will be hindered by limited financial resources, and it is likely to miss its targets.
- The quality and breadth of railway services will remain a challenge in 2020-24. India has a large rail network but its quality is inadequate, with frequent accidents and poor speeds that restrain efficiency. A lack of capital investment in the sector constrains the expansion of capacity. Despite piecemeal efforts, the overall quality of the rail network will remain poor in comparison with other territories with large rail networks, such as China and Europe. However, projects including a "bullet train" connecting Ahmedabad with Mumbai and several ongoing urban mass rapid transit projects will make progress during the forecast period.

Business environment outlook: Technological readiness                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2015-19 2020-24 2015-19 2020-24 2015-19 2020-24
5.8 6.1 45 47 10 12
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 17 countries: Australia, Bangladesh, China, Hong Kong, India, Indonesia, Japan, Malaysia, New Zealand, Pakistan, Philippines, Singapore, South Korea, Sri Lanka, Taiwan, Thailand and Vietnam.
India scores respectably for technological readiness, improving slightly to 6.1 in the forecast period, from 5.8 in 2015-19, on account of higher internet use. Still, improvements elsewhere mean that its global ranking falls slightly from 45th to 47th. The country boasts a relatively advanced R&D infrastructure, partly owing to the fact that the education system has historically been skewed towards higher educational outcomes. This has facilitated the development of relatively research-intensive sectors such as pharmaceuticals and technology. India has also been an enthusiastic adopter of e-government systems, seeking to improve the effectiveness of public service delivery and reduce corruption. Its Aadhar biometric identity cards are helping to enable this process. Nevertheless, high levels of poverty mean that mobile and internet penetration rates in India are still low compared with global and Asian norms.
Internet speeds are set to quicken as 5G services are rolled out
- India lags behind in terms of fixed broadband and mobile internet speed. According to the Speedtest Global Index, India ranked 75th out of 170 countries in June 2020 for fixed broadband connectivity speed. Its ranking on mobile internet speed was even worse, coming in 129th out of 138 countries. We expect that the launch of 5G networks will contribute to higher internet speeds in urban areas in the latter half of the forecast period. In 2018 the Telecom Commission, a government agency, approved the new National Digital Communication Policy, the objectives of which include providing minimum download speeds of 50 Mbps and enabling 10-Gbps connectivity to all rural regions by 2022. The policy also aims to generate 4m jobs in digital communication and to increase the sector's contribution to India's GDP from around 6% at present to 8% by 2022. However, acquiring spectrum licences and laying the requisite fibre network will create obstacles, and the government is likely to fall short of its targets.

E-commerce is focal point of India's digital revolution
- E-commerce has become the focal point of India's digital revolution, owing to factors such as FDI-friendly regulation, a growing middle class, the availability of relatively cheap mobile connections and skilled labour to develop indigenous technology platforms. According to GlobalData, a data analytics firm, the Indian e-commerce market will grow by an average of 20% a year between 2019 and 2023 to a value of US$93bn. Restrictions on the movement of the population during the pandemic are likely to hasten the uptake of e-commerce, particularly in retail. The development of online commerce will be facilitated by the government's Bharat-Net programme, which seeks to provide internet connectivity to every village in the country.
- India will leverage the technological ecosystem provided by Aadhar biometric identity cards in 2020-24. Aadhar provides residents with a unique identification number through a link with their biometric data. We expect that the system will allow both the government and the private sector to deliver official services, such as transfer of benefits, more efficiently. However, it is also likely to face public scrutiny, amid privacy concerns.

Economic forecast: Policy trends The government's majority in the lower house will give it flexibility in determining the economic policy agenda. Its key near-term priority is to contain the coronavirus outbreak, to which India is particularly vulnerable, given its large population and weak healthcare infrastructure. The widespread and stringent lockdown measures imposed from March were only partially successful in reducing the spread of the virus, which has accelerated since such measures were relaxed gradually from May. Despite the spread of the virus, we do not expect the government to re-introduce a nationwide lockdown. Nevertheless, sporadic local lockdown measures in states and cities will be adopted in the coming months to ease pressure on the healthcare system in those areas.
We expect the government to take up policy reforms after the crisis as it looks to support growth. The government plans to open up more sectors of the economy to private firms, by privatising or reducing the number of public-sector units. The administration will undertake piecemeal changes to legislation, such as a relaxation of regulatory requirements and a modest liberalisation of foreign direct investment (FDI) rules. In terms of improving the business environment, one area of attention will be the liberalisation of contentious labour and land laws. Progress on this will be limited and the benefits will only be seen in the latter part of the forecast period.
The lockdown will amplify the mounting non-performing loan (NPL) issue in the banking sector. Slow progress will be made towards policy changes to improve the health of the sector. Infrastructure projects-particularly pet projects of the Modi government, such as the National Infrastructure Pipeline-remain a priority, in response to the rapid pace of urbanisation and to boost the business environment. However, we expect a revival in infrastructure spending only from the fourth quarter of 2020, once the coronavirus outbreak is brought under greater control.

Economic forecast: Fiscal policy Fiscal indicators

Government revenue 8.8 8.2 8.6 9.5 9.7 9.8
Budget balance -4.6 -7.8 -6.7 -5.4 -5.4 -4.6
Government debt 46.8 56.3 57.7 58.8 57.0 55.0
The coronavirus outbreak will force the government to rewrite its approved budget for 2020/21, which is currently conservatively expansionary. It will temporarily suspend the Fiscal Responsibility and Budget Management Act to allow for more flexibility in supporting the economy. The lockdown has prompted an unbudgeted increase in social spending programmes, especially the National Rural Employment Guarantee Scheme, as well as an extension of existing financial support schemes for businesses.
The government announced an Rs20trn package (equivalent to around 10% of GDP) to support the economy in May. However, this headline figure includes liquidity measures provided by the Reserve Bank of India (RBI, the central bank) and advances by banks under the government's measures. The actual amount of additional budgetary spending announced equates to around 1.4% of GDP. We expect the government to announce another fiscal package, worth 1-1.5% of GDP, towards the end of the third quarter of 2020, including an infrastructure development programme. In view of a fall in revenue and lower nominal GDP, the budget deficit is forecast to widen to the equivalent of 7.8% of GDP in 2020/21.
As the economy recovers, the government will look gradually to consolidate the public finances. This will narrow the budget deficit to the equivalent of 6.7% of GDP in 2021/22. The authorities will look to deepen the tax base and increase (currently low) levels of tax compliance. However, the need to support welfare payments and infrastructure spending will maintain upward pressure on fiscal expenditure. We also expect subsidies to remain in place for labour-intensive, small-scale businesses-particularly those that are export-focused. This federal fiscal picture does not reflect the true level of the deficit. The deficits of many states and part of the expenditure of public-sector units represent implicit liabilities for the central government.
Economic forecast: Monetary policy Interest rates
(%)
  2019 2020 2021 2022 2023 2024
Commercial banks' prime rate (av) 9.5 8.7 8.0 8.4 8.9 9.0
Short-term interest rate (year-end) 7.2 5.9 5.1 5.5 6.0 6.1
Long-term interest rate (year-end) 7.0 5.9 5.1 6.2 6.5 6.6
The coronavirus epidemic will prompt further monetary-policy loosening by the RBI. The central bank has lowered its policy repo rate by 115 basis points, to 4% since March, while also widening the monetary-policy corridor by lowering the reverse repo rate (the "floor" of the corridor) by 155 basis points, to 3.35%. With inflationary pressure expected to moderate and economic growth under strong downward pressure, we expect a further 75-basis-point reduction in the policy repo rate over the remainder of 2020. We also expect the adoption of unconventional policy instruments, including long-term repo operations to lend to banks, which will include further long-term refinancing operations.
Monetary policy will aim to support businesses as the coronavirus pandemic suppresses household spending and business investment. However, the outcome may be far from satisfactory, as monetary-policy transmission is not smooth. While banking-sector lending to micro, small and medium-sized enterprises (MSMEs) will improve, as the government has provided a sovereign guarantee for those loans, banks will be reluctant to lend to other parts of the economy, given increased risk. The level of non-performing assets in the financial sector is alarming, and the coronavirus outbreak will only exacerbate the issue, with more firms forced out of business. Policy support from the central bank and the government will be needed to support the recovery of the banking sector, once the pandemic passes.
The RBI has maintained inflation-targeting as the cornerstone of its monetary policy framework. It seeks to contain consumer price inflation within a 2-6% range, and close to a target of 4%. However, strong political pressure on the RBI-which has forced out two hawkish heads of the bank under BJP rule-has complicated the achievement of these objectives.

Economic forecast: Economic growth The impact of the coronavirus: global and regional assumptions The Economist Intelligence Unit's forecasts are built on a series of epidemiological assumptions about the novel coronavirus (Covid-19). Without rapid access to a vaccine, we expect that the disease will eventually infect up to 30% of the world's population; of the symptomatic cases, we assume that about 15% will be severe and up to 1% will prove fatal. Death ratios will depend on a country's ability to detect, track and contain the virus, and the capacity of the national health system. Governments are gradually lifting restrictions on freedom of movement in countries where the number of cases is falling. Some countries may be forced to re-impose measures if cases spike again. Based on previous viral outbreaks and the progress made on other coronavirus vaccines (such as that for severe acute respiratory syndrome-SARS), we expect a vaccine to be available by end-2021.
We forecast that global real GDP will contract by 5%, year on year, in 2020. We believe that trade disruptions will remain severe and forecast that global trade will contract by 22.6% this year. We assume that oil prices will decline by about 37% this year, to average US$40.5/barrel, before they recover to US$45/b next year. Real GDP will contract in all regions this year, but the drop in output will be especially severe in OECD countries, at 6.3%. All G7 countries and all but two G20 countries (China and Indonesia) will experience a full-year recession, and the US's output will contract by 5.3%, while China will record real GDP growth of 1.4%. Asian countries will recover the fastest, with some (including India and South Korea) returning to pre-coronavirus GDP levels in 2021. Of the G7 countries, Germany's output will also be back to 2019 levels in 2021, but others will recover more slowly, with GDP returning to 2019 levels in either 2022 (Canada, France and the US), 2023 (the UK) or 2024 (Italy and Japan). Most countries have responded with fiscal programmes to support businesses and households, raising the risk of sovereign debt crises in the medium term. Central banks have cut interest rates and, more importantly, have stepped up as buyers of last resort for government and corporate debt.
Asia and Australasia will experience a recession in 2020 for the first time since 1998, with regional real GDP forecast to contract by 1.8%. All countries in the region will see their economic performances affected by demand slumps caused by lockdowns within their own borders and those introduced in other countries. Among the region's major economies, India is forecast to experience the steepest economic contraction, at 8.5% for 2020/21, followed by Singapore, Thailand and Japan. Some trade-dependent economies, such as South Korea and Taiwan, will evince a degree of economic resilience because their early response to the pandemic allowed them to avoid costly nationwide lockdowns. Parts of Asia are still expected to post GDP growth in 2020, although at a much less rapid rate than normal. Vietnam will grow by 3.3% this year, while China is forecast to expand by 1.4%, despite a steep economic contraction in January-March. While the pace of recovery will be sequentially weak in Asia in 2021, with many countries still forced to implement localised (if not national) lockdowns, a low base of comparison will help ensure real GDP rebounds to growth of 5.5% that year.
The political and geopolitical effects of the crisis will be significant. The pandemic has resulted in an extraordinary expansion of executive powers, with limited parliamentary oversight. Elections have been cancelled or delayed in some countries. When the pandemic has passed, governments' handling of the response will undergo scrutiny. Failure to address the humanitarian crisis triggered by the coronavirus could further erode trust in national institutions. A severe global economic crisis, followed by large-scale unemployment, could fuel a new wave of popular protests. The crisis may encourage support for the nation state, and a backlash against globalisation and open borders. It will also intensify the competition for global leadership between China and the US, and a realignment of geopolitical spheres of influence may ensue in Europe, Africa and other regions.
The Indian government closed the country's borders to international visitors on March 12th, in a bid to stop imported cases. Domestically, following a Janata ("people's curfew") on March 22nd, the administration declared a formal 21-day lockdown on March 25th, which stopped all non-essential services from operating. As the number of cases continued to rise, the government extended the lockdown to May 31st, with relaxation permitted before this date if certain epidemiological standards were met. The government eased movement restrictions between states on July 1st. The economic impact of the stringent containment measures has been severe, but the pandemic has still spread. The healthcare system in India suffers from a chronic shortage of beds and personnel, making it extremely vulnerable to the pandemic. We expect the government to seek a regional containment strategy to cope with a sudden rise in cases, and to try to cushion the economic impact through various relief packages.

We expect real GDP to contract by 8.5% in 2020/21-the sharpest contraction in economic activity since India's independence in 1947. The headline GDP number will be pulled down primarily by a 21.1% year-on-year contraction in April-June (the first quarter) of 2020/21, reflecting the impact of India's stringent lockdown measures. The economy will continue to contract in the second and third quarters, by 8.4% and 4.1%, respectively, as the administration is unable to control the spread of the virus and intermittent local lockdown measures are put in place. We do not expect the economy to register growth on an annual basis in the fourth quarter of 2020/21, as job losses, business closures and social distancing measures depress activity. Sectors such as travel, hospitality and tourism will be the most affected.
On a GDP expenditure basis, we expect private consumption to contract sharply in 2020/21, as people's economic activities are constrained during lockdown and as consumption remains low, even after the restrictions are lifted. Investment spending is also expected to decline steeply, as firms postpone activity amid high uncertainty around the virus. We also expect increased loan liabilities to be taken up by corporates and banks to further discourage new investment. We maintain our view that the government will continue to bolster the economy through increased expenditure, but the effect will be limited. We expect exports to fall as a global recession sets in.
Real GDP growth is expected to rebound sharply in 2021/22, but the headline forecast of 9.1% is exaggerated by an extremely low base of comparison in 2020/21. Economic growth will remain weak on a quarter-on-quarter basis, because of increased bankruptcies and as fiscal support is pared back. Economic growth in 2022/23-2024/25 will average 5.9% a year. Incremental progress on structural reform will provide support for growth in the latter part of the forecast period.

Economic forecast: Sectoral trends In 2020 the rural economy will recover more quickly than its urban counterpart, which helps the share of agriculture in GDP to grow. However, as the economy moves up the value chain and productivity improves, the share of agriculture in total output will continue to decline gradually; we expect it to fall from 20% in 2020/21 to 17.6% by 2024/25. The primary sector will remain important, as it will continue to employ around half of the population. As employment opportunities open up in the secondary and tertiary sectors, however, there will be a gradual shift in employment away from agriculture. Reforms to bolster supply-chain efficiency, as well as efforts to liberalise the food market, will support the sector's outlook in 2020-24.
There is significant scope for investment to enhance the sector's productivity, as almost half of all cultivable land remains dependent on annual monsoon rainfalls, rendering the sector vulnerable to poor or unevenly distributed rains. The government has recognised this vulnerability and has increased funding for irrigation schemes and crop insurance. As agriculture faces growing risks related to the availability of water, the success of these efforts will prove crucial to ensuring long-term sustainability. However, capital investment into the sector will be inadequate, and the bulk of public funding will continue to come in the form of populist short-term subsidies aimed at securing political support from farmers. We forecast that the agriculture sector will grow by 3.3% a year on average in the forecast period.
The industrial sector will expand at a robust pace after the coronavirus pandemic, as the business environment improves and the country's strong economic growth outlook attracts investment. We expect the sector to grow by an average rate of 4.1% a year in the forecast period. However, the share of industry in total GDP will remain relatively stable, increasing slightly from 27.5% in 2019/20 to 28.1% in 2024/25. Manufacturing will remain particularly concentrated in a few sectors, such as the automotive industry, and in a few geographic locations. This will render it vulnerable to sectoral swings, such as the downturn in demand for cars in 2019.
Government efforts to lift manufacturing employment and output are highly ambitious but will miss their targets; these include the "Make in India" initiative (which targets 100m additional jobs in manufacturing and a rise in its share of GDP to 25% by 2022), the "self-reliant India" package and the administration's special economic zone strategy, which is intended to develop manufacturing hubs throughout the country. In the absence of greater liberalisation of laws governing land acquisition and the labour regime, industrial expansion will lag behind potential, which will weigh on employment opportunities.
Accounting for 47.2% of GDP in 2019/20, the services sector will continue to be the main engine of economic expansion. Apart from the severe disruption caused by the pandemic, the sector has shown itself to be resilient and not entirely dependent on buoyancy in external markets. The sector's expansion will continue to be driven by already strong areas of activity such as telecommunications, as well as by services in numerous high-potential but currently underserved areas, including healthcare, retailing, hospitality and education. Information technology (IT) and IT-enabled services will remain a major source of export revenue, even as growth slows in the face of increased competition from countries such as the Philippines. Services will form a key sector of the economy in the forecast period, expanding by 3.5% a year on average, and its share of GDP will rise to 46.8% by 2024/25.

We expect consumer prices to increase by an average of 5.1% in 2020 as a whole. While food price inflation has remained elevated during the lockdown, we expect it to moderate once supply-side constraints ease, towards the end of the third quarter. Non-food inflation will continue to lag behind food inflation, helping to prevent a rapid pick-up in the overall consumer price index (CPI). Our forecast assumes a normal monsoon this year (and in every year of the outlook period).
Relatively subdued inflationary pressures in 2021 will afford the RBI scope to keep its policy rate unchanged in 2021 as it continues to support the economy. The adoption of a tighter monetary policy stance in 2022 will offset the inflationary impact of strengthening oil prices. The central bank will accord higher priority to containing inflationary pressures towards the end of the forecast period; consumer price inflation is expected to average 4.4% in 2024.
Low oil prices and reduced domestic demand will generate producer price deflation of 0.4% in 2020. As prices for oil and other commodities strengthen, producer price inflation will firm to an annual average of 3.6% in 2021-24.

The RBI's adoption of a fairly aggressive loosening stance in 2020, along with a sharp contraction in economic activity, will weigh on the exchange rate. We forecast that the rupee will depreciate by 6% on an annual average basis, to Rs74.9:US$1 in 2020, as the domestic economic situation worsens and investments move to safe-haven currencies. While some support will be provided to the currency by a current-account surplus, the central bank's efforts to build-up foreign-exchange reserves will more than offset it.
In 2021 we expect the rupee to appreciate slightly, to an average of Rs73.9:US$1, as foreign investment returns. The rupee will depreciate in 2022-24 amid rising oil prices and a persistent current-account deficit.

Lower oil prices and extremely weak domestic demand will contribute to India registering a current-account surplus equivalent to 0.9% of GDP in 2020, the first since 2004. The contraction in merchandise imports is expected to be sharper than that in exports because of the rampant spread of the virus domestically, leading to the surplus. However, merchandise imports are expected to rebound in 2021 amid a pick-up in domestic demand, returning the current account to a deficit.
Increased competition from other countries and changing industrial trends will weigh on the pace of growth in India's main service export sectors, particularly business-process outsourcing (BPO) and information technology (IT). Nevertheless, the services balance will remain in surplus throughout the forecast period, making a positive contribution to the current account. Owing to the large shortfall on merchandise trade, however, the current account will remain in deficit from 2021, averaging 1.1% of GDP in the remainder of the forecast period.
Significant foreign investment into Reliance Jio, a telecom operator, will support inward investment in 2020. However, foreign investment in the overall economy will be depressed in 2020-21. Inward investment will pick up from 2022 onwards, as the expanding economy and growing consumer demand provide opportunities for businesses and the business environment improves under the government's reform agenda.
Economic forecast: Foreign direct investment in India Stocks and flows India's large market and growing economy make it a favourable destination for foreign investors. Foreign direct investment (FDI) inflows into India have been strong in recent years, and in 2019 the country received US$50.2bn in FDI inflows. This compares favourably with an average of US$17.8bn in 2005-07, before the outbreak of the 2008-09 global financial crisis. Owing to an attractive growth outlook and significant market opportunities, the stock of inward FDI has been expanding rapidly, standing at US$426.9bn in 2019 (markedly higher than in 2010, when it stood at US$205.6bn). The 2019 figure was also higher than the corresponding stock in Indonesia (US$292bn) but significantly lower than in China (US$1.8trn) and Brazil (US$819.5bn).
Origin and distribution According to the Department of Industrial Policy and Promotion (DIPP), the largest source of FDI is Mauritius, which accounted for 30.4% of FDI inflows between April 2000 and March 2020. (Many foreign companies investing in India are incorporated in Mauritius for tax reasons.) Singapore is catching up quickly, as a similar tax treaty is reached and rates of taxation are among the lowest in Asia. Singapore surpassed Mauritius in fiscal years 2018/19 and 2019/20 (April-March), while it was the second most important foreign investor between April 2000 and March 2020, accounting for 20.8% of cumulative inflows. It is followed by the Netherlands (7.2%), Japan (7.1%) the US (6.3%) and the UK (6.0%). The most important sector for FDI is services, which attracted US$82bn between April 2000 and March 2020 and accounted for 17.5% of cumulative inflows, according to the DIPP. The computer software and hardware sector is the second-largest recipient, attracting US$44.9bn in the same period. The state of Maharashtra, which boasts the country's financial centre, Mumbai, is the largest recipient of FDI, garnering 30% of the total between April 2000 and March 2020. This was followed by Karnataka, which includes Bangalore, the nation's information technology hub, and received 18% of total FDI in the same period.
Determinants India's skilled, English-speaking workforce has been a significant attraction for FDI, particularly in the information technology (IT) sector. Since coming into office the current government has liberalised the FDI regime in a number of areas, including defence, pharmaceuticals, civil aviation and single-brand retailing. It has also done away with the Foreign Investment Promotion Board, an agency that was tasked with considering and recommending FDI on a case-by-case basis. The current administration will continue to open up the economy to foreign investors. However, more minor bureaucratic restrictions are often left unaddressed. Difficulty in acquiring land and laying off workers persists, along with other legal uncertainties, impeding the inflow of investment and hampering the ease of conducting business in India for foreigners.
Impact FDI has had the greatest impact on India's software industry and IT-enabled services. Call centres and other forms of back-office administration have become important industries, but India is moving up the value chain. The financial, pharmaceutical, telecommunications and power sectors have also been influenced significantly by FDI. The online retail sector is likely to be similarly transformed, with US-based Amazon and Walmart (through its Flipkart subsidiary) now having a significant presence in the e-commerce sector. Many online start-ups have been able to attract attention from venture capitalists and internet giants in the West. However, in offline retail, a significant relaxation of regulations for multi-brand retailers is unlikely to occur during 2020-24.
Potential Given the size of its market and rapid economic growth, India is attracting a significant amount of FDI, but the potential for even stronger inflows is reduced by relatively poor infrastructure, excessive bureaucracy and wrangling between government departments. The infrastructure, energy, telecoms, IT and insurance sectors are likely to be the key areas for FDI in 2020-24. Biotechnology and vehicle manufacturing (including parts) could also attract significant interest over the next five years. However, the serious economic contraction in 2020 will make some producers wary of entering the local market in the short term.

The Economist Intelligence Unit forecasts that the population will grow by 0.9% a year on average in 2020-24, down from 1.1% in 2015-19. This slight slowdown is linked to an improvement in living standards, urbanisation and generally improving economic conditions for women, which are resulting in women having fewer babies. According to data from the World Bank, the total fertility rate fell to 2.2 children per woman in 2018, from 3.3 in 2000. India is likely to reach the replacement level of fertility-2.1 children per woman-very soon. In the coastal states, the fertility rate is already below the replacement rate. However, poor and populous states such as Uttar Pradesh and Bihar will continue to record strong population growth, adding to social tensions and exerting further pressure on the already overloaded infrastructure.
High levels of gender disparity will increase the risk of social unrest By 2024 men will outnumber women by almost 50m. According to the latest census, held in 2011, there were just 919 girls for every 1,000 boys under the age of six, marking a decline from the previous census, which showed that there were 927 girls for every 1,000 boys. More recent research from the National Family Health Survey, conducted in 2015-16, shows that a skewed sex ratio exists across almost the entire country (the gender disparity is more pronounced in urban regions than rural areas). Historically, countries with wide gender disparities have tended to suffer from higher levels of social disorder, and we do not expect India to be an exception. Social tensions will be more notable in urban areas, fuelled partly by the inability of many men to find suitable employment opportunities.
Caste factors will be another important source of social strain within India in 2020-24. The Hindu-nationalist populism promoted by the Bharatiya Janata Party-led government will have complex effects. On one hand, it is likely to re-energise Hinduism, which could lead to renewed emphasis on traditional caste roles. On the other hand, the government appears supportive of affirmative action policies that favour caste-based "reservations" (quotas) for jobs and public services such as education, which may help those in low-status castes. Caste groups (including higher-status castes) that do not currently enjoy special job quotas, especially in public-sector jobs, will push for them in the next five years. Regardless of the government's policy approach, the ongoing trend of workers moving from conservative rural regions to more metropolitan urban areas will help to slowly weaken the roots of the caste system.
The agriculture sector will continue to employ the bulk of the labour force Growth in the working-age population will remain relatively strong, at 1.1% a year on average in 2020-24. However, unlocking the economic benefits from population growth will prove challenging. In the 1990s and 2000s China was able to transfer workers from agriculture to more productive work in the cities, thereby boosting economic growth and exports. However, India's manufacturing sector has failed to take off in a similar manner. The manufacturing sector in India boasts more success in capital-intensive industries than labour-intensive ones. Although the sector is set to grow, it is unlikely to provide enough jobs for all the migrants from rural areas, particularly because of advancing automation. Services will also provide new jobs, but many of these will not be suitable for low-skill workers. Many of those employed in the informal sector in urban areas will lose their jobs amid stringent containment measures, and will have to return to rural areas in 2020-21. Agriculture will thus remain the mainstay of employment.
A key challenge for the country's long-term development is the poor state of primary-level education. While enrolment rates have risen, educational outcomes remain abysmal, especially in the public sector. This reflects multiple factors, including underqualified and undisciplined teachers, the impact of caste within the education system, a lack of proper evaluations and bad infrastructure within schools. The situation has resulted in strong demand (even among poor households) for private education, including online courses.
Weaknesses in other parts of the education system will also come to the fore as more students seek secondary and tertiary education. Few universities operate at world-class levels, and most graduates are unequipped for the demands of employers-even in sectors such as engineering, which are crucial for long-term growth. The growing politicisation of the tertiary education sector and the authorities' lack of focus on improving educational standards mean that Indian universities will broadly continue to underperform. A few clusters of excellence will gradually emerge, however.

The middle class will continue to grow after the pandemic Even though The Economist Intelligence Unit expects the economy to shrink at a record pace in fiscal year 2020/21 (April-March), we still expect the country to post rapid rates of growth once the coronavirus (Covid-19) passes. A sustained economic recovery from 2021/22 will help to lift personal disposable income back to levels seen before the pandemic took hold. India's huge population will become an increasingly important market for consumer goods. Household consumption expenditure will rise from US$1.6trn in 2020 to US$2.3trn by 2024. However, GDP per head (at market exchange rates) will remain low at just US$2,606 in 2024, compared with US$14,142 in China and US$8,040 in Brazil in the same year. This will limit the bulk of consumer spending to food and basic necessities. This low average nevertheless masks the presence of a growing number of middle-class households, which offers considerable potential for suppliers of higher-value products and services. The rapid growth in personal incomes from 2021, combined with a more open domestic market, will make India an increasingly attractive market for foreign companies. Significant regional economic disparities exist, and the levels of opportunity for retail businesses will vary greatly across the country in the forecast period.
Growth in the e-commerce segment will be robust Opportunities for e-commerce will grow rapidly in urban areas, owing to their increasingly well-educated populations and growing penetration of broadband and smartphones. Foreign firms are positioning themselves to take advantage of this trend. In 2018 Wal-Mart (US) acquired a controlling stake in Flipkart, an Indian e-commerce company, and it competes aggressively with the local unit of Amazon (also US). Reliance, a local conglomerate, opened an e-commerce business, Jiomart, in April 2020. As India returns to a solid growth path in 2021-24, and as internet penetration rises, the share of e-commerce in the country's consumer market will rise, creating opportunities for both domestic and foreign firms. Nevertheless, regulation will provide some obstacles to their competitive capacity. The administration has imposed strict restrictions on retail-related e-commerce businesses, and even during the March-June lockdown, e-commerce businesses were banned from selling non-essential goods. Foreign firms see these measures as discriminatory, and the government will come under pressure to revise them in 2020-24.
As Indian consumers become more aware of international brands, imports of electronics and consumer goods will rise. Urban consumers tend to display more brand loyalty, especially to high-end brands, than their rural counterparts and value loyalty programmes. For most Indians price will remain the main determinant of the level of demand. Companies in the fast-moving consumer goods sector tend to address affordability by offering products in smaller sizes. This practice serves as a way to develop brand loyalty among new consumers.

As in most developing countries, food constitutes by far the largest category of consumer expenditure. Indeed, spending on food as a percentage of income will remain relatively stable during 2020-24, as households increase the share of more expensive foods, like meat, in their diets. Spending on transport and communications will increase as mobility around India rebounds from the virus-induced slowdown in 2020. The relatively poor state of government-provided services means that as Indians become richer, they will spend an increasing amount on private education.
Local factors will continue to shape consumer preferences Several non-income-related factors must be weighed carefully when assessing prospects in the Indian market. First, purchasing power is as location-specific as it is income-sensitive, and prices can vary to a considerable degree even from city to city, let alone between urban and rural areas. Second, cultural factors matter to a significant degree. Third, Indian consumers, including those who are moving up the income scale, are highly price-conscious. Fourth, it is important to note that there is hardly a single characteristic that applies across the entire country. India is a widely varying collection of markets, necessitating region-specific strategies. Finally, the steady expansion of consumer finance and the growth of a credit-card culture will increase the number of consumers in the forecast period.

From May 2019 The Economist Intelligence Unit's long-term growth forecasts have been revised to take into account the economic impact of climate change.
Initial conditions: The Indian economy began to move away from a state-directed socialist model in the early 1990s, when a balance-of-payments crisis triggered the first round of economic reform and market liberalisation. Since then, India has recorded rapid rates of expansion, with annual real GDP growth of 5% in fiscal years 1991/92-2019/20 (April-March). However, India's share of world GDP (at market exchange rates) remains low, at around 3.3% in 2019, compared with its 17.9% share of the world's population. This highlights the fact that there is still significant scope for further economic development. Low average productivity in India remains a key reason for widespread poverty. The gap in productivity between the agriculture sector and high-growth industries such as information technology (IT) is vast. Corruption is still endemic among local authorities, despite the fact that attempts to reduce graft have made progress at the higher levels of government under the Bharatiya Janata Party (which has led the ruling coalition since 2014). India's courts have long suffered from crippling understaffing, and a case backlog has built up over decades. However, the judiciary is largely independent of the government.
The skills mismatch will persist as education and training remain poor Demographic trends: Continued growth in the working-age population over 2020-50 will support India's economic expansion. However, even as the economy grows, a large proportion of the workforce will not find employment in productive formal-sector jobs. A mismatch between the skills offered by the country's workers and the demands of employers will persist for at least the next two decades, as the quality of teaching provided by the country's education and vocational training systems remains poor. Meanwhile, the rise of automation and growing use of artificial intelligence will dampen employment gains, even as India-based enterprises capture a larger market share of global manufacturing. Reaping the demographic dividend will prove immensely difficult in this environment. The Economist Intelligence Unit expects the vast majority of the workforce to be absorbed by low-productivity occupations in the urban services sector in 2020-50. Still, opportunities for better-educated Indians will proliferate amid rapid growth in professional services, manufacturing and high-technology areas such as telecommunications, IT and pharmaceuticals.
Continued migration to prosperous areas could stoke social tensions Divergence in economic fortunes within the country will result in strong pressure for Indians from poorer states to move into more prosperous areas. In the absence of major governance improvements, states such as Uttar Pradesh and Bihar will be a source of internal migrants, putting pressure on scarce resources in more prosperous and economically dynamic cities such as the capital, New Delhi, and the financial hub, Mumbai. There is strong divergence in fertility rates between states, with Bihar and Uttar Pradesh recording high total fertility rates (TFR) of 3.2 and 3 respectively in 2017; the more prosperous state of Kerala had a TFR of 1.7 in the same year. This diversion will continue in the long run, and the population of Uttar Pradesh alone could surpass 400m by the middle of the century. Significant levels of internal migration will be a source of political and social tensions. Meanwhile, workers will continue to look abroad, to areas such as the Gulf region and the US, for economic opportunities. Inflows from their remittances over the next few decades will be an important driver of economic activity in some states.
The unequal gender distribution of India's population will remain a threat to social stability over the outlook period. According to the latest census, conducted in 2011, for every 1,000 boys under the age of six there were only 919 girls. Child mortality rates are higher for girls than boys, and female foeticide is practised. As this trend continues, a major imbalance between the numbers of men and women will undermine social stability.
India's diplomatic, economic and military power will increase External conditions: As its economy expands in size, India will become an increasingly important diplomatic, military and economic power. Successive governments will seek to ensure India's primacy within South Asia and to cultivate ties with regional neighbours-excluding Pakistan, India's long-standing rival. We expect India's relationship with Pakistan to remain tense, as the two countries will struggle to reconcile political and strategic differences, especially on the issue of Jammu and Kashmir. Temporary bouts of high tension are likely. However, the growth differential between India and Pakistan will remain high, suggesting that India's military advantage over its rival will increase. Over time, this should deter Pakistan from initiating conflict. China's presence in South Asia (especially in Pakistan) will push India towards adopting a more defensive posture to shield its domestic market from China. Shared strategic and economic interests will bind India more closely to Japan and the US. Still, even as it becomes a major diplomatic power, India will remain hesitant to align itself fully with the West. This is partially related to India's complex relationship with Russia, which has been a major source of military equipment. Long-standing links with the Gulf region and Africa and deepening investment ties will provide India with the opportunity to expand its political, economic and cultural engagement in these regions over the period to 2050.
Institutions and policy trends: Although political power will be centralised under the current prime minister, Narendra Modi, in the 2020s, we expect this trend to reverse once he leaves office. Differences in policy approach at state level will thus have a significant impact on economic outcomes. Reform-minded states will see growth accelerate, while poorer states will demand increased funds from the central government to balance economic disparities. Despite state-level differences, India's democratic political system will remain firmly entrenched. The country's legal system will generally remain impartial (if slow) and the constitution will be respected (apart from a trend away from secularism). Pledged reforms on labour law and land acquisition will make incremental progress, if at all. India's integration into regional and global value chains will nonetheless be constrained by a lingering tendency towards protectionism. New technologies and the emergence of an increasingly vocal middle class will help the authorities to curb graft, particularly at the local level.
Services will continue to dominate the economy in the longer term Long-term performance: We forecast that India's real GDP growth will average 4.2% a year in 2020-50. The country's economic progress is premised on a shift up the value chain in IT, manufacturing, business and information services, as well as other sectors. Continued government-led investment to upgrade infrastructure will improve the business environment and help to enhance the performance of the economy. Improvements in agricultural procurement practices and greater supply-chain efficiency will make rural India more resilient to weather shocks. A stronger agricultural sector will temper the movement of Indians from rural to urban areas, and the urban population will overtake its rural counterpart only by the middle of this century. However, the shift of the workforce from rural labour into more productive urban jobs will remain the main driver of India's economic expansion in the period to 2050. One major concern over the country's long-term economic performance is the extent to which the government can manage this transition. Upgrading the quality of public education will be crucial if the government is to achieve this successfully. We expect gradual progress on this front in the decades ahead, which will enable the country to expand the low-skilled manufacturing sector that will be crucial to its medium-term growth prospects. A gradual improvement in the quality of education will also lay the groundwork for the development of the higher-value-added sectors that will be necessary to sustain the country's growth momentum in the longer term. A much faster pace of improvement in education and much deeper reforms in business regulations would produce a much faster pace of economic growth over the long term; however, this is not part of our central forecast, and the economy will thus expand at a slower pace than its long-term growth potential.
