Long-term outlook: Long-term trends Climate change and sustainability India will be highly vulnerable to climate change, and adverse changes in monsoon patterns could severely affect its agricultural sector, which remains greatly dependent on monsoon rain. More generally, water scarcity will become a challenge. Frequent floods have also led to massive disruption of business activity. The government has taken steps to manage the effects of climate change. However, given the scale of the environmental challenges that India faces, policy measures are unlikely to reduce the country's vulnerability to climate change significantly.
India is already the world's third-largest consumer of energy, and demand will continue to grow over the forecast period. The government is making efforts to diversify from conventional sources of energy, such as coal-fired thermal power stations. India is one of the most active members of the International Solar Alliance (ISA), which promotes the transition to solar energy, and the ISA has established its headquarters in Gurgaon, near the country's capital, New Delhi. India is likely to use the platform to leverage funding and assistance from developed nations and multilateral agencies to develop its own solar farm sector.
The country has also been making strides in developing wind energy. The National Institute for Wind Energy has estimated India's wind-power potential at 302 GW, with the states of Tamil Nadu, Gujarat, Karnataka, Maharashtra and Rajasthan having the greatest potential. Serious efforts in this regard have started; India's installed capacity in wind energy is now the world's fourth largest. According to the National Institution for Transforming India (NITI Aayog, the government's policy think-tank), around 304m people in India lived without electricity in 2017. Consequently, even as renewable sources of energy will make advances, the significant gap between supply and demand in energy will mean that coal-fired thermal power plants remain critical to India's energy mix.
In 2019 The Economist Intelligence Unit developed a model to calculate the impact of climate change on long-term growth, and we find that the Indian economy will be 3.7% smaller in 2050 than it would have been otherwise without this hit to growth.
Migration and urbanisation India will continue to see an influx of immigrants to urban areas, as workers move to cities for better-paid jobs. Public policy, which has long been rural-oriented, will increasingly have to tilt towards resolving overcrowding, poor housing conditions, anaemic infrastructure and declining sustainability in urban centres. The construction of urban mass-transit systems will increase sharply, along with other urban infrastructure such as roads, sanitation and power grids. However, the enormous scale of these challenges and limited government effectiveness will temper the pace of progress.
The biggest challenge for policymakers will be skilling and training the workforce of rural migrants, as they will largely move from the low-skilled agriculture sector and will be less proficient in the expertise required for productive employability in services and industry. Meanwhile, emigration to Western countries, particularly the US and Canada, as well as to the prosperous states of the Gulf, such as the UAE, will remain strong. As a consequence, India will remain one of the largest recipients of remittances in the coming years.
Long-term outlook: Methodology for long-term forecasts The time horizon for the detailed forecasts and analysis in the Country Forecast report is a five-year period. The Main report also carries a section on the long-term outlook, including projections of key macroeconomic and market size variables up to 2050. Depending on the indicator, average growth rates in a sub-period or values at select points in time are reported. Many companies make strategic business decisions over timeframes in excess of five years. The Economist Intelligence Unit's long-term projections will provide information to facilitate such decisions. Long-term forecasts and scenarios are also vital in understanding some of the big economic issues that will shape global business in the coming decades. We are well placed to build on and extend the five-year forecasts to produce long-term projections and scenarios because of the existing forward-looking analysis and models in the Country Forecast (in particular, the business environment rankings model). These are used to forecast some of the key drivers of long-run growth, as explained in detail below.
Growth projections The main building blocks for the long-term forecasts of key market and macroeconomic variables are long-run real GDP growth projections. We have estimated growth regressions that link real growth in GDP per head to a large set of growth determinants. The determinants of growth consist of the scope for convergence (based on initial GDP per worker at the start of a period); demographic variables; a set of policy variables (measuring the fiscal stance, openness to trade, and the government regulatory burden in product, credit and labour markets); a measure of institutional quality; geography (climate, location and the degree of primary export orientation); education levels and labour quality (as measured by mean years of schooling and life expectancy); the external economic environment (changes in the terms of trade); the level of development of information and communications technology (ICT); and historical legacies (history of independent statehood).
The regressions, which have high explanatory power for growth, allow us to forecast the long-term growth of real GDP per head for sub-periods up to 2050, on the basis of demographic projections and assumptions about the evolution of policy variables and other drivers of long-term growth.
Definitions of variables The dependent variable is GDPG: Average annual growth in real GDP per head, measured at national constant prices.
The independent variables include: LnGDPPL: The natural logarithm of GDP (adjusted for purchasing power parity-PPP) per worker (that is, per population aged 15-65) in constant 1980 US dollars at the start of each decade. Expressed as an index, US$=1.
LnSCHOOL: The natural logarithm of the mean years of schooling of the population aged over 15 at the start of each decade. Missing values for some countries are filled in by estimating mean years of schooling on the basis of an equation relating mean years of schooling (where available) to gross primary school enrolment ten years previously, and to secondary and tertiary enrolment ratios five years previously.
LnLIFEEXP: The natural logarithm of life expectancy at birth at the start of each decade. This variable also enters the equation in squared form, reflecting diminishing returns to growth of increases in life expectancy at high levels.
OPEN: Updated Sachs-Warner index of openness-the fraction of years during each decade in which a country is rated as an open economy according to the following four criteria: (1) average tariff rates below 40%; (2) average quota and licensing coverage of imports of less than 40%; (3) a black-market exchange-rate premium that averaged less than 20%; and (4) no extreme controls (taxes, quotas, state monopolies) on exports.
INST: Index of institutional quality (on a scale of 1-10) that is an average of five sub-indices of measures of the rule of law, quality of the bureaucracy, corruption, the risk of expropriation and the risk of government repudiation of contracts. Forecast values are based on corresponding indicators from our business environment rankings.
LABPOP: The difference between the growth rate of the working-age population (aged 15-65) and the growth rate of the total population in each decade.
TOT: The average annual rate of change of the terms of trade in a given decade.
GOVSAV: The average government savings ratio in each decade (current government revenue minus current government expenditure) expressed as a share of GDP.
TRADESH: The average share of trade (exports and imports of goods and services) in GDP, lagged by one decade to deal with the endogeneity of growth and trade.
GOVREG: An index on a scale of 1-10 of regulation of product, credit and labour markets. For forecast periods, the composite index is based on seven indicators from three categories of our business environment rankings model-from Policy towards private enterprise (ease of setting up new businesses, freedom to compete, price controls); from Financing (openness of the banking system, financial market distortions); and from Labour markets (restrictiveness of labour laws, wage regulation).
ICT: An index, on a scale of 1-10, of the development of information and communications infrastructure.
Control variables include PRIMARY: share of the exports of primary products in GDP at the start of a decade; TROPIC: percentage of the land area within a country that has a tropical climate; COLONY: history of independent statehood-a dummy variable taking the value of 1 if a country was a colony before 1945; and, in some specifications, regional dummy variables.
Summary of findings As in other studies, income per head and human capital are found to be important determinants of growth, with the coefficient on the logarithm of GDP per worker suggesting a relatively modest pace of convergence. The measures of institutional quality and of government regulation enter significantly in all specifications. We found a strong positive impact on growth of government savings and openness in all specifications. The criteria for classifying countries as open are quite permissive. The crucial aspect of trade policy captured by the measure is that it is a high level of distortion, rather than modest levels, that is deleterious for growth. The trade share variable is also moderately significant. The openness index (which is more of a true measure of policy) is hardly affected by the inclusion of trade/GDP shares in the equation. The correlation of the two measures is only .26. Although a tropical climate is highly significant, as is the share of primary exports in GDP, other geographic indicators-such as access to the sea, distance from major growth centres and the proportion of the population residing near coastlines-were not significant. A colonial past (pre-1945) is found to have a significant negative impact on growth, even in more recent periods.
Productivity growth The forecasts of GDP growth, of capital stock growth (based on estimated investment shares and assumed depreciation rates) and of growth in labour supply (based on projections of working-age population and assumptions on labour force participation) yield labour productivity growth and total factor productivity growth forecasts. The latter utilise the growth accounting identity, GY=b*GK+c*GL+A, where GY is growth of real GDP, GK growth of the capital stock and GL growth of human capital (the labour force adjusted for changes in skills). "A" stands for growth in total factor productivity; "b" and "c" are the shares of capital and labour in income. Trade values are forecast on the basis of simple import (function of GDP and relative prices) and export functions. Forecast market exchange rates (that is, the differential between PPP and market exchange rates) depend on the differential in labour productivity growth between a country and the US.

Data sources and definitions The sources for global and domestic data refer to historical data. The source for all forecast data, unless otherwise stated, is The Economist Intelligence Unit
Global data US & OECD GDP growth: OECD
World trade growth: Economist Intelligence Unit aggregate
US & OECD inflation: OECD
Oil prices: dated Brent Blend
Domestic data GDP: Central Statistics Office; all national-accounts data are for fiscal years beginning April 1st of year shown
Population: IMF, IFS
Public finance: World Bank, India CEM, unless revised by the GOI's annual budget papers
Oil production: Oil & Gas Journal; Ministry of Petroleum and Natural Gas
Inflation, exchange rates and money supply: IMF, IFS; Centre for Monitoring Indian Economy, MRIE; RBI, WSS
Yield on 91-day Treasury bills: World Bank, India CEM, unless revised by Centre for Monitoring Indian Economy, MRIE
Short-term benchmark interest rate: World Bank, India CEM; IDBI prime lending rate
Direction of trade: GOI, Economic Survey (annual)
Composition of trade and the current account: World Bank, India CEM, unless revised by Centre for Monitoring Indian Economy, MRIE or RBI, Annual Report
Foreign direct investment (FDI): IMF, IFS; UNCTAD, World Investment Report; includes reinvested profits
Foreign debt: World Bank, International Debt Statistics
Abbreviations CEM: Country Economic Memorandum
GOI: Government of India
IDBI: Industrial Development Bank of India
IFS: International Financial Statistics
MRIE: Monthly Review of the Indian Economy
RBI: Reserve Bank of India
WSS: Weekly Statistical Supplement
Guide to the business rankings model Outline of the model The business rankings model measures the quality or attractiveness of the business environment in the 82 countries covered by Country Forecast using a standard analytical framework. It is designed to reflect the main criteria used by companies to formulate their global business strategies, and is based not only on historical conditions but also on expectations about conditions prevailing over the next five years. This allows The Economist Intelligence Unit to utilise the regularity, depth and detail of its forecasting work to generate a unique set of forward-looking business environment rankings on a regional and global basis.
The business rankings model examines 11 separate criteria or categories, covering the political environment, the macroeconomic environment, market opportunities, policy towards free enterprise and competition, policy towards foreign investment, foreign trade and exchange controls, taxes, financing, the labour market, infrastructure and technological readiness. Each category contains a number of indicators that are assessed by The Economist Intelligence Unit for the last five years and the next five years. The number of indicators in each category varies from five (foreign trade and exchange regimes) to 13 (political environment), and there are 91 indicators in total.
Almost half of the indicators are based on quantitative data (eg GDP growth), and are mostly drawn from national and international statistical sources for the historical period (2015-19) and from Economist Intelligence Unit assessments for the forecast period (2020-24). The other indicators are qualitative in nature (eg quality of the financial regulatory system), and are drawn from a range of data sources and business surveys adjusted by The Economist Intelligence Unit for 2015-19. All forecasts for the qualitative indicators covering 2020-24 are based on Economist Intelligence Unit assessments.
Sources used in the business rankings model include Akamai Technologies, State of the Internet; CIA, World Factbook; The Economist Intelligence Unit, Country Risk Service, Country Commerce, Democracy Index, Risk Briefing; IMF, Annual Report on Exchange Arrangements and Exchange Restrictions; International Institute for Management Development, World Competitiveness Yearbook; International Labour Organisation, International Labour Statistics Yearbook; International Telecommunication Union, ICT Indicators Database; Transparency International, Corruption Perceptions Index; UN Conference on Trade and Development, Ecommerce Index; World Bank, World Development Indicators, Doing Business; World Economic Forum, Global Competitiveness Index; World Intellectual Property Organisation, IP Facts and Figures.
Calculating the rankings The rankings are calculated in several stages. First, each of the 91 indicators is scored on a scale from 1 (very bad for business) to 5 (very good for business). The aggregate category scores are derived on the basis of simple or weighted averages of the indicator scores within a given category. These are then adjusted, on the basis of a linear transformation, to produce index values on a 1-10 scale. An arithmetic average of the ten category index values is then calculated to yield the aggregate business environment score for each country, again on a 1-10 scale.
The use of equal weights for the categories to derive the overall score reflects in part the theoretical uncertainty about the relative importance of the primary determinants of investment. Surveys of foreign direct investors' intentions yield widely differing results on the relative importance of different factors. Weighted scores for individual categories based on correlation coefficients of recent foreign direct investment inflows do not in any case produce overall results that are significantly different from those derived from a system based on equal weights.
For most quantitative indicators the data are arrayed in ascending or descending order and split into five bands (quintiles). The countries falling in the first quintile are assigned scores of 5, those falling in the second quintile score 4 and so on. The cut-off points between bands are based on the average of the raw indicator values for the top and bottom countries in adjacent quintiles. The 2015-19 ranges are then used to derive 2020-24 scores. This allows for intertemporal as well as cross-country comparisons of the indicator and category scores.
Measurement and grading issues The indices and rankings attempt to measure the average quality of the business environment over the entire historical or forecast period, not simply at the start or at the end of the period. Thus, in the forecast we assign an average grade to elements of the business environment over 2020-24, not to the likely situation in 2024 only.
The scores based on quantitative data are usually calculated on the basis of the numeric average for an indicator over the period. In some cases, the "average" is represented, as an approximation, by the recorded value at the mid-point of the period (2017 or 2022). In only a few cases is the relevant variable appropriately measured by the value at the start of the period (eg educational attainments). For one indicator (the natural resources endowment), the score remains constant for both the historical and forecast periods.

Full text: - Sebastián Piñera of the centre-right Chile Vamos coalition won the 2017 presidential election and took office in March 2018. A change to a more pro-portional electoral system challenged the traditional domination of centre-left and centre-right coalitions; as a result, no coalition currently holds a majority in either house of Congress. This has culminated in legislative gridlock, which will slow the legislative agenda, although the need for consensus-building has kept policy centrist to date. The social unrest of 2019 resulted in a shift to more socially orientated, left-leaning policies, and this is likely to persist in the medium term. As a result, market-friendly reforms will be put on the back burner, although The Economist Intelligence Unit does not expect a significant break away from existing business-friendly policies.

Chile--highlights: Business environment outlook

7.50 7.65 23 19 1 1
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.

- Chile remains in top position in our business environment rankings for Latin America over the 2020-24 forecast period, despite the social crisis observed last year, and improves moderately in the global ranking. Although its economy will be hit by the coronavirus (Covid-19) pandemic, the policy stance towards foreign investors is not expected to deter-iorate and this will facilitate a relatively firm recovery in foreign direct investment (FDI), particularly later in the forecast period. Chile's strengths will continue to lie in an open foreign investment regime, a broadly level playing field, open trading relationships, and deep and sophisticated capital markets. Improvements to education and infrastructure-including renewable energy supply during the forecast period-will further underpin the environment for business.

- Annual real GDP growth will average 1.9% in 2020-24. This is a softer pace of growth than in the previous five-year period, mainly owing to the sharp contraction in real GDP (6.4%) expected in 2020 amid the pandemic. This will be followed by a strong recovery process relative to regional peers, although output will not reach pre-coronavirus levels until 2022. The current account will spring into surplus temporarily in 2020, as exports and copper prices recover faster than demand for imports and oil prices. It will return to a deficit thereafter, owing to higher debt repayments and profit repatriation by multinational firms, but it will remain manageable. Deficits will be financed through capital inflows, particularly foreign direct investment (FDI).

- At an estimated 19m in 2019, Chile's small population is growing, but at a slower rate than most of its neighbours. Chile's birth rate has fallen steadily in recent years, from 16.4 per 1,000 people in 2002-07 to 13.9 per 1,000 in 2014-18. Chile also has an older demographic profile than most in the region, with those aged 65 years and over accounting for more than 10% of the total population-a proportion that is set to rise to 14% by 2023. As a result, the dependency ratio has been rising and stood at 45.7% in 2019. The labour force is forecast to grow by an average of 0.6% in 2020-24. Health indicators are broadly comparable with those of other OECD economies.

- Retail services and import demand will remain sluggish in the near term, reflecting the hit to consumer sentiments stemming from the pandemic, but will pick up thereafter as the economy steps out of the crisis and income losses are recuperated. Ample government infrastructure concessions and expansion in the renewables sector will provide opportunities. Chile's market opportunities are constrained by its relatively small population; however, free-market policies, relative political stability and effective economic management, will continue to attract investment.

From May 2019 The Economist Intelligence Unit's long-term growth forecasts have been revised to take into account the economic impact of climate change.

- Broad consensus in favour of generally orthodox monetary and fiscal policies will underpin post-coronavirus, long-term economic growth, but challenges from new left-wing political parties are a risk, especially after the 2019 social crisis. Free-trade agreements within and outside the region will help to attract foreign investment. Average annual GDP growth is forecast to reach 2.4% in 2020-30, accelerating to 3.5% in 2031-50. The capital stock will continue to grow and investment will reach 27.3% of GDP by 2050. However, as growth in the working-age population slows, so will the increase in labour supply, causing economic growth to become more dependent on productivity gains.

Background: In 1988 the military ruler, Augusto Pinochet, lost a referendum that would have allowed him to stay in office. Instead, the centre-left Concertación de Partidos por la Democracia coalition (later Nueva Mayoría-NM) won the December 1989 general election and the next four presidential elections. A realignment of forces helped the centre right t0 win the 2010 election. Since then there has been alternation between governments on the right and the left. Michelle Bachelet of the NM, who was first elected president in 2006-10 before being succeeded by Sebastián Piñera (2010-14), was re-elected in 2014. Ms Bachelet was again succeeded by Mr Piñera, who took office in March 2018.
Political structure: The political system is presidential, with a bicameral legislature that comprises a 43-seat Senate (the upper house) and a 155-seat Chamber of Deputies (the lower house). The presidential term is four years and consecutive re-election is not permitted. This structure may be subject to change-possibly towards a more prime-ministerial model-as part of ongoing constitutional reform. The judiciary is independent, but the executive exerts some influence through the nomination of temporary judges and the control of promotions to the Supreme Court. Monetary policy is directed by the autonomous Banco Central de Chile (the central bank). Chile has 15 regions, 54 provinces and 346 municipalities.
Policy issues: The coronavirus (Covid-19) pandemic, combined with growing public discontent with long-standing issues of inequality and a high cost of living, will result in the centre-right Chile Vamos coalition putting efforts at fiscal consolidation on the back burner and adopting a more expansive fiscal stance than before. This will be accompanied by accommodative monetary policy to contain the hit to the economy and financial system stemming from the pandemic.
Taxation: Corporate income tax is assessed at two stages. Declared profit is subject to a 27% first-category tax (FCIT). When profit is distributed to shareholders or partners, a 35% second-category tax applies, minus a credit for FCIT. The tax rate on dividends and interest payments to non-banks is 35%. Royalties and fees transferred abroad are subject to a 30-35% withholding tax. Value-added tax (VAT) is levied at 19%.
Foreign trade: The general import tariff rate is 6%, but the trade-weighted effective average rate is less than 2%, owing to preferences granted through trade accords. In 2019 goods exports totalled US$69.9bn; goods imports stood at US$65.7bn.

Political outlook: Political forces at a glance Sebastián Piñera of the centre-right Chile Vamos (CV) coalition, who served as president in 2010-14, won the December 2017 presidential run-off and took office for a new four-year term on March 11th 2018. CV is chiefly composed of the conservative Unión Demócrata Independiente and the centre-right Renovación Nacional (Mr Piñera's party), but also includes the smaller Evolución Política (Evópoli). No party holds a majority in either the Chamber of Deputies (the lower house) or the Senate (the upper house), but CV holds the largest number of seats in both chambers. The centre-left opposition is comprised of the parties of the former Nueva Mayoría (NM) coalition, which led the previous government (2014-18), and under a previous configuration the Concertación de Partidos por la Democracia governed Chile from 1990 to 2010. After the last election, the left-wing Frente Amplio emerged as the third-largest force in Congress. The centrist Partido Democracia Cristiana (PDC) broke from NM in April 2018, and currently forms the fourth-largest bloc in the lower house and third-largest in the upper house. Independent parties, which are largely on the centre-left, also have a congressional presence.
CV holds 19 of 43 seats in the upper house and 72 of 155 in the lower house. It relies on votes from other coalitions or dissident members of the opposition to pass legislation. In recent times-especially after the social unrest in 2019-internal conflict within CV has grown, with some elements shifting to support more populist, left-leaning policies, as with the pension withdrawal bill. The need to win back support from within CV and from the opposition will keep policymaking broadly centrist.

Political outlook: Political stability The president faces a turbulent year ahead, with the global coronavirus (Covid-19) pandemic bearing down on Chile at a time of substantial domestic political uncertainty. A referendum on a landmark constitutional reform is due this year, and a presidential election is set for next year. In the meantime, the pandemic is having serious political consequences for a country that has been in the grip of protracted social unrest since protests broke out in October 2019. Although Mr Piñera's approval ratings saw a slight uptick in March-May, owing to a robust policy response by his administration to counter the economic fallout stem-ming from the pandemic, but even this modest boost has proved short-lived, amid criticism of the government's lax handling of the pandemic (the country has lacked a nationwide quarantine, and compliance with quar-antine measures in the capital, Santiago, has been poor. According to the latest poll by Cadem (a local pollster), approval ratings for the Piñera administration sunk to 16% on July 20th-from 23% in the first week of July.
Although Chile seems to have begun a flattening of its coronavirus curve and is bracing for a step-by-step reopening plan announced by Mr Piñera on July 19th, the government is far from out of the woods. Recent events, in the form of a popular, opposition-sponsored pension bill (which has secured congressional approval in line with our expectations), that allows early pension withdrawals of up to 10% of assets under management, suggest that the government will be susceptible to concerted opposition to its agenda, and will be powerless to prevent an element of populism creeping into policymaking. The pension bill had strong public support and was a trigger for renewed public protests. The bill even garnered the support of 13 lawmakers from CV, reflecting internal fissures within the ruling coalition, which could hinder governability and policymaking during the remainder of Mr Piñera's term.
Given that Mr Piñera has campaigned strongly against the passing of the bill, its approval in the Senate comes as a major political defeat for his administration, which will further undermine his political standing. His position will remain weak right up until the presidential election. Even assuming that the disease is brought under control (which The Economist Intelligence Unit expects to happen in the second half of 2020), there will be strong pressure on the government to fulfil its social agenda; we expect some hurdles in achieving this as fiscal resources have been increasingly stretched in the wake of the pandemic, and although some fiscal space is still left, this is less than what was available before the outbreak of the coronavirus. Although there is a strong possibility that regular protests will resume once the disease is under control, for now we assume that these will be smaller in scale than they were during the peak observed in October-November 2019. Although we expect policy-making to remain largely orthodox during the rest of Mr Piñera's term, there are increasing risks to this outlook, as highlighted by the opposition's bid to pass more populist reforms that could work towards undermining Chile's long-standing, business-friendly economic model.
Political outlook: Political and institutional effectiveness Chile's system of government has been considered the most effective and technically adept in Latin America, owing in part to a relatively high degree of political stability and a highly professional bureaucracy. Political stability, however, has been under threat since October 2019, when mass protests broke out across the country against long-standing issues of inequality and a high cost of living. Since the peaceful transition to democracy in 1990, successive admin-istrations have operated amid a broad consensus around maintaining the open and liberal economic model instituted by the military regime of Augusto Pinochet (1973-90), while also strengthening democratic institutions. However, the 2017 election, under new electoral rules, resulted in a more fractured Congress, returning Chile to its pre-dictatorship political landscape of coalitions of the right, left and centre. This has slowed the legislative process and will continue to do so. Although so far consensus policymaking has resulted in broadly centrist policies, some polarisation could crop up over time, with extremes on the right and left gaining more power vis-à-vis the centre.
Political engagement and turnout remain low, posing a challenge to long-term confidence in the system. Although no coalition holds a majority (a situation that could continue in future governments), dramatic policy shifts are unlikely. That said, the social movement of 2019 and the coronavirus pandemic have pressured the centre-right government into relenting to more populist policies and a shift in policy to focus more on social trends could continue with future governments. Changes to organic constitutional provisions require a four-sevenths majority in both houses, while passing bills to reinterpret or modify the constitution require a three-fifths and two-thirds majority, respectively.
Corruption in Chile remains low, even compared with OECD standards-it is the 27th least corrupt country in the world-according to the 2018 Corruption Perceptions Index prepared by Transparency International (a global anti-corruption watchdog). Nevertheless, recent years have seen several prominent scandals in both the public and private sectors, which have fuelled public resentment. The scale of wrongdoing, however, is not equivalent to current scandals in other countries in the region, and public prosecutors have so far proved energetic in bringing a number of perpetrators to account.
A civil-service reform in 2003 helped to increase meritocracy by reducing the number of political appointees at the head of government agencies by over 80%, and by making civil servants accountable to an independent directorate. Official transparency and efficiency has also been fostered by the centralisation of the procurement tenders of all government departments and public-sector agencies into a single online platform. Chile's judicial system is relatively efficient and transparent. The criminal justice system was modernised over a period of six years, following reforms in 1999 that created an office of public prosecutions and established a legal aid service, as well as a new code for penal procedures. Chile ranks highly in most measures of rule of law, protection of private property and overall institutional effectiveness.
Political outlook: Election watch Crucial votes are approaching in Chile, including a referendum on constitutional reform that was one of the major outcomes of last year's social protests, as well as the presidential election late next year. The electoral schedule has been pushed back slightly as a result of the pandemic, in a measure that has received unanimous support. The constitutional referendum was also delayed to October 25th (from April 26th), the local primaries to November (from June), and the local, gubernatorial and constituent assembly elections to April 2021 (from October 25th 2020). We do not currently expect the postponement of the 2020 electoral calendar to delay the legislative and presidential elections that are due in November 2021.
We will be watching the presidential campaign closely for signs that the broad policy consensus, which has dominated Chilean politics, is fraying and raising the chances of a political outsider. For now, our forecasts are based on an assum-ption that, broadly speaking, the orthodox policy framework that has served Chile in past decades will remain in place in the next government, although we also assume a greater focus on social welfare in the aftermath of last year's protests and, more recently, Covid-19.
From the ruling CV itself, Senator Felipe Kast from the centre-right Evópoli has emerged as the strongest candidate for the presidency. However, public support has been the highest for Joaquin Lavín of the Independent Democratic Party-61% approval, according to a June 15th Cadem poll, with 12% of respondents believing that Mr Lavín will become the next president. Mr Lavín, who is considered a traditional right-wing politician, has veered to the centre in terms of his stance on social issues, as well as the much-debated pension with-drawal bill, which he supported. However, it is still too early to make a decisive election call, especially given that Mr Lavín has made no official statement about his intention to stand for presidency. The situation will become clearer once the dust surrounding the coronavirus settles.
Political outlook: International relations Although the government will direct its focus from foreign policy issues-such as regional and global integration efforts-towards policies aimed at tackling the pandemic and restoring domestic stability, some progress is still being made on the front of digital integration. For instance, on June 14th Chile signed a three-way agreement with Singapore and New Zealand, called the Digital Economy Partnership Agreement to enhance digital connectivity to ensure business continuity during the pandemic. The deal could give impulse to the recovery of certain industries that are integrated into the digital economy (such as retail services), promoting consumer confidence, enhancing productivity and compet-itiveness, and boosting job growth in Chile. In the long term, the deal could serve as the example for future international agreements on digital economies.

Many of the countries covered in The Economist Intelligence Unit's business environment rankings (BER) will see some deterioration in the overall invest-ment climate during the 2020-24 forecast period. This reflects sharp economic recessions led by the coronavirus (Covid-19) crisis, which prompts govern-ments to turn inwards, prioritising domestic over foreign investors and pausing business-friendly reforms. Chile is one of the few countries that is expected to register an improvement (albeit slight) in its underlying BER score, which boosts the country's global ranking from 23rd to 19th place and consolidates its position as the most attractive investment climate in Latin America.
Chile's investment regime will benefit from a long-standing and well-functioning market economy, with an open investment regime, sophisticated capital markets and a large network of free-trade agreements (FTAs). A low public debt burden relative to the region provides the authorities with greater scope to tackle the coronavirus pandemic through large fiscal support packages for both businesses and households. The government's policy stance is unlikely to shift dramatically in any of the main categories comprising the overall BER. Chile's policies towards foreign investment, private enterprise and competition will therefore remain its greatest strengths in terms of the business environment. Foreign investment will be affected by a broader global downturn as business confidence weakens in 2020, but Chile's skilled labour force, firm rule of law and solid regulatory framework will entice foreign investors once global sentiment picks up.
A constitutional reform and populist policies would undermine business Our baseline forecast remains positive, but there are several factors that pose some downside risk in 2020-24. The first relates to the coronavirus outbreak. If the virus does not come under control and the economy sustains deeper and more prolonged damage than we expect, the government may come under pressure to change the policy stance, to the detriment of private-sector investors. Since the October 2019 protests, the government has been under significant public pressure to put business-friendly policies on the back burner and shift focus towards enhancing social security measures, reducing inequality and the cost of living. Additional risks stem from a possible reform to the constitution. The public is likely to vote in favour of rewriting the constitution in a national referendum scheduled for October. There is currently little indication of proposed amend-ments; this would be the responsibility of a committee that would also be selected in October. We believe that the reforms would respond to key social concerns that spurred the unrest in late 2019. Although we do not expect a significant rollback of existing business-friendly policies, the focus on new measures to improve the business environment will be less of a priority than before the unrest in 2019. Some opposition-backed populist reforms, such as the early withdrawal of pension funds, could seep into the policy framework, which would work towards undermining the business environment. Another major risk stems from next year's presidential elections, which could bring a major shift away from policy orthodoxy.

Business environment outlook: Chile's business environment at a glance Policy towards private enterprise and competition 2020-21: Government focuses on improving business climate by simplifying tax processes.
2022-24: Cutting of red tape with investor-friendly measures makes headway.
Policy towards foreign investment 2020-21: Investment regime remains among world's most liberal. Investment promotion agency maintains investor-friendly policies seeking to move beyond natural resources; foreign direct investment (FDI) drops sharply nevertheless amid broader global downturn.
2022-24: Chile's network of bilateral double-taxation and investment protection accords widens further. Outward investment grows.
Foreign trade and exchange controls 2020-21: Narrow import-tariff dispersion (0-6%) and free capital flows owing to multiple free-trade agreements.
2022-24: Export development remains a policy priority, and government moves to diversify trade away from its dependence on the US and China.
Taxes 2020-21: Corporate tax structure simplified to boost investment, but tax cuts unlikely. Maximum personal rate lowered.
2022-24: Simplification of tax code, including new tax-saving mechanisms.
Financing 2020-21: Government-backed loan guarantees available. Domestic long-term interest rates are high, and bank lending practices are conservative. Large firms retain reasonable access to bond markets, albeit at somewhat higher rates.
2022-24: Further measures to facilitate financing for small businesses, particularly new ventures.
The labour market 2020-21: Some measures to assuage public frustrations, including reductions in working hours and increase in the minimum wage. Trade unions remain strong.
2022-24: Liberalisation of some working arrangements, along with performance-related pay in public sector.
Infrastructure 2020-21: Generally good telecommunications; technological infrastructure is expanded further. Investment in power generation and highway network continues, but energy sector remains vulnerable to shortages.
2022-24: Upgrading of transport infrastructure through concessions. New energy investment comes on stream following connection between north and central grids, benefitting expansion of non-conventional renewable sources.
Technological readiness 2020-21: "Start-Up Chile" programme supported by government continues to attract small technology firms.
2022-24: Government focus on upgrading digital infrastructure, including rural broadband and public WiFi hotspots.
Business environment outlook: Macroeconomic environment                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2015-19 2020-24 2015-19 2020-24 2015-19 2020-24
8.3 6.6 11 33 1 3
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
Chile's macroeconomic environment shifts from being one of its strongest areas of the business environment in the 2015-19 historical period to one of its weakest areas in 2020-24. This reflects the impact of both the late 2019 protests and the coronavirus pandemic on economic activity. Real GDP will contract sharply in 2020 as a result of suppressed domestic and external demand, and although we are forecasting a partial recovery in 2021, real GDP will not return to pre-pandemic levels until 2022 at the earliest. Although copper prices fell sharply at the start of the coronavirus outbreak, they have since recovered, providing some respite to the external accounts. We expect a faster recovery of exports coupled with continued import compression to result in a temporary movement of the current account into surplus in 2020. This will be followed by a gradual return to deficit as oil prices recover and import demand picks up.
Countercyclical policy will increase the fiscal deficit sharply
- A sharp widening of the fiscal deficit is also a key factor behind the deter-ioration in Chile's score. The public finances were in excellent shape before the pandemic, with a very low public debt burden and ample savings in sovereign wealth funds, which have enabled the authorities to implement a counter-cyclical fiscal policy in response to the crisis. Although extensive financial support will help to prop up comp-anies operating in Chile in 2020-21 (and is major factor driving the country's BER scores in other areas), the increase in the fiscal deficit has a significant negative impact on Chile's score in this category. Other areas of the macro-economic environment will continue to score strongly. A solid institutional framework and a general consensus over orthodox policy, free markets and integration in the world economy will remain unchanged.
- The Banco Central de Chile (BCCh, the central bank) has been indep-endent for over three decades, and its autonomy is unlikely to come under threat in the forecast period. The BCCh is complemented by an efficient banking supervisory body, the Superintendencia de Bancos e Instituciones Financieras, which has helped to maintain a modern and well-capitalised banking sector.

Business environment outlook: Policy towards private enterprise and competition                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2015-19 2020-24 2015-19 2020-24 2015-19 2020-24
8.5 8.8 8 6 1 1
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
Decades of consistent market-friendly policy and reforms have kept Chile in pole position in Latin America, while it jumps two places in the global ranking for government policy towards private enterprise and competition. Following various privatisation programmes-mostly in the late 1980s under the military regime of Augusto Pinochet (1973-90)-Chile has only a small number of firms left in state hands (most notably Codelco, the world's largest copper producer). Governments on both the right and left have pursued market-orientated solu-tions to economic problems, which we expect to continue in 2020-24. In recent years red tape has been significantly reduced-for instance, since 2013 a firm can be created online in a single day and without high cost. Competition law is robust and is backed by an independent agency with broad powers to invest-igate and prosecute violations. A separate tribunal investigates claims of mono-polistic practices, including collusion and abuse of a dominant market position.

- In an effort to reduce unnecessary bureaucracy, in May 2018 the govern-ment launched the Oficina de Grandes Proyectos Sustentables (GPS), which is located in the economy ministry and serves as a one-stop shop for investors. As at July the GPS was co-ordinating 226 investment projects, representing US$68.5bn in investment in the next five years, and with the potential to create 77,780 new jobs. The GPS has been tasked with identifying and removing other investment bottlenecks.
- The platform "empresa en un día" (company in a day) was launched by the first government of Sebastián Piñera (2010-14) in 2013 to spur entrepreneurship. Since then, more than 550,000 companies have been created in Chile. In 2019 nearly 110,000 new businesses were created-a 7.3% increase from 2018. The total number of firms registered in Chile now exceeds a million, of which almost all are either small or medium-sized, and 1% are large. Small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) generate about 65% of all jobs.
- The state directly controls a handful of companies and holds stakes in another 22 businesses (as at end-2019) operating under the nominal oversight of the Sistema de Empresas Públicas (Public Enterprise System). State-owned firms are meant to generate value through fiscal transfers from their profits and by pursuing initiatives that improve social welfare, but are more or less unattractive to private-sector investors. They contribute to development targets in areas such as communications, defence, energy and natural resources, geographical integ-ration, and transport. There have been no major sales of government holdings since 2012; given the state's generally minor stakes, there is also little scope for further privatisations.

Business environment outlook: Policy towards foreign investment Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2015-19 2020-24 2015-19 2020-24 2015-19 2020-24
9.6 9.6 3 2 1 1
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
Chile's outlook for FDI inflows remains positive despite the pandemic Chile's score for policy towards foreign investment remains unchanged, despite the impact of the coronavirus on investor sentiment as first-quarter foreign direct investment (FDI) inflows have so far grown substantially in 2020, representing its strongest area of the BER. It also reflects the expectation that the impact of the pandemic on investment will not prompt a change in the govern-ment's underlying policy stance towards foreign investors. The country ranks second globally and will remain the top-ranked in Latin America (by some margin) during 2020-24. The foreign-investment regime is based on non-discrimination between local and foreign investors, as mandated by the constitution. The country grants foreign investors virtually unrestricted access to develop new ventures and acquire existing ones, which over the years has meant that the country has attracted substantial flows of FDI. Inward FDI rose to US$11.9bn in 2019 (from US$7.3bn in 2018), and we expect it to rise in 2020 despite the effects of the pandemic, owing mainly to a strong first-quarter performance. Our outlook for FDI remains positive for the remainder of the forecast period. A solid track record in terms of inward FDI in recent years, particularly during 2011-15 (when inflows averaged US$24.7bn per year), means that the stock of inward FDI per head is high, at just under US$12,000 in 2019 (compared with just over US$14,000 in the US). The country's natural resources and its long track record of economic and political stability, along with its openness to foreign invest-ment, means that FDI will recover faster than other countries in the region.

- Chile will remain one of the world's top destinations for copper mining investment. Before the coronavirus pandemic, the Comisión Nacional del Cobre (Cochilco, the state copper authority) had indicated that it believed mining investment would total US$72.5bn in 2019-28, with firms attracted by Chile's vast mineral wealth and close proximity to coastal ports. Cochilco has conceded that weaker demand will affect the copper sector in 2020, but has emphasised that it expects a rebound from 2021 and that it does not envisage a significant interruption to longer-term investment plans. We broadly share this interpret-ation, on the assumption that there are not damaging future waves of the pandemic, which would severely impact on demand for copper from China-a key importer. Copper prices are expected to recover from 2021, with China's longer-term infrastructure and urbanisation plans boding well for firmer demand. In turn, this will support firmer investment in Chile's copper sector.
- The Corporación de Fomento de la Producción (Corfo, the government's development-promotion agency,) and InvestChile (a new investment-promotion office) will continue to manage various industry-specific incentive programmes. Until now, these have aimed to promote investments in energy, forestry, marine activities, mining and tourism, but efforts may shift to focus on those sectors where a firmer recovery is anticipated. A separate government fund will also target the development of infrastructure projects. Corfo provides affordable financing, subsidies and tax credits for research and development, among various other incentives. InvestChile will continue to offer personalised advisory services to navigate the government's many investment-promotion programmes. We expect this broad structure to remain in place under the next administration.

Business environment outlook: Foreign trade and exchange controls                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2015-19 2020-24 2015-19 2020-24 2015-19 2020-24
8.7 8.7 28 21 2 2
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
Chile has more FTAs than any other country Chile's trade and foreign-exchange regime will remain broadly open during the forecast period, with the underlying score remaining unchanged and its global ranking improving by seven places in 2020-24. Although the coronavirus crisis will prompt a fall in foreign trade as a share of GDP, export and import volumes will not drop substantially enough to affect the underlying score in this category. Moreover, underlying policy will remain supportive and we do not expect the government to respond to the crisis by raising tariffs or veering away from a long-running commitment to free trade. We also do not expect any exchange restrictions to be introduced that would affect capital or trade flows.

- Chile has one of the simplest and most transparent trade regimes in the world. The country opted for unilateral trade liberalisation in the 1970s and has actively pursued FTAs to promote export-led growth. Chile has a single import-tariff rate, with very few exceptions, and has signed trade agreements with a broad network of international partners. As at July these totalled 29 agreements and involved 65 countries, which account for 88% of global GDP and 67% of the global population. Around 95% of Chile's trade is conducted on a preferential basis. The most important are FTAs signed with the EU (2003), the US (2004), China (2006) and Japan (2007). Chile also has FTAs with South Korea, Malaysia, Turkey, the European Free-Trade Association, Canada, Central America, Australia, Vietnam, Hong Kong and Mexico. Chile is also a member of the Pacific Alliance free-trade bloc-together with Mexico, Colombia and Peru-and has more limited agreements with India, New Zealand, Singapore and Brunei.
- The Piñera government signed an FTA with Brazil in 2018, just before the former Brazilian president, Michel Temer (2016-18), left office. The Chilean legislature ratified the agreement in July 2020, but the FTA has not been ratified yet by Brazil. Ratification is unlikely in the short term in the context of the coronavirus pandemic; at best it might come be ratified and come into force towards the end of the 2020-24 forecast period.
- With the failure of the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) following the decision of the US president, Donald Trump, to pull the US from the deal, Chile and the ten other remaining countries signed the Comprehensive and Progressive Agreement for Trans-Pacific Partnership (CPTPP) in March 2018. Mr Piñera submitted it to Congress in November and it was approved in the Chamber of Deputies (the lower house) after a lengthy debate in April 2019. Ratification by the Senate (the upper house), however, was held up in late 2019 by mass protests and, in early 2020, by the coronavirus outbreak. However, we expect eventual ratification within the forecast period.

Business environment outlook: Taxes                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2015-19 2020-24 2015-19 2020-24 2015-19 2020-24
7.4 7.8 18 14 1 1
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
The government is seeking to simplify the current tax system Chile's score for tax policy improves slightly in the forecast period, allowing it to rise to 14th place globally in the ranking, with the country remaining best-ranked in the Latin American region. Total taxes paid remain relatively low by international comparison, but filing procedures are onerous. According to the World Bank's Doing Business 2020 report, it takes 296 hours per year to prepare, file and pay corporate income tax, value-added or sales tax, and labour taxes, compared with an OECD high-income average of 159 hours.

- There have been several reforms to the tax system in recent years. A major reform passed in 2014 raised corporate taxes and created a dual-taxation system that for many in the private sector was too complicated to implement fully. As a result, the government signed into law a "reform to the reform" in February 2016 that left only one system in place, the so-called semi-integrated system, in which companies pay a 27% corporate tax rate, and shareholders also pay income tax, but with businesses permitted to deduct some earnings if these are reinvested. In 2018 the administration introduced another reform proposal that aimed to simplify the corporate tax code and create a unified system that integrated the corporate and personal tax regimes. However, following nationwide protests that began in October 2019, the bill underwent extensive changes in the Senate, where the idea of a unified system was rejected. The revised proposal simplifies and lowers taxes for small businesses, and introduces a variety of new levies including a new income tax bracket for the wealthiest individuals, a 40% tax rate for those earning above Ps15m (about US$19,000) per month and a surcharge on the property tax for those with properties valued above Ps400m.
- Public frustrations about meagre pension benefits (which often come in at below the monthly minimum wage of US$400) was one of the factors behind the bout of social unrest that erupted in October 2019. The government had already tabled a pension reform bill, but as a result of the unrest the authorities amended the bill, increasing the mandatory contributions paid by employers by 6 percentage points and beefing up a solidarity component of transfers to the poorest pensioners. Regulatory changes are also proposed that would incentivise competition among providers and increase returns on investments. The govern-ment estimates that these changes will collectively increase pensions by nearly 30%. The government pledged to speed up discussions around the bill during March, but since then the coronavirus pandemic has slowed progress. In mid-July, the government confirmed that a legislative commission will shortly assess the bill; we expect approval and ratification before the end of the current administration's term.

Business environment outlook: Financing                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2015-19 2020-24 2015-19 2020-24 2015-19 2020-24
8.1 8.5 8 7 1 1
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
Corporate access to finance will weaken in 2020, before recovering from 2021 Chile remains the leader in Latin America in terms of securing corporate finance, and its global ranking is set to improve by one place in 2020-24. Although the impact of the coronavirus pandemic will affect corporate access to finance in Chile, the fact that the banking sector was in solid shape before the crisis will mean that the impact on companies operating in Chile will be less severe than elsewhere in the region. A US$24bn credit line approved by the IMF will help the BCCh to ease monetary policy (through non-conventional means as the policy rate is already extremely low), which will feed through to the domestic banking system. Corporate bond issuance has dropped sharply in recent months on the back of the pandemic, but Chile continues to boast a sophisticated capital market with high levels of stockmarket capitalisation, and corporate issuance is likely to recover from 2021.

- Conservative lending practices helped Chile to avoid a credit bubble in the years leading up to 2008, and its low reliance on wholesale markets (even for subsidiaries of foreign US and European banks) enabled it to escape relatively unscathed from the 2008-09 global financial crisis and subsequent euro zone crisis. Nevertheless, the coronavirus pandemic has raised credit risks for lenders that are most exposed to the business cycle. We expect the system to be resilient, even in the context of the sharp deterioration in global conditions, with previous stress tests conducted by the BCCh showing that the banking system has enough capital and reserves buffer to deal with even a severely adverse scenario. That said, the cost of credit may rise in 2020-21, particularly for Chilean companies who operate in sectors most exposed to the downturn.
- Once underlying conditions improve, we expect large firms to benefit from easier access to long-term finance through credits and leasing, while some will also take advantage of other financing options, such as stock and bond issues, as well as what has been until now a competitive and flexible syndicated loan market for maturities of up to ten years.

Financing conditions for smaller firms will be even tighter, owing to Covid-19
- In contrast to larger firms, many small companies will find it more difficult to obtain bank credit, particularly in 2020-21. According to OECD data, just 18.6% of commercial lending goes to SMEs, one of the lowest levels in the OECD and well below other countries in the region; the level is 26% in Colombia and nearly 40% in Brazil. Small companies have often had to rely on 30-day credit lines, which have been more difficult to secure in the current environment. Part of the government's coronavirus support package is designed to improve the availability of credit for SMEs, while the Financial Market Commission has permitted the use of mortgage guarantees to safeguard SME loans. This will help to ease the problems facing SMEs, but overall financing conditions for these companies will still be tighter, making obtaining credit more difficult during 2020-24.

Business environment outlook: The labour market                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2015-19 2020-24 2015-19 2020-24 2015-19 2020-24
6.5 6.7 29 26 2 2
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
Chile performs less well in the labour market category, which despite some improvement in the score, remains one of the weaker areas of Chile's business environment in 2020-24. The improvement reflects the passage of education reforms, which will increase the supply of educated and skilled workers in the forecast period. These were introduced under the second government of Michelle Bachelet (2006-10; 2014-18) but will have more of an impact during the 2020-24 forecast period, owing to a gradual rollout of measures designed to address long-running deficiencies in the country's education system, which-although better than that of many neighbouring countries-lags behind that of the developing Asia region and other countries in the OECD (of which Chile is a member). The measures expand access to pre-school, university and vocational education. Businesses will continue to complain that the labour regime is too rigid and that it offers overly strong worker protections through restrictive regulations and high firing costs (one month's wage per year worked in the company). However, following social unrest in late 2019, no moves to pass legislation to scale back this protection are likely. On the contrary, measures such as a rise in the mini-mum wage and a reduction in the number of working hours will form part of a greater social agenda that is designed to placate restive public opinion.
Labour reform is in its early stages of implementation
- A labour reform approved in 2017 strengthened unions, as it expanded the categories of workers who can join a union, set a floor for negotiations (not permitting the weakening of workers' benefits) and prohibited the replacement of striking workers. It also prohibited the extension of benefits to non-union members. So far, the impact of the reform has been muted (only 9% of workers belong to a union, although the level is higher in the mining sector).
- Unemployment is forecast to virtually double as a result of the coronavirus pandemic, rising from 7.1% in 2019 to 15.2% in 2020. However, many of the jobs lost will be in low-skilled areas, meaning that skills shortages will remain a problem in some sectors.

Business environment outlook: Infrastructure                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2015-19 2020-24 2015-19 2020-24 2015-19 2020-24
6.5 7.3 29 27 1 1
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
Chile retains first place in the regional ranking for infrastructure in 2020-24 and climbs by two places, to 27th, in the global ranking. Chile's telecommunications and technological infrastructure is modern, particularly by regional standards, as the regulatory system for telecoms encourages competition and the early adoption of new technologies. The transport infrastructure is resilient and mostly withstands regular seismic events and other natural disasters. A series of natural disasters have impacted the country since 2010, including: an earthquake and a tsunami in 2010 in the centre-south region; earthquakes, tsunamis and floods in the north in 2014-15; the Calbuco volcano eruption of 2015; and wildfires in the centre-south in 2017. Virtually all damaged infra-structure has since been restored. Although a weakening of the public finances in 2020-21 will complicate ambitious plans for accelerated investment in a long-term infrastructure plan, we expect greater progress in 2022-24.

- Significant funding will continue to be channelled into transport infra-structure. A new underground railway line in the capital, Santiago, opened in November 2017. The government is planning to complete three new lines (numbered 7, 8 and 9), as well as extend three existing lines, but the timetable has already slipped and none of the new lines are now expected to begin operation within the 2020-24 forecast period. Additional transport funding will be allocated to the two largest metropolitan areas outside the capital, Gran Valparaíso and Gran Concepción, aimed at alleviating some of the congestion that these areas have been experiencing. Chiloé Island is also likely to be finally connected to the mainland via a 2.8-km bridge within the forecast period, despite repeated delays to construction.

New infrastructure plan aims to accelerate progress
- Chile's robust infrastructure is largely attributable to a successful con-cession system that was launched in the 1990s. Since the late 2000s, however, the number of new infrastructure investment projects has waned as the original group of projects reached completion. The government is trying to reverse this trend; in late June, it unveiled an ambitious US$50bn infrastructure programme that will cover the period 2020-50. The plan is front-loaded, with 45% of planned investment targeted for 2020-29. It focuses on the country's transport network, with over 60% of the plan dedicated to improving the road network. The plan also anticipates significant investment in the railway, airport and port provision. Most projects will be developed in public-private partner-ships (PPPs) with private-sector firms, although the authorities have not given a detailed breakdown of how much public money will be channelled into the projects. However, the government will struggle to make progress on this agenda at least in the near term; planning for the 30-year project started in early 2019 and its broad structure has not undergone significant change as a result of the coronavirus pandemic. The authorities believe that improving transport infra-structure is necessary in the long term, but attracting private-sector investment in some of these projects (particularly those relating to airport expansion) will be difficult in the current environment.

The completion of a key transmission line will reduce costs further
- Although energy infrastructure has been seen as the weakest part of Chile's infrastructure matrix, this has changed since Ms Bachelet's second term (2014-18), with the implementation of a long-term strategy (Energía 2050) that extends beyond our forecast period. Other improvements include a decrease in the price of renewable energy-which helped to spur an increase in clean energy sources-and the connection between the north and central energy grids. These efforts have helped to contain the price of energy, which for years was a major hindrance to invest-ment.

Business environment outlook: Technological readiness                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2015-19 2020-24 2015-19 2020-24 2015-19 2020-24
6.1 6.9 41 35 1 1
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
Chile's ranking for technological readiness is the highest in the region, improving by six places, to 35th, in the global ranking. Its score is supported by strong internet usage, and efforts by successive governments to improve technological and innovative capacity. Chile is one of Latin America's most advanced telecommunications and IT markets, and is supported by a regulatory system that seeks to promote competition and IT sector development. Mobile and internet penetration levels are high, while smartphone ownership is the highest in the region. Nevertheless, investment in research and development (R&D) is low. According to the latest OECD data, R&D investment in Chile was less than 0.4% of GDP in 2017, compared with an OECD average of 2.4%.

- E-commerce has been growing rapidly in recent years and will accelerate further in 2020 on the back of the coronavirus pandemic. The Santiago Chamber of Commerce estimates that online sales exceeded US$6bn in 2019, up by 27% from 2018; online sales have reached US$4bn in the first half of 2020 alone. This partly reflects the closure of many non-essential retailers during the second quarter of the year, but more customers are likely to continue to make purchases online even as all shops reopen.
- Chileans are among the most avid smartphone users in the region, with about 85% of access to the internet carried out using a mobile phone. Nearly all mobile internet users use smartphones, which account for 80% of total internet access. Fourth-generation (4G) connections account for 85% of total mobile internet connections and continue to rise rapidly. Together with government investment, funding by internet service providers for the development of fibre-optic networks (which currently account for about 30% of fixed broadband connections) will continue to increase internet use, as well as facilitate faster upload and download speeds.

The science ministry will lead national science and technology policy
- The Ministry of Science, Knowledge, Technology and Innovation was created in December 2018 and oversees all policies, programmes and plans designed to strengthen innovation in science and technology. The ministry has a technical advisory committee, which will periodically review its policies, and an inter-ministerial committee-comprised of the ministers of science, finance, economy and education-tasked with developing a national science policy.
- As part of the tax reform bill currently before Congress, the government is proposing the imposition of a value-added tax (VAT) on digital services provided by international companies such as Spotify (Sweden), Netflix (US) and the accommodation site AirBnB (US).

Economic forecast: Policy trends The government is focused on tackling the health and economic crisis created by the coronavirus (Covid-19) pandemic, and its policy focus has temporarily shifted from the social agenda to increasing the capacity of the healthcare system and bolstering the economy more broadly through policy stimulus. As Chile has slowly begun to flatten its infection rate curve in some places, the government is contemplating a step-by-step reopening plan for the economy, involving five phases-quarantine, transition, preparation, initial opening and advanced opening.
In the Santiago Metropolitan Region, the most-affected region in the country, reopening will depend on agreements with mayors and on epidemiological statistics. The economic policy response of the government has been the most robust in Latin America; the government has rolled out three rounds of fiscal stimulus, worth a total of US$28.8bn (12.1% of forecast 2020 GDP), aimed at improving primary health-care, supporting the incomes of the unemployed and informal workers, and providing loan support for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) and the middle class.
Perhaps the most important piece of reform has been the early pension withdrawal bill, which, if approved (and The Economist Intelligence Unit expects this to be the case), will allow individuals to withdraw up to 10% of their savings from Administradoras de Fondos de Pensiones (AFPs, private pension funds). In order to prevent its passage, Mr Piñera offered a one-off cash grant of Ps500,000 (US$650) for workers who have seen their income decline by more than 30%, as well as an enhancement of the US$1.5bn support announced for the middle class in July, as part of the third stimulus package.
Although no mechanism has been established thus far to compensate individuals for their reduced future pension payouts, there is a risk that the government will be asked to compensate savers for lower savings and the interest lost on withdrawn amounts (the government estimates withdrawals to reach US$20bn or 8.4% of GDP). This could severely strain the country's increasingly stretched coffers.
We expect the stimulus package to soften the blow to domestic activity and help to increase the healthcare system's capacity to better combat the spread of the coronavirus. Conventional monetary policy has been stretched out to the maximum (with an interest rate at virtually zero) and the Banco Central de Chile (BCCh, the central bank) will rely more on non-conventional measures to boost liquidity in the financial system.
Once the disease is brought under control and Congress resumes operations at full pace, policymaking will shift back to the social agenda. Failure to do so would prompt a renewed bout of protests and unrest, which would be detri-mental to an economy already hit hard by the coronavirus crisis.

We expect the central government deficit to balloon to 14% of GDP in 2020, in view of three rounds of expansive fiscal stimuli, totalling almost 12.2% of GDP, although some of the funds will be distributed over 2020-21. A gradual rollback of stimulus measures (amid economic recovery from 2021) will produce an incremental narrowing of the deficit, to 5.2% of GDP on average in 2021-24.
We expect government expenditure to spike to 32.4% of GDP in 2020, from 24.1% of GDP in 2019, in view of the large spending measures announced during the pandemic. Social spending will remain higher during the forecast period than before the protests, as the government seeks to address the concerns of protesters who have highlighted a problem of income inequality and inequality of access to public services in Chile. We therefore do not expect expenditure to fall to levels seen before the social crisis within our 2020-24 forecast period.
Government revenue will drop to 18.4% of GDP in 2020, from 21.3% of GDP in 2019, as revenue from tax collection will be substantially lower in 2020 than expected before the virus outbreak, owing to income losses and tax deferrals announced as part of the fiscal support package. We expect an expansion in revenue over the forecast period to be driven mainly by revenue from copper (as global demand and copper prices recover). The government's tax modern-isation bill, which was approved by Congress in January, also aims to generate an additional US$2.2bn per year (0.9% of GDP in 2020) in funds from tax collection.
In addition, opposition lawmakers have proposed a new wealth tax to the executive branch, of 2.5%, to be levied on those with more than US$10m in wealth. The executive has the authority to introduce new taxes without consulting Congress. Assuming that it is introduced (we expect this to happen), the new tax will raise about US$6bn and will be used to fund the Emergency Family Income plan. Based partly on new sources of revenue from the prop-osed wealth tax and the tax modernisation bill passed earlier this year, and partly on modest economic recovery post-coronavirus, we expect government revenue to increase from 2021, to reach 23.2% of GDP in 2024.
The higher deficit throughout the forecast period will drive up the central government debt/GDP ratio, from 27.9% of GDP in 2019 to 38% of GDP in 2020. The ratio will continue to increase throughout the forecast period and will reach 40.6% of GDP in 2024. We expect debt financing to come from a mix of sovereign wealth funds and bond issuance. Chile's two sovereign wealth funds hold a combined value of US$20.9bn (8.9% of GDP) as at April 2020.

Having taken rates to their technical minimum, the BCCh is now turning towards non-conventional monetary policy to support the economy, and we expect policy to remain quite loose for the rest of this year. The central bank has introduced a range of non-conventional measures to boost liquidity, including (but not limited to) a six-month conditional financing facility and a purchasing programme for bank bonds in the open market.
We expect a tightening cycle to begin later in 2021, based on the economy recovering as projected. This will result in real interest rates returning gradually to positive territory over the forecast period.
