We expect the Chilean economy to enter recession this year-the first time since the global financial crisis in 2009-and to register a steep 6.4% decline in real GDP, owing to the coronavirus pandemic. However, among Latin America's major economies, we expect Chile to register the smallest decline and the strongest economic recovery (relatively speaking), owing to its robust policy response coupled with a strong institutional capacity to implement stimulus measures (in contrast, we currently expect GDP to contract by 12% in Argentina, 9.7% in Mexico, 7.7% in Colombia and 7.5% in Brazil). The difference can also be attributed to less stringent lockdown measures compared with many other countries in the region-with only the Santiago Metropolitan Region entering full quarantine.
The sharp projected downturn in 2020 is also a result of a strong negative carryover effect from the last quarter of 2019, when GDP contracted by 4.1% quarter on quarter. The lower base of comparison resulted in stronger than expected sequential growth-of 3% quarter on quarter-in the first three months of 2020. The economic brunt of the pandemic will be felt more clearly in the second quarter; activity contracted by 8.7% month on month in April-the sharpest downturn in activity on record-and by 3.3% in May. We therefore expect a real GDP contraction of 13.9% quarter on quarter in April-June.
An anticipated recovery (albeit incomplete) in the second half of 2020 should result in positive carryover in 2021, when we expect GDP to grow by 5.2%. This solid growth rate masks the fact that real GDP will not return to 2019 levels until 2022, although Chile's recovery will be faster than the Latin American average (we do not expect agg-regate regional GDP to recover to 2019 levels until 2023).
In 2022-24 we expect real GDP growth to stabilise at an average of 3.5%. This reflects an expected recovery in global growth and rising copper prices, which will contribute to recoveries in the external sector and domestic demand. We expect the contraction in GDP to be driven mainly by declines in consumption and investment demand. We expect consumption to fall by 4.8%, owing to income losses amid a rise in the unemployment rate.
We expect the passage of the pension withdrawal bill to severely strain the country's domestic financial system, as it will require AFPs to liquidate their long-term investments at a time when asset prices have been severely hit by the pandemic-thereby affecting the AFP's soundness-and will also erode the pool of capital available in the economy to carry out further investments. This will, in turn, weigh on already pessimistic investor confidence.
The erosion of pension funds will lower investment capacity and the liquidation of assets at lower prices (owing to the pandemic) by pension funds to finance withdrawals will deter investors further. We expect fixed investment to contract by 16.5% in 2020.
Industries operating away from urban centres (which are the biggest hotspots of the virus)-such as agriculture and mining-will manage to continue operations at near-full capacity. Mining activity has remained largely resilient to the pandemic-induced economic fallout, as most mines operate in isolated areas. Industries such as construction, manufacturing, and services (retail, restaurants and hotels, and financial services) will be the worst hit components of output.


Enlarge this image.
Economic forecast: Sectoral trends Mining will remain among the largest economic sectors and contributors to growth over the forecast period. With about 200m tonnes in proven high-grade copper reserves (24% of the world's total in 2019)-which are advantageously situated close to the sea-Chile has been the favourite global destination for copper mining investment over the past two decades. This has made it by far the world's largest copper producer, with output of 5.8m tonnes in 2019, equal to 28% of the global total. The mining outlook in Chile appears slightly brighter, but the sector will continue to face structural pressures owing to cost-cutting measures and falling ore grades.
Although copper prices are projected to be lower than in the 2006-13 boom years (especially in 2020 when copper prices are forecast to fall by 9%, with the coronavirus pandemic bearing down on global demand and trade flows), the country will remain a competitive mining investment destination because of its favourable geological conditions, as well as its relative economic stability. The market is divided between Codelco (the state copper firm) and private mining companies, with private firms accounting for two-thirds of output. Codelco was nationalised in 1971 and is the largest copper-producing and exporting company in the world. By law, the company is required to hand over all of its profits to the state. Major multinational mining companies with a presence in Chile include BHP Billiton (Australia), Rio Tinto (UK-Australia), Xstrata (Switzerland), Anglo-American (UK), Freeport McMoRan (US) and Grupo México (Mexico). There are also numerous local private companies, such as Antofagasta.
Output has weakened in recent years, mainly reflecting the decline of copper prices and ore grades. Output fell in 2016 and 2017, owing to a 43-day strike at Escondida, the country's largest mine, as well as flooding in several northern mines. Growth returned in 2018, as prices and investment recovered, but was short-lived in 2019, as strikes broke out in major copper mines amid the protest movement of October 2019. Copper production has remained more or less resilient-and in fact, has even grown slightly-so far in the face of the corona-virus outbreak, as most copper mines are located in isolated areas. With copper prices recovering, we expect copper production to cross the 6-tonne mark by 2021, with further gains thereafter.
Codelco has continued operations at near normalcy in the wake of the coronavirus. A proposal to privatise the company to generate funds in order to finance the country's coronavirus response was rejected by the Chamber of Deputies (the lower house), and we do not expect the company to be privatised during the forecast period. Declining ore grades have forced mines to invest heavily in order to maintain output and extend their lifespan. Codelco's output will decline in 2020-21 as the transition to exploit deeper ore reserves temp-orarily harms production. Codelco plans to invest US$40bn until 2026 as it seeks to maintain mine production-by extending the life of ageing mines and exploring for new ores inside and outside Chile-and meet tighter environ-mental standards at its smelting facilities. In order to support huge investment in Codelco, the government has moved to eliminate the Ley Reservada del Cobre (copper reserve law), under which Codelco hands over 10% of its gross export sales for the acquisition of weaponry and munitions by the military. Transfers to fund military purchases were required irrespective of the copper price and the impact on Codelco's finances, which has undermined its capacity to invest and the company's debt has risen to above US$16bn. However, these payments will be phased out gradually over 12 years and improvements to Codelco's investment capacity will occur in the medium term.
Codelco's investment plan comprises five major projects: the underground transformation of Chuquicamata (launched in August last year); construction of a new mine level at the company's underground El Teniente mine (with start-up due in 2023), which has been halted temporarily in the wake of the pandemic; the expansion of processing capacity at its Rajo Inca and Andina mines (due in 2021 and 2025 respectively); and an expansion at the Radomiro Tomic mine (due for completion in 2021). Codelco's production was 1.7m tonnes in 2019, down by 5.5% from the previous year. Although production during the pandemic has remained largely resilient (with output growing by 4.7% in the first half of 2020), the economy will struggle to boost output in 2020-21 to 2017-18 levels, owing to temporary investment delays, but will steadily ramp up production from 2021 onwards.
We expect global demand for copper to contract by 2.9% in 2020, owing to the coronavirus pandemic, but we expect China's copper consumption in 2020-21 to grow as manufacturing and services sector activity have already begun to recover. China accounts for more than 50% of world's copper demand and as Chile's main trading partner (accounting for 48% of its exports) it will support steady growth in copper production in Chile in 2020-21, although not at the scale observed before 2019. Once the global economy emerges from the pandemic, we expect stronger growth in copper production to set in.

After a period of sustained depreciation earlier this year, the peso has regained ground and we expect some further nominal appreciation that will leave the peso at Ps725.7:US$1 by end-2020-still weaker than the rate observed at end-2019, amid the social crisis. We forecast that the currency will then continue to appreciate in the remainder of the forecast period, averaging Ps694.1:US$1 in 2021-24.

We expect the current-account to temporarily spring into surplus, albeit small, at 0.2% of GDP in 2020 (from a deficit of 3.9% of GDP in 2019), primarily driven by a sharp expansion of the trade surplus to 5.8% of GDP in 2020 (from 1.5% of GDP in 2019), in view of expected export recovery (which began in June) and continued import compression (albeit at a slower rate) in the rest of the year.
Compounding the uptick in the current account is the primary income deficit, which we expect to narrow in 2020 to 3.6% of GDP (from 3.8% of GDP in 2019), owing to a decline in profit repatriation abroad by companies working in Chile amid the pandemic. The primary income deficit will then widen throughout the remainder of the forecast period, entrenched by rising debt-service oblig-ations and a pickup in profit repatriation abroad. The former follows a rise in external debt to finance higher public spending during social unrest and the pandemic. This will lead the current account to return to a deficit from 2021 onwards, averaging 2.9% of GDP in 2021-24.

Economic forecast: Foreign direct investment in Chile Stocks and flows Despite its small size, Chile has historically been an important destination for foreign direct investment (FDI), particularly in its mining, energy and transport infrastructure sectors. FDI flows can fluctuate widely from year to year, often reflecting the fortunes of the copper mining industry. FDI fell dramatically between 2015 and 2017, from US$20.9bn to US$6.1bn. However, the decline bottomed out in 2018, and FDI inflows recovered in 2019 to US$11.9bn. Chile's favourable climate for foreign businesses pushed the stock of FDI to US$215.7bn in 2019, according to IMF data, resulting in an FDI stock/GDP ratio of 76.4%, compared with much smaller ratios for Brazil (44.6%) and Mexico (50%). Chile's importance as an investor in other regional markets has also increased in recent years, with a focus on the airline, shipping and retail sectors. However, outward flows have declined considerably in recent years, and totalled just US$8.4bn in 2019, down from an annual average of US$15.9bn in 2011-15. This reflected a global decline in crossborder mergers and acquisitions activity, and also political uncertainty throughout Latin America (where most Chilean outward investment flows) ahead of a busy election season in the region. A large stock of outward FDI in 2019 valued at US$152.2bn, equivalent to 52.9% of GDP (IMF data), is testament to the success of Chilean firms abroad.
Origin and distribution According to the latest data from the Banco Central de Chile (the central bank), Chile's largest source of accumulated FDI stock in 2018 was the US, which accounted for 13.4% of the total stock. Spain, Canada, the Netherlands and Italy accounted for another 36% combined. FDI broadly supports major investments in the mining, energy, agrarian (especially wine), wholesale and retail, telecommunications, financial services, and construction and infrastructure sectors. The last is driven by foreign firms finding opportunities under the government's public-private partnership concessions. However, much of the FDI flowing into Chile is routed through tax havens such as the Bahamas, Bermuda, the British Virgin Islands, the Cayman Islands, Luxembourg and Panama-which between them contributed a further 12% of the debt stock in 2017-making it difficult to ascertain the true countries of origin.
Regarding the sectoral distribution of FDI stocks, financial services accounted for almost 40% of the total in 2018, followed by mining (26.6%) and utilities (electricity, gas and water, at 8.4%). Other important sectors that have attracted significant foreign investment in recent years include manufacturing, transport, communications, real estate and business services, and retail.
Determinants Chile's foreign investment regime, which has been in place for three decades, is one of the most liberal in the world. There is a well-respected principle of non-discrimination between local and foreign investors, who also enjoy additional protection as a result of the rapidly expanding network of investment-protection accords and double-taxation treaties signed with other countries. Generally sound regulation, combined with political and economic stability, and firm growth, have helped to support FDI inflows since the early 1990s. Moreover, Chile's managerial talent and well-qualified labour force (by regional standards), together with a strong rule of law, low crime rates and a large network of free-trade agreements (FTAs), have attracted a growing number of multinationals to use Chile's capital, Santiago, as a headquarters for Latin America. Moreover, the entry of Chile into the OECD in 2010 made it subject to various investment-related provisions and guidelines relating to liberalisation of capital movements and trade in services (including business and financial services, insurance, culture, tourism, and travel).
Impact FDI had funded a growing share of gross fixed investment in Chile since the 1990s. In 2001-06 FDI funded 26% of gross fixed investment, contributing to the modernisation of infrastructure, including telecoms. The ratio rose to an annual average of 38.4% in 2007-15, owing to large mining and energy investments. Although it has slipped significantly since, reaching just 11.5% in 2019, it is expected to rise modestly to an annual average of 27.2% in 2020-24. FDI has made a major contribution in terms of the transfer of technology and managerial expertise, and has helped to foster competition between local and foreign firms in most major consumer markets, thereby providing Chileans with wider product ranges and lower prices than in neighbouring countries. Outward FDI has also grown as Chilean businesses expanded abroad, which has helped to establish many local firms as important regional players in their respective sectors. Although outward FDI flows dropped to a lowly US$580m in 2018, from an annual average of US$11.7bn in 2008-17, this is still a robust level (outward FDI stock totalled US$139.3bn in 2017, according to the IMF). The fact that Chilean firms operated in a competitive domestic environment, well before regional peers had liberalised their own economies, has enabled businesses to position themselves successfully in neighbouring countries. This has been most evident in the retail sector, where firms such as Ripley, Paris and Falabella have aggressively expanded into other markets such as Peru, Argentina, Colombia and Brazil.
Potential Chile will continue to attract large FDI inflows, owing to its transparent business operating conditions, political stability, a fundamentally sound economy, a huge network of FTAs, double-taxation and investment-protection accords, the most modern infrastructure in Latin America, and a growing pool of skilled labour. Nevertheless, The Economist Intelligence Unit expects FDI inflows to average a modest 5.5% of GDP annually in 2020-24 well below the level of 9% of GDP recorded in the bonanza years of 2008-15, during the commodities supercycle. The major acquisitions that have been common in the banking, telecoms and utilities sectors over the past two decades are unlikely to be repeated at the same pace, given already near-complete levels of economic openness and liberalisation. Nevertheless, the services sector (for example) will have ample opportunities in a market in which incomes are expected to continue to grow steadily. Renewable energy and related industries (such as lithium extraction) will also attract significant investment.

Working-age population grows slowly while overall demographic profile ages Chile's annual population growth rate is forecast to decelerate gradually, from 1.2% in 2019 to less than zero by 2024. This will bring the total population to 19.2m in 2024, leaving Chile as the least populated of Latin America's seven largest economies, and the only one of the seven with a population below 20m in 2024. The Instituto Nacional de Estadística de Chile (the national statistics office) forecasts that the rate of natural population growth-the crude birth rate minus the death rate-will continue to slow, from 8.6 per 1,000 people annually in 2010-15 to 7.4 per 1,000 in 2015-20, and to 6.2 per 1,000 in 2020-25. Although Chile displays a maturing demographic profile, the share of the working-age population will remain roughly stable, at 68% of the total, in 2020-24. The rise in the share of the population above working age (14.1% will be 65 or older by 2024) will bring this figure to one of the highest in Latin America.
Chile has traditionally been an immigrant-receiving country, although not to the same extent as other South American nations such as Argentina or Brazil. Since the 1970s most migrants have come from neighbouring Peru and Bolivia, with migrants often working in low-skilled jobs. However, the pace of inward migration has accelerated since 2005, with the number of foreigners in the country increasing by 123% between 2005 and 2014, to about 416,000, and in 2017 the government estimated that there were around 1m foreigners living in the country, of which roughly 300,000 were undocumented.
The surge in immigration is a consequence of the arrival of large numbers of Venezuelans and Haitians, prompted by humanitarian crises in their countries-and a rise in economic migrants from countries such as Colombia, Ecuador and the Dominican Republic-attracted by the higher wages and quality of life. The Economist Intelligence Unit expects net inward migration to continue, given Chile's relative prosperity, but it will proceed at a more moderate pace than in 2015-17 as the government has instituted new laws to control the inward flow. Outward migration from Chile peaked during the dictatorship of Augusto Pinochet (1973-19), but has slowed since then. The government estimates that 850,000 Chileans live abroad, largely in Argentina, the US, Brazil and Sweden.
Inward immigration will not boost overall population growth Chile's basic health indicators are similar to those of other OECD countries; life expectancy at birth in 2019 stood at 80 years (82.4 years for women and 77.6 years for men) and infant mortality stood at 6.2 per 1,000 live births, as per data from the World Bank. Infectious diseases and problems such as malnutrition are largely under control except in small pockets of extreme poverty. However, age and "lifestyle-related" conditions associated with sedentary living and increased consumption of processed foods-such as obesity (75% of the popul-ation are overweight or obese-the second-highest among the OECD countries), heart disease, colon cancer and diabetes-are on the rise.
Public healthcare policies will increasingly target obesity and unhealthy lifestyles. Only 2.5% of children under six years old were at risk of malnutrition in 2010, but 13.1% were overweight and 9.7% were obese. A universal healthcare plan, the Plan de Acceso Universal con Garantías Explícitas, was created in 2005 and offers fixed-price treatments for 80 conditions, including many expensive illnesses. The policy is sold at a fixed price and guarantees a maximum waiting time for medical attention for each condition. The public system covers around 80% of the population, against 17% covered by private insurance. During the social protests of late 2019, health sector reforms emerged as one of the key demands of protesters and this led to a slew of reforms to the health sector, including a reduction in waiting time, increased coverage of healthcare costs, lower cost of medication and increased spending per head on primary care.
The unemployment rate will soar amid the pandemic and fall slowly thereafter The economy was close to full employment in 2013-15, with average unemployment, at a historic low of 5.8%. However, furloughs and layoffs during the coronavirus (Covid-19) pandemic resulted in the unemployment rate reaching an all-time high of 11.9% in the second quarter. We expect the unemployment rate to continue to rise in 2020, before beginning a gradual decline over 2021-24. Informal sector workers are estimated to account for 36% of the labour force, according to the OECD; a low figure by Latin American standards (it is frequently more than half, even in large economies). However, the informal sector represents a large pool of untapped labour, which could-if brought into the formal market-boost long-term growth and tax revenue.

After contracting, income per head in US dollar terms will grow in 2017 Chile's market opportunities are constrained by its small population, at 18.9m in 2019 (forecast to grow modestly to 19.2m by 2024), but its high income-along with a legacy of political stability and effective economic management-will continue to make the country an attractive destination for investment in the region. In the past three decades it has generally outperformed all of the other economies in Latin America in terms of GDP growth and, amid the coronavirus (Covid-19) pandemic, is expected to undergo the softest decline in output in 2020, relative to the other major economies in the region. The Economist Intelligence Unit also expects economic recovery from the pandemic to be among the strongest and fastest in Chile, with real GDP growth averaging 4% in 2021-24, owing to its robust policy (especially fiscal) response to the crisis and otherwise strong macroeconomic fundamentals. Income per head at purchasing power parity will take a serious hit in 2020, sliding to US$23,421 per person (from US$25,159 per person in 2019) as the unemployment rate and, thus, income losses rise amid layoffs and furloughs during the Covid-19 crisis. However, the deterioration in the living standards will be temporary as a recovery is expected to set in from 2021 onwards, with GDP growth outstripping population growth throughout 2021-24. Despite declining over the past decade, inequality will remain pronounced, with income discrepancies between metropolitan and northern regions, and less affluent regions in the centre-north and centre-south.
Potential for more exports and imports will remain strong Chile's productive potential is limited by its small manufacturing base, which is dominated by agro-industrial output. As a result, a large share of consumer goods-such as electronics, cars and clothing-are imported. Consumer confidence in Chile has been declining since 2018 and reached record-low levels in end-2019 at the height of the social unrest. According to the University of Chile's consumer confidence index, consumer confidence slid below levels observed during the 2008-09 financial crisis, coming in at 85.1 (with March 2001=100), and is expected to decline further amid the coronavirus pandemic. This, combined with a forecast decline in income per head, will decrease household expenditure on imports drastically in 2020. We expect it to increase thereafter in 2021-24 as the economy emerges from the pandemic.
Retail sales in real terms dropped by 1.4% in 2019 and declined further in the first half of 2020, owing to stoppages in activity and demand weakness during the health emergency. We currently forecast that the volume of retail sales will drop by 45.2% in 2020, growing thereafter by 3.4% on average in 2021-24, supported by a well-contained inflation rate, low real-interest rates and rising income levels. Export earnings have already started to pick up as copper prices recover, and a recovery in demand from China will boost export volumes.

The Chilean market is competitive, with a strong foreign presence Consumer markets in Chile are well developed and competitive, owing to a free-market-orientated economy that has encouraged participation by foreign firms, as well as import penetration for a wide range of consumer goods. This has helped to bring prices down and attract a large number of participants, despite the small size of the economy, in effect turning it into a showcase market for firms wishing to expand in the region. Some highly competitive sectors include telecommunications and retail. A deep and sophisticated financial sector, which has historically benefited from ample credit supply, relatively low interest rates and narrow loan-deposit spreads, supports consumer expenditure. Large foreign and local firms co-exist in the banking and insurance sectors, with the insurance sector enhanced by high and rising statutory obligations. Despite this, the conservative lending practices of the banking system mean that small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) often find it difficult to obtain financing; these conditions will worsen during the ongoing coronavirus pandemic, despite fiscal measures and government-backed loan programmes. These constraints do not present a problem for larger blue-chip firms, however, which can access a wider range of financing options. Private financing for large companies will be forthcoming during the current crisis, as illustrated by the case of Chile's LATAM Airlines, which filed of Chapter 11 bankruptcy but managed to secure funds from private sources for its debt restructuring.

From May 2019 The Economist Intelligence Unit's long-term growth forecasts have been revised to take into account the economic impact of climate change.
Once the ongoing coronavirus (Covid-19) pandemic subsides, Chile's long-term outlook will benefit from a return to adherence to prudent monetary and fiscal policies, coupled with a commitment to the rule of law and protection of property rights. A wide network of bilateral free-trade agreements (FTAs) and a liberal foreign-investment regime will continue to help Chile to attract foreign direct investment (FDI), while simultaneously assisting local firms to expand abroad. It has also helped to diversify the economy into areas in which the country previously lacked comparative advantages, although a pronounced bias towards mining (the country's single largest industry and source of exports), and in particular, copper, will persist. Chile's efforts to become a regional platform for multinational corporations will continue, facilitated by its reputation for relative economic stability and security, its well-developed financial system, and the quality of its transport and communications infrastructure, as well as a comprehensive network of FTAs, double-taxation agreements and investment-protection accords. Chile's track record in raising real incomes has made progress, with GDP per head-in US dollars at purchasing power parity (PPP)-increasing from 20% of US GDP per head in 1990 to 38.6% in 2019. This gradual convergence will continue as growth outpaces that of the US, to reach a forecast 63.1% by 2050.
Initial conditions: Chile is a small country, representing only a 0.25% share of the world population in 2019, but it overachieves in its share of world GDP (0.35% at PPP), and global exports are strong (0.4% of the total). Chile's GDP per head (at market exchange rates) of US$14,891 in 2019 was the highest among Latin American economies (excluding the Caribbean). In PPP terms, GDP per head was US$25,159 in 2019, which was also the highest among non-Caribbean Latin American countries. In 2010 Chile was the second country in the region (after Mexico) to become a member of the OECD. Chile will continue to attract manufacturing investment, but its competitiveness as a global manufacturing centre will lag behind that of its Asian rivals, mainly owing to its small size. Chile will continue to find success in non-traditional production such as agro-industry and fisheries, and possibly some consumer goods, once Asia's labour-cost advantages erode. As a commodity producer, Chile faces more volatile terms of trade than its Asian competitors, whose comparative advantage is founded on low-cost manufacturing rather than raw materials. This implies that Chile's growth will remain strongly linked to international copper prices for the foreseeable future, notwithstanding a substantial diversification away from copper and commodities in general. The peso remains weak against its 20-year average, which will help to boost competitiveness for non-mining exports.
Demographic trends: Although Chile's population is still young by international standards, its demographic profile is ageing. Annual population growth will average just over 0.2% in 2020-30; the working-age population is expected to continue to grow, owing to a drop in young-age dependency. However, the working-age group will start to shrink from 2022, which will bring a rise in the dependency ratio. Despite Chile's relative affluence and the quality of its social services, immigration has not significantly contributed to overall population growth in recent decades. Although it may begin to do so over the next decade, the effect will not be significant. As a result, the demographic outlook will be dominated by trends among the native-born population, whose birth rates will continue to fall.
External conditions: Growth in export industries will be boosted by Chile's large network of FTAs. However, the single most important external factor affecting the Chilean economy is the international price of copper. Prices have fallen substantially, from a peak of 400 US cents/lb in 2011 to a low of 196 US cents/lb in December 2015, owing to the global slowdown and the end of the so-called commodities supercycle. The copper price has since recovered to average 272 US cents/lb in 2019, but after taking a small hit during the coronavirus pandemic, is forecast to average 248 US cents/lb in 2020, and will remain at the mercy of global sentiment. In the long term, however, demand growth from China and India, as well as other emerging economies, will keep copper prices high by historical standards. Chile has diversified its export base over the past 15 years, notably into non-traditional sectors such as fruit, salmon and wine. Nonetheless, mining (mainly copper) still accounts for approximately half of total exports, and The Economist Intelligence Unit expects this dominance to diminish only marginally, given Chile's unique geological and geographical advantages in natural-resource extraction. Service exports will also grow, benefiting from Chile's position as a regional business hub. Open and liquid capital markets make the country the most developed financial centre in the region-and smaller in size only than Brazil and Mexico-with ample crossborder opportunities in banking, insurance and securities markets arising from deeper regional integration. Finally, growing international aware-ness of the country's significant natural beauty will provide a major boost to tourism in the medium and long term.
Institutions and policy trends: Chile will maintain its strong pro-market policy direction of the past three decades. However, social pressures and rising expectations of the middle classes will lead to an increase in public-sector participation in certain sectors. Governments will drastically extend state funding of university places (tertiary education currently remains highly market-orientated) and renewable energy. Civil-service reforms will support bureaucracy efficiency and transparency, and reducing red tape will benefit the business environment as administrative procedures are simplified. Modern-isation of the judiciary will accelerate legal procedures, which already benefit from one of the most independent and least corrupt judicial systems globally.
Long-term performance: Chile's tradition of policy continuity, abundant natural resources, a favourable investment climate and modern infrastructure will be supportive of firm economic growth in the long term. The Chilean economic model will remain investment- and export-led, based on solid macroeconomic fundamentals, monetary stability and countercyclical fiscal management. Productivity growth will be helped by investments in new technologies and a gradual move towards higher value-added activities (made evident by the shift from agriculture to agro-industry). The financial sector will remain competitive, owing to a large pool of institutional investors (private pension funds, mutual funds and insurance companies), providing businesses and households with ample financing through credit and capital markets.
In the long term, modernisation of the education system and a more flexible labour market will be necessary to unlock higher potential growth; both of these issues are being slowly tackled by the current government led by Sebastián Piñera. The linking of Chile's north and central-south electricity grids could prove the catalyst for a revitalisation of the country's fragile energy matrix, which has resulted in Chile having some of the highest energy costs in the region. The lack of major fossil fuel reserves will provide an impetus towards developing renewable energy sources, and the country is on course to meet a target of 20% power generation via renewables in 2020, five years ahead of schedule (a long-term objective of 70% by 2050 appears more than feasible). At the same time, there is significant opposition to major hydroelectric projects on environmental grounds, and some green alternatives such as solar energy remain expensive, suggesting that Chile will be burdened by energy insecurity in the medium term. Overall, The Economist Intelligence forecasts that average annual GDP growth will reach 2.8% in 2019-30, falling to 2.3% in 2031-50. As growth in the working-age population slows, economic expansion will become more dependent on productivity gains and less so on the contribution of labour.

Long-term outlook: Long-term trends Climate change and sustainability Chile's long coastline and diverse topography leave it highly vulnerable to the effects of climate change. Changing climate dynamics will increase the likelihood and severity of natural disasters. These will directly disrupt agriculture and tourism, and glacial retreat will especially affect water resources. According to climate change projections by Chile's meteorological office, Chile's south-central area and the northern part of Patagonia should see temperatures rise and precipitation fall by around 60% between 2030 and 2059. Given that this is the heart of Chile's agricultural region-and also its farmed salmon industry-this will have a serious impact on the Chilean economy. Temperature rises affecting the oceans will also affect sea life, leading to a reduction in both the abundance and the diversity of species. This has been felt to some extent already in recent years, with an El Niño effect in 2016 disrupting the fishing industry, and a major drought affecting the country in 2018; this resulted in a water and agricultural emergency in the country. The Universidad de Chile says that at least 25% of the factors contributing to that year's drought reflect human action.
In January 2020 the government presented a draft climate change bill to Congress that sets a national target of achieving carbon neutrality by 2050, meaning that the country would emit no more heat-trapping carbon-dioxide (CO2) emissions than can be absorbed in its forests. The bill will set a total greenhouse gas emissions budget for 2030 and 2050, along with adaptation goals for each sector, which must be met within ten years of the bill's passing. The bill secured approval from the Senate Environment Committee on July 9th and awaits a general discussion in the Senate (the upper house). If approved, the law is expected to establish a medium- and long-term framework for climate impact reduction, and to create the institutions to manage climate change adaptation and mitigation efforts. In 2019 The Economist Intelligence Unit has developed a model to calculate the impact of climate change on long-term growth, and we find that the Chilean economy will be 2.5% smaller in 2050 than it would have been without this hit to growth.
An ageing demographic profile Chile's demographic profile shows an increasing proportion of the population over 65 years old. In 2019 approximately 11.9% of the population was over 65 years old. This is expected to climb to 17% of the population by 2030. This makes Chile one of the oldest populations in Latin America and the Caribbean (behind only Cuba and Uruguay). In addition to a lower birth rate, this also reflects an increase in life expectancy in the past 20 years as Chile has become a more affluent society. The ageing of the population presents a unique challenge for a developing country, where (until recently) providing sufficient economic growth and jobs for a working-age population was the biggest task.
The effect of Chile's ageing population has already been seen in the country's politics, with the state of the country's pension system becoming a major issue in the 2017 election, as well as during the 2019 protests. The government has also had to address the fiscal costs of an ageing population by promoting the hiring of senior citizens (to keep them in the workforce) and incentivising the postponement of retirement. The government has also sought to increase the number of doctors specialising in geriatrics working in the public health system, and to adapt urban infrastructure to accommodate the needs of the elderly. The shrinking working-age population as a percentage of the overall population has also made immigration more attractive to Chilean policymakers. The country has bowed to political pressure to standardise its immigration system after a large inflow in 2015-17, but still remains committed to welcoming regulated inward immigration
Long-term outlook: Methodology for long-term forecasts The time horizon for the detailed forecasts and analysis in the Country Forecast report is a five-year period. The Main report also carries a section on the long-term outlook, including projections of key macroeconomic and market size variables up to 2050. Depending on the indicator, average growth rates in a sub-period or values at select points in time are reported. Many companies make strategic business decisions over timeframes in excess of five years. The Economist Intelligence Unit's long-term projections will provide information to facilitate such decisions. Long-term forecasts and scenarios are also vital in understanding some of the big economic issues that will shape global business in the coming decades. We are well placed to build on and extend the five-year forecasts to produce long-term projections and scenarios because of the existing forward-looking analysis and models in the Country Forecast (in particular, the business environment rankings model). These are used to forecast some of the key drivers of long-run growth, as explained in detail below.
Growth projections The main building blocks for the long-term forecasts of key market and macroeconomic variables are long-run real GDP growth projections. We have estimated growth regressions that link real growth in GDP per head to a large set of growth determinants. The determinants of growth consist of the scope for convergence (based on initial GDP per worker at the start of a period); demographic variables; a set of policy variables (measuring the fiscal stance, openness to trade, and the government regulatory burden in product, credit and labour markets); a measure of institutional quality; geography (climate, location and the degree of primary export orientation); education levels and labour quality (as measured by mean years of schooling and life expectancy); the external economic environment (changes in the terms of trade); the level of development of information and communications technology (ICT); and historical legacies (history of independent statehood).
The regressions, which have high explanatory power for growth, allow us to forecast the long-term growth of real GDP per head for sub-periods up to 2050, on the basis of demographic projections and assumptions about the evolution of policy variables and other drivers of long-term growth.
Definitions of variables The dependent variable is GDPG: Average annual growth in real GDP per head, measured at national constant prices.
The independent variables include: LnGDPPL: The natural logarithm of GDP (adjusted for purchasing power parity-PPP) per worker (that is, per population aged 15-65) in constant 1980 US dollars at the start of each decade. Expressed as an index, US$=1.
LnSCHOOL: The natural logarithm of the mean years of schooling of the population aged over 15 at the start of each decade. Missing values for some countries are filled in by estimating mean years of schooling on the basis of an equation relating mean years of schooling (where available) to gross primary school enrolment ten years previously, and to secondary and tertiary enrolment ratios five years previously.
LnLIFEEXP: The natural logarithm of life expectancy at birth at the start of each decade. This variable also enters the equation in squared form, reflecting diminishing returns to growth of increases in life expectancy at high levels.
OPEN: Updated Sachs-Warner index of openness-the fraction of years during each decade in which a country is rated as an open economy according to the following four criteria: (1) average tariff rates below 40%; (2) average quota and licensing coverage of imports of less than 40%; (3) a black-market exchange-rate premium that averaged less than 20%; and (4) no extreme controls (taxes, quotas, state monopolies) on exports.
INST: Index of institutional quality (on a scale of 1-10) that is an average of five sub-indices of measures of the rule of law, quality of the bureaucracy, corruption, the risk of expropriation and the risk of government repudiation of contracts. Forecast values are based on corresponding indicators from our business environment rankings.
LABPOP: The difference between the growth rate of the working-age population (aged 15-65) and the growth rate of the total population in each decade.
TOT: The average annual rate of change of the terms of trade in a given decade.
GOVSAV: The average government savings ratio in each decade (current government revenue minus current government expenditure) expressed as a share of GDP.
TRADESH: The average share of trade (exports and imports of goods and services) in GDP, lagged by one decade to deal with the endogeneity of growth and trade.
GOVREG: An index on a scale of 1-10 of regulation of product, credit and labour markets. For forecast periods, the composite index is based on seven indicators from three categories of our business environment rankings model-from Policy towards private enterprise (ease of setting up new businesses, freedom to compete, price controls); from Financing (openness of the banking system, financial market distortions); and from Labour markets (restrictiveness of labour laws, wage regulation).
ICT: An index, on a scale of 1-10, of the development of information and communications infrastructure.
Control variables include PRIMARY: share of the exports of primary products in GDP at the start of a decade; TROPIC: percentage of the land area within a country that has a tropical climate; COLONY: history of independent statehood-a dummy variable taking the value of 1 if a country was a colony before 1945; and, in some specifications, regional dummy variables.
Summary of findings As in other studies, income per head and human capital are found to be important determinants of growth, with the coefficient on the logarithm of GDP per worker suggesting a relatively modest pace of convergence. The measures of institutional quality and of government regulation enter significantly in all specifications. We found a strong positive impact on growth of government savings and openness in all specifications. The criteria for classifying countries as open are quite permissive. The crucial aspect of trade policy captured by the measure is that it is a high level of distortion, rather than modest levels, that is deleterious for growth. The trade share variable is also moderately significant. The openness index (which is more of a true measure of policy) is hardly affected by the inclusion of trade/GDP shares in the equation. The correlation of the two measures is only .26. Although a tropical climate is highly significant, as is the share of primary exports in GDP, other geographic indicators-such as access to the sea, distance from major growth centres and the proportion of the population residing near coastlines-were not significant. A colonial past (pre-1945) is found to have a significant negative impact on growth, even in more recent periods.
Productivity growth The forecasts of GDP growth, of capital stock growth (based on estimated investment shares and assumed depreciation rates) and of growth in labour supply (based on projections of working-age population and assumptions on labour force participation) yield labour productivity growth and total factor productivity growth forecasts. The latter utilise the growth accounting identity, GY=b*GK+c*GL+A, where GY is growth of real GDP, GK growth of the capital stock and GL growth of human capital (the labour force adjusted for changes in skills). "A" stands for growth in total factor productivity; "b" and "c" are the shares of capital and labour in income. Trade values are forecast on the basis of simple import (function of GDP and relative prices) and export functions. Forecast market exchange rates (that is, the differential between PPP and market exchange rates) depend on the differential in labour productivity growth between a country and the US.

Data sources and definitions The sources for global and domestic data refer to historical data. The source for all forecast data, unless otherwise stated, is The Economist Intelligence Unit
Global data Manufactures price: UN, Monthly Bulletin of Statistics
Non-oil commodities: Economist Intelligence Unit aggregate
Oil prices: dated Brent
Ps:US$ exchange rate: IMF, IFS; nominal weighted index, 1990=100
US and OECD consumer price inflation: OECD
US and OECD GDP growth: OECD
US$ 3-month commercial paper rate: IMF, IFS
World copper prices: Economist Intelligence Unit aggregate
World GDP and trade growth: Economist Intelligence Unit aggregate
Domestic data Average copper price: LME, quoted in BCCh, Boletín Mensual
Balance of payments: BCCh
Budget balance: non-financial public sector (NFPS) balance only; Ministerio de Hacienda
Copper production: BCCh, Boletín Mensual; m tonnes of all copper products
Debt-service ratio: ratio of total debt service paid to exports of goods and services
Demographic profile data: UN, population projections, medium variant; ILO, labour force projections
Exchange rate: BCCh; market rates expressed as Ps:US$
GDP growth by demand component: Banco Central de Chile (BCCh, the central bank), Boletín Mensual; 2003 prices
GDP per head: US$ GDP divided by population
Inflation: BCCh; December 1998=100
Interest rates: IFS; bank rate offered (charged) on deposits (loans) of 30-89 days; given in annual terms by compounding weighted average monthly rates
PPP: purchasing power parity, average ratio of prices in Chile to prices in the US
Real exchange rate: ratio of estimated annual average purchasing power parity (PPP) for tradeable products to annual average exchange rate
Real GDP growth per head: real growth in GDP deflated by population growth
Total debt service: World Bank, Global Development Finance; principal repayments made against long-term debt, plus interest payments and IMF charges paid against total external debt
Total external debt: World Bank, Global Development Finance
US$ copper exports: BCCh, Boletín Mensual
US$ GDP: IFS; current prices, from local currency at annual average exchange rate
Wage and salary inflation: BCCh
Wage costs and unemployment rate: BCCh, Boletín Mensual
Abbreviations IFS: International Financial Statistics
ILO: International Labour Organisation
IMF: International Monetary Fund
LME: London Metal Exchange
Guide to the business rankings model Outline of the model The business rankings model measures the quality or attractiveness of the business environment in the 82 countries covered by Country Forecast using a standard analytical framework. It is designed to reflect the main criteria used by companies to formulate their global business strategies, and is based not only on historical conditions but also on expectations about conditions prevailing over the next five years. This allows The Economist Intelligence Unit to utilise the regularity, depth and detail of its forecasting work to generate a unique set of forward-looking business environment rankings on a regional and global basis.
The business rankings model examines 11 separate criteria or categories, covering the political environment, the macroeconomic environment, market opportunities, policy towards free enterprise and competition, policy towards foreign investment, foreign trade and exchange controls, taxes, financing, the labour market, infrastructure and technological readiness. Each category contains a number of indicators that are assessed by The Economist Intelligence Unit for the last five years and the next five years. The number of indicators in each category varies from five (foreign trade and exchange regimes) to 13 (political environment), and there are 91 indicators in total.
Almost half of the indicators are based on quantitative data (eg GDP growth), and are mostly drawn from national and international statistical sources for the historical period (2015-19) and from Economist Intelligence Unit assessments for the forecast period (2020-24). The other indicators are qualitative in nature (eg quality of the financial regulatory system), and are drawn from a range of data sources and business surveys adjusted by The Economist Intelligence Unit for 2015-19. All forecasts for the qualitative indicators covering 2020-24 are based on Economist Intelligence Unit assessments.
Sources used in the business rankings model include Akamai Technologies, State of the Internet; CIA, World Factbook; The Economist Intelligence Unit, Country Risk Service, Country Commerce, Democracy Index, Risk Briefing; IMF, Annual Report on Exchange Arrangements and Exchange Restrictions; International Institute for Management Development, World Competitiveness Yearbook; International Labour Organisation, International Labour Statistics Yearbook; International Telecommunication Union, ICT Indicators Database; Transparency International, Corruption Perceptions Index; UN Conference on Trade and Development, Ecommerce Index; World Bank, World Development Indicators, Doing Business; World Economic Forum, Global Competitiveness Index; World Intellectual Property Organisation, IP Facts and Figures.
Calculating the rankings The rankings are calculated in several stages. First, each of the 91 indicators is scored on a scale from 1 (very bad for business) to 5 (very good for business). The aggregate category scores are derived on the basis of simple or weighted averages of the indicator scores within a given category. These are then adjusted, on the basis of a linear transformation, to produce index values on a 1-10 scale. An arithmetic average of the ten category index values is then calculated to yield the aggregate business environment score for each country, again on a 1-10 scale.
The use of equal weights for the categories to derive the overall score reflects in part the theoretical uncertainty about the relative importance of the primary determinants of investment. Surveys of foreign direct investors' intentions yield widely differing results on the relative importance of different factors. Weighted scores for individual categories based on correlation coefficients of recent foreign direct investment inflows do not in any case produce overall results that are significantly different from those derived from a system based on equal weights.
For most quantitative indicators the data are arrayed in ascending or descending order and split into five bands (quintiles). The countries falling in the first quintile are assigned scores of 5, those falling in the second quintile score 4 and so on. The cut-off points between bands are based on the average of the raw indicator values for the top and bottom countries in adjacent quintiles. The 2015-19 ranges are then used to derive 2020-24 scores. This allows for intertemporal as well as cross-country comparisons of the indicator and category scores.
Measurement and grading issues The indices and rankings attempt to measure the average quality of the business environment over the entire historical or forecast period, not simply at the start or at the end of the period. Thus, in the forecast we assign an average grade to elements of the business environment over 2020-24, not to the likely situation in 2024 only.
The scores based on quantitative data are usually calculated on the basis of the numeric average for an indicator over the period. In some cases, the "average" is represented, as an approximation, by the recorded value at the mid-point of the period (2017 or 2022). In only a few cases is the relevant variable appropriately measured by the value at the start of the period (eg educational attainments). For one indicator (the natural resources endowment), the score remains constant for both the historical and forecast periods.

Full text: - Despite Venezuela's socioeconomic collapse and a public health crisis triggered by the spread of the coronavirus (Covid-19), The Economist Intelligence Unit expects the civic-military regime led by Nicolás Maduro of the Partido Socialista Unido de Venezuela to retain power throughout the 2020-24 forecast period. Mr Maduro's position will be supported primarily by his grip over a complex security apparatus and the opposition's lack of de facto power. On this basis, we expect continued deterioration of the economy, sustained outward migration, and a poorer and more violent Venezuela. Despite US sanctions (and their impact on oil production), the Maduro regime has managed internal dissent through a patronage system that rewards loyalty, as well as through its strict control over the security forces.
- The scale of the socioeconomic collapse and the elevated level of political instability will ensure that the Maduro regime continues to be challenged economically and politically. Low international crude prices, combined with US sanctions on the regime, mean that Venezuela is struggling to place its oil exports abroad. We therefore forecast domestic crude production to average about 400,000 barrels/day in the coming months. Moreover, given that it will lose control of the legislature in 2021, the opposition will be under strong pressure this year to step up its efforts to oust the regime. Mr Maduro will continue to face challenges to maintain the current patronage system and remain in control.
- De facto dollarisation of the economy is expanding. Concurrently, the government has taken measures that have allowed the official exchange rate to float. These measures have so far aided price stability and therefore increase the availability of some basic goods. However, the measures are not a product of economic orthodoxy, but of policy decisions to ensure the regime's survival. We do not expect to see the comprehensive economic and institutional reforms that will be required to resolve the economic crisis within the forecast period.

- Venezuela is ranked 82nd of 82 countries in the global business environ-ment rankings for 2020-24, having been in 80th place in the 2015-19 historical period, as the economic crisis deepens despite minor improvements. Reforms to institutions, economic policy and the business environment are unlikely.

Country forecast overview: Venezuela's business environment at a glance Policy towards private enterprise and competition 2020-21: Expansion of interventionist measures, including price controls. Corruption and selective application of regulations remain common and continue to undermine free competition.
2022-24: Contract rights remain weak, and red tape and ad hoc interventionism continue.
Policy towards foreign investment 2020-21: Most attempts to attract investment prove unsuccessful, owing to political and economic instability.
2022-24: Actual investment flows remain low amid ongoing economic volatility. Intellectual property protection and private property rights deteriorate.
Foreign trade and exchange controls 2020-21: Currency controls are weakened, but access to foreign currency remains limited.
2022-24: Efforts to remove trade and capital controls are taken on a gradual basis, and de facto dollarisation advances. Domestic supply of foreign currency improves as oil prices rise, albeit slowly.
Taxes 2020-21: Risk of further unrest and political instability reduces probability of tax increases, despite fiscal deficits. Severity of economic crisis precludes major rise in public spending.
2022-24: Tax system remains complex and unwieldy, but risk of discriminatory, ad hoc tax measures declines.
Financing 2020-21: Inflation remains high and concerns surrounding economic instability restrict financing to only short-term.
2022-24: Economic adjustments take time to feed through to solid, sustainable growth in credit to private sector and development of capital markets. Long-term finance remains in short supply.
Labour market 2020-21: Labour laws add substantially to non-wage costs. Past emigration of skilled labour aggravates skills shortages.
2022-24: Labour-market rigidities persist, despite some increase in flexibility of hiring and firing practices.
Infrastructure 2020-21: Underinvestment in water network and electricity grid leads to continued rationing and unpredictable blackouts.
2022-24: Investors remain highly cautious of committing to long-term capital projects. Infrastructure deteriorates even further.
Technological readiness 2020-21: E-government services remain almost non-existent. Deteriorating infrastructure limits adoption of new technologies. Telecommunications sector is opened to foreign investment, but with little interest.
2022-24: Limited regulatory capacity and years of underinvestment continue to restrict internet and mobile coverage.

Background: From 1958 until the mid-1990s, two parties-Acción Democrática and the Comité de Organización Política Electoral Independiente-alternated in power. Frequent economic crises and endemic corruption eventually led to a collapse in support for both parties and culminated in the 1998 election of Hugo Chávez, a former lieutenant-colonel and leader of a failed coup in 1992. Mr Chávez's policy programme exacerbated political polarisation, but several attempts to remove him from power before his death in March 2013 proved unsuccessful. His chosen successor, Nicolás Maduro, has seen his own popularity plummet as his mismanagement of a drop in oil prices, combined with strict sanctions on trade from the US, has plunged the country into a severe economic depression.
Political structure: Although Venezuela is nominally a federal republic with separation of powers, the ruling Partido Socialista Unido de Venezuela (PSUV) has systematically eroded institutions. In December 2015 the opposition coalition, Mesa de la Unidad Democrática, won control of the unicameral National Assembly (AN). In January 2016 the politicised Supreme Court declared the legislature to be in contempt of court, blocking all subsequent legislation. Since August 2017, a PSUV-only Constituent Assembly has granted itself a remit over all legislative matters, becoming the country's de facto legislature and sidelining the AN.
Policy issues: The most pressing policy issue is the need to stabilise an economy that remains mired in a long-standing economic crisis. The monetisation of vast public deficits has created an ever-increasing excess of domestic currency, triggering hyperinflation. Mismanagement of Petróleos de Venezuela (PDVSA, the state-owned oil company and originator of practically all foreign-currency inflows into the country) has resulted in a sharp contraction of oil production. This has restricted foreign-currency supply, giving way to currency controls, the rationing of imports, and the emergence of black markets for both foreign currency and basic goods. The scarcity of foreign exchange has also led to arrears on most of the external debt issued by sovereign and state-owned firms.
Taxation: The top corporate tax rate is 34% for non-oil companies and 50% for oil firms. The value-added tax (VAT) rate stands at 12%.
Foreign trade: The goods trade surplus fell to US$20.9bn in 2018 as the destruction of domestic supply led to increasing import dependence. The Economist Intelligence Unit estimates the 2018 current-account surplus to be 3.6% of GDP.

Outlook for 2020-24: Political stability The Economist Intelligence Unit considers that the coronavirus (Covid-19) outbreak and diminished oil rents-resulting from existing US sanctions and low international oil prices-present hefty challenges for the survival of the military regime led by Nicolás Maduro of the Partido Socialista Unido de Venezuela (PSUV). Owing to the bleak state of its healthcare system, Venezuela faces an uphill battle against the coronavirus, and there is a high risk that the ongoing socioeconomic crisis could evolve into a humanitarian calamity. The govern-ment's mandatory social distancing measures will be a source of unrest-as many workers simply lack the savings they need to survive without continuing to work-as will Mr Maduro's decision to remove some petrol subsidies in the face of fuel shortages.
Despite these compounding social and economic shocks, we expect Mr Maduro to retain power throughout 2020, ruling over what is becoming a much less populous and much poorer country. Mr Maduro has two main factors in his favour. First, the opposition led by the head of the National Assembly, Juan Guaidó, has lost the momentum that it held in 2019. Secondly, the regime retains strict control over the military, the police and paramilitary forces. Although the risks to our forecasts are very high, we assume that this control-together with the complexity of the security apparatus and the recurrent purges within it-will allow the regime to manage internal dissent.
Mr Maduro' recent actions show that he has the upper hand against the opposition. The new electoral council, inaugurated on June 12th, was packed with Mr Maduro's allies, while opposition members loyal to the regime were appointed as heads of two major opposition parties-Primero Justicia and Voluntad Popular. These actions set the stage for rigged parliamentary elections in December as opposition forces are now effectively disabled. The brazenness of these actions show that Mr Maduro is unperturbed by potential retaliation by the opposition and that political pressure against him is wavering.
Although it is not part of our baseline forecast, we recognise that there is a high risk of some sort of political transition. There are three main paths to this: military intervention, a negotiated transition or some sort of internal coup. We assess the prospect of military action by the US or Colombia as low, and we consider that a negotiated transition would also be difficult. In early March the US outlined a transition framework in which both Mr Maduro and Mr Guaidó would allow a new state council to be created and fresh elections to be held. However, the appointment of Maduro loyalists to the new electoral council demonstrated that this proposal has failed, as trust issues between the two sides are insurmountable.
We believe that the most likely scenario for regime change is an internal coup. The regime's main weakness is the fragility of its internal finances. Its patronage system is crucial for sustaining its security apparatus and resisting social unrest. Low international crude prices, US sanctions and the dampening effect of a global recession on workers' remittances will shrink US dollar inflows further. The regime will continue to benefit from funds from drug-trafficking and illegal mining activities, but a lack of hard currency could prove fatal to the patronage system and will test the regime's ability to maintain cohesion among its ranks. The regime's liquidity problems, and a rapidly worsening socioeconomic and humanitarian crisis, could prompt putsch attempts in the near term.
Outlook for 2020-24: Election watch Legislative elections will take place on December 6th, assuming that Mr Maduro clings to power and that the polls are not cancelled (Mr Maduro has hinted that they could be suspended owing to the coronavirus pandemic). These elections would be neither free nor fair, and the opposition would lose control of the National Assembly. If the opposition were to secure some sort of political change in 2020, the interim government would pursue deep-seated reforms to the electoral authority and attempt to hold a vote within 12 months of its formation, although achieving this would be a major challenge.
Outlook for 2020-24: International relations Mr Guaidó has marshalled strong support from the international community, but efforts by most governments in Latin America to support him have reached an impasse. Mr Guaidó's most committed champion, the US, has instituted several rounds of crippling oil sanctions-most recently placing severe restrict-ions on the Venezuelan operations of Chevron (a US oil company)-and has openly called for the Venezuelan military to accept Mr Guaidó in place of Mr Maduro. The US expects sanctions to put enough pressure on the regime's finances (and therefore on its patronage system) to force Mr Maduro to hold free and fair elections. The US also warned of additional sanctions in the near future. The US administration will remain hawkish in its approach to foreign policy, but we believe that a military intervention is unlikely, given the aversion of the US president, Donald Trump, to such adventurism. If tensions rise and political violence increases, the possibility of smaller-scale interventions cannot be discounted. Looking ahead, regardless of whether Mr Trump or his opponent, Joe Biden of the Democratic Party, wins the US election (our baseline forecast is for a Biden victory), we expect US sanctions to remain in place owing to strong bipartisan support. That said, efforts to reach a negotiated exit for Mr Maduro would increase under a Biden administration.
Mr Maduro's main global backers are Cuba, Russia, China and-more recently-Iran. Russia is helping Petróleos de Venezuela (PDVSA, the Venezuelan state-owned oil company) to circumvent US sanctions; in March the Venezuelan assets of Rosneft (a Russian energy firm) were transferred directly to Russia, representing a step-up in the US-Russia diplomatic crossfire over Venezuela. Nevertheless, Russia and China seem unwilling to provide the financing-amounting to tens of billions of US dollars per year-required to stabilise the economy and secure PDVSA's long-term future. Mr Maduro has openly courted the two countries, but has had little success in securing finance for investment. If a transition from the regime were to come about, we believe that Russia and China would be willing to work with Mr Maduro's successor to protect their current investments. Iran recently sent 1.5m barrels of petrol to Venezuela in exchange for gold shipments and is helping to fix the Paraguaná oil refinery.
Outlook for 2020-24: Policy trends The Maduro regime will focus on weathering the fuel shortages and containing the public health crisis caused by the coronavirus outbreak. Despite community spread and an accelerating number of Covid-19 cases, Mr Maduro has eased nationwide quarantine measures to some degree. A "7/7" system is currently in place, whereby seven days of more flexible social distancing measures are followed by seven of tighter restrictions. Measures will remain in place over the short to medium term, as Venezuela's health system is simply unprepared to deal with the coronavirus outbreak. The country's medical infrastructure is poor and hospitals face significant shortages of water, soap, medicines and electricity.
Given the risk that fuel shortages pose to the regime, Mr Maduro has taken some steps to alleviate fuel scarcity. On May 31st the regime announced a two-tiered petrol distribution system. Drivers will be subject to a monthly quota of subsidised petrol. When this has been reached, petrol will be available at internationally indexed prices. The regime will also designate 200 fuel stations across Venezuela, which will be operated by independent or private companies, with petrol in these stations costing a fixed US$0.50/litre. These measures seek to regularise black-market activity so that the regime (rather than a third party) benefits from the gains. Nonetheless, this will only work to an extent, as arbitrage opportunities are still possible under the new subsidy system.
Based on our view that Mr Maduro will retain power throughout our 2020-24 forecast period, we do not expect to see the comprehensive economic and institutional reforms that are required to resolve the economic crisis. De facto dollarisation is expanding; although this was not a tacit goal for the regime, Mr Maduro now welcomes it. Other under-the-radar adjustments are possible in the coming years, as long as these benefit the regime's survival. Such efforts alone are unlikely to bring about economic stability, owing to the absence of a comprehensive microeconomic reform or improvements in the rule of law, and policy predictability will not be forthcoming under the current regime.
Outlook for 2020-24: Fiscal policy The authorities have not published complete data on fiscal accounts since 2011. We expect the non-financial public-sector deficit to narrow in 2020, and the public debt/GDP ratio to remain high in the coming years. The sovereign's default on most of its interest and principal repayments will curb govern-ment spending. The regime relies heavily on monetisation to fund its deficits, driving hyperinflation and the rationing of foreign currency. Money printing will continue to finance the government's deficits in 2020-24. However, in the medium term, growing remittance inflows will partly offset the need to monetise budget deficits. We currently assume no debt restructuring in 2020-24. Venezuela's weak fiscal position is complicated by the existence of considerable off-balance-sheet debt financing-mainly PDVSA-issued debt and development funds from China-that understates the true size of total public liabilities.
All of the sovereign's outstanding global bonds are in arrears. However, bond-holders are yet to go to the courts, perhaps waiting for news of policy shifts or a change in government. The key PDVSA 2020 bond, which was secured using 50.1% of the shares of Citgo (PDVSA's US subsidiary) as collateral, fell due at end-October 2019 and was not paid. A US court ruled that PDVSA is an "alter ego" of the Venezuelan government; this will have far-reaching implications, as some international firms are seeking to seize shares of Citgo stock. However, the US considers Citgo to be under the purview of Mr Guaidó, thus currently shielding Citgo assets from seizure by creditors.
Outlook for 2020-24: Monetary policy The government's financing needs will force the Banco Central de Venezuela (BCV, the central bank) to ramp up money printing in the short term. Growing dollarisation and a strong contraction in domestic demand slowed hyper-inflationary pressures in 2019. However, we expect hyperinflation to return in the coming months, owing to monetisation of large fiscal deficits and severe goods shortages.
Overall, hyperinflation will continue until its underlying causes are addressed. Hyperinflation has quickened the pace of dollarisation of the economy (more than 50% of transactions are now thought to be conducted in US dollars). We believe that Venezuela is heading towards overall de facto dollarisation. Monthly inflation will rise again in the short term and will remain substantial. However, given the effect of dollarisation on price stability, we do not expect a return to the extremely high annual inflation rates of more than 1,000,000% experienced in 2018.
Outlook for 2020-24: Economic growth After an estimated contraction in real GDP of 36.2% in 2019 (and cumulative contraction of almost 70% since 2013), we expect an additional decline of 30.3% in 2020. The contraction reflects plummeting oil exports and the adverse effects of the government's quarantine measures, which will further dent domestic demand. Fuel scarcity will also hit the non-oil economy indirectly, through a scarcity of inputs and hyperinflation. From a demand-side perspective, the GDP contraction will be driven by falling real incomes and continued mass emigration (which is fuelled by unemployment, violence and social instability).
Low crude prices and weak oil exports will put significant pressure on the country to slash crude production. Venezuela's average break-even price is about US$15-20/barrel. US sanctions on the regime raise the risks involved in dealing with Venezuela, forcing the country to offer a hefty discount on its crude. This means that, at current market prices, Venezuela is making only a limited profit (its oil basket traded at an estimated US$25/b by end-July). The current circumstances have inevitably led to production cuts; oil output fell to 393,000 barrels/day (b/d) in June, according to OPEC, from 870,000 b/d in June 2019 and 1.3m b/d in the same month in 2018. We believe that output will average about 400,000 b/d over the coming months.
In 2021 we expect the economy to stabilise somewhat (contract marginally), owing to a stabilisation of domestic demand as social distancing measures are lifted. In 2022 economic growth will return on the back of a surge in oil prices. Despite serious operational problems (such as difficulties in obtaining equip-ment for repairs or finding qualified staff) and a limited pool of suitable buyers of Venezuelan crude, oil output will recover somewhat in the medium term as producers become more accustomed to the new post-sanctions export markets. Furthermore, relative macroeconomic stability will allow the non-oil economy to recover marginally in the medium term. There are substantial risks to our forecasts, which assume that Mr Maduro will retain power throughout 2020-24. In the event of a transition, there would be upside risks to our medium-term baseline; the degree of improvement would depend on the characteristics of the transition and on the new government's macroeconomic programme.
Outlook for 2020-24: Inflation Severely reduced domestic supply, constraints on import capacity and the monetisation of large public deficits will continue to stoke hyperinflation this year. Dollarisation and the regime's heavy restrictions on credit helped to subdue hyperinflation in the second half of 2019. Nevertheless, consumer prices rose by 19.5% month on month in June-the second weakest monthly increment in more than a year. This deceleration owes to subsiding effects of social distancing measures on demand-side inflationary pressures. However, as the economy reopens inflationary pressures will strengthen, owing to fuel scarcity, price controls and the ramping up of government money printing.
In the medium term, inflation will remain high for as long as the Maduro regime is in power, given huge fundamental imbalances between supply and demand, and the need for the regime to monetise its fiscal deficits. Weather-related shocks are a perennial risk to the inflation outlook.
Outlook for 2020-24: Exchange rates Hyperinflation will sustain bolívar depreciation in 2020. Given incessant inflation and its effect on nominal values, we believe that another currency denomination (as in March 2018) or a new currency is a strong possibility, although the exact nature of such a move is hard to forecast. In mid-2019 the regime announced a loosening of currency controls. Although this was a positive move, significant barriers limit access to US dollars via formal means. We still believe that the government will maintain a number of indirect controls on the foreign-exchange market. In this environment, a black-market exchange-rate premium is inevitable. On July 30th the official exchange rate was BsS258,000:US$1, compared with a black-market rate of BsS268,000:US$1. The premium (currently 4%) is small by historical comparison.
Outlook for 2020-24: External sector Venezuela will post a small current-account deficit of 2% of GDP in 2020, owing to lower oil exports and limited remittance inflows resulting from the global recession. The BCV's official figures for 2017-18 show that Venezuela posted current-account surpluses in this period. In 2019 the collapse of goods export earnings (owing to US sanctions on the oil trade) hit the trade balance hard. Nevertheless, based on the latest data, we estimate that the current account remained in surplus owing to growing inflows of workers' remittances and the non-payment of interest on bonded debt (saving in excess of US$5bn in 2019).
We expect the current account to return to surplus in the medium term, averaging 4.6% of GDP in 2022-24. Goods exports will recover as international oil prices increase and the country steps up trade with Asian markets. This recovery will be supported by continued weakness in domestic demand, rising remittances from abroad and the fact that the sovereign will remain in default throughout the forecast period.
