Data sources and definitions Sources for global and domestic data refer to historical data; The Economist Intelligence Unit is the source for all forecast data unless otherwise stated
Global data Oil prices: dated Brent
US and OECD consumer price inflation: OECD
US and OECD growth: OECD
US 3-month commercial paper rate: IMF, IFS
US$ effective exchange rate: IMF, IFS; nominal weighted index
World trade growth: Economist Intelligence Unit aggregate
Domestic data Balance of payments, exchange and interest rates: IMF, IFS
Budget balance: non-financial public sector
Commercial banks' prime lending rate: average nominal interest rate charged on loans to agriculture
Deposit interest rate: average nominal interest rate on 90-day term deposits
Exchange rate: IMF, IFS; market rates expressed as BsS:US$
External debt; World Bank, International Debt Statistics
GDP: at constant 1997 prices, BCV
Inflation: BCV, consumer price index (1997=100) for the Caracas metropolitan area
Labour market statistics: derived from a series given in ILO, Yearbook of Labour Statistics
Oil production and export volumes: Bloomberg
Population: Centro Latinoamericano y Caribeño de Demografía (Celade, Latin American and Caribbean Demographic Centre)
Social indicators: World Bank, World Development Indicators
Stock of foreign investment: IMF, IFS; UNCTAD, World Investment Report
Abbreviations BCV: Banco Central de Venezuela (the central bank)
IFS: International Financial Statistics
ILO: International Labour Organisation
UNCTAD: UN Conference on Trade and Development

Full text: - The Economist Intelligence Unit expects the current government to serve out its second term, which will expire in 2024. We expect the prime minister, Narendra Modi, to run a highly centralised administration and to make some progress on pushing through structural reforms.
- A deadly clash between Indian and Chinese troops in a disputed border region in June 2020 will cause a deterioration in diplomatic and economic ties, but we do not forecast large-scale military clashes. The incident will cause India to seek warmer relations with the US and its allies. Bilateral relations with Pakistan will also remain strained, but we do not expect outright hostilities.
- As a result of economic pressure, we expect the government to continue to unwind gradually the lockdown measures introduced in March. The ongoing spread of the coronavirus (Covid-19) may overwhelm India's healthcare system.
- The budget deficit will widen to 7.8% of GDP in fiscal year 2020/21 (April-March) as the government falls short on revenue and launches stimulus to keep households and firms afloat during the lockdown. The deficit will narrow but nevertheless remain wide during the remainder of the forecast period.
- We expect the Reserve Bank of India (RBI, the central bank) to cut interest rates by another 100 basis points in the remainder of 2020: its main policy rate will be cut to 3%. The RBI will also tweak its policy tools and regulatory framework to facilitate the transmission of accommodative monetary policy.
- Real GDP will contract by 5.8% in 2020/21. While the recovery in 2021/22 will be sluggish on a sequential basis, we expect the economy to grow by 8%, owing primarily to a low base of comparison.
- The rupee is forecast to depreciate against the US dollar in 2020, averaging Rs74.7:US$1 as global investors flee to safe-haven markets. It will strengthen slightly in 2021 before depreciating again for the rest of the forecast period.
- The trade deficit will narrow in 2020 amid a slump in global oil prices. It will widen from 2021 as India increases imports of capital goods. Business outsourcing and information technology will remain the key service export sectors in 2020-24.

- India's score improves over the forecast period, owing to improvements in the infrastructure category, but its overall regional ranking remains weak.

Country forecast overview: India's business environment at a glance Policy towards private enterprise and competition 2020-21: The government takes steps towards partial privatisation of some state-owned companies in 2021.
2022-24: The government continues to rationalise liquidation and bankruptcy laws to simplify the closure of insolvent businesses or merger and acquisition activity involving other corporate entities.
Policy towards foreign investment 2020-21: The government liberalises foreign direct investment (FDI) policy in several sectors, as it also encourages the use of locally made products. Investment from China will be heavily scrutinised.
2022-24: Foreign investment in export manufacturing increases markedly, albeit in only a few regions.
Foreign trade and exchange controls 2020-21: India remains reluctant to join major regional trade deals and pivots towards protectionism by raising tariffs.
2022-24: Full capital-account convertibility remains off the policy agenda.
Taxes 2020-21: The government provides only marginal tax rebates and breaks to businesses and individuals affected by the coronavirus (Covid-19) outbreak.
2022-24: Alcohol and petroleum products remain outside the scope of the goods and services tax.
Financing 2020-21: The Reserve Bank of India (the central bank) relaxes regulatory norms for debt-laden banks and non-bank financial companies, raising risks in order to incentivise lending and support economic growth.
2022-24: Private-sector banks account for a rising share of total lending, while bad debt issues persist in public-sector banks. Major consolidation and privatisations within the public-sector banks will continue.
The labour market 2020-21: Unemployment soars because of the lockdown; the government expands the national employment guarantee scheme. Labour laws are liberalised temporarily in some provinces through state-level ordinances.
2022-24: Some state-level liberalisation of labour laws is made permanent through legislation by the central government.
Infrastructure 2020-21: The government increases its budgetary allocation for infrastructure spending to support the economy through the coronavirus crisis.
2022-24: The construction of a high-speed rail link between Mumbai and Ahmedabad continues, but the project misses its targeted completion date of August 2022.
Technological readiness 2020-21: Most technological innovation continues to be concentrated in a few clusters, such as Bangalore and Hyderabad. Expenditure on research and development as a proportion of GDP remains low by international standards.
2022-24: The government makes efforts to digitise the delivery of public services, in an effort to cut corruption and promote the efficiency of "last-mile delivery" for such services.

Background: India gained independence in 1947 after two centuries of British colonial rule. Partition at the same time created the state of Pakistan, with which India has fought three wars (two of them over the disputed territory of Kashmir). India is the second-most populous country in the world, with an estimated 1.37bn people in 2019, according to the UN. Its economy was the third-largest in the world in 2019 (measured in nominal US dollars at purchasing power parity exchange rates).
Political structure: India has been a democracy since independence. At federal level, the Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) holds a majority in the Lok Sabha (the lower house of parliament), although it governs in a broader coalition, the National Democratic Alliance. India follows the UK model of parliamentary government, with a prime minister as head of government. It has a president as the head of state. The country has a quasi-federal structure, with state governments having their own legislatures and enjoying a fair degree of freedom.
Policy issues: We expect the ruling BJP to undertake policy reforms once the coronavirus (Covid-19) pandemic passes. The government has already announced measures to privatise or merge public-sector units in many industries to promote competition. The government will also make modest progress on the liberalisation of regulatory requirements and foreign investment. However, the primary focus of the government will be on structural reform, particularly the contentious labour and land laws. We expect only incremental progress on these issues. The current administration has made headway in speeding up infrastructure projects, and this will also remain a priority in the next five years.
Taxation: The government will maintain efforts to broaden the tax base in 2020-24, including by further digitising tax departments. This, coupled with strong economic growth, will support a pick-up in tax collection. Despite some reforms, including the introduction of a nationwide goods and services tax in 2017, India's tax system will remain highly complex.
Foreign trade: India's merchandise trade deficit narrowed to US$157.7bn in 2019, from US$186.7bn in 2018, while the surplus on the country's services account rose from US$80.8bn to US$84.2bn in the same period.

Outlook for 2020-24: Political stability The Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) won the majority of seats in the election for the Lok Sabha (the lower house of parliament) that took place in April-May 2019. The Economist Intelligence Unit expects the central government to remain in power for its full term, which ends in 2024. The results of the 2019 election were a testament to the popularity of the prime minister, Narendra Modi, who will remain the dominant figure in the government. Decision-making will remain centralised among the prime minister's office (PMO) and key ministers.
In late March the government began to implement what have been among the most stringent lockdown measures around the world, designed to stem the spread of the coronavirus (Covid-19). These measures were initially welcomed by the public as an effective method of halting the spread of the virus. However, the unabated spread of the epidemic and the extensive economic damage caused by the restrictions highlight the risk of social unrest. High levels of unemployment and the government's inability to provide income support will challenge the administration. We expect the government's reform agenda, especially the liberalisation of labour laws, to be another source of tension. Nevertheless, we do not expect these developments to unseat the government; this is because of the formidable support it enjoys from a large part of the citizenry and the lack of a strong opposition.
Over the medium term, protests by religious groups and communal clashes will pose a threat to political stability. Large-scale protests tied to the Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA) were only cut short by social distancing measures introduced to slow the spread of the virus. In contrast to the country's current secular constitution, several far-right groups, including some affiliated with the BJP, have long been pushing for India to be recast as a Hindu nation-a view that puts them at odds with minority groups in the country, notably Muslims. The risk of social instability is high in the latter part of the forecast period, particularly in the two-year period prior to the 2024 general election, if the ruling party moves ahead with its Hindutva (Hindu nationalist) agenda.
The security situation in the state of Jammu and Kashmir (J&K) will remain a central concern throughout the forecast period. We expect security risks in the area to remain high. Any attempt by protesters to destabilise the region is likely to face a heavy-handed response from the government, including the use of internet shutdowns, curfews and riot-control forces. The government's move has also increased the risk of terrorist attack by separatist forces in major Indian cities such as Delhi and Mumbai. A deadly border clash with Chinese troops in June 2020 will also affect political stability. Vocal domestic demands for a strong response pose political risks for Mr Modi, who will be reluctant to risk military escalation.
Outlook for 2020-24: Election watch The next general election is expected to be held around May 2024. The focus before then will be the state assembly elections. The results of recent state elections suggest that voters treat state and national elections differently, and that local issues tend to be more important in the former. We expect the BJP coalition to gain power in the upcoming Bihar election, to be held in late 2020, but only with the help of its coalition partner in the state.
In the Rajya Sabha (the upper house), the BJP and its allies form the largest grouping, although they command fewer than half of the seats. Assuming that the BJP retains control of key state assemblies and wins control of more in the next few years, the party and its allies within the larger National Democratic Alliance (NDA) will secure a simple majority in the upper house from end-2020. This will enable the alliance to pass legislation without opposition approval. However, it will struggle to win the two-thirds majority needed to make constitutional changes unchallenged.
Outlook for 2020-24: International relations Tensions with Pakistan have persisted amid the dispute over J&K. We expect relations to remain strained, but do not anticipate a complete breakdown of diplomatic ties. We believe that Pakistan's military will increase its support for militant groups in Indian-controlled Kashmir. This will raise the risk of terrorist attacks by non-state actors. Although small-scale military exchanges between the two countries are likely to occur in 2020-24, the nuclear arsenal of the two countries will act as a powerful deterrent against full-scale conflict.
A deadly border clash between China and India in June has led to a substantial deterioration in bilateral relations. India has taken steps to retaliate economically against China, such as toughening the approval process for Chinese investments and increasing tariff and non-tariff barriers on Chinese exports to India. Economic retaliation by China will focus primarily on tit-for-tat tariff increases rather than more detrimental export restrictions that could disrupt supply chains for Indian firms. We also expect further skirmishes tied to infrastructure development in border regions disputed by the two countries. However, large-scale military clashes are not within our core forecast.
Souring ties with China will encourage India to improve relations with the US, Japan and Australia, among other countries. India's foreign policy within South Asia will also focus on countering increasing Chinese influence in Nepal and Sri Lanka. India's relations with Bangladesh will remain cordial.
Outlook for 2020-24: Policy trends The government's majority will give it considerable flexibility in determining the economic policy agenda. Its key near-term priority is to contain the coronavirus outbreak, to which India is particularly vulnerable, given its large population and weak healthcare infrastructure. The widespread and stringent lockdown measures imposed from March were only partially successful in reducing the spread of the virus, which has accelerated since such measures were relaxed gradually from May. Despite the spread of the virus, we believe that the government will continue to take steps towards reopening the economy, adopting localised quarantine policies where necessary.
We expect the government to take up policy reforms after the crisis as it looks to support growth. The government plans to open up more sectors of the economy to private firms, by privatising or reducing the number of public-sector units. The government will undertake piecemeal changes to legislation, such as a relaxation of regulatory requirements and a modest liberalisation of foreign direct investment (FDI) rules. In terms of improving the business environment, one area of attention will be the liberalisation of contentious labour and land laws. Progress on this will be limited and the benefits will only be seen in the latter part of the forecast period.
The lockdown will amplify the mounting non-performing loan (NPL) issue in the banking sector. Slow progress will be made towards policy changes to improve the health of the sector. Infrastructure projects-particularly pet projects of the Modi government, such as the National Infrastructure Pipeline-remain a priority, in response to the rapid pace of urbanisation and to boost the business environment. However, we expect a revival in infrastructure spending only from the fourth quarter of 2020, once the coronavirus outbreak is brought more under control.
Outlook for 2020-24: Fiscal policy The coronavirus outbreak will force the government to rewrite its approved budget for 2020/21, which was conservatively expansionary. It will suspend the Fiscal Responsibility and Budget Management Act temporarily to allow for more flexibility in supporting the economy. The lockdown has prompted an unbudgeted increase in social spending programmes, especially the National Rural Employment Guarantee Scheme, as well as an extension of existing financial support schemes for businesses.
The government has announced an Rs20trn package (equivalent to around 10% of GDP) to support the economy. However, this headline figure includes liquidity measures provided by the Reserve Bank of India (RBI, the central bank) and advances by banks under the government's measures. The actual amount of additional budgetary spending announced equates to around 1.4% of GDP. We expect the government to announce another fiscal package, worth 1-1.5% of GDP, in the third quarter of 2020, including an infrastructure development programme. In view of a fall in revenue and lower nominal GDP, the budget deficit is forecast to widen to the equivalent of 7.8% of GDP in 2020/21.
As the economy recovers, the government will look to consolidate the public finances gradually. This will narrow the budget deficit to the equivalent of 6.7% of GDP in 2021/22. The authorities will look to deepen the tax base and increase low levels of tax compliance. However, the need to support welfare payments and infrastructure spending will maintain upward pressure on fiscal expenditure. We also expect subsidies to remain in place for labour-intensive, small-scale businesses-particularly those that are export-focused.
This federal fiscal picture does not reflect the true level of the deficit. The deficits of many states and part of the expenditure of public-sector units represent implicit liabilities for the central government.
Outlook for 2020-24: Monetary policy The coronavirus epidemic will prompt further monetary-policy loosening by the RBI. The central bank has lowered its policy repo rate by 115 basis points to 4% since March, while also widening the monetary-policy corridor by lowering the reverse repo rate (the "floor" of the corridor) by 155 basis points, to 3.35%. With inflationary pressure expected to moderate and economic growth under strong downward pressure, we expect a further 100-basis-point reduction in the policy repo rate over the remainder of 2020. We also expect the adoption of unconventional policy instruments, including long-term repo operations to lend to banks, which will include further long-term refinancing operations.
Monetary policy will aim to support businesses as the coronavirus pandemic suppresses household spending and business investment. However, the outcome may be far from satisfactory, as monetary policy transmission is not smooth. While banking-sector lending to micro, small and medium-sized enterprises will improve, as the government has provided a sovereign guarantee for those loans, banks will be reluctant to lend to other parts of the economy, given increased risk. The level of non-performing assets in the financial sector is alarming, and the coronavirus outbreak will only exacerbate the issue, with more firms forced out of business. Policy support from the central bank and the government will be needed to support the recovery of the banking sector once the pandemic passes.
The RBI has maintained inflation-targeting as the cornerstone of its monetary policy framework. It seeks to contain consumer price inflation within a 2-6% range, and close to a target of 4%. However, strong political pressure on the RBI-which has forced out two hawkish heads of the bank under BJP rule-has complicated the achievement of these objectives.
Outlook for 2020-24: Economic growth We expect real GDP to contract by 5.8% in 2020/21-the sharpest contraction in economic activity since India's independence in 1947. The headline GDP number will be pulled down primarily by an 18.1% year-on-year economic contraction in the first quarter of 2020/21, reflecting India's stringent lockdown measures. The economy will continue to contract on an annual basis in the second and third quarters of 2020/21, as job losses and business closures depress activity. Sectors such as travel, hospitality and tourism will be the most affected.
On a GDP expenditure basis, we expect private consumption to contract sharply in 2020/21, as people's economic activities are constrained during lockdown and as consumption remains low even after the restrictions are lifted. Investment spending is also expected to decline steeply as firms postpone activity amid high uncertainty around the virus. We also expect increased loan liabilities to be taken up by corporates and banks to further discourage new investment. We maintain our view that the government will continue to bolster the economy through increased expenditure, but the effect will be limited. We expect exports to fall as a global recession sets in.
Real GDP growth is expected to rebound sharply in 2021/22, but the headline forecast of 8% is exaggerated by an extremely low base of comparison in 2020/21. Economic growth in 2022/23-2024/25 will average 5.9% a year. Incremental progress on structural reform will provide support for growth in the latter part of the forecast period.
Outlook for 2020-24: Inflation We expect consumer prices to increase by an average of 3.4% in 2020 as a whole. While food price inflation has remained elevated during the lockdown, we expect it to moderate once supply-side constraints ease. Furthermore, a collapse in non-food demand will lead the fall in the headline number. Inflation will be pushed down further in the second half of the year by a higher base of comparison in 2019. Our forecast assumes a normal monsoon this year (and in every year of the outlook period).
The RBI will keep its policy rate unchanged in 2021 to bolster the recovery, which will lead to stronger inflation. The adoption of a tighter monetary policy stance in 2022 will offset the inflationary impact of strengthening oil prices. The central bank will accord higher priority to containing inflationary pressures towards the end of the forecast period; consumer price inflation is expected to average 4.4% in 2024.
Low oil prices and reduced domestic demand will generate producer price inflation of just 0.1% in 2020. As prices for oil and other commodities strengthen, producer price inflation will firm to an average of 3.5% in 2021-24.
Outlook for 2020-24: Exchange rates The RBI's adoption of a fairly aggressive loosening stance in 2020, along with a sharp contraction in economic activity, will weigh on the exchange rate. We forecast that the rupee will depreciate by 6.1% on an annual average basis to Rs74.7:US$1 in 2020, as the domestic economic situation worsens.
In 2021 we expect the rupee to appreciate slightly, to an average of Rs73.7:US$1, as foreign investment returns. The rupee will depreciate in 2022-24 amid rising oil prices and a persistent current-account deficit.
Outlook for 2020-24: External sector The lower oil price and weaker domestic demand will contribute to a narrowing of India's current-account deficit in 2020, to the equivalent of 0.4% of GDP. Merchandise exports will contract sharply because of disruption caused by the pandemic, but are expected to rebound in 2021 amid a pick-up in global demand.
Increased competition from other countries and changing industrial trends will weigh on the pace of growth in India's main service export sectors, particularly business-process outsourcing and information technology. Nevertheless, the services balance will remain in surplus throughout the forecast period, making a positive contribution to the current account. Owing to the large shortfall on merchandise trade, however, the current account will remain in deficit, averaging -1.2% of GDP in the remainder of the forecast period.
The coronavirus outbreak will also weigh on inward investment in 2020-21. Inward direct investment will recover in the rest of the forecast period, as the expanding economy and growing consumer demand provide opportunities for businesses and the business environment improves under the government's reform agenda.

Data sources and definitions The sources for global and domestic data refer to historical data. The source for all forecast data, unless otherwise stated, is The Economist Intelligence Unit
Global data US & OECD GDP growth: OECD
World trade growth: Economist Intelligence Unit aggregate
US & OECD inflation: OECD
Oil prices: dated Brent Blend
Domestic data GDP: Central Statistics Office; all national-accounts data are for fiscal years beginning April 1st of year shown
Population: IMF, IFS
Public finance: World Bank, India CEM, unless revised by the GOI's annual budget papers
Oil production: Oil & Gas Journal; Ministry of Petroleum and Natural Gas
Inflation, exchange rates and money supply: IMF, IFS; Centre for Monitoring Indian Economy, MRIE; RBI, WSS
Yield on 91-day Treasury bills: World Bank, India CEM, unless revised by Centre for Monitoring Indian Economy, MRIE
Short-term benchmark interest rate: World Bank, India CEM; IDBI prime lending rate
Direction of trade: GOI, Economic Survey (annual)
Composition of trade and the current account: World Bank, India CEM, unless revised by Centre for Monitoring Indian Economy, MRIE or RBI, Annual Report
Foreign direct investment (FDI): IMF, IFS; UNCTAD, World Investment Report; includes reinvested profits
Foreign debt: World Bank, International Debt Statistics

Country Forecast Norway July 2020 Updater

https://www.proquest.com/reports/country-forecast-norway-july-2020-updater/docview/2421645563/se-2?accountid=14357

Abstract: Key indicators Key indicators 2019 2020 2021 2022 2023 2024 Real GDP growth (%) 1.2 -5.5 2.9 2.4 2.0 2.0 Consumer price inflation (av; %) 2.2 0.8 1.0 1.1 1.4 1.7 General government budget balance (% of GDP) 6.4 -0.9 1.4 3.0 3.5 3.7 Current-account balance (% of GDP) 4.0 1.4 1.8 4.4 5.0 5.3 3-month Nibor rate (av; %) 1.6 1.2 1.3 1.5 1.7 1.9 Exchange rate Nkr:US$ (av) 8.80 9.98 9.96 9.62 9.33 8.97 Exchange rate Nkr:€ (av) 9.85 11.08 11.01 10.97 11.05 10.87 Exchange rate US$:€ (av) 1.12 1.11 1.11 1.14 1.19 1.21 Country forecast overview: Low regulatory burden, but probable rise in already high level of state influence in the economy, following emergency policy measures in response to the coronavirus pandemic and related temporary lockdown. 2022-24: A strategic plan guides the Norwegian Competition Authority to raise sectoral competition and procurement rules. Fact sheet Annual data 2019a Historical averages (%) 2015-19 Population (m) 5.4 Population growth 0.8 GDP (US$ bn; market exchange rate) 404.3 Real GDP growth 1.5 GDP (US$ bn; purchasing power parity) 370.8 Real domestic demand growth 1.8 GDP per head (US$; market exchange rate) 75,472 Inflation 2.5 GDP per head (US$; purchasing power parity) 69,213 Current-account balance (% of GDP) 5.6 Exchange rate (av) Nkr:US$ 8.80 FDI inflows (% of GDP) -0.6 a Actual. Oil companies pay an additional flat-rate tax of 50% on income derived from the extraction, processing and transport of oil, but benefit from a 78% tax refund on the costs of exploration for oil and gas.

Links: https://VS2GA4MQ9G.search.serialssolutions.com?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Apoliticalscience&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=Country+Forecast.+Norway&amp;rft.atitle=Country+Forecast+Norway+July+2020+Updater&amp;rft.au=&amp;rft.aulast=&amp;rft.aufirst=&amp;rft.date=2020-07-01&amp;rft.volume=&amp;rft.issue=&amp;rft.spage=&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Country+Forecast.+Norway&amp;rft.issn=09669450&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: - The outbreak of the coronavirus resulted in the imposition of significant restrictions on economic activity and population, generating a recession in 2020, with output contracting by 5.5% for the full year. Fiscal stimulus measures, as well as a substantial decline in oil sector revenue, will generate a looser fiscal stance that will persist throughout the forecast period (2020-24).
- Norway has a history of coalition governments and cross-party consensus, delivering high levels of political stability. The constitution does not allow for the dissolution of parliament. The ruling coalition comprises the Conservatives, the Liberals and the Christian Democrats (KrF) as a minority government, with 61 seats in the 169-seat parliament. The next election is in September 2021, and The Economist Intelligence Unit expects the centre-right bloc to re-enter government, owing to its competent handling of the coronavirus outbreak.
- We expect real GDP to contract by 5.5% in 2020, owing to the fallout from the virus. We do not expect a reimposition of a lockdown even in the event of a revival of infections. The economy will recover from 2021 to 2024, with growth averaging 2.4% as restrictions on trade and mobility gradually recede.
- We estimate that inflation will fall to 0.8% on average in 2020, from 2.2% in 2019, owing to worsening economic conditions, but pressures on core inflation from rising food prices pose an upside risk to price growth. Economic recovery will generate a rebound in inflation throughout the forecast period, generating inflation averaging 1.3% in 2021-24.
- In March Norges Bank (the central bank) reversed much of its monetary tightening, lowering interest rates by a total of 125 basis points, to 0.25%. Core inflation is falling as demand declines, and rates are expected to remain stable until the end of 2020. A steady policy of normalisation will follow, with policy rates reaching 1.5% by 2024.

- Norway's business environment score rises slightly for 2020-24, as the economy has become more resilient following oil industry reforms. Backed by vast oil wealth, the political and economic environments are robust, and financing opportunities should remain firm. Norway lags regional peers owing to limited market opportunities, tight labour market regulation and high wages.

Country forecast overview: Norway's business environment at a glance Policy towards private enterprise and competition 2020-21: Low regulatory burden, but probable rise in already high level of state influence in the economy, following emergency policy measures in response to the coronavirus pandemic and related temporary lockdown.
2022-24: A strategic plan guides the Norwegian Competition Authority to raise sectoral competition and procurement rules.
Policy towards foreign investment 2020-21: Generally positive attitude towards attracting foreign direct investment, but capital inflows constrained by weak global economy and new domestic investment screening regime that can block investment on national security grounds.
2022-24: The economy further diversifies investor countries beyond Europe, although to limited effect.
Foreign trade and exchange controls 2020-21: Absorbing the shock to global trade from the coronavirus will be a major theme, with a discussion around "reshoring" strategic industries away from China likely to follow the immediate crisis.
2022-24: No change in policy towards joining the EU or leaving the European Economic Area (EEA). A reassessment of EEA membership is possible, but unlikely. Efforts to promote bilateral trade deals continue.
Taxes 2020-21: Temporary stimulus measures and easing of tax-payment requirements for firms in response to coronavirus.
2022-24: Government investigates reform of subsidy regime for oil and gas exploration. Expansion of environmental taxes to meet climate change goals.
Financing 2020-21: Significant expansion of central bank liquidity to support functioning of financial markets. Policy interest rates remain at record-low level. Private-sector balance sheets weakened by economic fallout from the crisis.
2022-24: Credit demand likely to remain subdued following the crisis, but opportunities could emerge for growth of non-bank financing channels, including private equity and venture capital. Tighter anti-money-laundering rules.
The labour market 2020-21: The coronavirus shock leads to a substantial reversal in labour market performance.
2022-24: Improvements in employment and wages follow the crisis. Skills shortages remain an issue in some sectors.
Infrastructure 2020-21: Government applies 12-year transport plan (2018-29) and raises funds available for maintenance and construction of infrastructure projects. Gradual roll-out of fifth-generation (5G) mobile services.
2022-24: Investments in new road and rail transport links are made. Digital infrastructure upgrades continue.
Technological developments 2020-21: Implementation of Norway's cyber-defence strategy, after cyber-attacks on national infrastructure.
2022-24: The Open Artificial Intelligence (AI) lab grows in size and importance, underpinning AI preparedness.

Background: The Labour Party governed almost continuously in 1935-65, dominating until 2001, when a minority coalition comprising the Conservatives, the Christian Democrats (KrF) and the Liberals swept to power. In 2005 Labour returned to office in a centre-left coalition with the Socialist Left Party (SV) and the Centre Party-the first majority government in two decades-lasting until 2009. The September 2013 election led to a regime change, with a minority right-of-centre coalition of the Conservatives and the Progress Party (FrP) taking office. The centre-right coalition was re-elected in 2017. The Conservatives and the FrP were joined by the Liberals in January 2018 and by the KrF in January 2019.
Political structure: There is no right of dissolution between elections. Norway uses a modified proportional representation system: 150 out of the 169 members of the unicameral Storting (parliament) are "district mandates" elected by open-list proportional representation. The remaining 19 seats, the "levelling mandates", are distributed only between the parties that get more than 4% of the national vote and whose initial seat count (out of 150) is not proportional to their share of the vote.
Policy issues: The centre-right government will try to implement additional business-friendly policies and tax cuts, focused on further reducing the negative spillover effects of lower oil prices on wider economic activity and on strengthening the mainland economy. Spending from Norway's oil fund is expected to rise, but it will remain comfortably within the country's fiscal guidelines. Despite a cross-party agreement on tackling climate change, tension will persist in the Storting over the balance between industrial development and environmental protection.
Taxation: At the start of 2016 most parties agreed on a multi-year corporation tax reduction (from 27% to 23% by 2018) to improve competitiveness in the economy; it has since been reduced to 22% in 2019. Oil companies pay an additional flat-rate tax of 50% on income derived from the extraction, processing and transport of oil, but benefit from a 78% tax refund on the costs of exploration for oil and gas. The capital-gains tax was cut from 28% to 27% in 2014. The ordinary rate of value-added tax (VAT) is 25%. The top marginal income tax rate is 54.3% (including employers' social security contributions).
Foreign trade: Oil and gas output and prices greatly affect Norway's trade flows. The petroleum industry contributes about half of total goods export revenue. In 2016 the trade account registered its lowest level since 1999, but has been recovering since. The current-account surplus increased to US$16.1bn in 2019, down from US$31.1bn in the previous year. The trade and current-account balance will remain in surplus throughout the forecast period (2020-24).

Outlook for 2020-24: Political stability The current ruling coalition, comprising the centre-right Conservatives and two small centrist parties-the Liberals and the Christian Democrats (KrF)-is coming to the end of its term in September 2021. The coalition rules as a minority government, with just 61 members in the 169-seat parliament, after the far-right Progress Party (FrP) withdrew from government in January 2020 after a coalition dispute over infrastructure. Given the nearing of the next general election, scheduled for September 2021, and a strong tradition of political consensus, The Economist Intelligence Unit does not expect a change in government.
Despite the government being a minority in parliament, it is able to pass legislation with the backing of the FrP (which has pledged to support it in significant parliamentary votes). The ruling coalition can also rely on the support of other opposition parties (such as the centre-left Labour Party). Although the FrP will probably withdraw its support for the government on some matters (preventing the proposal of some legislation), the damage to political stability would be low, as the constitution prohibits a pre-term dissolution of parliament, and therefore a snap election.
In the near term the outbreak of the novel coronavirus has strengthened the stabilising influences on the political outlook. The government has mostly unwound its restrictions on social interaction, after being among the first group of European countries to experience a outbreak of the disease. Public support for the ruling parties has strengthened markedly during the crisis, and political support for the lockdown was wide-ranging. Despite the economic disruption caused by the lockdown, there has been no increase in support for populist parties in Norway. Populist movements have historically had limited electoral appeal in the country, as the far-right FrP takes a largely pragmatic approach to government, in contrast with other European populist movements. Their presence has only a marginal impact on political stability, as the domestic political culture is highly consensus-driven, with frequent collaboration between the government and opposition parties on a range of issues.
Outlook for 2020-24: Election watch The next general election will be held in September 2021. The Storting cannot be dissolved before completing a full four-year term, meaning that there is no risk of a snap election. A change in government is also not part of our forecast.
Although the handling of the coronavirus crisis is likely to shape political preferences in the run-up to the election, it is unclear how much of an effect it will have by September 2021. The governing bloc of right-wing parties (excluding the FrP) have seen their popular support increase in the wake of the pandemic, a feature common to most countries. We expect the government's competent handling of the coronavirus crisis to place the right-wing bloc in a good position before the election in 2021, although the decline in support for the FrP since 2017 means they may not be able to produce a stable majority.
Outlook for 2020-24: International relations EU relations will remain a significant foreign policy issue, and may steadily encroach on domestic politics as environmental affairs become increasingly prominent. As a member of the European Economic Area, Norway has access to the single market (in exchange for contributions to the EU budget), but must accept relevant EU regulations while having limited influence over them. This has historically been accepted as a substitute for outright EU membership (which has been rejected twice in national referendums in 1972 and 1994), but mounting concern over economic diversification and a reduction in carbon emissions has pushed environmentalist parties (the Greens and the Liberals) to support outright EU membership. Although we do not expect Norway to join the EU without a national referendum, political pressure for a third plebiscite on the matter may grow in tandem with environmentalist influence in the government.
Outlook for 2020-24: Policy trends Having passed the first stages of the pandemic ahead of neighbouring countries, the government's chief policy objective has been to steadily unwind the controls imposed in early March. Government policy has followed the broad European pattern, with enforced closures of schools, businesses and public events, alongside restrictions on movement (specifically from urban to rural areas).
As one of the European countries to act the earliest, Norway was also among the first to exit controls when it did so on June 15th. Restrictions on economic activity have been mostly withdrawn, with bars, gyms and restaurants allowed to fully reopen (under some social distancing measures) and all public events under 200 people are permitted. Internationally, controls on cross-border movement between other Nordic states (except Sweden) have been fully lifted, and restrictions on travel from EU states have been substantially reduced. Although the policy response in a renewed outbreak remains uncertain, early indications are that a renewed nationwide lockdown is unlikely, as the associated economic costs would be too great.
Nevertheless, a revival in infections as controls are lifted remains a substantial risk to our economic forecast in 2020-21 and will probably generate another contraction in activity, as fear of infection will supress demand. Countervailing this, a rise in infections is likely to be met with a more robust public response. Although the lockdown has proved economically costly, it has given time for improvements in the capacity of the healthcare system and in a trace and quarantine system that will reduce the spread of the virus even without a vaccine.
Outlook for 2020-24: Fiscal policy Like other European countries, Norway has announced fiscal stimulus in the wake of the coronavirus outbreak, although this is much smaller than in peer economies. Total discretionary stimulus has amounted to about Nkr160bn (US$16bn), or about 5.5% of mainland GDP. The budget that the government presented in October 2019 has been abandoned as the disruption from the coronavirus generates a dual shock to both the mainland and oil sectors. The government's new budget, presented in mid-May, targets a substantial with-drawal from the Government Pension Fund Global (GPFG; 4.2% of its value) to fund further expenditure, in breach of the government's fiscal rule to not withdraw more than 3% of the fund's value in any year. We expect that the government will have to lean on the fund for further fiscal support in the coming years, but this will not diminish its vast size. For the first time since 1993, this will not be enough to prevent a deficit in 2020, which we forecast at just 0.9% of GDP.
Existing government support for the labour market is similar to the measures implemented in response to the coronavirus in neighbouring countries. Under the system of permittering, the government temporarily pays a large portion (more than 60%) of the wages of workers who are placed on furlough. Expanded take-up of this scheme, although it will preserve much of the existing labour market for the duration of the pandemic, will leave the government liable for a significant increase in spending.
On the employer side, fiscal support has expanded rapidly. The government has deferred tax payments and purchased corporate bonds on the secondary market, reducing borrowing costs for businesses. About Nkr20bn has been set aside as a crisis fund to cover fixed costs for businesses during the coronavirus pandemic, modelled on the Danish fund set up for this purpose.
Outlook for 2020-24: Monetary policy In response to the substantial disruption caused by the pandemic, Norges Bank (the central bank) has lowered the policy rate by 150 basis points since February, to 0%-the lowest rate in modern history. This unprecedented mone-tary easing was completed over three meetings of the monetary policy committee. The central bank also lowered countercyclical capital buffers for major banks from 2.5% to 1% to ensure bank solvency and expand credit growth.
We expect Norges Bank to maintain its highly accommodative policy until the end of 2021, given the lingering uncertainty around the evolution of the pandemic, which will continue to weigh on business and consumer confidence. There are likely to be substantial scarring effects on both output and employment from the virus, with major risks to Norway's oil sector, with looser monetary policy required to accelerate the recovery in the near term. Looking ahead, Norges Bank targets inflation of "close to 2% over time", and the policy rate should rise steadily after 2021 when economic conditions improve. The steady rise in oil prices, the gradual recovery of the domestic economy and the revival in global trade should all generate a steady normalisation of interest rates over the forecast period.
Outlook for 2020-24: Economic growth Despite the shift in policy towards a steady easing of lockdown restrictions, the gradual pace of withdrawal throughout the second quarter of 2020 will guarantee a contraction in the second quarter of the year, after an initial decline of 1.6% in the first quarter. With most forms of the lockdown extending from March 12th to June 15th we judge that the bulk of the decline will take place in the second quarter, as 11 of the 14 weeks of restrictions took place in that time. The economy will rebound only in the latter half of 2020 as control measures subside and economic activity improves, bringing full-year output down by 5.5% from 2019. There remains a high risk that the rate of viral infection will increase as the social distancing measures are withdrawn, prompting a reimposition of controls later in the year. We judge that long-term scarring from the crisis will be significant, but modest compared with peer economies, as government support for short-term disruption to the labour market will remain substantial.
The coronavirus pandemic and the subsequent lockdown will primarily affect consumer spending and export demand in Norway, which we expect to decline by 6.9% and 11.8% respectively. On the consumption side, the imposition of social-distancing measures damages consumer spending both directly, through the prevention of consumer activities such as services spending, and indirectly, through a decline in total employment and consumer spending power. On the external side, similar lockdowns among major trading partners (namely the UK and Germany) will weigh on demand for major exports, such as energy goods and shipping.
The export-oriented oil and gas sector will be especially damaged by the outbreak. Demand for both gas and oil globally is strongly pro-cyclical and Norway's entrenched exposure to markets in Europe (the region worst hit by the crisis) implies a substantial contraction in real exports this year. Although firms within Norway's oil sector (especially Equinor, the state-backed oil firm) are in good shape, real exports and the outlook for investment in the sector have worsened significantly.
Investment in both the oil and non-oil sectors will also weaken, as uncertainty around a possible recurrence of the virus (at least until a vaccine is produced) will chill investor appetite for risk, and cuts in oil sector production will weigh on the returns of offshore projects. Growth will recover more substantially from 2021 onwards as economic life returns to normal and the risk of a reimposition of controls steadily abates. However, the prospect of lasting damage to household balance sheets (with household debt at 110% of GDP in December 2019), business confidence and oil investment will keep real GDP below pre-crisis levels until 2023.
Outlook for 2020-24: Inflation The inflationary effects from the coronavirus lockdown have been broadly negative, with the collapse in energy prices and demand for non-essential goods pulling down price growth . Headline inflation initially fell from 1.8% in January to 0.7% in March, before rising to 1.3% in May. Nevertheless, now that restrictions are being lifted, inflation has started to pick up pace again. Rising core inflation, owing to a depreciating currency and a rise in food price inflation, to over 3% in May, will erode consumer purchasing power.
Looking ahead, we expect that the disruptive effects of the coronavirus on consumer demand and oil prices will drag down inflation in 2020, to an average of 0.8%. This trend will be supported by an easing in household stockpiling as controls on social distancing abate, and as the fall in oil prices (which we expect to average US$40/barrel this year) ripples through the economy. The downward movement in the krone and a stronger than expected recovery in consumer spending continue to pose upside risks for inflation.
Outlook for 2020-24: Exchange rates The krone has largely matched the substantial changes in global energy markets since January. Between end-2019 and end-June, it depreciated by roughly 8% on a trade-weighted basis, as the price of oil has collapsed from US$65/b to US$39/b and economic activity has slowed.
Although the krone has strengthened from its nadir in March (when it had depreciated by over 17% since December), conditions of subdued demand and slower growth are likely to prevent the krone from fully returning to its December value until 2024, when oil prices have recovered, and production is restored. Further downward shocks to oil prices, chiefly from shocks to global demand, remain a risk to our exchange-rate forecast.
Outlook for 2020-24: External sector Norway's current-account surpluses are structurally supported by large inflows on the trade and primary income accounts, respectively reflecting the economy's position as a major oil exporter and the size of the GPFG.
Although inflows in both of these components will be damaged by the economic fallout from the coronavirus, we do not expect either of these accounts to fall into deficit. Oil exports will be damaged by the proposed cuts to production, but we expect that this will be balanced by the reduction in goods imports, keeping the trade balance in surplus despite the fall in oil prices.
As the coronavirus abates, steady rises in oil prices from 2021 onwards will further support the trade balance, and increases in production (barring any government intervention) will continue throughout the forecast period. We expect that this, combined with a revival of growth in major trading partners (particularly the UK and Germany), will support a rise in the current-account surplus over the forecast period, to 5.3% of GDP in 2024.

Full text: - Despite Venezuela's socioeconomic collapse and a public health crisis triggered by the spread of the coronavirus (Covid-19), The Economist Intelligence Unit expects that the civic-military regime led by Nicolás Maduro of the Partido Socialista Unido de Venezuela will retain power throughout the 2020-24 forecast period. Mr Maduro's position will be supported primarily by his grip over a complex security apparatus and the opposition's lack of de facto power. On this basis, we expect continued deterioration of the economy, sustained outward migration, and a poorer and more violent Venezuela. Despite US sanctions (and their impact on oil production), the Maduro regime has managed internal dissent through a patronage system that rewards loyalty, as well as through its strict control over the security forces.
- The scale of the socioeconomic collapse and the elevated level of political instability will ensure that the Maduro regime continues to be challenged economically and politically. Low international crude prices, combined with US sanctions on the regime, mean that Venezuela is struggling to place its oil exports abroad. We therefore forecast a reduction in domestic crude production in the coming months. Moreover, given that it will lose control of the legislature in 2021, the opposition will be under strong pressure this year to step up its efforts to oust the regime. Mr Maduro will continue to face challenges to maintain the current patronage system and remain in control.
- De facto dollarisation of the economy is expanding. Concurrently, the government has taken measures that have allowed the official exchange rate to float. These measures have so far aided price stability and therefore increase the availability of some basic goods. However, the measures are not a product of economic orthodoxy, but of policy decisions to ensure the regime's survival. We do not expect to see the comprehensive economic and institutional reforms that will be required to resolve the economic crisis within the forecast period.

- Venezuela is ranked 82nd of 82 countries in the global business environment rankings for 2020-24, having been in 80th place in the 2015-19 historical period, as the economic crisis deepens despite minor improvements. Reforms to institutions, economic policy and the business environment are unlikely.

Country forecast overview: Venezuela's business environment at a glance Policy towards private enterprise and competition 2020-21: Expansion of interventionist measures, including price controls. Corruption and selective application of regulations remain common and continue to undermine free competition.
2022-24: Contract rights remain weak, and red tape and ad hoc interventionism continue.
Policy towards foreign investment 2020-21: Most attempts to attract investment prove unsuccessful, owing to political and economic instability.
2022-24: Actual investment flows remain low amid ongoing economic volatility. Intellectual property protection and private property rights deteriorate.
Foreign trade and exchange controls 2020-21: Currency controls are weakened, but access to foreign currency remains limited.
2022-24: Efforts to remove trade and capital controls are taken on a gradual basis, and de facto dollarisation advances. Domestic supply of foreign currency improves as oil prices rise, albeit slowly.
Taxes 2020-21: Risk of further unrest and political instability reduces probability of tax increases, despite fiscal deficits. Severity of economic crisis precludes major rise in public spending.
2022-24: Tax system remains complex and unwieldy, but risk of discriminatory, ad hoc tax measures declines.
Financing 2020-21: Inflation remains high and concerns surrounding economic instability restrict financing to only short term.
2022-24: Economic adjustments take time to feed through to solid, sustainable growth in credit to private sector and development of capital markets. Long-term finance remains in short supply.
Labour market 2020-21: Labour laws add substantially to non-wage costs. Past emigration of skilled labour aggravates skills shortages.
2022-24: Labour-market rigidities persist, despite some increase in flexibility of hiring and firing practices.
Infrastructure 2020-21: Underinvestment in water network and electricity grid leads to continued rationing and unpredictable blackouts.
2022-24: Investors remain highly cautious of committing to long-term capital projects. Infrastructure deteriorates even further.
Technological readiness 2020-21: E-government services remain almost non-existent. Deteriorating infrastructure limits adoption of new technologies. Telecommunications sector is opened to foreign investment, but with little interest.
2022-24: Limited regulatory capacity and years of underinvestment continue to limit internet and mobile coverage.

Background: From 1958 until the mid-1990s, two parties-Acción Democrática and the Comité de Organización Política Electoral Independiente-alternated in power. Frequent economic crises and endemic corruption eventually led to a collapse in support for both parties and culminated in the 1998 election of Hugo Chávez, a former lieutenant-colonel and leader of a failed coup in 1992. Mr Chávez's policy programme exacerbated political polarisation, but several attempts to remove him from power before his death in March 2013 proved unsuccessful. His chosen successor, Nicolás Maduro, has seen his own popularity plummet as his mismanagement of a drop in oil prices, combined with strict sanctions on trade from the US, has plunged the country into a severe economic depression.
Political structure: Although Venezuela is nominally a federal republic with separation of powers, the ruling Partido Socialista Unido de Venezuela (PSUV) has systematically eroded institutions. In December 2015 the opposition coalition, Mesa de la Unidad Democrática, won control of the unicameral National Assembly (AN). In January 2016 the politicised Supreme Court declared the legislature to be in contempt of court, blocking all subsequent legislation. Since August 2017, a PSUV-only Constituent Assembly has granted itself a remit over all legislative matters, becoming the country's de facto legislature and sidelining the AN.
Policy issues: The most pressing policy issue is the need to stabilise an economy that remains mired in a long-standing economic crisis. The monetisation of vast public deficits has created an ever-increasing excess of domestic currency, triggering hyperinflation. Mismanagement of PDVSA, the state-owned oil company and originator of practically all foreign-currency inflows into the country, has resulted in a sharp contraction of oil production. This has restricted foreign-currency supply, giving way to currency controls, the rationing of imports, and the emergence of black markets for both foreign currency and basic goods. The scarcity of foreign exchange has also led to arrears on most of the external debt issued by sovereign and state-owned firms.
Taxation: The top corporate tax rate is 34% for non-oil companies and 50% for oil firms. The value-added tax (VAT) rate stands at 12%.
Foreign trade: The goods trade surplus fell to US$20.9bn in 2018 as the destruction of domestic supply led to increasing import dependence. The Economist Intelligence Unit estimates the 2018 current-account surplus to be 3.6% of GDP.

Outlook for 2020-24: Political stability The Economist Intelligence Unit considers that the coronavirus (Covid-19) outbreak and diminished oil rents-resulting from low international oil prices and existing US sanctions-present hefty challenges for the survival of the military regime led by Nicolás Maduro of the Partido Socialista Unido de Venezuela (PSUV). Owing to the bleak state of its healthcare system, Venezuela faces an uphill battle against the coronavirus, and there is a high risk that the ongoing socioeconomic crisis could evolve into a humanitarian calamity. The government's mandatory social distancing measures will be a source of unrest-as many workers simply lack the savings they need to survive without continuing to work-as will Mr Maduro's decision to remove some petrol subsidies in the face of fuel shortages.
Despite these compounding social and economic shocks, we expect Mr Maduro to retain power throughout 2020, ruling over what is becoming a much less populous and much poorer country. Mr Maduro has two main factors in his favour. First, the opposition led by the head of the National Assembly, Juan Guaidó, has lost the momentum that it held in 2019. Secondly, the regime retains strict control over the military, the police and paramilitary forces. Although the risks to our forecasts are very high, we assume that this control-together with the complexity of the security apparatus and the recurrent purges within it-will allow the regime to manage internal dissent.
Mr Maduro' recent actions show that he has the upper hand against the opposition. The new electoral council, inaugurated on June 12th, was packed with Mr Maduro's allies, while opposition members loyal to the regime were appointed as heads of two key opposition parties-Primero Justicia and Voluntad Popular. These actions set the stage for rigged parliamentary elections in December as opposition forces are now effectively disabled. The brazenness of these actions show that Mr Maduro is unperturbed by potential retaliation by the opposition and that political pressure against him is wavering.
Although it is not part of our baseline forecast, we recognise that there is a high risk of some sort of political transition. There are three main paths to this: military intervention, a negotiated transition or some sort of internal coup. We assess the prospect of military action by the US or Colombia as low, and we consider that a negotiated transition would also be difficult. In early March the US outlined a transition framework in which both Mr Maduro and Mr Guaidó would allow a new state council to be created and fresh elections to be held. However, the appointment of Maduro loyalists to the new electoral council demonstrated that this proposal has failed, as trust issues between the two sides are insurmountable.
We believe that the most likely scenario for regime change is an internal coup. The regime's main weakness is the fragility of its internal finances. Its patronage system is crucial for sustaining its security apparatus and resisting social unrest. Low international crude prices, US sanctions and the dampening effect of a global recession on workers' remittances will shrink dollar inflows further. The regime will continue to benefit from funds from drug-trafficking and illegal mining activities, but a lack of hard currency could prove fatal to the patronage system and will test the regime's ability to maintain cohesion among its ranks. The regime's liquidity problems, and a rapidly worsening socioeconomic and humanitarian crisis, could prompt putsch attempts in the near term.
Outlook for 2020-24: Election watch Legislative elections will take place on December 6th, assuming that Mr Maduro clings to power and that the polls are not cancelled (Mr Maduro has hinted that they could be suspended owing to the coronavirus pandemic). These elections would be neither free nor fair, and the opposition would lose control of the National Assembly. If the opposition were to secure some sort of political change in 2020, the interim government would pursue deep-seated reforms to the electoral authority and attempt to hold a vote within 12 months of its formation, although achieving this would be a major challenge.
Outlook for 2020-24: International relations Mr Guaidó has marshalled strong support from the international community, but efforts by most governments in Latin America to support him have reached an impasse. Mr Guaidó's most committed champion, the US, has instituted several rounds of crippling oil sanctions-most recently placing severe restrictions on the Venezuelan operations of Chevron (a US oil company)-and has openly called for the Venezuelan military to accept Mr Guaidó in place of Mr Maduro. The US expects sanctions to put enough pressure on the regime's finances (and therefore on its patronage system) to force Mr Maduro to hold free and fair elections. The US also warned of additional sanctions in the near future. The US administration will remain hawkish in its approach to foreign policy, but we believe that a military intervention is unlikely, given the aversion of the US president, Donald Trump, to such adventurism. If tensions rise and political violence increases, the possibility of smaller-scale interventions cannot be discounted. Looking ahead, regardless of whether Mr Trump or his opponent, Joe Biden wins the US election (our baseline forecast is for a Biden victory), we expect US sanctions to remain in place owing to strong bipartisan support. That said, efforts to reach a negotiated exit for Mr Maduro would increase under a Biden administration.
Mr Maduro's main international backers are Cuba, Russia, China and-more recently-Iran. Russia is helping Petróleos de Venezuela (PDVSA, the Venezuelan state-owned oil company) to circumvent US sanctions; in March the Venezuelan assets of Rosneft (a Russian energy company) were transferred directly to Russia, representing a step-up in the US-Russia diplomatic crossfire over Venezuela. Nevertheless, both Russia and China seem unwilling to provide the financing-amounting to tens of billions of US dollars per year-required to stabilise the economy and secure PDVSA's long-term future. Mr Maduro has openly courted the two countries, but seems to have had little success in securing finance for investment. If a transition from the Maduro regime were to come about, we believe that Russia and China would be willing to work with Mr Maduro's successor to protect their current investments. Iran recently sent 1.5m barrels of petrol to Venezuela in exchange for gold shipments and is helping to fix the Paraguaná oil refinery.
Outlook for 2020-24: Policy trends The Maduro regime will focus on weathering the fuel shortages and containing the public health crisis caused by the coronavirus outbreak. Despite community spread and an accelerating number of Covid-19 cases, Mr Maduro has eased nationwide quarantine measures to some degree. A "7/7" system is currently in place, whereby seven days of more flexible social distancing measures will be followed by seven of tighter restrictions. Measures will remain in place over the short to medium term as Venezuela's health system is simply unprepared to deal with the coronavirus outbreak. The country's medical infrastructure is poor and hospitals face significant shortages of water, soap, medicines and electricity.
Given the risk that fuel shortages pose to the regime, Mr Maduro has taken some steps to alleviate fuel scarcity. On May 31st the regime announced a two-tiered petrol distribution system. Drivers will be subject to a monthly quota of subsidised petrol. When this has been reached, petrol will be available at internationally indexed prices. The regime will also designate 200 fuel stations across Venezuela, which will be operated by independent or private companies, with petrol in these stations costing a fixed US$0.50/litre. These measures seek to regularise black-market activity so that the regime (rather than a third party) benefits from the gains. Nonetheless, this will only work to an extent, as arbitrage opportunities are still possible under the new subsidy system.
Based on our view that Mr Maduro will retain power throughout our 2020-24 forecast period, we do not expect to see the comprehensive economic and institutional reforms that are required to resolve the economic crisis. De facto dollarisation is expanding; although this was not a tacit goal for the regime, Mr Maduro now welcomes it. Other under-the-radar adjustments are possible in the coming years, as long as these benefit the regime's survival. Such efforts alone are unlikely to bring about economic stability, owing to the absence of a comprehensive microeconomic reform or improvements in the rule of law, and policy predictability will not be forthcoming under the current regime.
Outlook for 2020-24: Fiscal policy The authorities have not published complete data on fiscal accounts since 2011. We expect the non-financial public-sector deficit to narrow in 2020, and the public debt/GDP ratio to remain high in the coming years. The sovereign's default on most of its interest and principal repayments will curb government spending. The regime relies heavily on monetisation to fund its deficits, driving hyperinflation and the rationing of foreign currency. Money printing will continue to finance the government's deficits in 2020-24. However, over the medium term, growing remittance inflows will partly offset the need to monetise budget deficits. We currently assume no debt restructuring during the forecast period. Venezuela's weak fiscal position is complicated by the existence of considerable off-balance-sheet debt financing-mainly PDVSA-issued debt and development funds from China-that understates the true size of total public liabilities.
All of the sovereign's outstanding global bonds are in arrears. However, bondholders are yet to go to the courts, perhaps waiting for news of policy shifts or a change in government. The key PDVSA 2020 bond, which was secured using 50.1% of the shares of Citgo (PDVSA's US subsidiary) as collateral, fell due at end-October 2019 and was not paid. A US court ruled that PDVSA is an "alter ego" of the Venezuelan government; this will have far-reaching implications, as some international firms are seeking to seize shares of Citgo stock. However, the US considers Citgo to be under Mr Guaidó's purview, thus currently shielding Citgo assets from seizure by creditors.
Outlook for 2020-24: Monetary policy The government's financing needs will force the Banco Central de Venezuela (BCV, the central bank) to ramp up money printing in the short term. Growing dollarisation and a strong contraction in domestic demand slowed hyperinflationary pressures in 2019. However, we expect hyperinflation to return in the coming months, owing to monetisation of large fiscal deficits and severe goods shortages. Overall, hyperinflation will continue until its underlying causes are addressed. Hyperinflation has quickened the pace of dollarisation of the economy (more than 50% of transactions are now thought to be conducted in US dollars). We believe that Venezuela is heading towards overall de facto dollarisation. Monthly inflation will rise again in the short term and will remain substantial. However, given the effect of dollarisation on price stability, we do not expect a return to the extremely high annual inflation rates of more than 1,000,000% experienced in 2018.
Outlook for 2020-24: Economic growth Low crude prices and weak oil exports will put significant pressure on the country to slash crude production. Venezuela's average break-even price is about US$15-20/barrel. US sanctions on the regime raise the risks involved in dealing with Venezuela, forcing the country to offer a hefty discount on its crude. This means that, at current market prices, Venezuela is making only a limited profit (its oil basket reached an estimated US$25/b by end-June). The current circumstances have inevitably led to production cuts; oil output fell to 570,000 barrels/day (b/d) in May, according to OPEC. However, we believe that average output could fall to as low as 500,000 b/d over the coming months.
In 2021 we expect the economy to grow marginally, owing to a stabilisation of oil output, base effects and the lifting of social distancing measures. In 2022 economic growth will accelerate on the back of a surge in oil prices. However, in the medium term, oil output will continue to fall-albeit gradually-owing to serious operational problems (such as difficulties in obtaining equipment for repairs or finding qualified staff) and to a limited pool of suitable buyers of Venezuelan crude. Export volumes will start to recover marginally in 2022-24 (owing to moderately higher global oil prices), as producers become more accustomed to the new post-sanctions export markets. Furthermore, relative macroeconomic stability will allow the non-oil economy to recover marginally in the medium term. There are substantial risks to our forecasts, which assume that Mr Maduro will retain power throughout the forecast period. In the event of a transition, there would be upside risks to our medium-term baseline; the degree of improvement would depend on the characteristics of the transition and on the new government's macroeconomic programme.
Outlook for 2020-24: Inflation Severely reduced domestic supply, constraints on import capacity and the monetisation of large public deficits will continue to stoke hyperinflation this year. Dollarisation and the regime's heavy restrictions on credit helped to subdue hyperinflation in the second half of 2019. Still, consumer prices rose by 15% month on month in May-the weakest monthly increment in over three years. This deceleration owes to subsiding effects of social distancing measures on demand-side inflationary pressures. However, as the economy reopens inflationary pressures will strengthen, owing to fuel scarcity, price controls and the ramping up of government money printing.
In the medium term, inflation will remain high for as long as the Maduro regime is in power, given huge fundamental imbalances between supply and demand, and the need for the regime to monetise its fiscal deficits. Weather-related shocks are a perennial risk to the inflation outlook.
Outlook for 2020-24: Exchange rates Hyperinflation will quicken the pace of bolívar depreciation in 2020. Given incessant inflation and its effect on nominal values, we believe that another currency denomination (as in March 2018) or a new currency is a strong possibility, although the exact nature of such a move is hard to forecast. In mid-2019 the regime announced a loosening of currency controls. Although this was a positive move, significant barriers limit access to US dollars via formal means. We still believe that the government will maintain a number of indirect controls on the foreign-exchange market. In this context, a black-market exchange-rate premium is inevitable. On June 26th the official exchange rate was BsS202,080:US$1, compared with a black-market rate of BsS210,120:US$1. The premium (currently 4%) is small by historical comparison.
Outlook for 2020-24: External sector Venezuela will post a small current-account deficit of 2.1% of GDP in 2020, owing to lower oil exports and limited remittance inflows resulting from the global recession. The BCV's official figures for 2017-18 show that Venezuela posted current-account surpluses in this period. In 2019 the collapse of goods export earnings (owing to US sanctions on the oil trade) hit the trade balance hard. Nevertheless, based on the latest data, we estimate that the current account remained in surplus as a result of growing inflows of workers' remittances and the non-payment of interest on bonded debt (saving in excess of US$5bn in 2019). We expect the current account to return to surplus in the medium term, averaging 5.2% of GDP in 2022-24. Goods exports will recover as international oil prices increase and the country steps up trade with Asian markets. This recovery will be supported by continued weakness in domestic demand, rising remittances from abroad and the fact that the sovereign will remain in default throughout the forecast period.

Full text: - An economic crisis stemming from the coronavirus (Covid-19) pandemic will complicate policymaking for the government, led by Lenín Moreno, for the remainder of the president's term (which ends in May 2021). Commitment to fiscal discipline in the face of a deteriorating macroeconomic environment will embolden political opposition to the government ahead of presidential and legislative elections in February 2021 and will raise the risk of social unrest. Irrespective of the election outcome, The Economist Intelligence Unit expects sizeable barriers to both governing and stability to persist, considering the highly fragmented political landscape. Assuming that a centrist government is elected, these headwinds will hamper piecemeal liberalising economic reforms.
- Ecuador is one of the smallest markets in our business environment rankings. The country's mineral reserves will continue to attract oil and mining investors, but the domestic market will grow only slightly as it struggles to recover from the recession engendered by the coronavirus outbreak. We forecast that GDP per head (at market exchange rates) will rise only marginally in 2021-24, after falling by about 8% in 2020, and will remain below its 2019 level of US$6,206. As such, business opportunities will continue to be restricted by low purchasing power and a small market size.
- Under the auspices of the IMF, the government will cut public spending and investment to shore up the public finances. Despite a statistical rebound in real GDP in 2021, the country's short-term growth prospects will be curbed by soft oil prices, which will also weigh on the fiscal and external accounts. Notwithstanding political and economic uncertainties, we expect dollarisation to be maintained in the 2020-24 forecast period, as it remains popular for delivering macroeconomic stability and taming inflation.
- Ecuador's population growth is slowing but will average 1.3% per year in 2020-24; this is on a par with growth in neighbouring Andean countries. The unemployment rate will average 6% in 2020-24, but underemployment will stay high. The informal sector will remain substantial, partly owing to labour market rigidities. Although low levels of productivity and a wealth of natural resources offer scope for Ecuador to catch up with more developed countries, poor prospects for institutional improvements are likely to preclude a stable economic policy direction and OECD-like income levels in the long term.
