- Ecuador scores poorly in our business environment rankings owing to its dependence on oil and the current administration's timid embrace of orthodox policymaking. Although the country's score improves slightly in the forecast period, its global ranking remains low. The government will seek more private investment, but structural shortcomings in the investment environment will not be fully addressed, hindering investors' perceptions.

Country forecast overview: Ecuador's business environment at a glance Policy towards private enterprise and competition 2020-21: Fuel subsidies are partially lifted. Implementation of anti-trust policies is subject to politicisation. Select industries (such as mining) benefit from policies promoting supply-side growth.
2022-24: Government continues to scale back state's role in development. Nonetheless, regulation and licensing continue to favour state-run companies over private-sector firms. New public-private partnership model is trialled.
Policy towards foreign investment 2020-21: Overtures to foreign firms and pro-business reforms partly offset government's continued interventionism.
2022-24: Inadequate property rights protection and questions regarding access to foreign arbitration deter investment. New mining projects attract investment.
Foreign trade and exchange controls 2020-21: Government maintains capital outflows tax and increases import tariffs to protect dollarisation. Efforts to pursue free-trade agreements (FTAs) flounder amid collapse in global trade and growing protectionism by major trading partners.
2022-24: Supply-side reforms enhance national competitiveness and government begins to phase out capital outflows tax.
Taxes 2020-21: Government implements tax reform to expand tax base and improve collection. Certain exemptions are eliminated, and other burdensome regulations are simplified.
2022-24: Efforts to increase tax collection and tackle tax evasion continue, supporting revenue growth. Tax system remains complex.
Financing 2020-21: Deposit and credit growth weaken amid sharp economic recession, raising risks to banking sector stability.
2022-24: Financing is still below potential, as public-financing needs curb growth of long-term lending to private sector.
The labour market 2020-21: Government takes steps to reduce public wage bill and reduce labour market rigidities.
2022-24: Quality of workforce remains poor. Labour reforms are slow to take effect. Educational outcomes remain weak.
Infrastructure 2020-21: Fiscal constraints lead to cancellation of several projects. Efforts to drum up large-scale foreign investment achieve little success.
2022-24: Renewed interest in port and airport development sustains new cycle of investment.
Technological readiness 2020-21: Investment to expand fourth-generation (4G) broadband availability.
2022-24: Increasing adoption of civic technologies by government. Fifth-generation (5G) technology remains in its infancy.

Background: Ecuador restored its presidential democracy in 1979, but its institutions remain fragile. External economic shocks have contributed to the ousting of three presidents by popular protest since 1997. The current president, Lenín Moreno, took office in May 2017, succeeding Rafael Correa (2007-17)-the longest-serving president in Ecuadorean history. In February 2018 a series of constitutional reforms introduced by Mr Moreno (including the reintroduction of a two-term limit for the presidency) were approved by referendum. Although this was a step towards deeper democratisation, persistent social and fiscal challenges will continue to weigh on governability.
Political structure: The 2008 constitution increased executive power but has done little to foster institutional capacity to tackle problems such as a politicised judiciary, powerful business lobbies, and mobilised grassroots and indigenous groups. The political system is fragmented. Mr Moreno retains strong executive powers, but his party, Alianza País, lost considerable standing after it splintered following the results of the 2018 referendum.
Policy issues: Dollarisation has provided macroeconomic stability but exposed Ecuador's underlying lack of competitive-ness. Modest oil prices during the 2020-24 forecast period, relative to the previous decade, have necessitated fiscal adjustments. The Moreno administration secured a three-year IMF agreement-along with other multilateral financing-in March 2019 to meet various objectives, including putting the public finances on a sustainable trajectory, but programme performance has been lacking. The novel coronavirus (Covid-19) pandemic will further complicate the government's reform agenda, especially given the lack of fiscal space to counter the hit to the economy and financial system.
Taxation: Taxes have been subject to frequent changes. The main taxes in Ecuador are income tax, levied at rates of up to 35%, and value-added tax (VAT), levied at 12%. Private firms must distribute 15% of their profits among their employees.
Foreign trade: Ecuador recorded a trade surplus of US$1bn in 2019; petrol export earnings averaged 39% of total export revenue, compared with over 50% during the commodity boom in the 2000s.

Outlook for 2020-24: Political stability The coronavirus (Covid-19) pandemic presents the president, Lenín Moreno, with two immense challenges before his term ends in May 2021. First, his administration must manage the health crisis with limited resources. Despite the swift imposition (in mid-March) of strict national lockdown measures, including a daily curfew from 2pm to 5am, the virus has spread unabated, with more than 55,200 cases reported as at June 28th. A gradual, region-by-region easing of restrictions began on May 4th, but the process will be slow and the risk of a second wave of infections will persist as economic activity resumes.
The president's second challenge is to stabilise the economy as oil prices languish, lockdown measures stifle activity and external demand shrinks. With no fiscal space to mount a countercyclical response (Mr Moreno has announced aggressive cuts to public spending), the political opposition will be emboldened and the risk of social unrest will be significantly heightened.
These immense challenges will prove awkward for the president to overcome. His party, Alianza País (AP), has 42 seats in the legislature, 27 short of the threshold for a majority. Considering that a general election is approaching (due in February 2021) and that the government is implementing austerity measures amid a crisis, the opposition will offer limited support, and some members of Mr Moreno's party will be reluctant to back his policies. The conservative Partido Social Cristiano (PSC) and the left-wing Revolución Ciudadana (RC), the faction loyal to Mr Moreno's predecessor, Rafael Correa (2007-17), will be overtly obstructionist. Mr Moreno's popularity will provide little upside; his approval rating stood at 14.7% in May, down from 24.7% a year earlier.
Despite this-and although political jockeying will be a constant undercurrent as elections draw near-The Economist Intelligence Unit expects cross-party support for some government policies to materialise. In particular, the conservative Creando Oportunidades (Creo) party may yet extend further support to the government (as it did in mid-May, after Mr Moreno abandoned plans to raise taxes as part of the government's emergency economic legislation). However, even assuming that the government secures enough support to facilitate policymaking, political uncertainties will prevail (rather than dissipate) in the short to medium term as the economy enters a sharp recession.
There is a high probability that protests will occur in the next few months. Informal employment as a percentage of total non-agricultural employment is over 60%, and there is little relief coming from the government, which does not have the fiscal capacity to help to offset losses faced by informal workers, let alone formal businesses. Austerity measures on top of the worsening economic conditions will amplify the likelihood of unrest. In particular, labour unions and indigenous groups, including the Confederación de Nacionalidades Indígenas del Ecuador (Conaie, Ecuador's largest indigenous organisation), which was largely responsible for intense protests in October 2019, will pressure the government to change course.
Outlook for 2020-24: Election watch The February 2021 general election outlook is highly nebulous at this stage, given uncertainty regarding the course of the pandemic. Nevertheless, we do not expect any party to secure the presidency without a run-off vote; to do so, it would have to garner 50% of the first-round vote or secure 40% with a 10-percentage-point margin of victory over its rivals. Mr Moreno does not intend to run for re-election. Considering his government's commitment to unpopular economic measures, it is unlikely that a member of his centre-left AP would secure enough support to win outright. A first-round victory for Creo's leader, Guillermo Lasso, or for candidates from the PSC or RC, is equally unlikely, given the fractured nature of the political landscape. However, as Mr Correa has the enduring support of about 20% of the electorate, a candidate backed by him (probably from the RC) is likely to play a significant role and reach the second round.
In the event of a second round, we believe that a candidate pursuing broadly centrist economic policies would be most likely to take the presidency. Although a Correa-backed candidate would be well poised to reach the second round, there are factors (most notably corruption) weighing on Mr Correa's appeal; the former president was sentenced to eight years in prison on bribery charges in April. Meanwhile, the PSC performed well in municipal elections in March 2019, and Creo's appeal may grow as it attempts to improve its image through a renewed focus on governance. The vice-president, Otto Sonnenholzner of the AP, may also run, having risen to prominence through his role in spearheading the government's pandemic response. A deepening of the economic crisis, leading to political instability, is a major risk to our outlook.
Outlook for 2020-24: International relations The coronavirus pandemic will encumber Mr Moreno's liberalising trade agenda in the short term. We expect only limited progress on discussions with the US about a free-trade agreement (FTA) and on the country's accession to the Pacific Alliance (a regional trade bloc) for the remainder of his presidency. The absence of an existing bilateral agreement with Mexico will present a challenge beyond the near term; before the crisis the two parties ambitiously set February 7th 2021 (the date of Ecuador's general election) as the deadline for an FTA. This appears increasingly unfeasible, and Ecuador's chances of entering the bloc by 2024 have declined considerably, despite support from the presidents in the Alliance and from Mexico's foreign minister. In addition to the coronavirus pandemic, changes in government and policy direction may hinder the accession process.
Outlook for 2020-24: Policy trends The economic fallout from the coronavirus pandemic will push Ecuador closer to a disorderly default and a balance-of-payments crisis. Having made an agreement with private creditors in April to defer interest payments of US$811m due between late March and August 15th, the government is seeking an amicable restructuring of its debt with its creditors. Although we expect the government to successfully reach an agreement with bondholders, the risk of a disorderly default cannot be discounted. Avoiding this outcome will require, more than ever, support from the IMF (and other actors), but meeting the conditions required to access funds from these sources will be extremely complicated politically, heightening risks in the coming months.
In the face of political pressure to loosen fiscal policy and suspend external debt payments, Mr Moreno will try to maintain discipline and work to improve the country's credibility. This will catalyse much-needed multilateral financial assistance. In the wake of the coronavirus crisis, the government nullified its three-year, US$4.2bn extended fund facility (EFF) with the IMF (accompanied by US$6bn in additional multilateral financing, intended to be disbursed between March 2019 and December 2021). It also accessed US$643m through the Fund's rapid financing instrument (RFI) in early May-the RFI is being extended to many emerging markets around the world and comes without the conditionalities that a fully fledged IMF programme entails. However, the RFI and other recent multilateral financing-US$500m from the World Bank and US$300m from the Development Bank of Latin America-will not be sufficient to stave off economic collapse.
A successor arrangement with the Fund will be vital in navigating the economic crisis at hand. Negotiations with the Fund will be buoyed by the passage of emergency economic legislation in May that goes beyond the immediate necessities of the pandemic. Approved reforms to public financial management will reduce discretionary budget changes considerably and establish a savings fund, improving the country's medium-term fiscal framework. However, an uncertain economic and political outlook is likely to weigh on the Fund's willingness to pledge a large amount of financing. Assuming that a centre-right or centre-left government takes office in May 2021 and provides for policy continuity, we expect that improving competitiveness, tackling fiscal imbalances, protecting the poor and fighting corruption-the primary objectives of the government's defunct EFF-will continue to be priorities. At the same time, given these political assumptions and the depth of the economic crisis, we view IMF assistance beyond 2021 as highly probable, suggesting a piecemeal advancement of business-friendly policies and complementary reforms in 2021-24.
Outlook for 2020-24: Fiscal policy The non-financial public-sector (NFPS) deficit will widen to 7% of GDP in 2020, as the already shaky finances coming into the coronavirus crisis will be hit hard by a sudden halt in domestic economic activity and lower oil revenue than budgeted. The government will attempt to offset the erosion of revenue through sweeping procyclical spending reductions to the tune of US$4bn (about 4% of GDP and 15% of the original 2020 budget). However, even assuming that spending cuts materialise, that debt-servicing costs are reduced through bond renegotiations and that new, extraordinary multilateral and bilateral assistance is forthcoming, the damage will be substantial. We expect public debt as a percentage of GDP to rise from an estimated 46.9% in 2019 to 60% in 2020.
Assuming broad policy continuity, and without details of the government's prospective successor IMF agreement, we expect that the NFPS deficit will narrow gradually from 2021, shrinking to 1.6% of GDP by 2024, and that the public debt/GDP ratio will stabilise at about 61%. The successor programme to the government's defunct EFF will shed light on how fiscal targets and fiscal policymaking will adapt to the looming economic recession. Given the deterioration of economic conditions, we expect the Fund to be more lenient in its terms, but irrespective of the changes to the programme, implementation risks will be alarmingly high, as social and political obstacles to reform exceed their pre-crisis levels.
Although we are cautiously optimistic that the government will avoid a disorderly default, there are substantial economic and political risks to our assumptions. On the one hand, it remains to be seen whether the depth of the recession will prove too challenging for the government to navigate, even with multilateral and bilateral financing (the government estimates that it will receive about US$2bn from multilateral creditors and China) and the successful execution of debt-management operations. On the other hand, although it is not our baseline forecast, there is a risk that next year's general election will result in victory for a populist government that then cuts ties with the Fund and suspends external debt payments, despite the fact that doing so would lead to an extremely severe crisis and put dollarisation at risk. If either of these risks were to materialise, we would revise our assumptions.
Outlook for 2020-24: Monetary policy As a dollarised economy, Ecuador lacks independent monetary policy and will not be able to foment a monetary policy response to the economic crisis. Monetary conditions will continue to be determined largely by external factors, but real local rates will remain elevated, owing to Ecuador's high risk premium. Monetary growth will hinge on foreign-exchange inflows and the confidence of domestic lenders, both of which will be markedly undermined by the rapid deterioration of the economy. The threat of de-dollarisation will sustain the risk of capital flight, which in turn raises the risk of preventative measures being implemented in the short term to protect domestic liquidity levels.
Outlook for 2020-24: Economic growth We expect Ecuador to endure its worst recession since the financial crisis that it suffered at the turn of the century; we forecast that real GDP will shrink by 11.5% in 2020, driven by a severe contraction in the second quarter. Export volumes will decrease by 15% as external demand falls markedly. However, this drop will be overshadowed by a sizeable 26% decline in import volumes, reflecting a significant deterioration in domestic demand.
Low oil receipts will lead to a retrenchment in government consumption, indirectly feeding through to private consumption, which will be constrained by a worsening labour market. Economic and political uncertainties will weigh on private investment, which will decline for a second consecutive year. Assuming that the coronavirus outbreak is more under control by end-2020-prompting a recovery in external and domestic demand-we expect growth to rebound in 2021, but real GDP will remain below 2019 levels.
Political uncertainties will be elevated ahead of the February 2021 general election, precluding a more robust pick-up in domestic demand. We expect growth to be modest in 2022 (following the 2021 rebound), but it should slowly improve thereafter as policy uncertainties wane, oil prices rise and moderate improvements to the business environment materialise.
Outlook for 2020-24: Inflation Softening commodity prices, weak demand and a stronger US dollar will produce deflation this year. Consumer prices were flat in 2019, and we expect them to fall by 0.6% by year-end. We expect inflation to pick up slightly, to an annual average of 0.9% in 2021-24, as import costs rise owing to renewed dollar weakness and an increase in commodity prices. Dollarisation will help to contain inflation, but the economy will remain vulnerable to increases in food and energy prices.
Outlook for 2020-24: Exchange rates Risks to dollarisation have risen and will remain elevated in the short term. The economic crisis presents major problems of financing and liquidity, as oil prices have tumbled and access to global financing is limited. These problems are likely to be exacerbated by a short-term strengthening of the US dollar (hurting competitiveness) and a dip in reserves.
Nevertheless, we currently assume that dollarisation will be retained in the 2020-24 forecast period, as the government's commitment to its IMF agreement and to fiscal discipline allows for greater multilateral financing. The real effective exchange rate will remain stronger than its long-term, pre-dollarisation average, but there will be some depreciation in real, trade-weighted terms as the US dollar begins to weaken in 2021-24.
Outlook for 2020-24: External sector The current-account deficit will widen in 2020 as the external backdrop deteriorates. A slump in oil revenue will weigh significantly on the trade balance in the short term as oil prices and external demand recover at a tepid pace. Non-oil export earnings will slip, owing to domestic restrictions on business operations to prevent the spread of the coronavirus and a retraction of demand in major export markets, but will retain some dynamism as external demand recovers. The deterioration of the trade balance will be softened by import compression as the domestic economy languishes, but remittances are likely to suffer, as economic activity has ground to a halt outside Ecuador, widening the current-account deficit. Foreign direct investment (FDI) inflows will suffer in 2020-21 and remain below 1% of GDP. They will pick up thereafter and average 1% of GDP in 2022-24.

a Actual. b Economist Intelligence Unit estimates. c Economist Intelligence Unit forecasts.
Data sources and definitions Sources for global and domestic data refer to historical data. The source for all forecast data, unless otherwise stated, is The Economist Intelligence Unit
Global data US and European GDP growth: OECD
World trade growth: Economist Intelligence Unit aggregate
OECD consumer price inflation: OECD
Commodity prices: IMF, IFS; non-oil
Oil prices: Brent average import prices
US$ 3-month commercial paper rate: IMF, IFS
US effective exchange-rate index: IMF, IFS; nominal weighted index, 1990=100
Domestic data Trade by country: IMF, Direction of Trade Statistics Yearbook
US$ GDP: IMF, IFS; local-currency GDP converted to US dollars at annual average market exchange rate
US$ GDP at PPP: IMF, IFS; The Economist Intelligence Unit; local-currency GDP converted to US dollars at estimated annual average of consumer products' PPP
PPP: purchasing power parity; average ratio of prices in Costa Rica to prices in the US
Population and growth: CELADE
General government debt: includes debt of the non-financial and financial public sectors
Lending rate: average rate charged by commercial banks on non-preferential loans. The rate is weighted by loan amounts
Deposit rate: average rate weighted by deposit amount on 30- to 59-day time deposits
Inflation: IMF, IFS; derived from consumer price index (CPI), 2006=100
Real exchange rate: The Economist Intelligence Unit; a real exchange rate of less than 100% indicates that the currency is undervalued vis-à-vis relative prices and vice versa
Balance of payments: IMF, IFS
Long-term external debt: World Bank, International Debt Statistics; year-end medium- and long-term publicly guaranteed and non-guaranteed debt outstanding with an original maturity in excess of one year, plus arrears and year-end IMF debt outstanding
Total external debt: sum of long-term debt, short-term debt and arrears
Total debt service: World Bank, International Debt Statistics; principal repayments made against long-term debt, plus interest payments and IMF charges paid against total external debt
Debt-service ratio: ratio of total debt service paid to exports of goods and services
Abbreviations CELADE: Centro Latinoamericano y Caribeño de Demografía
IFS: International Financial Statistics
IMF: International Monetary Fund
OECD: Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development
